Сражения космических кораблей в космосе сменили собой битвы мехов против гигантских жуков, управление звездолетом с его менеджментом в реальном времени сменилось на шахматное поле 8х8, где три гигантских робота мужественно отбиваются от орды подземных монстров в пошаговом бою. Главный кит ItB - кажущийся поначалу незамысловатым, однако очень комплексный и удачный геймплей. Сравнение с шахматами тут как нельзя лучше. Не оставлю без внимания логичный, как и все игра, интерфейс и крайне подходящий и приятный саундтрек.
Словом, игра вышла на загляденье, если мне чего-то и не хватает, то это текстов из FTL, с его выборами, простенькой историей и описаниями. Увы, этой не самой сильной, но приятной стороне прошлой игры здесь не нашлось места. И, если уж я заговорил о недостатках, люди жалуются на некоторую излишнюю лёгкость игры и короткую сессию, чего я, признаться, не ощутил даже на нормальном уровне сложности, но кому что. Тоже касается и графики, которая перестает обращать на себя внимание после пары часов игры, но будь у игры более технологичная картинка никто бы явно был в претензии.
В остальном же, прощай Faster Then Light, здравствуй моя новая любимая игра жанра "позалипаю на часик, ой...".

40952442.review:
Kaijujutsu - Mech vs Bugs

Overview.
Into the Breach, made by Subset Games (FTL) is a turn based strategy game in which the player must fend of a swarm of giant bugs. 

Overview
Simple mechanics but not a simple game. Each battle starts with the player placing their mechs onto the field. Each mech has health, movement and an ability or 2 as well as the option to heal. Vek also have health, movement and an ability or 2. Once the mech are place the battle begins and the Vek move about the board attacking buildings or mechs. Each building represents power to the grid (the players overall health). Once the grid is depleted or all your mechs are destroyed, the game is over and the player will have to start over.

Combat
Combat involves dealing with the Vek threat as new ones spawn every turn. But shooting them to death isn't always an option, nor is it always the best option. Not only can players kill the vek, but they can move them as well. Different abilities allow the player to push the Vek about. Pushing them into another object yields extra damage. Pushing a Vek into a hazard can allow a low damage unit the power to kill a stronger enemy. Because the Vek attack order is known (an icon in the top right will inform the player), players can manipulate the Vek into attacking each other. Pushing can be used defensively as well to free up a teammate that has been immobilized, push a vek away from attacking the grid, or push a Vek onto a spawn point thus delaying an enemy from joining the fray. There is no time limit, so players are free to contemplate as long as necessary to create the best turn.

Into the Breach is more than just tactics though. During each battle their are optional objectives (which the player will know of in advance). Completing these objectives during a battle can heal the player's grid or yield reputation which is spent at the end of each island to purchase new items. Completely all the objectives on a island grants the player bonus item (notice I do not say protecting all the civilians and the grid is needed to "perfect" an island). 

Furthermore, each mech his a pilot that can gain up to 2 passive bonuses, such as more movement or health, and Unique pilots have a special ability like armor to prevent damage or the ability to fly. If your mech is destroyed in combat, the pilot dies and is replaced with an AI that cannot gain abilities though can be replaced with a new pilot if one is found. Reactor cores, which can be found, earned through objectives, or bought for reputation grant more power to a mech to have more health, movement or upgrade their abilities. Players may have to sacrifice grid or pilots to serve the greater good while managing their upgrades and weapons to be prepared for whatever the Vek throw at them.

Player can be severely punished for mistakes. It is easy to miss a Vek passive or a push interaction that unravels a player's plans. The devs do provide some leniency in allowing moved mechs that haven't attacked to be returned as well as a single turn reset per battle. Still, an early mistake can mean missing out on upgrades which can snowball into not keeping up with the increasingly tougher enemies.

The enemy AI can be manipulated to some extent (the degree of which I do not know) as players are aware how much an enemy can move and their attack/abilities. Trying to anticipate enemy movement can be frustrating and is the biggest RNG in the game. I cannot say for certain the game is 100% fair which may turn off some players.

Experience
The visuals are functional but not stunning. The music by Ben Prunty is excellent. There is a good deal of replay ability with 10 squads of 3 mechs each to start with as well as a custom and random squad option. There are 3 difficulty settings allowing players to ease themselves into the game (in fact, nearly all achievements can be completed on easy mod). There are moments when I felt like I was totally screwed on a turn only to finally figure out the correct play which is an amazing feeling. I appreciated the abundance of FTL references as well. 

I haven't experienced any bugs (outside of the Vek) or crashes in 77 hours of play. There are a few aspects in regards to interaction that are not clear at the onset, such as buildings take no damage from fires or to heal a mech you select its repair ability then target the mech. Some of the menuing, like changing squads to see achievements is a little clunky.

Overall
Into the Breach is a solid game. I wouldn't say it's a must have, but I've definitely enjoyed most of the time I've put into it. It will be easy for some to sink hundreds of hours into the game that is pretty accessible to various player capabilities.

In a nutshell, it's good, but not FTL.

The shortcomings mostly come from the pace of it. The entirely turned-based action, with regular stops and starts. The various upgrades aren't bad in themselves, there is just less of a sense of desperately finding a store, or making decisions that you don't know how long you will have to stick with. Your choices feel more restricted, and although it does share FTL's ability to destroy an apparently safe run out of the blue, it also seems to have lost the fear of the slow descent in failure that ran along side.

There was something in FTL that compelled me to finish every achievement, to unlock every craft and to engage in the repetition for the chance of unlocking secrets. Into the Breach doesn't give that same inspiration. I played for just over twenty hours, and by that point my interest had dwindled to the point where I can't see myself playing any more.

That said, 20 hours for £11 feels like a reasonable return, and I certainly did enjoy it. The core gameplay is enjoyable if limited, it operates as a puzzle game that works, and the game sits together with the sort of polish and decent ideas that you would expect from the development team.

I'm not a completionist, which could well be the difference between me getting 20 hours out of it, and you getting 60 hours if you are so inclined. Ultimately, though, I wasn't a completionist when I played FTL, and that still had enough clout to pull me into that. So for me, decent, but not as good.

40912639.review:
Awesome game, albeit not nearly as replayable as you would expect form this developer.

It's a lot easier to describe it as a chain of a small 1-2-turns long chess-like puzzles. You have 3 (sometimes a bit more) [strike]chess pieces[/strike] units, and you have a turn that you have to solve. Depending on what you did, the next turn will be a bit harder or a bit easier.

The gameplay is surprisingly satisfying, and you will probably find this game enjoyable for 10-20 hours, until it literally runs out of things to offer.

You see, there is a big game-design problem. The game tries to be rogue-like-ish, somewhat similar to FTL, at least in spirit. That implies some amount of randomness, and the most notable example is the enemy spawns. But the same randomness that is supposed to make the game less repetitive limits the depth of the "puzzle" part of the game.

Unless you managed to block all the spawn points of enemies (which is not always possible), you have no idea what you'll have to deal with on the next turn, so you can't really plan 3-4 turns ahead (you can try, but RNG will have the final saying). Because of that, the game can't really throw anything really difficult at you (you can't make informed decisions about the next turn anyway, so it would be just unfair), and all single-turn problems are somewhat trivial after you familiarized yourself with each squad's abilities.

So, from your perspective you will have:
1) Solvable turns: ones where you took 0 damage, moved towards mission objectives, and blocked as many spawns as you wanted, depending on your goals. Those turns are very satisfying at first, but becoming annoyingly mundane after a few hours.
2) Unsolvable turns: very rare occasions (usually on Hard mode, near the end) where you have to sacrifice something (a time pod, some grid power, or maybe a mission objective), because the spawns did not cooperate, you didn't get any good weapons from the previous areas, and you literally can't stop all enemies no matter what you do.

Individually, unsolvable turns are unlikely to end your campaign, but you will probably get frustrated anyway, because it feels like you are losing not because you made any mistakes, but just because some stupid RNG made you to. Developers obviously tried to minimize the amount of situations like that, so most turns are solvable "in 1 turn", and therefore have a very limited strategic depth.

I would definitely recommend this game as a very unique strategy/puzzle experience, just don't expect getting hundreds of hours of fun out of it.

[u]What I liked: [/u]
[list]
    [*]Chess- like strategy that is unique
    [*]Replayability through different mech squads
    [*]Finding a solution to beating seemingly impossible odds

[/list]
[u]What You Need to Know: [/u]
[list]
    [*]Most people will be wondering how this compares to FTL as that game is still a pinnacle of game design. You will not be disappointed with how this game is similar to FTL but also completely different.

    [*]Ok now that sounds contradictory, but let me tell you that the game is rogue like, short campaigns, different starting mech squads with different playstyles and similar purchasable gear sot that anyone that has played FTL will feel just at home with.

    [*]Now everyone even me at first was like but how do the mechanics work? It seems so simple and casual when you look it at face value. This game is more like chess than a typical RTS. You have 3 mechs that all have vastly different abilities. The goal isn’t only to kill enemies; it’s to not lose power by not letting buildings get attacked.  Your mech’s can push, pull, damage, swap, stun, make enemies kill each other; you do this with a few simple attacks at most 2 for each mech. You can choose to have only 1 attack for each mech when you find a good passive or limited use per battle ability. This might sound simple to you but what really shines it the way you use these abilities. 

    [*]The game requires careful planning of your attacks, the enemy’s turn is told to you so that you have to maneuver them away from damaging building, objectives, or you mechs with the abilities mentioned above. You will almost always have more enemies than mechs and at times more than double. The beauty is when you come with a plan to not take damage and make enemies damage or kill each other. Abilities mechs can have range from a simple push an enemy and damage, pull toward mech, and ranged rocket with 4 cardinal tile push. You can get advanced with self-damaging ramming pushes with shields from another to prevent said damage, freeze you and another enemy, to swapping an enemy with your flying unit over lava or water that kills them instantly. I’m trying to say that the abilities of each squad are designed to be used together or harmonize well and when used to win odds that seemed impossible to prevent is amazing and happened so much for me.

    [*]You get a good variety of enemies, a charging one, line of sight ranged, artillery ranged, 2 kinds of melee, one normal and another that prevents movement unless broken out of tile range, explosive spawning and spider spawning (my most hated enemy) and a passive one that buffs enemies that until killed that gives buffs like extra health, armor, regenerating health or explode on death.  Maps start with a few and more spawn each turn, but can be delayed when something is on top of the spawn damaging what is there. You do get buffed version of each enemy that increase health, damage and maybe some range. You have bosses for each island that more just the normal enemies but more health and damage which was kind of lame. [h1]Charming, addictive, and utterly absorbing, Into the Breach is already 2018's game to beat.[/h1]

Take the turn-based precision of any tactics game, throw in the theme of Starship Troopers, a bit of the roguelike addictiveness of FTL, and you'll arrive at Subset Games' superb sophomore effort called Into the Breach. Yeah, I'm down with spoiling the outcome of the review like that because honestly, I can't imagine many players being able to repress their fondness for what is surely one of the most charming video games we'll see all year.

The setting once again takes us into the far future where humanity's interstellar colonization has drew them the ire of the Vek; a hostile race of insectoid aliens that don't appreciate human-y things like power plants or buildings full of helpless people. A small band of time-travelling soldiers is all that stands between them and total annihilation and so as commander of this elite squad it's your job to direct the mechanised troops in order to push back the Vek and protect your employer's interests across four warring islands.

At first glance the game is somewhat reminiscent of an obscure title called Faselei! where players would program giant mechs to carry out actions in a later phase. With Into the Breach, only the enemy turns are programmed in advance and the player's time will be spent trying to foil those impending threats by any means necessary.

Those who bemoan a lack of true heroism in video games can rejoice at last because innocent lives are very important to your ongoing success here. Every battlefield structure is linked to your primary energy grid and thus when a building full of bystanders is razed - alongside a guilt-imposing alert of how many casualties were just sustained - the grid's health depletes along with it. In true roguelike fashion there's no reloading a save or checkpoint either, so learning to protect the grid is essential if you hold any hope of reaching the final mission.

It's no coincidence that each map shares the same 8x8 tile layout as a chessboard because the elements that make Chess such a painstaking pleasure are very much evident here too. Into the Breach is all about minimization and I'm not just referring to how adorable the giant mechs look in pixel art. Minimizing the damage caused by the Vek is your paramount concern and yet there are times when minimizing the risk of future turns is just as vital. Similar to Chess, you can get very good at Into the Breach by thinking multiple turns ahead of your current position and there will be many times where you'll need to sacrifice your pieces - or should I say, pilots - in order to prevent key objectives from failing.

Positioning is a vital concept here and simply moving enemies from one tile to another is sometimes the best tactic for maintaining control of the board. Many weapons include the ability to push other units because of this and you'll find the tempo of battle flows in your favour when enemies can be pushed into water (often drowning them for an instant kill) or onto tiles where other enemies would have otherwise spawned.

The sheer tactical awareness that this sort of approach requires is made easier to digest by the gorgeous user interface. Every attack vector and unit ability is clearly signposted through the use of animated tooltips and the tutorial featuring the well-balanced Rift Walkers squad will have new players aware of the basics in minutes.

That's not to say that every rule is as clear as it could be. I'm not sure why buildings are immune to fire for example and it's not always clear what effect certain actions will have on tiles that are undergoing a status change. Do smoke clouds counteract any existing status effects? Do flying enemies drown if they're hit by a freeze ray whilst they're hovering over water? Do they thaw out when the same occurs over lava or A.C.I.D.?

This aspect of trial and error can occasionally upset things and the lack of reference means that you'll likely be making mistakes even after mastering the game's subtleties. An in-game encyclopedia would have been a nice addition in this sense, but then again perhaps that would've added more clutter than is really necessary.

It's important to always be informed though because like FTL, Into the Breach is another one those games where a single bad move from the player can spell disaster. Fortunately Subset Games dialled the difficulty back a bit here by adding an inspired reset turn option which acts as a one-use lifeline that will frequently help players escape some of their more common blunders.

Opening up the game even further is a robust achievement system which unlocks brand new squads of mechs to play with. Maybe you'll harness the power of lightning as Blitzkrieg, burn the Vek to a crisp as the Flame Behemoths, or just make your own fully customized team from any mech that you have available. Surviving pilots are another persistent bonus that can be carried over between sessions and because the campaign's length can be freely determined by the player, it helps anyone who is less skilled see more of what's on offer without having their progress walled off.

There's so much more awesome content to discover that's it's hard to do justice to it all. Consider though the little dollops of character brought about by the writing and Ben Prunty's catchy soundtrack, the myriad bonus objectives that thrust players into cameos alongside allied tanks and terraforming machines and earthquakes, tidal waves, erupting volcanoes, and haywire robots frozen in ice.

Will the grid defences hold this turn? you ask, as another Vek mortar flies through the air towards a robotics factory that you really needed to protect but got so caught up in the turn that you forgot to keep it covered! And so too will there be stories of the miracles you pulled off in the face of adversity and the combos you made involving that one weapon acquisition or that one custom squad full of OP Cryo Mechs.

It's an addictive package to be sure, one so entertaining and intuitive that the biggest challenge can be finding something to criticize. If you want a direct comparison with FTL, then Into the Breach does seem to have a shorter lifespan because of its minimalist design. This is an easier game on the whole (to the point of tedium if you play on the Easy setting) and certain scenarios will start to feel samey with fewer chaotic elements to consider. There's also a minor point concerning its final mission that whilst still thinky and backed by a wonderfully tense piece of music, doesn't compare to the outright climax of felling the Rebel Flagship.

But so too is this game more accessible than its predecessor and the rules that govern it more dependable for the entry level strategist. I observed very few bugs in this release build and the overall impression I get is that a lot of time went into making the experience as smooth and as satisfying as possible. The prevalence of 'turn angst' not withstanding of course!

If the game shares one major thing in common with FTL, then it's the fact that I want to immediately start playing it again only moments after shutting it down. It was never going to be easy for Subset Games to equal the brilliance of their first effort, but honestly, with Into The Breach they may have just topped it.

Into the Breach is a tactical strategy game in which you are the last line of defense against icky insect (Vek 🕷 ) alien invaders. In strategy terms I'd liken it to a game of chess. You know all the moves your opponent can make, but what you need to think about is not the next turn - but the turn after, and the turn after that. Can you think ahead and set yourself up to counter the next 5 turns?

[h1]Survival Strategy[/h1]

If so, you win the round. You don't need to destroy the enemy - you simply need to survive and save as many people and power as possible. If the enemy attacks a building, you lose power to the grid. If the power ⚡️⚡️ is gone, it's game over. Humanity is doomed... in this timeline anyway. Into the Breach is is a slow paced strategy puzzle game of thinking ahead and protecting your assets from all directions, occasionally sacrificing your own life. You're expendable, but the universe is not. 

Enemies are varied and differ from island to island, with map mechanics and your own varying team abilities thrown in. So calling it similar to chess is a very simple analogy - it's a lot more complex with a lot more components thrown in to the mix. If you're thinking it sounds a little too cerebral, you don't need an eidetic memory as the moves from your opponents are telegraphed for the next turn which simplifies things in the short-term. As you go up in difficulty and play around with different team mechanics, strategy definitely intensifies.

[h1]Oodles of replayability[/h1]

In addition to unlocking different teams with different abilities that seriously affect the way you play the game, you can purchase upgrades and have to decide how to power them. You can level up your pilots who can die (your mechs keep fighting, but you'll need to find a new pilot to boost their stats). You can choose the island you play on, and which map you play, with different maps having different goals for rewards. Of course, the harder the challenge the higher the reward - and risk.  Even after beating the game, there is a ridiculous amount of replayability here with achievements that reward you with coins that can be spent on unlocking different teams.

[h1]Boo 😱, RNG[/h1]

My only criticism is like any game with random chance, there is an element of frustrating RNG that can sometimes mar the experience. Although there are no XCOMesque hit chances and you know exactly what you and the enemy will do, the map placement and bonus events can sometimes make playing a perfect (or even good) game feel impossible, especially on the hardest difficulty. On the whole though, I do think that a loss is mostly going to be your own fault. Thanks game, for reminding me that I'm not a tactical genius.

[h1]Unique and Addictive[/h1]

Despite this being heavily advertised as a game from the makers of FTL: Faster Than Light, don't be mistaken into thinking Into The Breach is similar in mechanics. It's a completely different genre and has nothing really similar gameplay wise. What it does have in common is that it's a well-polished unique game that'll keep you playing time and time again. Even when you lose horribly. That's a pretty good thing to have in common!

[h1]It's a highly recommended from me on this one. ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️[/h1]

40875977.review:
Into the Breach... wielkie roboty, wielkie potwory, podróże w czasie, a wszystko w sosie turowej strategii na klaustrofobicznych mapach.


Na początek kilka słów o tym, jak do sprawy podeszlo studio. Subset Games jest szeroko znane środowisku graczy dzięki wydanemu w zasadzie z zaskoczenia FTL: Faster Than Light. Osobiście przynam, że mimo iż rzeczona gra w mojej bibliotece znajdowala się już od dawna, to dopiero teraz zdecydowalem się przysiąść i ją ukończyć. A poprzez fakt, że to dość wymagający rogue-like, to jako raczej sredniemu strategowi, było dość trudno. Ale opłaciło się, bo mogę na świeżo porównać te dwa dzieła. A jest co porównywać.

 Produkty Subset Games łączy jedna wspaniała cecha - solidność. Ktoś, kto jak ja, spędził dużą część życia na grach planszowych, od razu zauważy wspolny mianownik z FTL i ITB. Mowię tu o prostocie rozgrywki, której mechanika ma być już po kilku chwilach całkowicie zrozumiała dla gracza. Jednocześnie jednak, owe proste zasady mają zapewniać losowość każdej gry tak, by każde do niej podejście bylo inne i zachęcało gracza. (Uwaga jednak: prostota zasad nie jest tożsama z łatwością rozgrywki. Niniejsze tytuły pokazują, że jest dokładnie odwrotnie)
W przypadku FTL mieliśmy przekrój statku, który stawał się dla nas swego rodzaju planszą, a zadaniem naszym było takie operowanie systemami i kolejnymi punktami podróży, by w końcu pokonać nienawistnego lidera Rebeliantów. Into the Breach natomiast, ukazuje nam planszę (za każdym razem inną) i zmusza do tak umiejętnego używania zespołu trzech jednostek, by turowo pokonać wrogich Veków, ochronić budynki cywilne, a czasem wykonać dodatkowe zadanie (ochrona jadącego pociągu, wysadzenie tamy czy nawet zalesienie pustynnego terenu), które gwarantuje nam dodatkowe punkty na zakończenie misji.

SUROWCE

 Skoro jesteśmy już przy owych punktach, FTLowcy pamiętają zapewne, jak cennaw naszym reaktorze była energia, dzięki ktorej zasilać mogliśmy systemy statku, broń czy specjalne boty bojowe. Tutaj owym surowcem jest reputacja, której punkty wydac możemy na ulepszenie naszego zespołu. Kupić możemy dodatkową broń, wynająć dodatkowego pilota do naszych mechów, zapewnić sobie wsparcie nalotów bombowych czy, tak jak w FTL, zainstalować w naszych jednostkach ulepszenie reaktora. Pozwala to zwiększyć ilość punktów ruchu, zadawanych obrażeń czy jakość pancerza.

DECYZJE, DECYZJE...

Każdy kto w FTL grał dłużej niż godzinę, pamięta zapewne jak poważnych wyborów musieliśmy dokonywać jako kapitan. Co najważniejsze, każdy z nich był permanentny, nieodwracalny i trzeba było liczyć sie z jego konsekwencjami. Nie inaczej jest w przypadku ITB. Na polach bitwy często zostaniemy zmuszeni do zrobienia rachunku zysków i strat, i wybrania mniejszego zła. Czy lepiej uszkodzić ( a nawet stracić) naszego mecha, czy może jednak pozwolić by ten wielki żuk zburzył szpital (zmniejszając tym samym szanse na pomyśle ukończenie misji)?

ROGUE-LIKE CZY ROGUE-LITE?

Ważnym aspektem każdej rozgrywki jest tutaj przegrana. Typowa dla Rogue-like'ów jest permadeath. Większość fanów FTL pamięta zapewne zgrzytanie zębami, gdy po raz kolejny oglądaliśmy rozpadający się kadłub naszego statku. Jednak za każdym razem (prócz treningu) pojawiała się możliwość odblokowania dodatkowych aspektów gry, takich jak kolejne modele statku, które pozwalają nam inaczej prowadzić rozgrywkę. Tak samo jest z ITB. Każda porażka (a te z pewnością się zdarzą) pozwala nam zdobyć specjalne medale, dzięki którym pod naszą komendę trafiają nowe zepoły mechów. A te potrafią niesłychanie zmienić nasze podejście do prowadzonych działań. Jedna ekipa jest świetna w działaniach ofensywnych, inna zaś świetne sobie radzą ze specjalnymi rodzajami wrogów, jeszcze kolejne doskonale dostosowują otoczenie do własnych potrzeb. Co ciekawe, w przeciwieństwie do FTL, tutaj fabuła doskonale tłumaczy kolejne podejscia do rozgrywki. Za każdym razem nasze roboty walczą w coraz to nowej linii czasowej, więc kolejne bitwy na tych samych obszarach wyglądają zupełnie inaczej.

Podsumowując. Into The Breach jest dla mnie świetną grą, która potrafi przyciągnąć na długie godziny (jeszcze jedna tura,misja,wyspa,gra...) Dla fanów FTL - pozycja obowiązkowa. Dla wielbicieli turowych strategii - prawdziwa perełka, którą zdecydowanie warto mieć w swojej kolekcji i poświecić jej trochę czasu.

A teraz wybaczcie, bo idę ratować świat przed wielkimi komarami.

KW

Currently over 40 hours of Into the Breach (over 600 hours FTL, if its relevant :P)

Its a turn-based strategy game at its core. I guess there are some similarities to chess. Like in chess you need to prioritise what you will be attacking or defending. And like chess you will be able to choose where/who is going to be taking damage. You're going to take damage, you can be sure of that. Whether its a mech getting hitting around, or the power grid getting hit. It will surely happen. So just keep that in mind.

There is also a little rogue lite element thrown into the mix, as you can choose to save one of your pilots at the end of a game. Win or lose, you can keep one of the pilots. Which does give you an advantage in your next play through.

There are four different islands to clear, and then the boss level. Each island allows for about 5 regions to be played. Each island is a specific biome. Each region has its own win rewards: Points to be spent; power to be utilised on the mechs; or power, to keep the power grid going.

The power grid, is like the health meter of your game. When the power is depleted its game over. If you manage to fill the power meter, any additional power gives a chance for an attack on it to be evaded.

Each play through has three mechs. Each has a pilot, but one of the pilots will either be a survivor from a previous game or selected traveller. The travellers have different abilities allowing for different styles to dominate a play through. There are 8 mech squads, 7 of them need to be unlocked as you play through the game. They are all quite different in how they play. Which can be a little confusing when you start out with a new squad.

One of the biggest plus points for me is that you can play the game in bite-sized pieces. Play one map, or one region. Its up to you. Its something that you can jump into quickly, bash some Vek around, and then go do whatever else you need to.

I've thoroughly enjoyed the game thus far. Its a solid little title. Check it out!

40863129.review:
Análise original em: https://goo.gl/vCC7xx

Into the Breach é um jogo independente de estratégia em turnos desenvolvido e distribuído pela Subset Games, mesmos criadores do aclamado FTL: Faster Than Light. Através de sua progressão roguelike, o jogo nos coloca em situações de escolha extremamente difíceis, dentre as quais temos que decidir entre a vida da população que devemos salvar ou a de seus pilotos. Com uma proposta de decisões táticas baseadas nos movimentos futuros dos seus adversários, Into the Breach busca trazer combates desafiantes e inteligentes. Será que o jogo consegue entregar o que promete? Veja nossa análise abaixo:

Jogadores de FTL se lembrarão de quão desesperador era se encontrar em situações que pareciam não ter solução. Por mais que passássemos a maior quantidade de tempo possível buscando sair da enrascada, às vezes era praticamente impossível. Into the Breach consegue trazer a mesma sensação através de um gameplay simples e incrível ao mesmo tempo. 

O jogo é construído na mesma progressão roguelike de FTL: Faster Than Light. Temos que percorrer quatro ilhas atacadas pelos Vek, criaturas gigantes em forma de insetos que por alguma razão estão atacando a humanidade. Você, como o comandante de um trio de Mechs, deve bolar estratégias em mapas 8x8 gerados de forma randômica com o simples intuito de sobreviver. Temos cinco turnos para evitar que os insetos destruam os Power Grids, estruturas do mapa que se assemelham a prédios cheios de civis. Em um primeiro momento, parece fácil de se aguentar meros cinco turnos em um mapa relativamente pequeno, mas, meu caro, Into the Breach exige muito estudo e reflexão sobre cada jogada. Um simples movimento errado pode fazer com que você perca o jogo de vez, e, rapaz, como isso é frustrante.

Tenho certa experiência com jogos de estratégia em turno, já que sou um grande fã do gênero (principalmente de XCOM). Agora, se teve um jogo que me fez queimar neurônios foi Into the Breach. Sempre estamos em desvantagem numérica e, apesar de sabermos os próximos movimentos dos inimigos, é muito difícil de se lograr sucesso em defender todos os Power Grids ao longo das quatro ilhas, estas que vão se tornando cada vez mais difíceis. 

Em Into the Breach, é essencial que se consiga bônus de objetivos através de Reactor Cores e Reputation. Por meios desses itens, podemos melhorar nossos Mechs com novas habilidades e armas, e isso é simplesmente es-sen-ci-al. Por um lado é mais fácil tentar sobreviver os cinco turnos sem buscar os bônus de cada mapa, por outro o jogador fica cada vez mais de mãos atadas, visto que os inimigos ficam cada vez mais difíceis enquanto seus Mechs não evoluem. Dessa forma, Into the Breach acaba sendo um jogo de equilíbrio. Em certo momento será mais prudente perder um Mech, em outro, pode ser que seja melhor evitar ataques aos Power Grids. Tudo depende da situação em que somos colocados.

Por falar em situações, Into the Breach é simplesmente excelente em criar níveis difíceis e inimigos que agem com bastante inteligência para atrapalhar nossos planos. Durante meu gameplay, tentei procurar por padrões de movimentação dos Vek nos mapas, mas logo percebi que isso é muito difícil de se fazer. As ações dos inimigos são sempre muito inteligentes e, por mais que saibamos o próximo passo deles, toda a sua estratégia pode mudar quando um novo inimigo surge e resolve prender um dos seus Mechs. Eu gosto de tratar Into the Breach como se fosse um jogo de xadrez da modernidade. As peças têm movimentações e habilidades diferentes que permitem cercar e fazer diferentes estratégias contra os inimigos. Ao mesmo tempo em que tentamos estar um passo à frente e frustrar as ações hostis, temos que nos prevenir contra ações inesperadas e calcular cada possibilidade para sempre realizar as melhores movimentações e decisões possíveis. Cheguei a passar questão de meia hora realizando uma simples ação, mas o prazer de fazer a melhor jogada é incomensurável. O mais incrível é quando parece que não temos como sair de certa situação e milagrosamente pensamos numa solução engenhosa. Diferentemente de muitos outros jogos de estratégia em turnos, que têm a sua dose de sorte, Into the Breach transforma toda a experiência em um grande puzzle, já que sempre se sabe de antemão quem os Vek atacarão, qual será o dano e em que ordem. Isso dá um nível de controle maior ao jogo, já que a variável da incerteza é extremamente diminuída.

Para deixar o jogo ainda mais variado, acumula-se pontos a cada timeline que iniciamos, estes que podem ser trocados por equipes variadas de Mechs. As opções existentes são muito interessantes, e alteram de forma considerável as estratégias que podem ser utilizadas em cada situação. Meu esquadrão favorito até então consiste de um robô que dá dano em cadeia através de choques, um que puxa inimigos para próximo de si e outro que arremessa pedras que causam dano e empurram os Vek. A combinação dos três elementos em muitos momentos é mortal, já que temos a possibilidade de eliminar muitos inimigos de uma só vez. É praticamente um cheque-mate.

Agora vamos ao momento exaltação. Into the Breach possivelmente será lembrado como um divisor de águas no gênero da estratégia em turnos. Isso acontece porque enquanto equipes inteiras demoram para desenvolver puzzles, situações e mapas cuidadosamente feitos para apresentar desafios e proporcionar diferentes estratégias de embate, Into the Breach gera de forma randômica cenários que dão inúmeras possibilidades de combate instantaneamente e de forma magistral. E mais, não há loading! Talvez este seja o momento em que pararemos de encontrar jogos com mapas pré-determinados e nos depararemos com mais títulos que fazem uso desse tipo de engine. É simplesmente genial o que foi feito.

Para fechar a cereja do bolo, Into the Breach traz uma trilha sonora que junto com seus gráficos pixelados e minimalistas, contribuem muito para que apreciemos a beleza do seu design e passemos horas e horas quebrando a cabeça tentando chegar até a última ilha.

Para aqueles que amam um design inteligente, Into the Breach é incrível. Para aqueles que amam jogos de estratégia em turno, Into the Breach é fenomenal. É realmente difícil de se encontrar pontos negativos neste jogo, que tem o potencial de mudar a forma como jogos de combate tático são desenvolvidos. Com uma gama de possibilidades enorme e customização de armas e habilidades em um sistema RPG, Into the Breach tem tudo para ser o indie do ano.

Não importa se você tem seis ou sessenta anos, é menino ou menina, uma coisa une todos nós: a paixão por robôs gigantes. A única coisa que pode ameaçar a hegemonia de robôs gigantes em nossos corações são monstros gigantes. Os criadores de FTL conseguiram unir as duas forças para um embate mortal que deixará ondulações no tecido do espaço-tempo por eras. Ou pelo menos pelo tempo que você jogar Into the Breach.

Sim, é um clichê muito antigo colocar máquinas de combate do tamanho de prédios contra "kaijus", mas os desenvolvedores desse jogo não apenas não tem receio de apelar para aquele nosso fascínio interior pelo tema como também guardam algumas surpresas em seu universo e envolvem tudo em uma jogabilidade sólida e viciante.

Ao contrário do que se pode esperar de uma história básica como essa, Into the Breach começa com o fim da Humanidade. Os monstros gigantes venceram. Colossais insetos chamados de Vek emergiram das entranhas do planeta, os mares se levantaram, nossa civilização foi reduzida a ruínas e todos os esforços resultaram em fracassos. Mas um intrépido esquadrão de pilotos de robôs gigantes foi incumbido de uma missão que não pode falhar: retornar ao passado, cancelar o Apocalipse e salvar pelo menos uma linha temporal da tragédia.

Embora o enredo não seja exatamente o foco do jogo, a Subset Games consegue embutir o conceito em sua atmosfera e até mesmo em sua mecânica. De um lado, temos a pressão constante que o extermínio está logo ali no horizonte: há o desespero daqueles que moram nas cidades atacadas, há a esperança que aparece quando os robôs desembarcam no solo, há uma contagem de baixas civis com cada prédio destruído.

Do outro lado, vemos uma elegante solução para a tela de fim de jogo e o problema do "permadeath": o jogador não fracassa em definitivo. Você salta no tempo para tentar novamente (e é óbvio que você irá tentar novamente), com a possibilidade de salvar pelo menos um de seus pilotos e todas suas evoluções, para liderar uma nova equipe em outra linha temporal.

Dará certo da próxima vez ou a Humanidade estará novamente condenada, enquanto você tenta e tenta, pulando entre universos? Com ameaças, desafios e recompensas randomizados, a resposta dependerá apenas do que o próprio jogador aprender e de sua capacidade de entender as táticas do combate e usá-las a seu favor.

Nem mesmo a vitória final e a erradicação dos Veks significa uma conclusão e Into the Breach te convida para novamente escolher um piloto para liderar um novo esquadrão em outra linha temporal e repetir essa batalha infinita. Uma batalha infinita entre robôs gigantes e monstros gigantes, até o final dos tempos.

No momento em que os Mechs pousam no solo com estrondo e o povo saúda sua chegada, você já sabe o que te espera: uma luta de proporções épicas. Mesmo com gráficos retrô e um mapa que cabe inteiro na tela, Into the Breach tem as proporções de uma aventura maior que a vida. A trilha sonora injeta a dose certa de adrenalina na hora em que a diferença entre ganhar e perder se torna mínima, para logo em seguida subir triunfante ou se tornar melancólica e te lembrar que a extinção da raça humana depende de você, basta uma sucessão de decisões erradas.

Para vencer em Into the Breach é necessário posicionar seus robôs nos locais corretos e executar os ataques certos em um combate por turnos que exige muito raciocínio e escolhas difíceis. Destruir aquele Vek perigoso ou salvar aquele prédio? Interceptar um tiro e se arriscar a perder um Mech ou permitir que o inimigo destrua uma peça importante de tecnologia enviada através das barreiras do tempo? Em cada turno é executado um balé de peças similar ao xadrez. Um xadrez com robôs gigantes e monstros gigantes, onde é possível desferir um murro devastador na cara de um besouro de 10.000 toneladas ou ver com horror centenas de pessoas sendo levadas à morte porque um trem bateu em um louva-deus nascido no Inferno.

Suas decisões, para o bem ou para o mal, são carregadas ao longo da campanha. Ao todo, o título apresenta quatro ilhas que precisam ser protegidas da ameaça Vek, cada um com suas características peculiares. Ao longo da sua travessia, o jogador acumula uma grade de energia necessária para operar os Mechs. Alguns locais salvos ampliam essa grade de energia. Cada prédio destruído pelo inimigo reduz essa grade de energia e, se ela chegar a zero, é hora de abandonar essa linha temporal e tentar novamente. Ou seja, embora pareça se tratar de uma luta para destruir os Veks, a grande verdade de Into the Breach é que se trata de um jogo de salvar a Civilização.

No início, você irá perder e perder, até se acostumar com essa dança. E, assim, a Subset Games mais uma vez combina a temática com a mecânica do título.

Gerenciar os recursos fora do campo de batalha, escolhendo missões, administrando pilotos e evoluções dos robôs são tão importantes para a vitória quanto as batalhas em si. Com tantas variáveis a se considerar simultaneamente, a possibilidade de desbloquear esquadrões com habilidades completamente diferentes e missões randômicas, Into the Breach compensa a curta duração de sua campanha (que pode ser fechada em duas horas) com uma infinitude de universos paralelos a serem salvos.

Por que uma pessoa nunca pode se cansar de robôs gigantes enfrentando monstros gigantes.

Originalmente publicada em [url=http://www.gamerview.com.br/into-the-breach/]http://www.gamerview.com.br/into-the-breach/[/url]

[b]TL;DR:[/b] if you like puzzles and turn-based strategy you'll enjoy this game. Think Chess crossed with XCOM, without the RNG.

I've heard it described as a strategy game with rogue-like elements. I think that's misleading. I see [i]Into the Breach[/i] as a puzzle game. You play as a group of three giant mechs, tasked with defending (what's left of) the Earth from a crawling, sprawling alien menace called the Vek. The Vek often outnumber and outgun you, but they have one weakness: they are slow. Each turn in-game, the Vek aim for their targets, giving you a chance to respond. All in all the game is about minimising the damage they do to your structures, while killing them off as soon as possible. The game takes place on a 8x8 board; it might sound cramped but there's enough room there and enough mechanics to make a surprisingly deep experience.

Each mission has a different objective: for example, don't take too much damage; defend some NPCs; defend a building, that sort of thing. A few mission types give you extra NPC units to control, or powerful landscape-changing buildings to unleash upon the Vek; these help keep things varied.

Generally speaking the game is very good at making it clear how the Vek will behave; there are a few occasions where the game hadn't explained this or I'd misunderstood. For instance, an enemy whose sprite faces left (say) will still face left even if they are aiming to fire a projectile to the right; it means you have to look for markers around the enemy rather than the enemy themselves. (I guess the trade off is that you can quickly recognise an enemy by sight.)

It's very replayable. Similar to FTL, achievements unlock new ways of playing the game, this time in the form of new mech squads. Learning how to play each new squad is rewarding, with little achievements to point you in the right direction. There's a good mixture of easy and hard achievements, so even if you're not planning to complete the game you can still unlock a good number of the squads.

Let me also mention the [url=https://benprunty.bandcamp.com/album/into-the-breach-soundtrack]soundtrack[/url], which does a good job of racking up the tension. Lead by a [url=https://soundcloud.com/jody-macgregor/into-the-breach-guitar-riff]guitar riff[/url] which crops up everywhere, each of the game's environments has its own audio theme to match its distinct visual theme.

Into the Breach is the love child of Pacific Rim and Quantum Leap given form as a rogue like turn based RPG. You take charge of 3 mech pilots battling giant insects (the Vek). On your first run you'll have the Rift Walkers mech squad, one A-list pilot (hollywood superstar - comes  with 1 perk and earns 2 more on levelling up) and two B-list pilots (supporting actors - no free perk but will earn 2 via levelling up). Your goal is to cleanse the Vek from the earth.

Victory or defeat will see your surviving squad members jump into a new timeline and you get to choose a crew member to follow (bring) into this new version of Earth. Whoever you choose will get to keep all the xp & skills they've earned. Everytime a new timeline starts you may pick your mech squad and colour scheme, after which they can't be changed.

ItB is a game that is designed to be played multiple times, as each campaign lasts 1-2 hrs; you have the option of clearing 2, 3 or 4 islands before tackling the final mission. 
Each island has a unique set of terrain hazards and is pick 4 from 7 regions, with the only criteria being that they're adjacent to a previously cleared region.  Each region has its own challenge and rewards. The final mission is a 2 stage fight which scales in difficulty depending on how many islands you've cleared. 

There are also challenges - 3 per mech squad, plus others that are open to all squads. Each challenge gives you a reward  token and each new squad( & colour scheme) costs 3-6 tokens to unlock.

I suppose I'm writing this to offer a somewhat different perspective from what I'm seeing a lot in the reviews here. There are many who didn't get more than 10 or so hours out of Into The Breach before it lost their interest for various reasons. I'm not here to dispute that their assessment is fair, which I'm sure it is. Rather, I'll just offer what I see roughly 30 hours in so far.

I'm not going to explain the gameplay loop, as you can find plenty of in-depth reviews here. I'll just offer what you can expect concerning late game, replayability, and difficulty.

Late game: for one, you will most likely have unlocked all squads. From there, you'll be working on 3 and 4 island victories for each. All squads also have 3 unique challenges which net you coins to unlock the rest of the secret content. These can be hit or miss, as some can be accomplished just by playing the squad often enough, while others will require you to target them specifically and basically do a throw-away run just to get it. I'm gonna go ahead and guess that accomplishing all of this will take at least 50 hours: as I said, I'm 30 in with a 2-island victory for each squad and most of the challenges completed.

Then you're into free play, where I think ITB is losing a lot of players compared to FTL, and I'm not sure why. Much like FTL, you can start with a squad that plays a specific way, but drastically changes with the discovery of one weapon or passive ability. By selling a mech's starting weapon and equipping a new one, you essentially change their entire playstyle. Sure you're not going to see as many combinations as in FTL, as FTL has hacking/boarding/drone control in addition to their weapon selection and passvies. But I still feel that a run of ITB can be quite varied and unique.

Finally, just a note on difficulty. Many claim that ITB is too easy and not nearly as hard as FTL. In FTL, some runs are unwinnable based on your loadout or if you happen to encounter a ship that you simply can't compete with--if you don't have missle defense, or a way past 3-4 shields yet, etc. The flagship itself is only consistently beatable with a few specific loadouts that either include hacking, boarding, flak, or bombs.

In contrast, ITB is consistently beatable with any squad. They were designed that way. Sure you may have to sacrifice power ocasionaly, and it may take you a long time to find the right solution. But that IS the essense of this game's difficulty: The fact that sometimes you'll be sitting on one turn for 10-20 minutes until you finally figure out the perfect play. That, to me, is extremely satisfying. And it hasn't gotten old yet. 

So, will you enjoy this game if you liked FTL? I think absolutely. Will you get as much replayability? That's something I can't answer. I think the mechanics are definitely there--I put about 100 hours into FTL + AE when it came out, which I know is paltry compared to what others got out of it. But I can honestly see getting at least that much out of ITB as well.

40814243.review:
Usually it isn't necessary to underscore the genre of a game. But this strategy, turn-based game is unlike many others that share these tags, and, perhaps most importantly, is almost nothing like Subset Games' previous masterpiece, Faster than Light. It is better to approach Into the Breach as a puzzle game, and framed this way, it is a phenomenal title.

The finely polished systems of Into the Breach are deceptively simple, yet highly rewarding. You control three mechs on a grid trying to fight off the insidious Vek, giant insects that threaten all human life. Positioning is king. Every move the enemy will take on its turn is clearly telegraphed, including the chronological order of each environmental event or enemy action. To protect buildings and complete objectives, you must carefully consider how each action will affect subsequent enemy actions. Blocking enemy fire with your own mech or another enemy, pushing an enemy into an environmental hazard, freezing yourself, choosing between blocking an emerging enemy and destroying a damaged one: all these choices must be juggled in a choreographed dance of mechanized bug murder.

World building is passable. The artwork is enjoyable and well-executed for its style, clearly delineating island types according to the corporate flavor. The levels scale to your current progress, and leaders and mech pilots have their own, albeit limited, personalities.

The soundtrack is composed by the talented, ever-capable Ben Prunty. The ominous, slightly mournful tones of the title screen and strategic map give way to tense, yet upbeat battle tracks, each crafted to match the battle environment.

Even understood as puzzle game though, it’s not perfect. I have my gripes: the grid system—which amounts to a “health bar” for your run and decreases every time a building is destroyed—feels out of place. In a game that rewards you for perfect positioning, where almost all choices are clearly good or bad, the (usually tiny) chance of randomly negating building damage does little to prevent poor play while failing to reward competence. If you’re playing well, you’ll never need to rely on grid resistance, yet higher grid resistance is often a reward for playing well.

I generally don't enjoy puzzle games, but I managed to get a good 20 hours out of this title, unlocking all but one squad and every pilot (apparently there are secret pilots, but I never saw them). (Perhaps 40% of my "playtime" was AFK. Dad life, amirite.) I beat the game on my first run, but I attribute that more to my dabbling with chess than the inherent difficulty of the title. Unless you are gunning for particularly difficult achievements, patient, careful moves will reward you with smooth, near-perfect runs almost 100% of the time. RNG will neither save you nor destroy you.

If you enjoy puzzle games, I highly recommend this title. If you only enjoy them somewhat, wait for a sale.

40810984.review:
Into the Breach is Subset Game's second game and follow up to their wildly popular debut, FTL: Faster Than Light. Much like FTL, Into the Breach is a sci-fi rogue like adventure, although this time, the emphasis is on turn based battles between time traveling mechs and the insectoid aliens called "Vek" (and sometimes mech against mech in point of fact). In fact, I would call this something akin to FTL meets Starship Troopers meets Pacific Rim meets The Terminator meets Time Cop. So, how does Into the Breach stack up?

[h1]Story[/h1]

The story, written by Chris Avellone, is quite a bit less substantial than most if not all of Avellone's previous work (Pillar of Eternity, Planescape: Torment, etc...). In fact, he was even the creative director for Fallout: New Vegas. Being one of the great writers in video games doesn't mean you always write full RPG stories though. Into the Breach is more pulpy in nature and the story is fairly lite. Where you really see Avellone's influence more than anywhere else though is with the inclusion of pithy and sarcastic dialogue, such as there is in this game. Although Into the Breach isn't really about story overall, the story is in fact the perfect motivation and I can find no flaws in it outside of the fact that there was an opportunity to really build the story up further than it has been already.

So, the story features a trio of soldiers from alternate timelines/the future going back in time and traveling timelines with their Pacific Rim sized mechs to fight off the Vek, an alien race of insects that is destroying the world in each timeline. Your goal is to fight them off, find out where the source of the Vek is to found, and destroy their hive. Then on to the next timeline to do it all over again.

8.5 out of 10

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Gameplay in Into the Breach is surprisingly complex. Well, maybe it's not so surprising to fans of FTL. Grid based tactical combat is the order of the day here. The standards are there: a small battle maps featuring enemies, obstacles, traps, and various objectives such as protecting power plants or terraforming a map, killing "x" amount of enemies, and so on. Accomplishing the goals set to each region will grant you corporate favor, energy, and power cores (that function as the points for upgrades).

There are ten different mech units that can be unlocked via finishing timelines and unit objectives, which vary amongst the ten based on their specific skill sets. These give you coins that can be spent to unlock the mech units. You begin with one and will earn the other nine pretty quickly. Their specialties range from specific elemental damage to flight, melee or ranged combat, healing and buffs, etc...and each unit is well balanced with three mechs that (typically) includes a heavy mech, a medium/light mech, and a support mech. You can also create your own custom units using any previously unlocked mech.

Each mech has its own specialty and its skill trees (represented by modifications to the mechs) have two upgrades each (and two modification slots per mech) along with one available upgrade to both health and movement. Health is obvious and is counted in points. Most mechs start with between three to five health and this can be upgraded via modifications as well as the mech pilot's level and attendant buffs.

Speaking of pilots, these are the time traveling heroes in the game. They can and often do die. Should this happen, and you haven't recruited a new pilot (this is typically either done via the occasional time capsule that will fall onto the battle maps or as an island reward for not failing any region goals), the mech's A.I. will take over until a replacement is found. This is not ideal however as the A.I. doesn't gain experience and abilities. Pilots on the other hand do gain levels (three is the max level presently). Each level comes with a buff that is passed along to the mech, be it extra health, armor bonus, movement bonus, or other abilities. After a timeline is completed, you may choose to take one pilot along with you to the next timeline. this obviously provides you with a bit of a starting bonus as your pilot is already going to be leveled up to some extent if not outright maxed out.

There are a couple other aspects to the game. You have to maintain energy supplies to power and repair your mechs. If your energy ever falls to zero, you will have failed the timeline and will need to start a new one. Fortunately, you can still take one of your pilots with you if you so choose. You also save people's lives with each region and island you clear, and this essentially functions as a high score leaderboard type thing. Each island is divided into regions, and once you have cleared enough regions of Vek to have three contested areas left, the Vek will surge up and destroy some of the lands you just cleared, culminating in a direct attack to the island's corporate headquarters, which you will have to fend off. This is the boss fight for each island.

Your goal ultimately is to kill off the Vek from each timeline. You accomplish this by clearing "Corporate Islands" of the Vek presence. Islands are functionally nations, each with it's own specialty, terrain, regions and government. Each island's CEO functions as your point of contact. You go about the slaughter of Vek through grid based tactical combat maps. It's group turn based (meaning all the Vek will move, then your entire group will go, then any environmental effects will go off, then all the Vek will go, rinse and repeat until the battle is over. There are also a limited amount of rounds available to conquer each region. Once the timer is down to zero, combat stops and any objectives left unfinished are failed. That might seem unforgiving, and on hard difficulty, it is without question incredibly difficult, but the timer itself is generally not an issue unless you've been bogged down in battle and the objectives weren't battle related, and even then, you will generally fall backwards into completing objectives anyway.

I would like to note for y'all that starting with easy and moving up to hard is the way to go. You can still lose on Easy difficulty, but it's better for learning the game mechanics. By the time you get to Hard, you will be fighting/fending off far more enemies, and any mistake you make could potentially cost you the game (and definitely will repeatedly lol), so it's good to have some experience before leaping off the edge into the unknown.

There are even more aspects to gameplay that I haven't covered here, and that should give you a good indication as to the depth that can be found within.

All in all, this is a flawless game. No technical issues and perfect gameplay. 10 out of 10

[h1]Graphics[/h1]

The graphics Into the Breach brings to the table are going to be no surprise to FTL vets either. This is a really nice looking game with very cool animations, nice artwork during the cutscenes, and an overall cool feel to the graphics in general.

A bit pulp, a bit anime-ish, solid isometric imagery....this game does everything well from a graphical perspective. The set pieces look very cool and the actual character designs have a nice, almost watercolor quality to them. This is a visually pleasing game without a doubt. Not groundbreaking, but nice.

8 out of 10

[h1]Audio[/h1]

The audio is all ambient and combat oriented outside of the soundtrack itself, which has an almost whimsical, Borderlands/Firefly-esque, mysterious quality to it. Really, really nice and something I personally have not grown tired of at all after fifteen or so hours spent with the game so far. Everything sounds great and there is a solid vibe to the game overall. Unobtrusive but relevant.

9 out of 10

[h1]Verdict[/h1]

Wrapped up in the comment section.

40805698.review:
[h1] 太长不看版 [/h1]

《ITB》目前固然有一些不可回避的缺点，比如游戏引导和提示方面不够完善以及数量有限的地图和简略的剧情造成的重复感。但从创新性方面来看，游戏的确给玩家带来了新鲜和刺激的体验。在传统战棋游戏的基础上对机制的创新，贯穿始终的设局与破局的理念以及大量的不确定因素给玩家带来的思考与挑战都是使这款游戏成为杰作的重要因素。至少对于我个人来说，《ITB》是今年到目前为止最优秀的策略游戏。

[h1] 这不是一款战棋游戏 [/h1]

虽然从游戏形式上看很像，但《ITB》不是一个战棋游戏，而它与象棋、围棋等棋类游戏也不相同，从形式上看它更像是一款策略解谜游戏，比较核心的理念是设局与破局。

[h1] 设局，破局，再设局 [/h1]

在敌方行动的回合中，外星生物会完成移动和“攻击预约”的动作，“攻击预约”是我自己创造的一个词，听起来其实也挺形象的，就是上面提到的本回合的攻击动作会在下一个回合得到结果反馈，而本回合只是对即将进行的攻击行为的预约。敌方回合完成后，相当于给玩家设置了一个“局”。玩家需要权衡自己当前的目标和各种状况，控制机体来破解敌方设的局，这是一个破局的过程。敌方一旦进行了“攻击预约”，在下个回合行动之前不会主动改变已经预约的攻击，除非玩家的行为干扰或者破坏了地方的攻击行为，这是由预约这个行为本身决定的。因此，玩家回合破局的过程其实是针对敌方的一个“再设局”的过程，利用预约后无法改变的攻击行为，玩家可以通过改变敌军的位置来使它们互相残杀，也可以为即将被敌军攻击的建筑加上保护罩。敌方为玩家设的局，玩家在回合内就有机会破掉，但同时给敌方设置的局，敌方是无法破解的，这是博弈过程中不公平的表现，实际上对玩家更有利。

从设局与破局交替进行的过程来看，《ITB》更像是一个解谜游戏。玩家综合自己当前的情况进行权衡，在每个回合的博弈中实现利益的最大化。

[h1] 胜利目标与难度 [/h1]

[b] 短期目标与长期目标 [/b]

如果不考虑刻意刷某个成就的情况，游戏的长期目标就是成功通过最终的关卡，击杀最终boss并获得相对高的分数。而为了达到这个长期目标，玩家需要面对很多个短期目标，逐步实现短期目标来为长期目标积累更多的优势。举个例子，游戏中完成两个岛屿的任务就可以去打最终boss，但我们权衡当前驾驶员的等级和机体武器升级状况后会考虑继续完成第三甚至第四个岛的战役后再去面对最终boss。虽然完成的岛屿越多，最终关卡难度越高，但同时玩家也能积累更多的优势，实际上是为长期目标服务的。

根据玩家当前的状态，短期目标的优先级是可以变化的。从我个人的经验来看，短期目标的优先级排序是：声望点数(星星)>任务中舱体(包含核心)>击杀更多敌人>能量值(闪电)>驾驶员生还。玩家所遇到的每一个任务都只有5个回合的长度，只要在5个回合之内能量值不降为零就可以胜利，因此完成任务不是我们的短期目标。

声望点数是短期目标中价值最高的，完成一个岛屿之后可以花费得到的声望来购买武器、能量值或者核心，这对于长期目标的贡献最大，因此是我们每个任务中最先要争取的；其次是随机坠落的舱体，可以提供核心一定概率的驾驶员；第三个是击杀敌人，得到的经验值可供驾驶员升级从而得到新的被动技能，对长期目标有贡献；第四个能量值是优先级可以变动的短期目标，在能量值充足时为了声望点数等价值更高的目标可以损失一部分，但能量值很低时为了不至于导致游戏结束，获取和保护能量值变为了最高优先级。

在不同的情况下追求不同的短期目标，使得达到长期目标时的利益最大化，这是一般的战棋类游戏所不具备的。类似火纹或者机战这种战棋游戏每一关的胜利目标非常明确，玩家的所有决策都是为了达成这个目标而使得利益最大化的，因此相比之下策略性就大打折扣了。

[b] 难度 [/b]

不少玩家觉得《ITB》的难度比较高，每一关破局的过程也比较烧脑，往往需要考虑后续的场面和局势。其实从短期和长期目标来看，这个游戏的难度我认为在一定程度上是由玩家自己决定的。比如像某个任务中要保护机器人工厂，但工厂生产出来的机器人却会反过来攻击玩家。如果我们要追求声望点数这个短期目标，那么必然要同时避免机器人和外星生物攻击的基础上保护工厂和居民建筑，这时候游戏难度陡然升高。但如果我们故意放弃一个工厂，虽然失去了一点声望值，但也避免了新机器人的产生对我方造成的影响，这就是主动降低了过关难度。

类似的例子还有保护火车的任务，击杀敌人同时保证火车不被撞或被攻击是很困难的，有时我们不得不放弃一点声望值让火车损坏，保护损坏的火车要比运动的火车简单得多。实际上火车关卡我很多时候都直接放弃一点声望值来保护损坏的火车，有些时候不主动降低难度确实是对自己的一种折磨。

牺牲短期目标来降低游戏难度的方式，是《ITB》区别与普通战棋游戏的一大特色。

我们对战棋游戏的S/L大法非常熟悉，那么为什么要使用S/L大法呢？一个原因是很多战棋游戏中命中率的概念是个玄学，反复读档就为了那一下攻击命中或者闪避；另一个原因就是我们不愿意也无法放弃短期目标，不读档必然会对短期目标造成影响。短期目标损失的同时又对我们过关没有任何好处，哪怕是一点难度的降低，这个后果我们承受不来。

《ITB》中短期目标可以牺牲的特点给了玩家更高的自由度和容错性，很多时候一步走错不至于全盘皆输，游戏难度还有可能会下降一些，缓解玩家的过关压力，游戏的魅力可能就在于此吧。

[h1] 不确定性与挑战性 [/h1]

《ITB》中的不确定性或者说变数是这个游戏的另外一个魅力。

想象一下我们曾经玩过的那些战棋类游戏，敌我双方开局时排兵布阵，随着回合的流逝互相角逐，一开始我们就知道双方的实力差距和兵种特点，那么不确定性何在呢？更多的时候是在关卡进行过程中那些特殊剧情引发的双方阵容变化，是这些意外造成的不确定性使得游戏更富有变化。这样描述可能不够直观，举几个例子更加生动形象一些。

火纹中有些关卡在进行到一半时，会因为剧情而出现敌方的援军或者我方新加入的同伴，在这些人出现之前游戏局势可能已经稳定了，但这些人的出现打破了这种稳定，出现的位置、人物的属性特点打破了之前的平衡，使得我们需要重新决策如何才能在这些“意外”发生之后还能达到过关利益的最大化。机战也是同样道理，关卡中偶然出现的敌人，朋友，甚至是剧情杀，为游戏增添了不确定性，使我们不得不重新考虑策略，这是我们感到游戏“很刺激”的来源。但所有的这些“意外”只是战棋类游戏中的插曲，大多数时候我们在开局就已经把整局游戏的策略确定下来并按部就班地执行了，这使得过关的过程往往比较枯燥。

在《ITB》中，每个任务中的每一个回合都在不断地发生“意外”，这些“意外”的来源就是从地底随机位置出现的随机种类的敌人。可能很多玩家都有这种感觉，每一关让我们焦头烂额的往往是这些新出现的敌人，本以为完美破掉的局，下一个回合可能又会陷入更难的局中。上一个回合自己制造的伤害敌人的烟雾，在下一个回合可能就正好阻碍了自己的机体发射武器；上一个回合调动到地图一端来击杀敌人的一个机体，在下一个回合地图另一端可能就有一个敌人只能由它来解决；上一回合站位密集的三个机体，下一回合可能就会因为互相影响无法自由行动。

传统战棋游戏中，随着回合的进行，玩家实际上是在不断积累优势，在单局博弈中玩家的利益不断放大，最终赢得博弈。而在《ITB》中每一个回合都会产生意外，新出现的敌人打破原有博弈的平衡，使得敌我双方的优势和劣势重新分配，这是游戏最刺激的地方。我们需要在每个回合都重新思考策略，改版原有的行动方式，应对全新的场面局势，追求短期目标的利益最大化。在每一局的博弈中不断改变策略是避免游戏落入模式化按部就班行动的枯燥循环中的关键因素。

玩家总结出来的很多游戏中的技巧，其实也是为了能更好地应对每个回合中的意外，减少不确定性给破局带来的影响。比如己方的机体尽可能不要都扎堆在一起，不要使某一个机体脱离主要战场太远，三个机体行动的先后顺序也要根据情况进行调整等等。包括很多玩家提到的一点，游戏中的“位移”比“伤害”更加重要，也是这个意思。因为应对每回合的这些不确定因素是，有限的伤害很多时候不足以扭转突如其来的劣势，但灵活的位移往往可以利用敌人“攻击预约”的特性来有效破局，使玩家在博弈的过程中占据主导地位，最大化每个回合的收益。

每个回合中的不确定性和让人毫无提防陡然增加的挑战性是《ITB》最吸引我的地方，也是我认为游戏可重玩价值的最大体现。可解锁的机体和多样的武器在我看来应该算是陪衬，不断调整策略来赢得每一场博弈的胜利是带给了我最大的乐趣。

40802362.review:
* Design by the FTL people
* Production quality (sound! art!) by the FTL people
* Front-mission/advance/tactics/block-mover-puzzle-games/something-all-their-own
* Starts out perhaps underwhelming. Ends obscenely addictive
* Very-very-tight focus done well

Those are my major points. I will elaborate.

* Design by the FTL people

It clearly is. The mechanics and gameplay are not at all like FTL but the general principles are all there. Every game is its own phenom. You CAN get screwed by luck of the draw. Or you might get double-halberds with cloaking + hacking modules and that thingy that lets you fire all weapons on the first turn by the third map (maybe a little less extreme than that but when you win/luck-out big you still win big in this game).

There is progress even when you lose. You unlock pilots as you play. Each one has interesting 0-level abilities that can sync up very well with the right gear/strategy/etc.

Losing is okay. If it isn't, stay away from this developer. 

* Production quality (sound! art!) by the FTL people

Oh yes. FTL is superior but it's the same people (I think) and it's awesome.


* Front-mission/advance/tactics/block-mover-puzzle-games/something-all-their-own

There's an almost billiards aspect to this silly simple yet complex tbs 8x8 map game where most attacks move enemies and objects in one direction or another depending on how fancy your equipment is. The AI for a change, can't swim even though your mechs can, so knocking powerful non-boss units into water, glowing-green-sludge/A.C.I.D/etc is deeply satisfying to those of us who died many deaths on the NES for the crime of assuming we could swim.

Every map gives you a chance to re-try a turn. You will use it. I suspect no matter how good you are, you will use it. And you will love that character that let's you use it twice for a while, until you get better.

* Starts out perhaps underwhelming. Ends obscenely addictive

Yeah, at about 20 minutes I was starting to feel on the verge of disappointed. Then I got to some upgrades and realized there was a fair bit of breadth that I wasn't seeing yet. It's there and it's worth finding.



* Very-very-tight focus done well

The design is so minimal yet so... not-basic. It's a very clever game. Well worth a time-investment.

40800097.review:
This is one great [i]depth filled turn based strategy![/i] Quite the game to test your brain in many different ways.

But first, just because this is made by the folks who made FTL does [u]not mean it is FTL.[/u] If they wanted to ride off of FTLs popularity, they could have made an FTL 2, but they chose to be [b]creative[/b] and made something wayyyy different while still applying what they know about games. (AKA, it has a lot of the same style as FTL.) It's not FTL, but it's still really good.


For starters, the main gameplay premise is quite interesting. Mixing in [u]time travel themes[/u] into a [u]futuristic near-apocalypse[/u] world with the [i]goal to be preventing the apocalypse[/i] using freaking mechs in [i]as many time lines as possible[/i]. A win or a loss both result in the same outcome, (which is interesting); go back in time to a different timeline and try to save the world again. That gives each playthrough purpose and allows for the whole rogue like idea to be canonical...but it's only sorta rogue like...Prior playthroughs can actually [i]directly[/i] change future playthroughs, as well as the whole usual unlocking more ways to play the game.

Now, each playthrough is pretty short, and you actually get a choice in how long the game plays, as well as what order you play it in (the island mechanic is pretty neat.) Plus it is a [i]bit[/i] easier to reach victory than other rogue likes I have played...but there are tons of different ways to play the game, each set of mechs is totally different, and it would be hard to run out of things to do, even after lots of playthroughs.


The battles themselves are the real gameplay, and for a good game, they have to be pretty cool. There are all types of goals-just a time based victory usually isn't enough to get far with upgrades and all-and you choose what objectives to play on. When in battle, there is a [i]lot[/i] more to work with than the usual turn based combat game. There's tons more to battle than just damaging the bad bugs. You [u]know what attacks they will make[/u], so often its more about [u]preventing[/u] damage to civilian buildings (which are the one thing that losing can lead to a game over-lose all your mechs and the game still goes on! lose all the civilians, and the one run is over) which involves a lot more than just killing them.

You can move enemies, freeze enemies, reverse enemies, smoke bomb enemies, drown enemies, shield allies, even [i]make enemies attack eachother[/i]...the limits of avoiding damage are all down to your mech kit...and there are a lot of mech kits to unlock, each one with a totally different play style. You only get 3 mechs ion a game, [i]ever[/i], so choose wisely! And find the play style that suits you. The uniqueness of each mech really impresses me.


The game is really deep, so trying to talk about anything in a review would take ages. It's best to see exactly what the game has to offer by playing yourself...but that's all the basics for you. If it sounds complex...that's because it is, which is all part of the fun and challenge!

Want a cool indie TBS? Into the Breach is right here, totally worth the small $15 Subset are asking for.

40798370.review:
Into the breach is a fun game about three giant robots dead set on murdering the crap out of a leigon of giant bugs while also trying to protect random buildings. Think Pacific Rim meets Chess.

There are three mechs to a squad. Four different classes of mechs. Each mech can have two different peices of equipment some of which is class specific and some which isn't. Each mech gets a pilot, pilots level up with kills and gain extra stats, usually movement, HP, reactor power, or grid defense (% chance damage doesn't harm a building). There are special pilots You can find that have special abilities like moving after you attack or adding extra armor.

At the end of each run you can pick a pilot to carry on to the next run assuming they are still alive. If a mech is killed the mech is disabled but returns after the battle. The pilot of a destroyed mech is killed.

There is very little random chance in the combat. Abilities always do what they are supposed to do, attacks never miss, and it makes the combat very strategic and very cerebral. You also have the ability to reset the turn once per fight.

Into the breach is a very entertaining game that took me about 20 hours to finally beat on the hardest setting. Unlocking all the squads was the hard part.

My only major criticism is that certain mechs (aegis, Jet, Rocket) are really overpowered compared to some of the other mechs which are really weak and practically worthless (Leap, Hook). I'd also mention that since the game has so many movement based abilities there should really be more environmental hazards as so many squads focus on moving the enemy around it's really hard to finish the game with them when there are so many maps that just don't give them a chance to actually kill anything. Either put more hazards in the game to take advantage of or remove the (kill this boss) section. Having so many Kill X missions really makes damage focused squads the way to go.

Wow this game is great! It is a RNG-based strategic puzzle game kind of like Chess. What I mean is, every turn brings in new Vek and the Vek never move the same spots in any turn or any mission. It forces you to spend time to think about how to achieve the best possible outcome of each turn in order to win. The variety is insane:

25 different mech types to choose from and a secret squad to bring in 3 new units. You can randomize the mech squad or customize one choosing ANY combination of units you want even the same types. So the combinations are endless and each combination brings a different strategic style of playing to your game further increasing the replayability.

Also, if you see a negative review of some idiots wining about how this game isn't the "FTL" they wanted or this game isn't "FTL" or making comparisons, let me explain:

This is NOT FTL. Just because a game developer was successful with one game doesn't mean they are obligated to create the same game for the rest of their studio's life. It is frustrating to see people marking it negatively simply because they didn't get the kind of game they wanted.

If you are looking for a strategic puzzle game with endless possibilities that is very quick to play, simple to learn but difficult to master then this is the game for you. If you are looking for something similar to FTL or an FTL clone, look elsewhere because this is not what you want.

One of the best strategy games I've played in a long time.

TLDR: The game is not bad necessarily but the lack of randomness, lack of variety of enemies, the small scale and the easiness makes it feel repetitive after a few hours.

Full Review: Is the game bad? No, but the game gets repetitive. The way the game is organized is similar to FTL except with islands instead of sectors. The gameplay is quite different then FTL though. Into the breach is more like a chess game except with only 3 pieces under your command. This makes the game more of a mind game but with only 3 pieces there are very few moves you can make. On top of that there is very little randomness so once you come up with a way to solve the problem you don't have to worry about it failing (FTL used the miss mechanic and real time engagements to counter this). It doesn't help that there is very little enemy unit variation. The game is also rather easy I only lost once which was my first time; I think this is because of the lack of randomness so you just have to do the math and end the turn. 
Edit: The game also lacks the mystery and exploration that made FTL so good and entertaining.

40792253.review:
[h1]Rating[/h1]
[b]7/10[/b]

[h1]Worth it?[/h1]
Yeah, I believe it is.

[h1]Playtime[/h1]
That depends on where do you want to get to in a game. If you just want to see the credits roll, it's not gonna be that long.
I finished my first (successful) playthrough in about 5 hours, but that's just the tip of the iceberg. 
There are so many unlockables that it would take a lot more than that to get 100% completion.

[h1]Comparison[/h1]
It feels like [b]FTL[/b] had a baby with a very simplified version of [b]XCOM[/b] and a procedurally generated game of chess. With mechs and giant bugs instead of pawns.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The human kind has been destroyed by an infestation of alien creatures known as Vek. As a last resort a group of mechs is sent back in the time to try and prevent the final destruction of the world. You gain control of three machines and their commanders in an attempt to try and defeat the aliens before it's too late.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
It's an isometric tile-based pixel-art goodness, simplistic in nature, but that works well here.
In most cases it's pretty clear what's going on and what's about to happen, but once or twice I haven't noticed a field that was a target of an enemy attack, because it was obstructed by something else.
Another thing worth mentioning is the lack of proper movement and attack animations. Units just teleport from tile to tile, and during attacks a projectile is shot from their position, but they just stand there unaffected. 

[h1]Audio[/h1]
The soundtrack by [b]Ben Prunty[/b] is really good. If you enjoyed music in [b]FTL[/b], you'll have a good time with this one too. You can check it out on [url=https://benprunty.bandcamp.com/album/into-the-breach-soundtrack]Ben's Bandcamp[/url].

[h1]Mechanics[/h1]
Nicely done, almost everything working smoothly and exactly how I expected. One exception - when you're spending reputation and buying things, some items are limited to a specific mech type and you might not remember which is which. To check you have to click out of the shop, then click into a specific mech to check it's type. But that's a tiny inconvenience.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
There are 4 islands that need defending, each split into 8 regions, so in theory that's 32 missions + the final fight in every playthrough. But that's not really the case. On each island one region is safe at the beginning and then acts as a mini-boss fight location. You get to that after completing 4 other selected regions. The remaining 3 are permanently lost, so you have to choose wisely, depending on which rewards you want more.
Once the mini-boss is defeated, an island is secure. When you secure 2 islands, you can attempt the final mission, or continue securing other islands. The difficulty is increased with each secured island, so the final fight is easier with just 2 islands completed and harder if you've secured all 4. It's completely up to you. That's between 10 and 20 missions (+ final fight) per playthrough.
The main part of the game is all about fighting aliens. Each fight takes place on an 8 by 8 tile grid, three of your mechs fight against a number of enemies. It's turn-based and all Vek attacks are telegraphed - you know where they will attack in their next turn. So what you have to do is prevent them from completing those attacks. You can push or pull them onto another tile, where they can drown, get burned, fall off the map, get in the line of fire of another Vek or simply miss their shot. You can also punch, shoot, bomb or slam into them, causing damage and destroying them. There's a lot of ways to win, with different mechs, weapons or tactics. You have to constantly adjust to the enemy types, the environment or a specific scenario. 
Each mission will offer some bonus objectives which, if met, will grant you additional rewards. For protecting a train, taking minimum damage, destroying a water dam, killing a number of enemies or preventing them from spawning you can get additional reputation (currency), reactor cores (mech upgrades) or additional grid power (that's what's keeping your mechs operational - you lose when it gets to zero).
You start the game with only one squad of mechs available. Playing with each squad sets 3 goals for you. Completing each goal (which are also achievements) gives you coins that can be used to unlock additional squads. You'll need to unlock 30 achievements to get access to all 8 squads.
There are 3 difficulty levels - Easy, Normal and Hard. While [i]easy[/i] in FTL wasn't that easy, here it is just that. But if you like a challenge, normal and hard will offer it to you. From what I can tell, there's just one achievement related to the difficulty level (beat the game on hard), others can be achieved on any difficulty. 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
The developers put themselves in a very awkward position. Every promotional material for this game shouted: [b]"From the makers of FTL"[/b].
On one hand, after that, there is no way to avoid the obvious comparison. Is it as good as [b]FTL[/b]? In my opinion - no.
On the other hand, without mentioning their previous success, I doubt people would notice [b]Into the Breach[/b] on its own.
A friend of mine said this game would be perfect on a mobile device and I couldn't agree more.
After spending 13 hours here, I think I'll take a break from playing constantly and just turn it on every once in a while for a quick battle or two.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
- great tactical battles
- a lot of content unlockable through gameplay
- good fun for a good price

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- unflattering comparison to FTL
- lazy movement and attack animations
- not available on mobile devices



[i]For more reviews, follow my Curator page[/i] - [b][url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/31210849-Sublime-Dent/]Sublime Dent[/url][/b].
