40784800.review:
https://niveloculto.com/analisis-into-the-breach/

El mundo de Into the Breach está sumido en un conflicto interminable. Lo que queda de la humanidad lucha por sobrevivir ante el incansable embate de los vek, una especie de insectos alienígenas y gigantes que, tras conquistar el subsuelo del planeta, planea hacer lo propio con su superficie.

A los mandos de un escuadrón de tres mechas enviados desde el futuro, somos lo único que se interpone entre la vida y la muerte, el último recurso de un planeta que ya no puede soñar con un mañana mejor, sino que se conforma con no perder lo que le queda del presente.

Sobre esta base, Subset Games construye el eterno retorno a una guerra que atraviesa infinitas líneas temporales, un recurso al servicio de un doble uso, pues sirve de base para la construcción de ese status quo de perennidad, al tiempo que justifica el funcionamiento cíclico de sus partidas. Esta es una guerra que se enfrenta al estilo Simeone, partida a partida, y cuyas victorias son peregrinas, puntos y seguido relativamente inútiles, pues el final de cada despliegue coincide, ni más ni menos, que con el inicio del siguiente.

Pese a que las fichas que uno maneja no dejan de ser enormes vehículos tripulados y armados hasta las trancas, sobrevivir en Into the Breach es una cuestión más de maña que de fuerza. La cantidad de variables que uno debe manejar en cada ronda es considerable: tipos de terreno, estados alterados, posiciones relativas, climas adversos y cataclísmicos, alcances de movimiento, la lista es extensa. En conjunto, todos estos elementos convierten la experiencia en algo que tiende más al puzle que a la pura estrategia, pues serán numerosas las ocasiones en que habremos de pensar no sólo en el turno corriente sino en los que le sigan.

La estructuración de Into the Breach en torno a la repetición no solo se limita al tiempo, sino que también organiza su espacio. El territorio se concibe aquí a partir de tres escalas diferentes: las cuatro islas que componen lo que queda de su mundo, las regiones en las que se divide cada isla y el tablero de 8×8 casillas que las transforma en escenario de combate. Conquistar cualquiera de estos pedazos no es sino la vía hacia el siguiente, un suma y sigue hasta el enfrentamiento final con los vek.

Dicha conclusión se desbloquea desde el momento en que se supera la primera isla, y pese a que la dificultad de Into the Breach se adapta automáticamente al nivel del escuadrón, para las primeras tentativas de enfrentarla lo recomendable es visitar todas las regiones posibles para hacer acopio de recursos, armas y experiencia, en el amplio sentido de la palabra.

Además, cada una de las islas cuenta con su propia personalidad e idiosincrasia, por lo que no es hasta que se superan todas que se puede tener una imagen completa de lo que Subset Games han fabricado a partir de un puñadito de detalles.

Siguiendo casi un modelo clásico, hay regiones verdes y boscosas, otras cubiertas de hielo y nieve, unas áridas y desérticas y algunas industriales y cubiertas de mares ácidos. Todas ellas se presentan como naciones controladas por corporaciones y sus CEOs, que en la suave distopía de Into the Breach han sustituido a los gobiernos populares en su intento por organizar la resistencia.

Destaca en esta línea, también, cómo varía el diseño de las edificaciones según se avanza por el título, desde los prismas de hormigón que tachonan los valles de Archive INC., hasta los edificios champiñón que se elevan sobre las estepas heladas de PInnacle Robotics, o cómo varían los retratos de sus personajes para ofrecer un abanico de arquetipos que va desde veteranas oficiales hasta inteligencias artificiales superdesarrolladas.

Para llevar a cabo tan magno cometido, deberemos repartir fuego y furia a nuestros enemigos a través de pequeñas escaramuzas por turnos, siempre bajo el mismo esquema funcional: un grupo de veks emerge en algunas de las casillas de los tableros de 8×8 en que se dividen los escenarios de combate, amenazando tanto a los edificios residenciales en los que se acinan los humanos supervivientes como el objetivo principal de turno. Como contramedida, desplegamos nuestro trío de guerreros en casillas de nuestra elección y que comience la fiesta del obús y el servopuñetazo en la boca.

A ello también contribuye un selector de dificultad tan honesto como inmisericorde. El modo fácil es ideal para hacerse con las dinámicas básicas del título y experimentar el efímero sabor de la victoria. En normal, uno empieza a comprender que no la cosa no trata tanto de cuánto terreno puedes quitarle a los vek como cuánto puedes evitar que te arrebaten. Jugar en difícil es, directamente, un acto de fe, y cada pírrico triunfo se siente como un hito de estrategia marcial.

Avanzar a líneas temporales más difíciles, además, devuelve consecuencias progresivamente más difíciles de asumir. La lista de pilotos caídos en combate va extendiéndose sin apenas poder evitarlo, algo terrible tanto narrativamente —al fin y al cabo, estás perdiendo un compañero— como mecánicamente, pues el sustituto, si lo hubiera, será un pipiolo al lado de la veteranía del caído.

En conjunto, cuánto más complejo se hace todo más distancia se crea entre jugador y conflicto, hasta llegar a entender la crudeza de una guerra que hay que ganar a toda costa y en la que nada ni nadie es prescindible. Queda el consuelo, eso sí, de que tras cada derrota lo único que espera es una nueva reiteración, una oportunidad más de meterse en la cabina de los mechas y caer desde los cielos sobre unos vek que no conocen, ni conocerán jamás, un ápice de tregua.

40779123.review:
Subset Games, the developers of gangbusters roguelike [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/trar/recommended/212680]FTL: Faster Than Light[/url], decided to try their hand at making a tactical mech game. You've got to hand it to them for using their FTL money to do what they wanted to do as game developers instead of raking in even more dollars with FTL 2: Electric Boogaloo. What money they did have was used well, because Into the Breach is a good time.


Gameplay can be described as a pseudo-puzzle mixture of chess and Ironman XCOM, except you can have a mech pilot [i]travel back in time[/i] and try again in an alternate timeline if a game goes pear-shaped. You'll doom Earth in that timeline to giant voracious insects, yeah, but you might be able to save it in the next one. The chess parallels become more evident on closer inspection: battle maps are 8x8 just as chess boards are, your mechs and the Vek are initially positioned similarly to how white and black chess pieces are, and just like white, the Vek always move first.

On the other hand, chess doesn't let you do stuff like customize piece placement, upgrade and level up pieces, or [i]travel in time[/i]. There's no diagonal movement, but since mechs and Vek have health you can bodyblock attacks if needed, as well as shift most Vek around with your attacks - that aspect's more like billiards than chess. The savant-like memorization typical of high level chess isn't needed here, since there's no one board/piece arrangement to memorize potential movesets for, and the Vek's next moves are always telegraphed in advance.

There's also a strategic element in that you can choose different missions with different rewards based on what you need more, and mission/island choice ought to consider how well your particular mech squad would handle them. Mistakes...or cold-hearted triage...on the battlefield can influence what rewards you go for, and mech upgrades can open a lot more possibilities. Different pilots for your mechs can even be unlocked, with differing abilities.

Achievements grant in-game coins, which are used to unlock new mech squads with differing playstyles - that's a pretty interesting incentive for achievement hunting that I don't see many games doing like Into the Breach does. Perhaps most importantly, the game avoids almost all the unfair random chance that marred FTL, and has a much more fairly designed final battle.

If I had to make a criticism, I kind of wish battlefields were bigger, and possibly with more mechs to use. At the same time though I recognize how the interconnectedness of the other mechanics somewhat depend on the limited size. The game would also lose some of its cool chess-like qualities if it had bigger maps.


The overall result is an elegant and very satisfying example of turn-based tactics, especially when you're able to come up with a clever plan for a turn to get out of a tight spot. The tension that develops when more Vek spawn and complicate your plans, on the other hand, is an effective counterweight. The game is playable in bursts or in long stretches, so you needn't dedicate hours at a time if you don't want to - and good thing too, because resolving tricky battlefield situations can get taxing after a while.

It's all the more impressive when you consider it was mainly developed by two guys; Chris Avellone as writer meanwhile is a different kind of impressive and adds just the touch the game's setting needs. It helps style-wise that the graphics are as polished as they are. Ben Prunty also returns to deliver another great [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/trar/recommended/807320]soundtrack[/url] that enhances the experience.

I definitely recommend this if you're into turn-based games or chess, and if you liked FTL or like things with giant mechs in them, you ought to at least try it.


Also the initial time-traveling pilot available to new players resembles LazyTown actor Stefán Karl Stefánsson. I thought that was neat, so I changed my first pilot's name accordingly.

Into the breach is a very nice puzzle game, with a small touch of RPG progression for the mechs.
The game is very enjoyable, albeit a little repetitive. The various mechs add variety, but the enemys are always the same, and after a few runs you end up always bumping in the new upgrades. This is way different from FTL where there were so many upgrades to choose from. 

The game design is excellent, and usually you can get at a glance what is happening on the board. In case you misinterpret something, there's a "reset turn" feature but it's very poorly designed in my opinion. It cannot be used once the "end turn" button has been punched, and it happened to me quite often that I realized I did a very, very stupid mistake right after the end of my turn. In this case, you can jump on Alt+F4, and if you're lucky you'll return to where you were. Moreover, there's a confirmation feature in case you end your turn with remaining actions, but not if you're going to stupidly fail an objective or lose a mech. In my opinion, the "reset turn" feature should remain active while the current turn is being resolved. Apart from this little thing which made me rage-quit ongoing quite a few times, I really enjoy this game so far!

There are also a few design problems with some teams for example there's a type of enemy which has plenty of hit-points a powerful attack and will go underground if you hit it, but the fire behemoth have no way at all to hit it (the only way is to combine the artilery attack to set it on fire and then the flamethrower attach to actually damage it). With some other teams (eg the default team), all three attacks will damage this enemy. I'm sure those small balance issues will be fixed in the future.

The music is great but a little bit repetitive as well, and I ended up turning it off.

Overall, a great game that I definitely recommend! I hope that future updates will add additional content, but at the current price tag the game is definitely worth a buy!

Final Fantasy Tactics meets Pacific Rim mit Zeitreisen? So oder so ähnlich kann man das neue Spiel der FTL-Macher beschreiben. Dabei haben die hochhäuser-großen Insekten namens Vek die Menschheit bereits vernichtet. Doch die Menschheit hat eine Geheimwaffe. Mithilfe von Zeitreisen schickt Sie immer wieder riesige Kampfmaschinen (Mechs) los um die Zeitlinie zu korrigieren und falls die totale Vernichtung droht, begibt sie sich zurück "Into the Breach". 

Das Spiel vergibt keine Fehler. Speichern ist nicht. Eine Entscheidung wie ein unbedachter Angriff, kann nicht ohne weiteres zurückgenommen werden. Dies machte auch den Reiz bei FTL aus und wird auch bei "Into the Breach" fortgeführt. Zwar kann man Bewegungsaktionen rückgängig machen, sobald allerdings eine Aktion ausgeführt wird, war es das. Einzig ein temporärer Zeitsprung kann eine völlig misslungene Runde rückgängig machen. Diesen sollte man aber mit Bedacht einsetzen, denn in jeder Mission ist dies nur einmal möglich.

Während das Spiel ähnlich wie FTL innerhalb von etwa 1,5 h +/- komplett zu schaffen ist, kann man immer wieder spielen um weitere Einheiten und Piloten freizuschalten. Durch Erfolge und Errungenschaften verdient man sich Münzen um andere Teams gegen die Vek ins Feld zu schicken. Die Teams sind immer zu dritt und jedes Team hat eine eigene Strategie, an die man sich zum Teil erst gewöhnen muss. Von schildbewehrten Mechas, hinzu wettermanipulierenden Flugzeugen, Eispanzern, Wissenschaftsfahrzeugen, Steinewerfern, Hakenkanonen, Feuerkämpfern, Nahkampfeinheiten und Blitzpeitschen gibt es hier eine ganze Bannbreite von kreativen Ideen und Spielweisen.

Ein Manko gegenüber FTL, sind die fehlenden Entscheidungsmöglichkeiten und auch die zum Teil geheimen Missionen und die Möglichkeit innerhalb des Spiels Dinge zu entdecken. Hat man das Spiel einmal geschafft, spielt man immer wieder die gleichen Missionen auf vier verschiedenen Inseln. Diese sind zwar immer leicht abgewandelt und die Karten ändern sich natürlich auch leicht, aber im Grunde ist es dasselbe. Das Einzige was sich ändert sind die Mechs und die damit verbundene Spielweise. Damit fehlt dem Spiel ein wichtiger zufallsbasierter Aspekt. Nichts des do trotz ist Subset mit "Into the Breach" wieder eine gutes Spiel gelungen, dass Taktikfans und Casual Player begeistern wird.

40752297.review:
Short version:
It's a fast-paced, minimalistic, yet surprisingly deep turn-based tactics with focus on positioning and board control and featuring giant walking deathmachines, nasty bugs and timetravel.

Long version:
First off, don't compare with with FTL: Faster than light. These may be 2 games by the same developer, but that's where similarities end.

Into the Breach is a turn-based tactics system that's fairly unique in that it is designed for short play sessions.
You'll be fighting over 2 to 4 islands before going into a final battle, where on each island you'll be fighting for 5 out of 8 territories. And battles last only 4 or 5 turns. If a full campaign takes more than 2 hours, it's because you're really taking your time.

The base mechanics are relatively simple: Aliens invade and take a turn moving and setting up their attacks, then you move your mechs to kill those aliens, or to reposition them so they don't hit important targets. Where important targets include civilian buildings and special buildings that cost grid points when lost (and running out of grid means losing the campaign), special units such as trains that need protecting, and lastly your own mechs.
Then aliens deal their damage and bring in reinforcements, and the next turn starts.
This all happens on a small 8x8 board, where you'll have 3 units active at the same time.

To add variety to those basics:
- You'll be unlocking a total of 8 different Mech squads, each with their own unique playstyle. You can also build a custom squad using any mechs from any squad, or go with a random squad.
- You'll be finding and unlocking other time travellers to pilot your mechs. You start each campaign with one of those, and 2 generic troopers. All pilots will gain experience levels and get randomized bonuses when they do, in addition the Time travellers all have a unique ability of their own. Picking the right pilot for your squad can make all the difference too.
- While missions all have the same basic objective of simply surviving long enough, and a number of different objectives on top of that that give rewards: extra grid points, reputation points that you can spend on gear after completing an island, or extra power cores to upgrade your mechs.
- Each island also has a specific flavor, with different types of hazards being added to the maps.

The depth in the gameplay comes from understanding how your squad of choice works, which enemy does what, how you can turn enemies on each other and (often enough) what to sacrifice where in order to still meet your objectives. Or maybe you'll need to sacrifice an objective to ensure your grid stays up.


All this is wrapped up in a basic time travel plot, where as the last survivor of the alien invasion you can go back a few weeks and see if you can turn the decisive battles around in favor of humanity (and their allied AIs).

The game is not without it's flaws though. 
- Outside of combat, there really isn't much to do apart from making sure you go on missions you actually have a good chance of completing, and how you upgrade your mechs. (more power, extra weapons)
- And while there are enough different maps to fight over, there aren't too many different objectives to be seen per island. So the game does get repetitive from that angle.
- Unlocks are also dependent on spending coins, which are earned by getting achievements. While the achievements aren't bad in themselves as they are designed to teach to the tricks of a squad, or of the game in general, this does seem a bit flavorless. It would also support the backstory more that some of the squads would be unlocked by completing specific islands etc.

In closing:
Into the Breach is certainly a very good game, ideal for playing in short bursts, and with a strong core gameplay loop. For that, it's well worth the asking price. 
Just don't expect much outside of that core gameplay, because that's where it falls short.

40742540.review:
From the makers of FTL, Do you like mechs?  Do you like Advance Wars?  Do you like short sessions of interesting, semi-random but well designed and replayable turn based strategy with a meta game and advancement that doesn't make you want to claw your eyeballs out?

This game is for you.

I was surprised by Into the Breach.  It's balanced to an incredible degree with a lot of RNG removed and replaced with intelligent design that plays into being strategic.  But, if you screw up, the sessions are at max an hour to an hour and a half, so no big deal, start another one.  It is a game that perfectly incapsulates a one more turn style of play.  There are eight teams of very different mechs unlocked as you complete game achievements, but you purchase them with coins you get from achievements, so you can choose who you want to play around with as you go.  More to the point, the combat, while a bit minimalist in some places is smart, has a huge number of variables that can go into gameplay, and offers nice twists on objectives beyond kill all enemies. Also, the meta is really well built, as you gain coins to buy mechs across both single sessions and multiple playthroughs and you can carry over your best pilot from your previous one to give your next run a much needed boost.

I love this game.  My biggest gripes are the story is a bit meh, it's fine for what it is but more would have been cool.  Also, you can get a secret squad of mechs which costs as much as all the others combined...and it's really lame.  Stick with the base eight. 

This game rocks and I'd recommend it to anyone with a love of mechs and turn based strategy RPGs.

40740004.review:
Into the Breach is an odd pickle. It rings faintly of chess and Advance Wars, but with an asymmetric slant in what I can only describe as a "reactive TBS". The playing field is small, each encounter only lasts 5 turns, and each turn consists of the enemy units committing to lines of attack which you then attempt to disrupt.

Half the time it seems like there's some sort of hyper-complicated logic running just under the surface that dictates enemy behavior will allow you to just barely scrape through each turn with some clever planning. The other half of the time it feels like the random chance events in FTL where before you've even begun planning your first turn everything's already gone to hell and even your best shot at damage mitigation will still be unavoidably disastrous.

I can see how it would be a turnoff to strategy buffs who are more used to broader management, unit engagement hierarchies and longer-term conflicts, particularly as there's not a great sense of escalation as you progress. I've never really cared for any of that in strategy games though, so for me swapping that out for squads that play differently and moves that push enemies around and into environmental hazards is quite fun.

It's been a long time since I've seen a game accomplish what it set out to do so well. The fundamentals of Into The Breach border on perfection, but unfortunately the game is too afraid of muddying the clarity of its mechanics to stray much further beyond fundamentals. What is in the game is almost perfect, but I cant help but think of what they sacrificed for such simplicity. It makes the game very accessible to a large audience, but those who love what they see will claw past the immaculate surface and be disappointed to find that there's just not much else beneath. Into The Breach has only one major flaw, and that is there isnt more of it.

The main factor that enhances replayability is your squad of mechs, of which there are nine, for a total of twenty-seven mechs. This means you will have nine playthroughs of the game that feel relatively fresh. That's a decent amount of content, around eighteen hours worth. And it doesnt count the amount of time you spend unlocking the new squads either. You'll be playing through the same four islands, with the same mission types, with the same final mission. But the abilities of your mechs will ensure that you tackle all these missions in completely different ways. 

Now granted you can get a fresh experience even after you unlock all the mechs by making custom squads, playing random squads, trying new pilots, or doing challenge runs. But you have essentially completed the games content at this point. This isn't necessarily bad as lots of good games have much less content than this, but FTL this is not. You might be able to sink a hundred hours into this game if you really try, but you'll be hard pressed to get more than that. In the end there are only four islands, the maps are selected from a limited pool and not randomly generated, and that final mission will always be virtually the same.

TLDR: Game is fantastic but there isnt enough of it. I really REALLY want more. Give me more please. GIVE ME MORE.

[b] tl:dr Great game, great soundtrack, good replayability. Subset Games going 2 for 2. [/b]


[h1] Disclaimer : This is not FTL, but it's just as good [/h1]

[b] Gameplay [/b]
Into the Breach is almost akin to chess, as in a perfect information, team and turn based strategy game. 
You will drop your mech team on the map, and use their abilities to defend the energy grid against the alien Vex menace.

The game is extremely placement heavy. In order to be efficient, you will have to push and pull the enemies to save your power grid, and eventually kill them in order to not be overrun. 
Maps last about 5 turns, with each one providing you with a set of bonus objectives to gain [i] Reputation stars (currency) [/i] and/or heal your power grid for future encounters. 
You then go on to clear island by island, upgrading your mechs after each one until you either clear the world from the Vex, or fail to defend the power grid. After that, you are given the opportunity to save one of your pilots and start again.

Interesting mechanics:
[olist]
  [*]Friendly fire is a very real threat, which can put you in some serious pickles, but also help you immensly.
  [*]You can customize your mech team before each playthrough, making every game potentially really unique
  [*]Special tiles and environmental hazards make you think ahead, so as to not shoot yourself in the foot.

[h1]Premise[/h1]
You are a Time Traveling Mechcommander.  A soldier that has watched countless lives lost and many versions of Earth fall to the insidious, Insectoid Vek.  Your objective is to gather resources, allies, upgrade your mechs and blast those abominations to tiny bits!  Save the Corporate Islands and Save the Earth!  If you fail, you will travel back in time once more, with new knowledge and different mech squads to draw from.

[h1]Here thar be poor design choices[/h1]
I just want to start out by saying this, For all this game’s promise it should be an early access title.  There are so many little things that add up to a dull repetitive gameplay, boring combat, frustrating limitations and an uninspiring world.  I always want to play the game in it’s base form before mods, but trying to complete this game even ONCE is a slog.  Yeah, somehow these devs made time traveling, futuristic mech warriors into boring, bland, grunts. Oh it hurts so much to say that.

[h1]The good.[/h1]
For once I’m skipping this.  Mostly because all the good are outweighed by the bad in almost every way.  You don’t feel like an amazing prodigy or a heroic soldier, you feel weak, under-armed, frustrated school janitor.  Especially in later levels as you wander around hoping the demonic little Vek children will stop bugging you long enough to finish cleaning up.  If anything I want to control the Vek more than the actual Mechs!  I’ve lost count of the times that I’m 1 space away from doing anything important, and the limits on the Mech weapons just exasperate this glaring flaw.
 
[h1]The Story[/h1]
What I said at the top?  That’s the whole story.  Nothing you do will add to it and you get no background on what’s going on.

[h1]Lack of a glossary[/h1]
This is a slap in the face for completionists.  Instead of getting pictures, clips, an excerpt, a blurb, flavor text, short story, ANYTHING to flesh out this world you’ll just have to bookmark the wiki.  A shame since this was an easy way to add some achievements you could actually look forward to completing.  Want one perfect example?  The artillery upgrade “Buildings immune” that prevents damage to buildings.  How does it work?  Advanced AI?  Smartchip tech?  Fin-stabilized missiles?  Freaking radio signals or electromagnetic shields?  Nope for all you know it’s “Magic”.
 
[h1]The UI[/h1]
There are quite a few quality of life problems. 
[list]
[*]You can’t see enemy range of movement-  This is a must for any tactical turn based game and it’s lack of inclusion stinks of laziness.  You get 8+ places to place your 3 mech squad, but not a simple green overlay to show if they can be targeted?  What’s the lack of information?
[*]Lack of player confirmation for post battle choices-So on my 5th playthrough I finally get a perfect island completion bonus (literally didn’t know that was a thing till that moment)!  And I get the option to choose 1 of 3 amazing rewards, I accidently click on 1 because I’m confused by the blurb on the bottom and instead of a confirmation message (“are you sure?”) it locks in my choice.  I learned later that I picked the worst one AND that the other 2 were super rare. Joy.
[*] This game suffers from the exact same issue as FTL- It has crashed my PC enough times to convince me to never take it starting up properly for granted...
[*]No warning what enemies will spawn-  This problem is everywhere, from your mission briefing, to your actual mission.  This feature is a must for any defense game, tower defense or strategy game.  That it isn’t here just means you roll the dice on if a support unit or a terrifying Alpha will wreck your playthrough.
[/list]

[h1]Scoring system[/h1]
Oh boy, this is 100% arbitrary. It’s based off of defending your buildings and killing enemies that’s it.  And there are no bonuses, cut scenes or unlocks for higher score, D:(
 
[h1]The achievements[/h1]
The achievements are the game’s unlock currency.  In a good turn based game, you should be able to get multiple achievements in 1 run and unlock.  So in theory, they should allow for multiple playstyles and different fun video clips that inspire multiple playthroughs right?  Maybe a few easier achievements that help you understand the finer points of the game?  Nope, baring 5, they are all bland, time consuming and difficult.  In fact, there are only 5 achievements at over 50% of players unlocked and exactly HALF are at under 10% of all players unlocked  Many of these are literally impossible to unlock without denying yourself resources or refusing to use powerful, RECOMMENDED tactics. Or worse, they are locked behind acquiring certain squads  Below are some examples...

[list]
[*]Perfect Battle(Current unlock level amongst players 37%)- Take no Mech or Building Damage with the Rusting Hulks Squad (Repaired Damage is still damage)-  This should NOT be restricted to 1 squad, there are many versions of this that limit your chances for fun with custom squads.
[*]Untouchable-(Current unlock level amongst players 9%)Finish a Corporate Island without Taking Mech Damage. (Repaired damage is still damage)-So we aren’t allowed to block Veks from spawning, position mechs to block incoming power grid damage OR even get our mechs pushed back.  Better pray to your RNG god of choice that the buildings can withstand multiple hits.  Worse yet, to prevent catastrophic failure, you must deny yourself Vek kills early on by focusing on pushing Vek instead of straight up damaging them.
[*]Trusted Equipment(Current unlock level amongst players 4.2%)-Finish 3 corporate Islands without equipping any new Pilots or weapons-3 islands is over half your run..  Also, have fun with ignoring any chances for new gear.
[*]Engineering Dropout(Current unlock level amongst players 4.1%)-Finish 3 corporate islands without powering a weapon modification.-  I have nothing more to say here, the devs have a formula their following with 0% of the logic that marks intelligent testing.
[/list]

 [h1]“optional objectives” (Optional only if you don’t want tangible rewards)[/h1]
I’ve played for 4 hours and only seen 4 types and none of them added anything other than tedium.
[list]
[*]Protect building/object- This is just Babysitting a rock or a mindless drone.  Hooray.  Your choices or successes here add no urgency or story elements.  What I would have done?  Use it to expand on player choice.  Sooooo, imagine you save a hospital but one of your pilots is critically wounded protecting the building from the last acidic shot of an Alpha Centipede!  A brave team of doctors saves their life at the cost of a little bit of that pilot’s Exp (That amnesia/head trauma man).  I WISH this was the case, instead you just get “reputation”  Which is a truly wasted opportunity.
[*] Stop enemies from emerging-  So we are limiting where we an position our units?  What’s worse, you often won’t be able to use a weapon if you choose to do this.  Worse yet?  You don’t even get exp for this, so a core part of the game is to deny your pilots exp early on...
[*]Change the Terrain/unfreeze buildings- Way to limit your player’s actions even more.  What’s next?  Leave one unit at the start to “Escort civilians” (Don’t even think about it devs!)
[*] Retrieve time pods!-  gaining extra pilots, weapons, reactors and loot!  The issue here?  The programming team messed up and made Vek able to move TURN Zero and kill them.  They claim this has been patched, but you have to wonder why this was there in the first place...
 [/list]

[h1]The fail state[/h1]
This has caused the most controversy of all the game’s mechanics.  You lose instantly when your power grid drops to zero.  You take damage to your grid whenever a Vek make a successful attack against any Grid Building.  Unfortunately they start with an have a 80% success rate and upgrading your “Grid Resistance” is expensive, time consuming, and unrewarding.

See my Comments below for the rest of the review.

40705195.review:
[h1]Into the Breach ——做一个纯粹的破局者[/h1]

于[url=https://cowlevel.net/game/Into_the_Breach/review/3060986]奶牛关[/url]也发了一份排版更好点的图文版，随意。

许多人把Into the Breach比喻为象棋，但我想可以用下面这段话来形容它更为合适：

玩家与对手（AI）坐在一个8x8的棋盘面前开始对弈，规则都和象棋一样，但玩家只有3个棋子，对手手上的兵棋却多到用不完，每回合随便动几枚棋子就是一场对玩家发起的“将军”（check）。当然，“将军”（check）不是“将死”（checkmate），在如此悬殊的敌我实力差距下，玩家的目的并不是要消灭敌人，而是在敌人接连不断的“将军”中寻找“解将”的机会。理论上，对手无限复活的兵棋可以“将军”玩家到永远，但在这个游戏里，作为玩家的你，只用坚持五回合就能获得胜利，五回合就好。

直白点说，[b]Into the Breach（后称ItB）想给玩家带来的体验，就是“解残局”[/b]。残局破解和普通象棋对弈尽管使用的是同样的棋盘，同样的规则，但玩法和乐趣却是完全不同的。下普通的象棋时，你的对手和你处在同样的阵容，类似的水平，下棋时不仅要考虑自己擅长的策略，更重要的是考量对手的思路布局战术，这是一种博弈的快感。但破解残局不同，敌人的思路已经定死了，就是“要将军玩家”，你的任何一个步骤都只需要简单的推理，就能猜出敌人下一回合的行动，而作为破局者，应该花费大量的精力去发现敌人作战网里的漏洞，依靠隐藏很深的一套“连招”去反推敌人，这种以少胜多的破解快感就是解残局的魅力。

==========

AI永远是在策略游戏中最难模拟的，尤其是象棋。ItB是一个单机游戏，玩家的敌人是AI，这也就意味着，它在体验上就不会用象棋去代替，而是寻找其它出路。以解残局为核心的制作思路就是游戏得出的“最优解”。因为解残局根本不需要去推理敌人会干什么——严格来说，并不是不需要推理，而是太容易猜测以至于这根本不是破局的关键——因此在itb里，AI是特别好做的，它只用派兵去攻击玩家的“将”就行了。甚至在ItB里，AI的表现形式直接剥去了这层简单推理的外壳，每一个敌兵在下一回合的行为都直接显示在本轮的玩家视角里。因此，棋盘上，敌人的行为一清二楚——它要你死。玩家在无需上述简单推理的状态下，就能够将余裕去思考更重要的、更纯粹的，也是游戏最希望带给玩家的“解围”快感上。

把AI问题巧妙地规避掉，其实整个游戏的制作企划和方向就没问题了。接下来要做的事情，就是将整个战斗系统做好、做丰富，来优化玩家的破解体验就好。和制作组前作FTL一样，Into the breach同样是一个roguelike游戏，而残局的设置往往可不是随机生成的，但rl的随机要素往往也容易摧毁策略深度本身。因此ItB需要做够大量的战斗元素，来让每局随机生成的棋盘都有足够的要素去支撑才行。

首先，是玩家需要守护的“将”、“王”，也可以理解为“生命值”，在游戏里叫作Power Grid，可以回复，但最多也只能存7格，看似很多，一个失误也是弹指一挥间。在棋盘里，会导致Power Grid流失的单位是建筑，它被安置在这个8x8棋盘里的各个角落，敌人随手一打就是打到建筑，影响生命值。这个设定意味着，玩家要守护的东西并不是一个单位，而是整个地图里零碎放置的东西。游戏不希望玩家简单地把要守护的东西围起来，而是要主动分散自己的作战单位，活用装备和道具，控制住整张8x8的棋盘才行。也就是说，你需要尽可能利用地图里给出的一切元素才能获得胜利。

其次，是兵棋的强制位移技能。比耗费大量资源去杀掉敌人，不如用一个简单的技能把敌人推到不会攻击到建筑的地方，来得更为节省。游戏中给出了大量的影响位移技能，甚至可以直接把敌人推进海里，岩浆里达到直接秒杀的效果。本质上，游戏本身就更加鼓励使用位移，而非清空一个兵的生命值来达到解围的效果。位移，可以说是整个游戏在“解围”策略中最核心的手段，玩家需要思考如何把敌人的阵型推成自己想要的结果，再使用AOE，或者敌人误伤的方法来获得以少胜多的结果。这种combo的获取方法会随着难度和进度推进而逐步提高，也是游戏最希望玩家在游戏里“思考、推理、演绎，最后得出combo解”这一连串过程所得到的破局快感。

位移看似机制很容易，但在游戏这个面积有限的地图里并不好想。正如之前所说，玩家并不需要和AI去博弈，可策略游戏怎么能没有博弈内容呢？因此，位移技能的加入也意味着，玩家需要和自己手头上的资源进行博弈。我把一个原本要攻击核心实验室的敌人推到了一边，但这时，那个敌人打到的是我手上的主力战斗兵了，这个“换血”划算吗？又或者说，这个“推动”动作本身又是否是一种浪费行动点的行为呢？ItB厉害之处在于，在这个超小的棋盘里，任何东西都是一种资源。

资源，就意味着是用来消耗的。

玩家手上的三个战斗单位的血量是资源，给单位加血不是用来保命的，而是用来给建筑“挡枪”的；
每张地图的支线目标是资源，尽管完成目标的奖励很丰厚，但Power grid没了，一切就都完了。
Power grid也是资源，有的时候击杀核心怪物更为重要，暂时放弃掉一两格grid，总比怪越堆越多，导致直接崩盘来得好。
甚至，敌人本身也是资源，使用巧妙的位移技能把怪物留着，用它们的行动去打自己人，效果要比派兵打更为节省自己真正的资源。

游戏中的方寸土地都是资源，也因此，每次随机生成的内容才会更容易给玩家带来一个又一个精彩的电车难题，不断地去思考资源的交换与损失是否合理，是否能带来获胜。这种思考快感，贯彻在游戏体验的始终。


最后，就是增加玩家作战单位的有趣性了。将每种资源分门划类，每一类做成一个以此资源为核心的作战兵种。使玩家在使用不同小队下都可以使用不同的核心战术。以火焰而核心的火焰巨兽（flame benemoth）小队没有直接伤害技能，但烧伤debuff出众，开局总是杀不掉怪物，靠位移技能撑几个回合，地图便到处都是着火地格，敌人会自己慢慢烧死，爽的一批。钢铁柔道家（steel judoka）小队则人如其名，主要使用出色的位移技，依赖敌人误伤来进行战斗。每个小队都有自己的特点与核心作战思路，乐趣各有千秋，可能有那么一点平衡性缺失，但单机游戏的重点还是在增加乐趣上嘛。而且从我每个小队都能四岛hard通关来看，每个小队都是能够一战的。（容我装一波逼）

==========

逼装完了，下面说说游戏的不足。

第一，是游戏的引导做得很奇怪。

理论上，这样一个“硬核”策略游戏，应该将打通普通难度的玩家引导到挑战高难度。但是，游戏将成就系统做成了一个解锁小队的作用，这意味着，玩到游戏提供的所有内容必须先刷成就。成就大多是使用各个小队满足一些苛刻的条件，刷的方法当然是疯狂玩easy难度啦。但等刷完后，玩家基本上也已经把所有小队，所有内容都在easy难度下体验了个遍了。当此时才开始挑战Hard难度，大多数玩家已经腻了。


第二，也是我认为比较伤到游戏核心问题的，是游戏中敌人的AI。

之前我所说，在itb中，敌人的AI并不重要——这句话是错的。正因为在游戏中，敌人的任何操作策略能够在玩家眼里一板一眼的显示，玩家才更容易发现敌人AI中暴露出来的问题。确切来说，itb本身的战斗系统是相当复杂的，AI要做的，的确仅仅是进攻我方的单位而已，但如何进攻，仍旧需要AI来思考。在这个敌我实力悬殊、且随机生成的棋局中，AI真的要计算的话，绝对会难以控制般的，在几步内彻底弄死玩家。

实际上，电脑的确计算了。

制作组很聪明，他们知道AI不顾一切的攻击，玩家是赢不了的。因此他们给AI设置了一个“让敌”功能，当场上敌人太多，按照正常的进攻策略，会计算出玩家下一回合必然失败，因此会故意给玩家制造缺口，“特意”的派几个敌人去攻击玩家的作战单位。这对玩家而言是最开心的结果，因为你的单位本身就是要进行移动攻击其他更需关注的敌方单位，也就意味着，这几只“特遣”敌方单位在本回合内不造成任何威胁。

什么意思呢？说白了就是敌人会让子。尽管玩家失误过多依然会导致游戏失败，但实际上，任何一局都是有完美最优解的（有时可能会损失一些grid但无关痛痒）。而这种完美优解的解决方式却不是依靠游戏那个纯粹、复杂的战斗系统带来的，而是靠AI妥协而来。

这种感觉，就像是你看到了一个路边摆的残局摊，围观群众都解不出来，然而你瞎试却试出来了。一开始，你沾沾自喜，后来一想不对劲啊，原来是摆摊的主人弱智，无意或有意地做错了一步棋，让你赢了，这种获胜，没有使你感到快乐，却使你觉得……自己是个托。

当然，我并不是觉得这种使AI妥协的方法有多么极大地影响游戏体验。因为从整个游戏系统的完成度来看，FTL工作室打造这款策略游戏所花的五年时间绝非在摸鱼，而是真的在打磨整个系统。结果到最后，系统已经做得非常精致，但依然发现，游戏存在着上述的这样一个“敌人强度无法控制”的缺口无法弥补。因此，就和游戏核心玩法“控制资源，寻找优解”一样，制作组最后选择了弱化AI来进行妥协。游戏制作的思路我是能够理解的，但最后在游戏里呈现的这幅形式，还是不得不让我感叹，完美又纯粹的策略游戏果然还是不存在的呀。

[h1]总结[/h1]

在游戏未发售前，我自己的游戏小圈子里都对这个游戏充满期待，认为它将是一个完美的游戏，因为ItB的构想蓝图相当伟大。

策略游戏在早期一直通过刻意加大上手难度，堆信息量来营造“硬核”的气息。从XCOM早期版本和现代版本两者来看，那个过去的时代已经过去了。如今的策略游戏，都在往简化的路子上走。但是简化并不意味着难度的下降——反倒是上升了。现代的欧美SLG中，每一回合，电脑都想让玩家当场去世，每一次操作，玩家都在进行着brainstorm，我享受这种感觉。

对于游戏制作而言，这种简化而保持策略深度的设计更容易暴露系统的问题，因此将更会是一种极难的挑战。而ItB值得钦佩的地方，就是想做这件事。它将策略游戏彻底的极简主义化，只需为玩家带来无尽的战斗和无尽的思考。

尽管从目前来看，ItB还不够完美，但它已经足够纯粹，而我喜欢这种纯粹感。

TL;DR A few simple rules, zero randomness in combat and perfect information allow fun, satisfying complexity to emerge. Has a run-based structure like FTL and that's about it for similarities. 

Well, reading the other reviews, I've realized that I'm an intellectual dwarf compared to the tactical megaminds that apparently populate Steam, because it took me 13 or so hours before I could beat a run on Easy and about 5 more before I got the chicken dinner on Normal. So if you're coming off playing FTL on Hard with one hand and They Are Billions on 400% with the other, this may not be the game for you. 

One thing I do agree with the megaminds on is that this definitely is not a conventional strategy game. Every enemy attack is perfectly telegraphed, and *every* attack either hits or it doesn't. That's why people are describing this as feeling like a puzzle game: often, there is a clearly optimal solution to the board as laid out and you just need to find it. For some people, that's a dealbreaker, and I get it. I like XCOM, I like D&D: the chance of coming through clutch when you're probably fucked balanced by the chance of getting screwed on something you should have in the bag can add spice to the game. But I also like chess puzzles and Invisible Inc., and Into The Breach scratches the same itch that those things do. 

I would say the best moments in this game fall into two categories. One, you think you're fucked and have to take a huge hit to the face. And then suddenly you see it: a beautiful combination of tractor beams and acid-bath drownings and shielding the citizenry with your giant robot bodies, and the only way to leave your pretty good run intact. Two, you suddenly notice a new thing one of your mechs can do. Not that the game ever hides anything on you, but it doesn't hold your hand about stuff like how your giant rock launcher mech's rocks don't break unless they hit an enemy, which means they're perfectly good conductors of a lightning whip strike from another mech in the same squad. 

That said, it's certainly not perfect. The story is functional, and lines up with the gameplay in some neat ways, but it's nothing super special or deep. Procedural generation means that maps eventually start to blur together a bit, although it takes longer than it should because of decent variety in environments and missions within those environments. And although I like the final boss structure here much more than FTL's 'There's a secret checklist we're not telling you about and if you didn't complete it you're fucked' style, I think 'It's two consecutive somewhat tougher but otherwise normal battles' swings a bit far the other way. 

None of that was a dealbreaker for me, though. I've gotten my money's worth on this game already, and I'll keep coming back to it for a while to see if I can beat it on Hard, or with different squads, or with squads of my own devising.

I rarely buy games at full price because everything seems to have issues in one way or another. Too short of a game. Anti-consumer monetization. Performance issues. Poor design choices, you name it.

I also don't play strategy games, never been into them, yet somehow I gave this game a chance because it looked very interesting. I can gladly say I don't regret it at all.

The gameplay is very rewarding and the combat is in-depth. Every turn you have to figure out how you can save the targeted buildings while simultaneously keeping your squad alive and fighting back the Vek. The game always keeps you on your toes, demanding your attention. The stakes are high.

Into The Breach has very good progression. There are 8 squads, all of which have 3 mechs with unique abilities. Each squad has three achievements tied to them and additionally there are global achievements. When you complete these achievements, you get medals that you can use to unlock new squads. Each squad plays differently and it really adds to the longevity of the game.

During battles there's a chance that a time pod falls nearby. Sometimes they have a new pilot inside, and these pilots offer bonuses for your mechs. When you first encounter a new pilot, you unlock them in your hangar and you can pick one pilot from all your unlocked pilots at the start of each new playthrough.

I have to say, the soundtrack is amazing and Subset Games are right up there with Supergiant Games for me. Excellent Indie devs, that is.

If you're into strategy games, I can't possibly imagine why you wouldn't enjoy this game. If you aren't into strategy games, I still recommend you give this game a chance. An hour is enough to find out if this game is your type, though if you're like me you'll end up binging three hours and looking forward to the next session.

40700304.review:
America started the giant monster movie genre and Japan took the concept of “Kaiju” and ran with it. For whatever reason, video game adaptations of these behemoth beasts never completely took off. We have the Rampage series and the King of the Monsters iterations, but nothing quite as big or as smart as Into the Breach. It’s about time titan-sized tactical chess was released upon the world.

Subset Games, makers of the masterpiece Faster Than Light, have waded through space and time to bring us another sci-fi turn-based strategy game. Although it’s quite different from their last outing, you can expect the same level of polish and addictive gameplay. Into the Breach may be small in scope, but there are no chains large enough to tie it down.

As a fearless pilot seated in one of several weaponized mech robots, it’s up to you to protect humanity from the scourge of Vek – a medley of mutated insects capable of mass destruction. Each battle plays out on a tiled eight-by-eight grid that you and your adversaries take turns attacking and defending. With every successful mission, your crew advances toward the Vek hive and collects upgrades and experience along the way. Failure sends a pilot of your choice back to an alternative timeline to start anew, while keeping your current mech’s upgraded attributes. Every move is entirely deliberate, with no random number generator to muddle your approach.

While you’re sure to face adversity, the game never feels unfair. Missteps are painful, but even total defeat results in a clever tie-in with the premise. While enemy types may get stale, bouncing them into lava never does. A variety of environmental effects also help shake-up your surroundings. The overwhelming number of upgrades, weapons, and mechs will keep hardcore strategy fans engaged and Into the Breach also serves as a perfect way introduce newcomers to a turn-based model. Protect the grid and protect Earth!

40691130.review:
Into The Breach (ITB) is a quickfire blast of intense strategy, and if that’s your bag then it will please you enormously.

Others have compared it to Advance Wars and XCom, but it isn’t much like either of those. ITB punishes relaxed play more than either of those games, but it also holds up its end of the bargain by giving significant rewards for success.

Each battle takes place on an 8x8 grid, with your three mechs often outnumbered by baddies, more of which emerge from the ground as you play. It’s turn based, so you can take as long as you like to consider your options, and you can roll back movement if you are not happy. But once a mech has fired its weapon or taken an action (such as repairing itself) that mech cannot move (unless you have a perk that allows a subsequent move). You can also reset your whole turn once per battle.

Battles are played out over 5 turns, and your objectives per battle will depend on which of several regions you decide to do battle in. There is a persistent power grid meter that will fall as the buildings in each region get destroyed, so as well as surviving the battle and meeting any objectives you also have to protect buildings to maintain the power meter.

There are several classes of mech you can use, which are unlocked using tokens you gain during campaigns. The more you play the more styles of mech you can unlock. You can assemble any kind of team of three mechs you like, either by chaos rolls, ordered rolls or by editing the team manually. You can put together any combination through the team editor, even having three identical mechs, and there are various achievements to be gained as you explore the combinations.

Then there are pilots, whose experience is carried from playthrough to playthrough. They can be killed too, which gives the game a real edge. In one recent game I was in the final level and lost my star pilot to an environmental hazard I just hadn’t seen. The character is still available to play with, but they will lose all their valuable experience.

Regions are bundled into islands, and you will have to clear a minimum of two subsidiary islands before you can progress to the final island. So, if you are in good shape after two islands it makes sense to go to the final one, but if you have struggled and need to stat up you can keep playing and see if you can recover some ground. On easiest difficulty this is pretty straightforward, but the higher settings are quite taxing (at least they were for my old brain!)

The rewards for clearing an island include tokens which allow you to refill the power meter, and others you can use to upgrade your mechs.

The deceptively straightforward interface and level design might make you think the game is simple or easy, but it’s really more like chess or a complex card game, with all the parts finely balanced the way a good board game would be.

One of the most innovative elements, and the one that makes the whole game nicely different, is the way you can see every enemy action before it happens. Enemies get to emerge from the ground, make a move AND set up an attack all in one turn, but the consequences of the enemy attacks do not happen until the player ends their turn, so using all the various weapons at your disposal you can thwart the enemy plans by destroy their units directly or even move them around so that their attacks hit empty space or other enemy units. Very cool!

All in all this is a terrific half hour time waster that deserves a place in the collection of every turn based strategy fan.

Into the Breach is a game where everything superfluous has been stripped away leaving only incredibly compelling strategy gameplay where every decision you make is so important, so impactful. 

Gameplay is wholely deterministic with enemy attacks telegraphed ahead of time which means that your victories and defeats (oh so many mistakes and abandoned timelines) are completely your own. Every turm becomes a tense exercise in damage limitation as you try to figure out how to achieve as much as possible with your movements and actions, to manipulate the battlefield for maximum effect with your squad: move the enemies with your abilities so they miss or hit each other, move a mech so it can body block one shot while shooting at another guy so that he's moved one tile and will stand over an enemy spawn point next turn, leave that civilian building to take a hit so you can save the power plant. 

The balance is very well done on the normal difficulty, demanding a good ammount of thought be put into your play and some tough decisions be made, with the option of an easy difficulty that's still somewhat challenging but allows for a bit more of a learning curve or where you can treat every turn as a puzzle to achieve perfect play and save everyone, and a hard difficulty for the exceptionally skilled or masochistic.

Definitely my favourite release of 2018 thus far, and I'd go as far as to say that I consider it to be a near-perfect game, with my only gripes being that I'd like to see more map and mission veriety, but when the only complaint you can find is "I want more" you're looking at a damn good game.

40682620.review:
[h1]Into the Breachとは、詰将棋です。[/h1][b]
「詰将棋みたい」、ではありません。「詰将棋」です。
「ローグライク」でも「ターンベースストラテジー」でもなく、「よくもわるくも詰将棋」なんです。[/b]


[h1]簡単なゲームの内容[/h1]
　本作は、伝説の「FTL」開発者が送る新作です。
　あなたは未来から来た3機の巨大ロボを指揮し、人類文明を脅かす虫型生物Vekと戦います。
　基本はターン制シミュですが、すべての敵はこれから自分が移動・攻撃する場所を予め宣言します。あなたはその宣言された敵の行動に対抗すべく移動・攻撃等を行うことが求められます。
敵の行動が全てわかってるから簡単と侮るなかれ、こちらの手駒は3つに対し、敵は平気で５－６匹（ときに７匹以上も！）出現します。あなたは3手で、6手行動できる敵を抑えるのです。こんなの無理！でもそんななかでも、如何に3手で敵を妨害し、人類の街を守る最適解を考えるのです。
　限られた手駒を動かし、突きつけられた問題を解いていく。その様はまさに詰将棋なのです。


[h1]実は不満の声も多い[/h1]
　人気ゲームの続編だし、さぞ評価もいいと思いきや、[u]実はレビュアーからの評価は必ずしも好意的なものばかりではありません。[/u]
[list]
　[*][u][b]「プレイが全く同じ内容の繰り返し」[/b][/u]。変則ルールは多少あれど、基本は、虫が出る→街を守る→戦場を移動→虫が出る・・・のワンパターンです。
　[*][u][b]「ドラマチックな展開の欠如」[/b][/u]。ほんっとおおに最初からクライマックスにかけて、全く同じ展開が続くだけで、プレイの緩急に欠けて単調さに拍車をかけます。ラストのネタバレすると、[spoiler]ラスボスすらいません。既出のちょっと強い敵の使い回し[/spoiler]です。
　[*][u][b]「これローグライクとは言い難いよね」[/b][/u]。確かにマップや敵配置、得られるアイテム等は毎回ランダムですが、正直何回かやってればほぼ同じようなメンツになって見つけるワクワク感は薄れちゃいます。
　[*][u][b]「メックのカスタムの幅がなさすぎ！」[/b][/u]。メックには様々な武器は一応装備できますが、結局初期の装備しかろくに使わないことも大半です。見た目のカスタマイズ？い、色なら８色くらいから選べるくらい・・・かな・・・
[/list]
　他にも、プレイすればわかりますが「島２～４クリアとか分ける意味あんの？」「これ武器を購入する意義あんまないよね？」みたいな不満は、実際に存在します。私も、上記全てそのとおりだな、と感じます。


[h1]それでも私が傑作と呼ぶ理由[/h1]
　単調、ワンパターン、ゲームデザインの不満。なんだこれ。微妙ゲーじゃねえのか？・・・それでも本作を傑作と呼ぶ人も、少なからずいます。私も傑作と呼びます。
　理由は他ならぬ、そのワンパターンな戦闘の[b][u]「神がかり的なゲームバランス」[/u][/b]です。
上　記の自駒３に対し敵駒６のシチュ。どう考えてもこんなの無理だよ！狙われている街を犠牲にするしかないのか・・・などと考えていると、ふと、[b]「こうすればいいんじゃね」[/b]とひらめくことがあります。まずこの駒をこうして、次のこの駒をこうすると、あら不思議！敵は壊滅状態に陥ったではありませんか！やべえ！多勢に無勢を覆した俺天才じゃね？！
　この難易度バランスが実に絶妙。毎回自動生成されるマップや敵の配置という「問題」は、ヌルゲーでもなければ無理ゲーでもない絶妙な塩梅のものばかり。そしてどんなにきつい状況になっても、問題の「解法」が必ず存在するのです。そしてそこに至ることができたときの喜びは筆舌に尽くしがたい！


[h1]良くも悪くも詰将棋[/h1]
　毎回盤と駒が自動配置される「問題」を、あなたの「手駒」で解決する。これは正に、良くも悪くも詰将棋なのです。将棋や囲碁、チェスのような、何百年とプレイされてきた盤上ゲームとも肩を並べる比類なきゲームバランスで勝負しています。
　そう考えると上記の不満点もこんな説明ができてしまいます。

「同じようなパズルばかり」？[b]当たり前です。詰将棋ですから。[/b]
「ドラマチックな展開がない」？[b]そりゃそうです。詰将棋ですから。[/b]
「ローグライクじゃない」？[b]まあそうだよね。詰将棋ですから。[/b]
「メック（＝駒）のカスタムの幅がない」？[b]ないよ。詰将棋ですから。[/b]


[h1]まとめ[/h1]
　Into the Breachは、将棋や囲碁、チェスにも肩を並べる新たなターン制ゲームのフォーマットです。将棋やチェスに興味なくても大丈夫。私も興味ありませんでしたがドハマリしてます。自分の頭脳に挑みたい方は、派手な展開にさえ期待しなければきっと満足できるはず。

　・・・とはいえ、せっかくビデオゲームであるからには、「詰将棋だから」という免罪符なんて使わなくていいよう、ドラマチックな展開がもうちょっとあってもよかったな、と思うのは紛れもない事実。ということで、DLC期待してますSubset Gamesさん。


[h1]最後に[/h1]
　FTLのEasy詐欺をトラウマにしてる方へ。大丈夫。本作のEasyは本当にEasyです。簡単すぎてヌルゲーにすら感じるのでパズルやターン制シムに自信があるなら初見Normalでも楽しいですよ！

The game feels like and looks like a really well made Game Boy Advance (If anyone remembers that system) game that ripped off Advance War and made the formula for the game type better by implementing various knockback, mobility, environmental, and status mechanics into the game; all of which blend and interact with one another nicely. Knock back and enemy/ally unit placement/manipulation are easily the strongest core mechanics within the game.

The core gameplay itself (Positioning and attacking with your units, and moving enemy units with knockback and/or applying a status) while simple is strong, satisfying, and at times can create complex puzzle like situations in regards of what to do with your units so that no cities are damaged.

The RNG in the game seems to be a bit off as i've had levels be generated to be impossible not to take major damage and levels that spawn in with very easy enemy placement. There's no real narrative story but a general concept for a conflict and the enemy unit types don't vary a great deal and only symbolize significant strength increases with color. The player Mech variety is nice though you have to spend time unlocking achievements to gain coins to unlock all of the Mechs. Into the Breach is the second game from the Devs behind FTL. The basic premise is giant robats fighting giant bugs; just your standard Sci-Fi action stuff. Then you add a dash of time travel and you've got Into the Breach.

Now if you are coming to this game from FTL, don't expect a similar game. Into the Breach has more in common with chess than it does with FTL. Each turn takes place in two basic phases. The giant bugs (each with unique attack styles and abilities) move into position to attack your cities. These cities are your game's health bar. You then move your 3 mechs in an attempt to stop these attacks from damaging your cities. Every attack does exactly what it says it will, 100% of the time. There is not XCOM style 99% misses. You click punch that bug back a tile, it goes back a tile. And this is really where the genius of the game is. The bugs will follow through on their planned moves regardless of what happens. So if you knock one of their own in the way, you get a helping hand from the enemy.

All in all each mission plays like a mini puzzle that reacts to your actions. You then have to manage the upgrading of the mechs and which of your three pilots you want in the next timeline. All in all Into the Breach is a wonderfully challenge. It isn't FTL, but that is 100% okay!

This game has great polish, great music and great UI. The game is a puzzle game more than anything else, where the moves you make against an AI opponent have nothing to do with RNG and are always static, but this is also true of the CPU opponent. What is determined by RNG is how your units level up and what gear you will receive. This means that while RNG won't influence the outcome of the actual battles (making it more of a puzzle game), your turn OPTIONS in battle will be determined by RNG, while the enemy constantly grows in power in a static way. This means you can't compensate as easily for bad gear RNG during a battle because your enemies won't miss, and you won't get any lucky hits. You can't "gamble" the way you might in a roguelike turn, risking the odds for a higher reward. Personally I find the predictable, puzzle-like aspect of the game to be dull, and the RNG aspect of gearing up / leveling up to be great, but inappropriate for the puzzle style of play.

This is the kind of game I'd initially want to recommend to my friends who like puzzle games, but then they'd be turned off by the RNG aspect of what options they're given. I am not sure this game caters to puzzle or roguelike fans, but because the actual design quality (music, graphics, controls, UI) of the game is so high, the game is still worth a try to see if it's your cup of tea.

What appeals to me the most about Into the Breach is how it feels like I’m playing chess but without all of the “playing chess” of it.  While it poses as and has all of the makings of a game that falls more in line with other turn-based strategies like X-COM or Advanced Wars, it stands apart by using simplicity to trick you in to thinking you won’t keep losing until you hate everyone and everything.

[h1]64 Squares of Strategy[/h1]
At first glance, Into the Breach doesn’t look like it’s going to throw much at you.  It’s visually very similar to Advanced Wars and I think if you watched a trailer cutting together a bunch of quick scenes you would assume that’s what it was.  However, instead of large armies and damage based on dice rolls, you start each play session picking a specific squad that you’ll be using until you either win, or much more likely, fail miserably at saving humanity.  Each of your three-mech unit has a pilot that can level up and gain stat boosts or special skills and each mech has a starting weapon or ability (sometimes two).  These mech abilities end up defining your each mech and make them feel very similar to chess pieces that perform a singular task.  The difference there is that, if you’re successful, you can outfit your mech with additional weapons and abilities that can change or expand its role in the game.  

You’ll be using these mechs to face off against a bug-like alien threat that burrows up through the ground threatening humanity.  Each side will trade off like other turn based strategies, but what makes it unique is that, after the initial placement of your units on the map (in a defined area away from the in-place bugs), the aliens move first.  They don’t attack in this move, but rather position themselves and broadcast the attack that is about to happen.  This creates a mechanic where your job is to react to the actions of the enemy to stop them from doing damage.  Their goal is to attack buildings, and every building they destroy lowers the potential number of rescued civilians at the end of the game.  However, more important than score, every destroyed building lowers your power level by one.  The power level is treated essentially as hitpoints for the campaign.  If you run out of power, it’s game over.  

The moderate variety of enemies with their different attacks, strengths, and weaknesses creates a dynamic level of gameplay when placed up against your selected squad of three mechs and their assigned abilities.  For something that is so minimalistic, even after hours of gameplay I felt like I was encountering new scenarios that challenged me at every turn – and that’s even before I’ve unlocked more than half of the mech squads.  If there is one thing that is frustrating about this game, it’s the fact that unlocking mechs can force you to do employ strategies that aren’t really optimal and one suboptimal attack can easily cascade into a waterfall of failure.  Yet, to some degree, that’s one of the interesting challenges to the game itself – and another reason to go ahead and knock out some rounds on easy difficulty.

[h1]Save the world… or try to save it again[/h1]

The overarching goal of Into the Breach is to save the world from the bug-aliens by clearing at least two of the four main islands, each lead by a unique caricature of a leader and boasting their own distinct biomes and hazards.  Once you’ve achieved that, a fifth island is unlocked and serves as the final battle.  It’s more  challenging, but the difficulty dynamically changes with however many islands you’ve done.  So it’s possible to win with 2, 3, or 4 islands completed and there are achievements for each.  Yet it seems like it might be tougher to finish three or four islands successfully than to just beat the game itself.

If you lose all of your power hitpoints and fail, you’re not left just to restart from scratch, you get to exploit the game’s bit of “time travel” where you send one of your (preferably experienced) pilots back in time to start the next campaign.  The same happens even if you win in order to give you the same advantage whatever the case is for your next run.  The time travel concept also is present in the single “reset turn” action you get in each battle.  While you’re always able to undo movement, this allows you to also undo actions like attacks in case there’s a consequence you didn’t anticipate after acting.  It sounds silly, but I find that I use it in the majority of the battles.  It creates a gameplay loop that takes the edge off the frustration of losing a run whether you’ve been on it for a few minutes or a few hours.  That, along with unlocking new groups of mechs, had me restarting immediately even after losing in the final fight.  It’s really impressive that the developers managed to do this both in FTL and in their new title.

[h1]Not FTL, but just as addictive[/h1]

Despite being fundamentally and mechanically as different as possible, Into the Breach captures much of the same pure fun that made FTL a classic.  It provides a type of gameplay that starts out simple and approachable with very straightforward rules, but it grows in complexity and difficulty at a rate that keeps it engaging and makes it fun many hours in.  It takes all of the right aspects from familiar games and mixes them in the formula (if it can even be called that) that made FTL such a lasting icon, but does it in a way that feels new even to someone like me who’s played way too many games.  I hope that Subset Games can keep putting this much obvious care and refinement into future games because it’s the core of what makes Indie games so wonderful to play.

Yes, I do recommend this game and despite this being a positive review I will still be critical of the game. Gonna try splitting this up if you're just looking for specifics.

What I love about "Into the Breach" is hard to place. As far as strategy games go this one is really simple. It lacks the length and depth you'd find in other prolonged games. My fondness for stories and systems to master does not mean I can't enjoy this. This game is actually really great for the casual player. A person maybe short on time looking to get in and out. An hour or two of playing and you've just saved the world. Not a bad thing depending on perspective. At the worst there is a lot of wasted potential but best not to think on what ifs or could haves.

[b] The good	[/b]
Comparing "Into the Breach" to "FTL: Faster than Light", the other game from the same devs, I'd say "Into the Breach" has a better foundation of gameplay. It isn't one big random number generator. The player has a battlefield to control and the game doesn't keep secrets. Mouse over an enemy or a tile and you can learn just what they are about and there is no ambiguity in the text. If a boulder is gonna fall some place on the board it won't say "A boulder will land here". It will say "A boulder will land here killing any unit here". The game is, for the most part, in the players hands. It is a true strategy experience in the sense that you look at the data and make a choice. And with the various different mechs to unlock and weapons/tools you can obtain there will be a lot of choices to consider.

You also have more freedom to perform well and be rewarded. In "FTL" you can win fight after fight after fight and amass a hoard of scrap. No guarantee you'll get value out of it though as shops are the rarity and without repairing or buying better weapons your run could just be doomed to fail. Not so in this one. Play well and defeat the Vek and you'll find a use for the game currency.

[b] The bad	[/b]
Sadly I think this is where the praise ends. Looking back on "FTL" it did feel at times like winning or losing wasn't up to me. The little thing called luck that determined a good portion of my success stories in it. But it had something more that "Into the Breach" doesn't have. It had a level of charm with its music and the random events that kept things interesting. The graphics weren't great on paper but very fitting to the game all things taken together.

I feel "Into the Breach" lacks that. None of the music stands out to me. The characters are some interesting in mannerisms but you're not gonna see much past that. Perhaps that's all fitting and intentional though. This game is about a gritty war after all. However the end result does mean I'm not left with any lasting feelings or as enamored with the game.

Also huge spoilers about the ending I wasn't too fond of. [spoiler] The ending feels like nothing. You're playing and fighting and if you lose you go back in time to try again in the hopes of saving a timeline from the Vek. When you win you go back in time again to save.... another timeline from the Vek? I don't even get any cool character endings or anything? I don't know, just felt this was lame and a bit underwhelming.	[/spoiler]

[b] The unforgivable	[/b]
The absolute objectively bad thing I can see is the tutorial. For an opt in tutorial it leaves out a few very key details. Information is always available to the player by mousing over stuff and usually doing so will show a tool tip the first time but the tutorial never gives mention to things like the "reset turn" button (which barring a game update isn't even present in the tutorial) or the "attack order" icon. It doesn't point out the "undo move" button either as a potential option to the player. I know it is there in plain sight next to "end turn" but maybe it would have been kind to tell the player, that felt like they needed the tutorial, that this is an option for when you end up in the wrong place. This last section may just be a gripe with the devs but it's relevant to bring up as one of the games shortcomings.

40657776.review:
Into the Breach is the sophomore game of Subset Games, the creators of FTL (Faster Than Light), and it's safe to say that they delivered another hit.

The game is a turn-based strategy game, that plays a little bit like chess. The goal of the game is to save the world against an alien threat, in order to do so you have a team of 3 mechs with unique abilities, upgrades, attacks, and more. You get sent down to a square tile (much like a chess board) where you will have to survive and save civilians, as well as completing bonus objectives to gain extra resources. To make the game more challenging you have a power grid, each time an alien destroys a building you will lose 1-2 bars (depending on the structure), once you run out of bars you lose the game, so the game is not all about saving yourself, and you will be in situations where you will have to choose between sacrificing 1 of your mechs in order to save a building. 

The game can be beat in just a few hours, but don't let that scare you away, the game is built to be replayed over and over again, and with randomly generated challenges for each battle, every play-through will be different. 

Overall Into the Breach is a very simple but solid game, with ranging difficulty so even if you're new to turn-based games you won't have any problems jumping in and learning the ropes quickly. At first it may seem a bit confusing, but it won't take long until you get the hang on things, and once you do there is hours of fun to be had with this title. 

I strongly recommend this game to fans of strategy & turn-based games, and if you've ever wanted to get into those kinds of games, Into the Breach will be a great starting point.

TL;DR: Must-have by anyone who enjoys tactical games. Those who don't, stay away. Play this game for the fun of fiddling with tactical tools, not the feeling of progression and levelling-up. 

The review by Rock, paper shotgun is spot on in describing the game's features.  (see https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2018/02/27/into-the-breach-ftl-sequel-review/). It's a no frills (almost) perfect information tactical game with a laser sharp focus on providing tactical tools to manipulate the battle in your favour. Every turn feels like a puzzle where you manipulate the board in response to enemy action. 

What I will elaborate on instead is what the game lacks. It lacks a complete Skinner Box, a.k.a. progression system. There is little in the form of positive reinforcement systems within the game to trick your brain. Progression is pretty light, this isn't a game you play to feel like you're building up a epic squad take on epic enemies. The only thing which is getting "epic" is you, the player, in your actual skills.

Instead, you play this game for fiddling with the mechanics. Think of it as playing with a very well made toy. You can do all sorts of cool and interesting funny maneveurs with the tools you've been given which make YOU feel like a badass. Even the achievements (through which you unlock new stuff) are not given for WINNING the game. The achievements are tied to playing with the game's systems, such as make 4 enemies die from friendly fire with the Judo squad. Block 4 damage with shields in the laser/shields squad. Win a battle killing fewer than 3 enemies with the ice squad. That sort of thing.

But does your toy "level up" as keep playing with it? Not this one. By the end of the game your squad is stronger, sure. But it's pretty light. Being a "play this game for the fun of fiddling with tactical tools" means it doesn't have as much longevity as some other game with a Skinner Box. But that's fine. I never liked grinding anyway.

Dear God/Bhudda/RNGesus, thank you for this game.

WHAT I LIKE ABOUT THIS GAME:

The gameplay is addicting, and there are so many great things about this game!

The RNG is minimal, with the only effects being Randomly generated maps (Which have rules to them, so no map that is too crazy) and a chance to not be penalized for messing up. From FTL being life and death with a roll of a dice, it feel really good to get something new.

The Mechs and Vek (The enemy you have to fight) look really good, especially for pixel art.

Each Pilot is memorable from the cool headed Starter Pilot War Vet to the Gardener AI Pilot. 

The Battles are Fair: You know what you are getting (because you can see the map before the fight and where the ememy are, there are no secret objectives [aside from Time Pods], and the enemy broadcast what they will do before you move so you can theoretically counter everything they do), and you know most of everything when you enter the fight. Nothing is hidden from you, so what you make is what you get. This game is the biggest "You Reap What You Sow" example I have seen in a while.

The Soundtrack is amazing, but I never had any doubts about Ben Prunty's skills.

Death Sucks, but it is a harsh lesson, and it can make you feel more determined to win next time.

The "Aha!" moment when you get a perfect battle is amazing to feel, and you feel rewarded for success because it wasn't handed to you: you earned this victory, through grit, tears, and selling your soul to RNGesus and the three other high Gods of Gaming.

Animation is crisp, and aside from small lag moments when moving the mouse (I blame my computer mostly) it runs like a gem. No waiting periods, loading screens, just fluid combat.

You don't have $15 (In which case you have my sympathy)

You are not a fan of Rogue-Like games, and tend to rage easily. Because losing in this game hurts, and if you have trouble losing games, you will hate this game.

You hate games that (as of 3/7/2018) have a critic score of 91 on Metacritic and a user score of 8.1 (from 90 submissions).

FINAL VERDICT:

Into the Breach、は同名のMTGにあるカードの訳でいうと「突破口」だそうだ。
このゲームは、そのタイトル通りに「突破口」を見つけるゲームである。

プレイヤーは8×8の小さなマップの中で4～5ターンという短い期間の戦闘を何度もこなしていく事になる。
大きな特徴としては、毎ターン敵が最初に移動し、これから攻撃する対象と範囲が事前に示される仕組みになっている。
敵の行動に対して、自軍の3体の個性あふれるmechを動かし、敵を攻撃して撃破したり、または攻撃によって動かしたりして攻撃範囲をずらし、味方の施設（破壊されすぎるとゲームオーバー）や自軍のmechが破壊されないように戦っていくのだ。
4～5ターンで戦闘が必ず終わる為、無理に敵を撃破する必要はない。
飛べない敵を動かすことで海や穴に落としたりすると即死したり、ユニット同士をぶつけると両方にダメージが入るなど、敵を動かす事で働くギミックも多い。
このゲームには命中率やダメージの乱数などは存在しないので、こと戦闘に関しては全てプレイヤーの選択に委ねられる。
時には何かを犠牲にする事も往々にしてあるが、一方で敵の苛烈な攻撃を全て躱す「突破口」を見出した時は他のゲームとは一味違う快感がある。
プレイヤーに全てを委ねる非常に秀逸なバランスとゲームデザインは何度やっても飽きることはない。

一方で、ストーリーや武器・強化システム、UI等も全て優秀。
勝つまでタイムトラベルするストーリーはローグライクと見事にマッチしているし、強化システムもその場で強化した際の強さがわかるよう簡単なムービーがついている。
UIもすっきりしており、書いてある英語も日本語化しなくとも大体意味が類推できる上、FTLと違って英文の選択肢がないので英語のままでもプレイに支障はほぼない。
BGMや効果音もゲームに相応しいレトロチックなサウンドで、このゲームの雰囲気を申し分なく高めてくれている。

実績を全て解除するまでプレイしたが、ここからがスタートな予感さえしている。

40633700.review:
The best part of Into the Breach comes when you find yourself in a situation that seems unwinnable. There are simply too many enemies, too many variables. You stare at the screen for 10 minutes, 20, 30-- if only I could get a unit right THERE to knock that one to the side-- if only I still had that weapon I unlocked last run that pushed everything in a straight line-- if only that unit had a melee attack-- and then it hits you. The perfect solution. You need to make use of all your units, using their abilities perfectly, taking advantage of the tertiary effects of their attacks and the special abilities of your pilots, but you can do it. You can not only survive this no-win situation, you can WIN, and you can do it in style.

What makes Into the Breach great is when you execute a seemingly perfect plan-- knocking enemies to the side so they target each other, forcing them to cover their own allies' spawn points, sending them flying into a lake-- and then realize, when it's too late to matter, that your brilliant plan just sent the corpse of a giant bug-monster flying into a city, demolishing it and killing dozens of people.

The best part of Into the Breach is when you've finally mastered a new squad of mechs; you've learned how their abilities work in tandem, the best way to utilize them, the best pilot for the job, which upgrades to prioritize and why. They move like a well-oiled machine, running circles around the Vek and making it look easy.

What makes Into the Breach great is how every time you unlock a new mech squad, for your first couple missions (often your first couple runs) they feel useless; their abilities aren't just worse than the squad they were using before, they're actively detrimental. You're accidentally cancelling your own attacks, or blowing up buildings with the shockwave from your artillery blasts, or setting your own units on fire. Your reaction every time you're working with a new squad is "wow, these guys suck, huh?"

The best part of Into the Breach is when you finally win. After trying over and over, giving up on timeline after timeline, you finally, finally, FINALLY win. You defeat the Vek, and you save humanity, and you know that it was through your practice, your intelligence, your understanding of your mechs and the enemy Vek, that you were able to do it. And it feels GREAT.

What makes Into the Breach great is knowing how much sacrifice it took to get there. Even in those timelines you saved, you couldn't help everybody. There were regions on each island you were forced to abandon, hundreds of lives you decided were acceptable losses. There were times when the situation really was unwinnable, and you prioritized the lives of your own pilots, or you prioritized completing an objective, over the lives of the people you were supposed to protect, and you did it for the greater good. Not to mention the timelines you couldn't save: all the lives, all the worlds that were lost because of your mistakes, your ineptitude, your frustration, your inexperience.

10/10. Play Into the Breach.

Into the breach is a very simple and focused game, without a lot of scope to its gameplay. The actual gameplay feels more akin to solving a puzzle than anything, and as you complete more islands the puzzles become more complex. There's a good foundation to build a truely great game here, but right now it feels kind of barbones, like a title that just released on early access. This isn't bad though as the moment to moment gameplay puzzle solving is fun, and the game is cheap.

Many of its current systems though don't really provide the experience it seems to be going for outside of the moment to moment gameplay. You never feel like your mechs make significant progress because how you approach the combat puzzles doesn't really change as the game goes on, you just get slight modifiers which might slightly change up your strategy, but it's not enough to be truely engaging imo. When I complete an island I pretty much always take the power cores instead of anything else because you need power cores to get stronger, and upgrade the weapons you do have. Wheather you choose to do 2 islands or 4 feels of little consequence because the scope of both feel quite similar, due to how boring the upgrades are and how you'll only really grab 1 or 2 weapons on your whole run because weapons are useless without the power to power them and make them stronger.

You have to achievement hunt for coins which are used to unlock other mech squads. As someone who isn't an avid achievement hunter I thought this system was servicable, as the reward is pretty cool, but I could see why people that hate achievement hunting wouldn't enjoy this.

Right now there is quite a bit of content here to enjoy between the different mech squads and learning how to use them, trying out your own custom mech squads, or maybe even doing a challenge run with the first random squad you get. I could see someone getting about 30 hours of gameplay, but it's hard to imagine anyone playing this game for upwards of 100+ hours as many have done with ftl.

I see a lot of potential for into the breach and as it is now I do reccomend it because of it's price point. However I would love to see what this game could turn into if it's given the proper development time. What about bigger maps, more mechs on a map at a given time, mechs that feel like they evolve over the course of a game and are different than when they started, which could be solved by as easily as giving the player more power cores and adjusting the difficulty slightly, longer runs that feel more akin to a campaign rather than an arcade run. It's kind of like xcom, if xcom was locked to 4 characters per mission, which to anyone whose played xcom, knows that it's a far more fun game when you play with 6 per mission.

Un juego que sorprende y mucho. 
No os dejéis engañar por sus gráficos ni por su aparentemente simple jugabilidad, estamos ante un juegazo de estrategia con un potencial de rejugabilidad enorme y que te hará desesperar mientras tratas de hallar una solución que sabes que esta ahí, pero que no logras ver. 
Pare un juego de combates, y lo es, pero es mucho mas. Su jugabilidad se asemeja mas a un puzzle o a una partida de ajedrez, donde lo único que importa eres tu, tus movimientos, los enemigos y el entorno. 
Sin RNGs, sin porcentajes, sin sorpresas, con unas reglas claras, y un reto por delante. 
Lo que mas me ha sorprendido de este juego es la IA. Para mi roza la perfección. No por que sea dificil ganarle, eso es un recurso fácil, mas bien por todo lo contrario.  Puede jugar mejor o peor según el nivel al que la pongas, pero siempre analizara el tablero y creara una situación perfectamente resoluble si has jugado bien, por lo que si pierdes, tu seras el único culpable. 
El contenido no es demasiado, hay unos 10 o 15 tipos de enemigos y 24 mechas que son los personajes que tu podrás utilizar, usándolos siempre en grupos de 3. Los mapas, tienen unos pocos elementos a tener en cuenta y unos pocos eventos que ocurrirán durante la partida. 
Todo lo demás es jugabilidad pura, y aun con lo poco que he nombrado arriba, te dará decenas de horas de rejugabilidad.
Un juego fácil de entender, pero muy difícil de dominar. Como he dicho, muy similar al ajedrez, no solo en forma, también en posibilidades y profundidad. 

Totalmente recomendado si te gustan los indies, los juegos de tablero, o los roguelites basados en la rejugabilidad. Si te gusto FTL probablemente te guste into the breach tambien, pero ten en mente que son juegos muy diferentes. 

Nota: 8.5/10
