40618381.review:
This game does not have the staying power of FTL, I am sure. As it doesn't have the same kind of random events you can happen onto that keep the game fresh for dozens of hours. Instead, it relies on semi-procedurally-generated missions. These are great.

The game is $15 USD. I don't need to get the at least 200 hours I've gotten out of FTL through the years to get my money's worth or love it. And holy crap do I love it.

So the game starts with a five-second cutscene that tells you everything you need to know about the story and that makes the metaprogression of multiple runs and unlocking things part of the plot which is really cool, and then you jump right in.

And what you jump into is very easy to understand, very clear in its mechanics, and very well-designed and very fun.

I adore the music of FTL, and Ben Prunty has perhaps done an even better job with this soundtrack. I don't see myself listening to it on its own as much as FTL's, but I certainly will still do so. But for the game, it's phenomenal. It makes a lo-fi isometric game that actually fails to establish scale properly in a number of ways (I'll get to that) feel perfect anyway. It makes you feel like a mech pilot fighting for humanity's survival. It's melancholy and rich and anachronist in a way that fits the game's setting so well. You have futuristic synths merging with violins beautifully. It makes me want more of this setting so much. Hell, it's made me play another run immediately multiple times.

Then there's the mechanics. Into the Breach boils down tile-based tactics to a minimalist state that retains all the fun, but cuts out much of the frustration. It is all deterministic; non-random; in the battles themselves. You have perfect information every turn. No playing the odds of hitting and getting screwed. Just your wits. But the battles are small enough in scale that nothing ever gets too intimidating or stressful.

There is, however, one exception to the non-randomness of battles, and it's my one real gripe with the game: building damage. Essentially, you have a life bar that continues on through the whole game in the form of the "power grid." If buildings are destroyed, the power grid takes damage. This can be healed, but essentially what you're always trying to do is prevent buildings being destroyed. Mechs heal at the end of combat, but the power grid doesn't, so you often end up blocking attacks on buildings with your mechs. The point is, buildings have a chance to resist damage. And this can be improved through abilities and essentially "overhealing" your power grid. But this is pointless. I doubt you could get the chance to resist damage above 40%, and even above 25% generally requires sacrificing other rewards. Which is really just pointless. The odds are still so low that the damage will be resisted and the consequences so harsh that you just don't want to be in that situation anyway. So I just don't think the mechanic is even worth having, and it's a black mark of randomness in an otherwise beautifully not-random set of mechanics.

My even more minor gripe is that the scale of the game just doesn't work great. The fact that you're fighting giant insects makes everything feel smaller, especially when you're against big flying wasps, which would be too big to fly. Thus, my brain at least has trouble imagining them as they're intended and just sort of slips back into thinking of them as insect-sized, or at least as more human-sized, with your mechs as armored people. If the enemies were more alien; less buglike, this wouldn't be so much a problem. Also, the scale of other things is off or inconsistent. Buildings and mechs are almost as tall as mountains. Trees come to like... where your mechs' shoelaces would be. It's hard to get a handle on how big everything's meant to be. And then add in conveyor belt squares in one zone, and it gets more confusing. These conveyor belts are as wide as the base of a mountain and can move mountain-sized mechs around. How? What are these for? I have to avoid thinking about it or it hurts my brain.

But neither of these are huge deals. The game is great. Runs are shorter than FTL runs, which reduced the stress considerably. Though there is less margin for error than FTL, so if you graphed the stressfulness of both games, they'd probably look quite similar.

I'd basically recommend Into the Breach if you like FTL, if you like XCOM or Fire Emblem, if you like mechs, or if you like roguelites or roguelikes. I quite like all of these things, so I freaking love this game and will get many dozens of hours of very high enjoyment from it.

Update after a few more runs: There is one additional gripe I have. The unlocks are based on achievements, with each squad having its own three achievements that'll give you coins for unlocks. Kinda like how ships in FTL had their three achievements. But you can also mix and match mechs from different squads. However, if you do this, that just makes that squad "The Custom Squad", which has its three achievements. So you're disincentivized from doing a custom squad quite quickly, in favor of the default squads. And I don't like some of the squads, or some of the mechs. This would be solved by giving each mech its own achievement to get. Then it would be more fun thinking of a squad to help you achievement hunt if there were one you were having trouble with, and let you make a squad that would lessen your dislike of a given mech. For example, putting a mech that shields buildings with the mech whose attacks chain through and damage buildings annoyingly.

Again, it's not a huge gripe, as I don't hate any of the squads I've unlocked (I have one left to unlock [though it sounds like the least fun <which is why I left it for last {so we'll see how I feel about that one}>]) to the point I don't have fun playing them, just less fun, and this method does mean more replay value as you're forced to achievement hunt elusive achievements singly rather than all together in a custom squad. And once you've done all the squad achievements, custom squad away!

40618071.review:
Into the Breach is a very well balanced strategy game. It's easy to pick up, and has the perfect level of difficulty. 
The art style, music and interface is highly reminiscent of FTL, with some assets that look like they were pulled strait from FTL itself. The recycled feel is actually admirable to me in this case because it suggests that the two games belong to the same universe even though they play completely different and never claim to be related. It's somehow a sequel without being a sequel.

I classify this as a rogue-medium game. what I mean by that is, some of your aquired abilities will be carried over into the next game, but you do have the opportunity to lose everything for your next game. My biggest problem right now is that exact rogue-mediumness. There are two conflicting strategies that come from it. 

strategy 1:
you can sacrifice everything that could carry to the next game to maximize the progress you make through the current game.
 
strategy 2:
you can sacrifice your progress in the current game to maximize progress in a future game. 

The strategies are in no way mutually exclusive, but I often feel like I have to go with strategy 2 because I can't find the perfect balance between the two, and I'm not good enough to finish the game from a fresh start. This makes the game feel a little bit grindy and distracts me from what I assume is the real purpose, beating the final boss.

Overall I really like playing this game, and I remain impressed with the ability Subset has to sharply focus on a simple and fresh gameplay concept.

7.5/10

I really like the idea for this game. However there is just no substence in this game yet for me to recommend it. After a single play through (about an hour long) you have been to every location in the game and have seen every enemy in the game. 

There are 4-5 Islands in the game. Each Island is broken into into sections, about 8 or so. The islands differ in appearance for example a snow island or a desert island. But each section on the island is pretty indistinguishable from the others on the same island. From what I could see each island has about 4-5 different kinds of enemies including the boss. The enemies very only slighty from island to island.

You start with a set of 3 mechs and drop down onto the first island. You beat 5 sections (each section is a single fight) then you fight the boss section. The goal of each section is to survive a certain amount of turns and protect the buildings. The buildings represent the power grid of each island and each time a building is hit the power grid decreaes. When it runs out you lose. There are also bonus missions like kill a certain number of enemies or protect some building or whatever. Each of these side mission wil either give you more power for the grid, island reputation, which you use to purchase upgrades for your mech at the end of each island, or you get an extra power slot for your mechs. After that you move onto the second island, then the thrid, then the fourth. After you beat the fourth island you move onto the final island. You do 2-3 fights on that island then you win. As I said this all took about an hour for me to do. You can choose one of your pilots to move on then you do another run which is the same exact thing on the same exact islands. 

The only way to make one run distinguishable from another is the set of mechs that you use. There are 8 sets of 3 mechs. So 24 mechs total. Each set is unlocked by doing achievements with your current set to earn coins that you use to purchase another set. All the sets seem to have a theme about them. For example one set focuses on shielding and another on fire. Each of the 3 mech in the set have different weapons and abilities. This is actually where the game shines the most. Some mechs fire a missle or a laser other mechs might not even do damage to enemies but simply push or pull them. This is the most fun part of the game, using strategy to figure out how to defeat the enemies with your mechs. You can buy upgrades or new weapons for the mechs at the end of each island and use the mech power slots to use them. However the upgrades and different weapons are not interesting. Never have I seen a weapon or upgrade in the shop that i thought was better than what the default equipment is. The upgrades for things like health are pretty limited. Each mech starts out with around 2-3 health and by the end of the run you can only increase it by 2. You can also only increase damage by 1 point most of the time.

Unlike FTL there are no random events or diffenent paths you can take that make each run unique. The only random thing that happens is a pod that sometimes drops in battle. The pod carries weapons, pilots, etc.

I think with more locations, more enemy variety, and something like events to spruce up each run would break up some of the monotony of sameness in each run.

That being said the game looks amazing. The mechs, the enemies, the menus, and especially the ui. Hovering over an enemy shows you exaclty what it is going to do and where, hovering over an ability gives you an example of how that ability works.

It's really good. It's a very interesting take on a turn-based combat game that's very much in the style and comfort zone of Subset Games. The menus and the loading screen are all very familiar.

The gameplay so far is very fun. It's never tedious and you can continue to find new ways to deal with the Vek my ways of mech upgrades, new pilots, new weapons, etc. There are lots of different ways to tackle each stage, and it's always interesting, despite all the stages being the same size, and them re-hashing old stages later on. ie: blow up the dam 2-3 times during a play through.

Somehow this doesn't seem to take away from the core gameplay (yet). I would like to see more stages of varying size, and a greater bestiary of enemies to deal with. Some larger and more difficult bosses could really add to this game.

It's a great game, and as a big fan of FTL, I'm certain I will get my money's worth out of this title. As it is now, I don't believe it has the replay value of FTL yet, but neither did FTL until the Advanced Edition came along.

These are great devs, and they look after their products with patches and expansions. You won't be disappointed with ITB.

40614522.review: Into the Breach is an instant classic in turn-based strategy.  Each battle is on an 8-by-8 grid, with the player reacting to the enemy monster's intended attacks.  There are almost no random rolls involved in resolving the player's plan, and the various mechanics and tile modifiers are presented as transparently as possible by the UI.  Many of the player's actions manipulate the enemy placement on the battlefield, and this can lead to engagingly complex scenarios.  There's nothing quite like being in dire straits and then seeing the one move that miraculously prevents catastrophe.  Other times you have to grimly choose between failing your objective, letting civilians die (too much of this and game over), or sacrificing your pilots.  Individual campaigns are not terribly long, but for replayability there are a total of 8 unlockable squads, along with the ability to use a custom squad from the 24 available mechs.

40613800.review:
This game might or will be yet another case of a game that hype train will do more bad than good and might even bring some hate bandwagon coming.
It is not bad at all and gameplay idea and execution are excellent - small tactical turn-based strategy, where you obliterate enemies while using mechs or envintorment is really fun and with small maps being randomly generated, it gives a lot of replay value. It feels like a great puzzle game.
That aspect of the game is perfectly executed, but there are issues, sadly.
Weaponry is pretty disappointing and instead of being a progression, many of them feel rather arbitrary or extremely situational (like one use per battle), same goes for other upgrade thingies.
Speaking of upgrade, upgrade system is extremely limited, it feels almost half-baked. If you want to upgrade your mech, you need [strike]pokeball[/strike] cores, that cost 3 reputation points. Without perspective, it doesn't sound like much, but if you consider you can make 9-10 points per island on your best run, you can buy 3 cores. It wouldn't be so bad if not for the fact that with those 3 cores you will unlock +1 damage or some HP or +1 move for only one mech, and you have 3 of them. And that power is also necessary for weapons, too, so if you want to get new weapon (or any weapon for your mech, because there are types that don't have weapons) it makes upgrade system feel unbalanced. Upgrade doesn't feel like in FTL, where you got more power and kicked so much butt with your lazors of death and felt like da boss, because you upgraded. Here, resources are sparse, and most upgrades are situational or downright pointless (like a rocket that you can use only once per battle and requires 2-3 cores to run - now, how the heck you're supposed to work with that in the beginning or why would you want in the first place might be a good questions to be asked).
It's hard to explain to someone who didn't play it, but imagine RPG game which takes forever to level up, attribute points are extremely sparse and new abilities cost a lot. Or you go to the shop with nickel only to find out there are things mostly for a dime. Or imagine playing through entire FTL with 1 or 2 upgrades to your power meter.
Also, there are only 4 islands + 1 final boss island that you unlock once you beat 2 out of 4 islands. Why would you bother to beat all 4, when the final boss scales anyway? You could say for fun, but others might say why waste time - it would be like in FTL in sector 2 getting a warp straight to sector 8 and being able to beat the boss with your peashooter, because it scales to your level. It just doesn't matter.
It also misses some quality of life things, like for example repair - instead of just clicking repair and ending move of that unit, you have to click repair, chose that unit to repair and then it does it. Why is it made that way, when you can't heal other units, only yourself, I don't know. Other weird situation you might be in is killing enemies before time runs out - when you kill all enemies and have one turn left, instead of game ending the match automatically, because you killed everything, you still have moves to do or press end turn to end it. It is little rough around the edges.
Also, game lies to you - it says that when you will get power beyond grid meter, grid shield gets permanent upgrade, which is complete bull. It is not permanent - or rather, it is permanent, but only in the session you're already playing, meaning when your all dudes die, you loose that bonus.

Thankfully, the game just launched, so there is hope the game will get more balanced and get some more content (like more islands, weapons). 
Mechs are fun and varied, story is non-existent pretty much like in FTL, but most important part, the gameplay, is great It's not worth 10, or even 9, but 8/10 sounds good enough. If they will work out all of the issues with balance and upgrade system, this game will be another smash hit.

40612594.review:
[h1]Overview[/h1]
Into the Breach is a thought provoking turn-based strategy that feels almost like chess. This game manages to do away with as much RNG as possible while still retaining enjoyable procedural generation. The theme of trying to save the world is created well by the graphics and music. The graphics make even these large mechs appear diminutive and part of a larger mission. The music is solemn and forlorn, reminding the player that the fate of humanity rests on their shoulders.

[h1]Game Breakdown[/h1]
[u]Gameplay:[/u]
The gameplay consists of using three mechs to defeat large insects known as Vek. It is the player’s job to kill, push, pull, and zap the Vek. Combat is performed on a grid-based map comprised of cites, environmental objects such as mountains, and sometimes an optional objective. Combat is really smooth and feels quite rewarding. What makes it so unique is that the Vek will show how they will attack first and then the player is able to react to them. It is all the more painful to know that one has already failed instead of ever having a chance. The grid-based map is also what gives the game its chess like qualities. It is important to protect these cities as they are important to the overall meta-game.

It is important that the Vek don’t destroy any city buildings as each on that is annihilated reduces the player’s power supply. Power supply is what keeps the player’s mechs moving. If it hits zero then the player loses as they can no longer defend against the Vek horde. Power is also a constant between missions and all of the islands where missions are held. This makes a player really think about how much power they are willing to let be destroyed so that optional objectives can be completed. Don’t worry, power can be regained through completing optional objectives and buying it using reputation earned at each island. 

The four islands each have a different theme that makes their battlefield unique. One island has pools of acid on random tiles that will lower the defense of any mech or Vek that stands in it. When an island is completed then the reputation points the player has gained by completing optional objectives may be spent on weapons, reactor cores which upgrade mechs and their weapons, and power to fill a player’s power supply. Unwanted weapons and pilots can also be sold to make reputation. This system once again reinforces the fact that players must make difficult decision on whether they want to finish optional objectives to buy something, or instead complete the main objective only without power damage.

Mechs can be run by the AI, but it is best to have an actual human pilot. Pilots gain experience and level up performing actions during combat. Abilities gained from level ups are randomly generated, so finding the best mech pilot is part of the fun. There are also unique pilots who have special powers and have their own dialogue to flesh out their characters. One of these unique pilots is available at the start of every “run” and more can be unlocked later. Pilots can be lost however as they die when a mech’s hp reaches zero. 

Mechs come in different classes and are better with different weapons. An example would be that flying mechs are able to traverse water tiles without having their weapons disabled. There are eight teams of mechs, seven of which can be unlocked, each with their own unique strengths and weaknesses. These mech teams each have their own set of challenges which provide coins used to buy new mech squads. Each mech starts out with one weapon and can equip a second one. These weapons may require power or may only have a set amount of uses. 

Most weapons will either be gained by buying them with reputation or picking up time pods that randomly appear on mission. Mechs and the weapons equipped on them can then be upgraded with power that is installed using the aforementioned reactor cores. These upgrades can range from simple damage upgrades to providing entirely new functions to weapons. The mech customization is the part of the game I had the most fun with. Into the Breach gives the players lots of choices, and choosing which mech gets the extra power can make or break a run

Overall, Into the Breach is an amazing turn-based strategy that is a must buy for any fans of the genres. While the game creates a lot of choices for the player to make, every single one of them feels impactful. Finding a crazy solution to a mission is one of the most satisfying gameplay experiences I’ve had in a while.

[u]Story:[/u]
The story is one of time travel. The distant future was destroyed by the Vek, so our brave mech pilots must travel to the past, or “Breach”, to defeat the Vek as they just start to appear. While the story isn’t fleshed out very much, it creates a great theme for the game which every other part of the game supports. The desperate struggle for humanity’s future isn’t a unique plot, but it creates a great, solemn atmosphere 

[u]Sound:[/u]
The sound of this game’s weapons are satisfying to use and aren’t obnoxious. The sound design for the enemies is where Into the Breach really shines. Each enemy has a different set of sounds that all sound so perfectly insectoid. The sound really makes the Vek feel like living creatures that would scare anyone who saw them. The music is another sound aspect that is well designed. It is solemn and reminds the player of the importance of their actions.

 [u]Graphics:[/u]
The graphical style is pixel art and it works very well. Due to the scale of the Vek and the mechs, we are given a zoomed out version of the world so there isn’t much detail on each individual object. Mechs and different Vek are easily recognizable however and I never felt confused. The graphics are quite static though, which I didn’t find a problem but it may be for some. The mechs don’t have unique animations for each weapon or attack. A pushing attack may have a mech’s graphic slam into a Vek without a lot of motion. The idle animations of waiting units are pleasant and the graphical effects associated with weapons are also enjoyable.
 
[u]Performance:[/u]
The game ran great and there aren’t even any loading times. After selecting a mission, the play field zooms right in and there is no wait time. This fits with the theme of urgency but also is just satisfying to not have to wait constantly on loading screens.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[u]Pros:[/u]
Great Gameplay
Amazing Use of Theme
Fun Challenges
Diverse Mechs and Weapons
Lots of Meaningful Choices
Meaningful Meta-game

[u]Cons:[/u]
“Simple” Graphics

[u]Rating[/u]
[b]9/10[/b].

40610298.review:
[b][i]Review copy provided by developer[/i][/b]

I’ve come to realize that turn-based strategy is probably my favorite genre. It didn’t occur to me until recently, but my time spent with Invisible Inc, XCOM, Darkest Dungeon, and other slow-paced, cerebral titles accounts for some of my best gaming experiences. Now I can add Into the Breach to that hallowed list, not merely because it belongs next to other greats but because it helped me reach this realization. This is one of the few games I could easily play indefinitely, testing new permutations of strategy and risks thanks to an absolutely brilliant confluence of design.

The world has ended, and you have failed it. The monstrous insects known as the Vek have destroyed the last vestiges of humanity, but all is not lost for you can slip through temporal breaches into new timelines where there is still hope. Commanding a team of three pilots and their giant mechs, it’s up to you to stop the invasion you couldn’t stop before. As you save cities and islands from the crawling onslaught you’ll earn the trust and aid of corporations, offering you new weapons and upgrades to support your strikes against the invaders. Once you’ve secured enough resources you can take the battle to the Vek hive and attempt to save the timeline once and for all.

Of course, if you fail there are always other timelines. Into the Breach isn’t a roguelike but it has a similar structure, where every game has some slightly randomized elements due to existing in a new timeline. I’m always a fan of integrating story with game systems and the structure of saving or abandoning timelines as you work through new runs of the game is extremely clever. So too are the related systems like being able to carry a victorious pilot forward to the next timeline, or locating time pods during battles that contain valuable new resources for your efforts. The presentation here is top-notch, pitched and melancholy at just the right degrees, thanks to this unified foundation.

As genius as the premise is, it’s the gameplay that makes this one stand apart. Each mission takes place on a small, gridded battlefield between your three mechs and whatever the Vek can throw at you. All you have to do to win is survive usually five turns, after which the giant insects get so disheartened I guess they give up and go home. But it’s not just about your mechs surviving, because each map has buildings that form the local power grid. This grid is essentially your life bar, and if too many buildings are toppled by the monsters, you lose. New Vek burrow up from the ground almost every turn, too, so it’s imperative that you keep up with their attacks and find some way to counter them.

The thing is, you get to see attacks coming before they happen. At the beginning of each turn, the Vek make their moves and prepare to attack with giant mandibles or acid globs or whatever else they have cooking. After that, you get to use your three mechs to mitigate as much damage as possible to the grid, your objectives, and yourselves. It’s not a straight shootout either, because most weapons can push or pull enemies, too. Because of how enemies work and how short missions are, you’ll soon find most of your strategy revolves around moving enemies away from their targets rather than killing them. After all, you can move an attacking Vek next to another Vek to make them hit each other, or put something atop an emerging Vek to stop it from joining the fight, or just smash them into each other for extra damage.

This one brilliant twist is enough to give the game an entirely different complexion from most turn-based strategy. It becomes a puzzle game, where every turn you pore over your options trying to find the best use of your three mechs against the approaching chaos. In many missions you won’t be able to save everyone, leading to tough choices about what sacrifices to make. Losing grid puts you closer to failure, losing pilots can limit your tactical options, and losing objectives cuts down on your rewards. Staring at a turn for five or ten minutes and then finally figuring out the one safe path forward is an amazing feeling, and a big part of why this game succeeds in being so engrossing and gratifying. But it can also be stressful, and if you forget a key part of the situation or just end up trapped, that’ll be the end of that timeline and a few hours worth of work.

You’ll need to be prepared to fail now and then, especially with the game’s open-ended difficulty structure. Each run plays out over four islands, each carved into multiple sectors. Sectors have different objectives that earn you grid power or currency if completed, and the more objectives present the harder the mission. Once you’ve cleared two islands of the Vek menace you can opt to keep going, or attempt the final mission. If you keep clearing islands the final mission scales up, so the longer you go the more difficult it gets. Honestly it’s a great way to make the game accessible to everyone, and serves as a good counter to the disappointment of losing a long or promising timeline. And I need to mention the dozen or so mech squads you can unlock through achievements, each so unique in its design that you’ll hardly have any idea how to triumph with them until you try them out.

The struggle plays out in rich, clean pixel art reminiscent of the old Advance Wars games in the best way. You’ll never have trouble seeing what’s going on even when maps are burning, sinking, exploding, and melting all at once. The UI is just as clean, putting all the information you need right at your fingertips and featuring an incredibly clear and useful turn order list to help you plan your moves. The sound design is up to the task as well, though the soundtrack isn’t quite as catchy as I was hoping in the wake of FTL. But what a minor complaint that is in light of how much this game gets right. Into the Breach has built an absolutely captivating system of strategy that manages to be thought-provoking and challenging without being the least bit confusing. Mastering the game is an exquisite joy from start to finish, and anyone with even a passing interest in mech tactics owes it to themselves to give it a try.

As a strategy game, Into The Breach offers some incredible depth in remarkably bite-sized chunks, and is easily a contender for one of 2018’s best games.

The creation of the folks behind 2012’s roguelike FTL, Subset Games has once again hit paydirt with this tactical, tense, and enjoyable concoction of a game. Into The Breach challenges you to make the correct decisions with all the information available to you, and success or failure is all your own doing. There’s nothing quite like making the player acutely aware of their strengths and weaknesses when it comes to a strategy-heavy joint.

The backstory is relatively simple. Extraterrestrial invaders known as the Vek have infested our world, and it is up to you and your trio of time-traveling mechs to dispense some justice. Battles take place on a small 8x8 grid, populated by important buildings, hazards, and natural impediments.

The Vek wants to destroy these buildings, which power you up, while you must do your best to protect them. Simple stuff, really.

But what is not simple is the persistence that carries over from battle to battle, island to island (four in total, and one more for the end boss). The power grid stays constant, while the difficulty, terrain, and species of monsters change up, forcing you to be on your toes at all times. Lose all power and you start again, with the caveat that you get to bring over a pilot (that is hopefully useful) to the next campaign.

Yes, there are certain side objectives in addition to killing all invaders that can reward you with power, reputation or reactor cores (which can be used for purchasing upgrades and such). However, it is always a risk to pursue them.

Do you take the brunt of damage to save a building, or sacrifice it to land the killing blow on an annoying, acid spitting foe? With a variety of mechs in different squads at your disposal, the options to deal with the threats in Into The Breach are substantial.

There are mechs that damage, some with abilities to teleport and heal, and some which can push or pull enemies from across the grid. Partner these with pilots with unique abilities of their own, and the potential is vast.

There is always an inherent risk of a wrong move leading to an unstoppable avalanche of damage that can cost you both a vital mech and a seasoned pilot. You truly have to master all the abilities to minimize the loss in each battle.

The Vek can be repelled by outrightly damaging them, pushing them into water/lava, smashing them against each other, or simply stop them from spawning by having your mechs occupy spawning points.

Each battle is a chess game, albeit with the enemy movement made transparent to you. The sense of predictability is only overshadowed by the helplessness that can sometimes occur. While the enemy makes the first move, they stay committed as you plan yours.

Time and planning will help you make the best decisions in order to stave off their relentless assault, especially when you factor in environmental hazards. Lightning can strike, lava will spew, and tidal waves can wash away precious squares for movement, all which happen in a set order that you can check. If you can survive a certain number of turns, the battle is yours as the Vek beat a hasty retreat.

With the wealth of information at your fingertips, the only deciding factor, oftentimes, is you and you alone. There are no hidden surprises or secrets, and no unfair difficulty spikes.

You know exactly what went wrong on your first or hundredth run, Into The Breach is painfully honest like that. And as a gamer, it can bring utter joy or downright disappointment as you venture towards ending the Vek threat.

Into The Breach is a game both about the future and the past. As you plan out each move to counter each action of the enemy, you can be blessed or haunted by your past actions in previous battles carried forward. It requires you to be fully tuned for the duration of each one to two-hour run, and to cut your losses and savor the victories when you can.

This is a hard game, but only if you do not learn. It is a cycle of failure, learning, and hopefully, leading to success, and is utterly irresistible to pass on. Into The Breach is a perfect strategy game in manageable portions that you don’t ever want to stop playing.

Just finished this game yesterday. Not 100% though, good luck with that. 

In many ways this game is similar to FTL. It's like subset games took random elements of FTL and put them in different places. For example, the ship power is now mech power.
1 ship in FTL is equivalent to 3 mechs in the sense that the starting choice you make influences how you tackle missions, which missions you take and what upgrades you buy. The segmented damage bar of the ships now applies to everything. The art style is the pretty much the same which is a plus in my opinion. The music is the same but not as impactful. Heck there's even a final boss that's split into phases.

[u] Gameplay [/u] 

It is fun and very tactical, but to some the novelty might wear off after a while. It gets better as you unlock more mech squads due to the sheer variety of approaches each squad provides. Mech abilities can be combined in interesting ways either in combination with the environment or the placement of enemies/allies. Every squad I have unlocked so far plays differently and takes a while to get used to. 
In terms of difficulty Into the Breach can really be a pain in the ass. I don't know if the emergence of the Vek each turn is random or if there's a pattern to it but sometimes the right Vek spawning at the wrong time can spell doom for you and your crew.
I think the comparisons to Chess in other reviews are pretty apt but Chess has more justice to it. In Chess everything is there for you to see and if you miss a tactic or combination it's your own fault.

[u] Music [/u] 

It's a shame as there are a couple of really great tracks and I like the style of Ben Prunty's music but it just doesn't have the same weight. Every track in FTL is identifiable and has a unique character to it. In Into the Breach sometimes the music isn't even playing, whilst your sitting there visualising your plan in silence, although this might be a bug (literally).

One of the innovative things they have done is to make the achievements you get tie in with the gameplay. Achievements earn you coins which allow you to purchase more mech squads. 

[u] Summary [/u]

I like the fact that you could run this game on pretty much anything, the file size is tiny and it only requires a mouse/trackpad to play. Also, you definitely get your money's worth. £11 is great for the amount of depth Into the Breach has. Overall I'd recommend it and if you like unlockables or you're a completionist then go for it.

40605339.review:
感谢奶牛关与野蔷薇给予的游戏key及评测机会。https://cowlevel.net/
原文图文链接：https://cowlevel.net/game/Into_the_Breach
由于评测字数所限，下面内容仅为冰山一角，建议点击上方图文链接。


        《Into the Breach》是一款科幻题材的游戏作品。其故事主要讲的是，人类在面对地下繁殖的巨大生物的威胁之时，现有的科技似乎无能为力。而玩家则是从未来穿越而来的救星，驾驶着未来的机甲拯救不同时间线的地球。

        这款游戏是《Faster than light》的开发商Subset games的新作。玩家将在游戏中体会到不一样的战棋玩法和烙有Subset games印记的Roguelite游戏风格。各方评价非常之高，IGN甚至给出了9分的高分。

        那这款备受瞩目的佳作到底牛在哪呢？请允许我评测一番吧~

        一开始，当听说《Faster than light》的开发商Subset games制作了一款战棋游戏，我是震惊的。他们的新作居然从Roguelite转战战棋游戏，这几乎相当于转行了。而由于《Faster than light》的优秀素质，让我对这款游戏充满了别样的期待——这款作品到底是像核心战棋《火焰纹章》系列呢，还是像以刷刷刷和收集要素为最大玩点《魔界战记》系列呢？而最后，我发现，嗯，虽说形式变成了战棋，但还是最像《Faster than light》那一套玩法——Roguelite。

        我个人认为，Roguelite的核心无非就是亮点：1）每次进入游戏都是全新的随机场景。2）每次探索Game over之后都能带一点点遗物回来。而这两点，要做进战棋，可不容易。一方面，战棋游戏的节奏非常缓慢，若是玩家花上半个小时玩上一关，第二关你告诉他“对不起你死了，你只能带走一点点的遗物，然后从头开始玩吧！”那基本离被退款也不远了。另一方面，战棋游戏对战场布局和棋子落位有时有着较高的要求，这玩意做成随机了，如果像魔界战记的支线那样刷刷刷倒还好，主线可该怎么控制进程？

1）简化战斗过场动画与技能
        虽然是机甲大战异形的题材，但是《Into the Breach》重点很明确：我不是卖机设的，我是卖游戏性的。像《机器人大战》系列那样繁杂的战斗动画与特技，在《Into the Breach》中是找不到的。千万不要小看玩家在战棋类游戏中，选择棋子技能所消耗的决策时间。这种类似《口袋妖怪与信长野望》的战斗设计，使《Into the Breach》的节奏提升了很多。

2）摒弃RPG要素与刷刷刷
        虽说《Into the Breach》的战斗动画比较接近于《口袋妖怪与信长野望》，但其游戏整体节奏还是要比后者快上不少。这是因为在《Into the Breach》中，没有刷刷刷，没有收集要素。玩家在每局游戏中，只能线性地向前进发，没有回头路与重复关卡，我们只能依靠策略最大化使用靠着自己的运气捡到的那些道具，和最大化关卡奖励。而这，也使得这款作品看上去充满了Roguelite的味道。

3）简化地图场景
        《Into the Breach》的地图非常的小，而且没有那些复杂的地图高度、角色站位面向设定。哪怕是游戏的最后一关，数了数，也就8*8大小的格子。这样的地图可以直接免去战棋游戏中常见的布阵“前戏”。一旦开始这一关的内容，恐怕第一回合就要的短兵相接，直接战的死去活来。这种设定在战棋游戏中非常少见。

4）简化棋子数量
        在《Into the Breach》中，玩家大多数情况下几乎只能操作3个友军。而这使得每回合的战棋操作数大大降低。试想一下，要是动辄20个棋子的战棋关卡，我方布局每个棋子哪怕只需要6秒，那也要整整120秒才能进行一个回合。而假如一关要15回合，光我方的操作就要占据半小时。而这其实是战棋类游戏慢节奏的主要因素之一。但假如只有3个棋子要动呢？操作节奏可以快上10倍。

5）简化HP值
        《Into the Breach》恐怕是我见过这么多战棋游戏中，唯一一款HP值都在个位数的游戏。这使的游戏中的击杀非常的迅速，这也使得这款游戏玩起来有种不是你死就是我活的快感。而且由于地图场景中有一些即死场景，这样的话，对敌人的击杀就更迅速了。

6）简化回合数
        以上种种微创新，使得这款游戏的每回合战斗，很可能在一两分钟之内就结束了。但是，为了使得《Into the Breach》能跟上Roguelite核心思想的节奏，仅仅这样的优化恐怕还是不够。于是，《Into the Breach》做出了一项非常重要的设定，将战棋游戏中常见的“20回合内结束战斗”改成了大多数情况下“5回合内结束战斗”。这样，每一关的游戏时间几乎就不可能超过20分钟了。

小结
        正因为做了以上种种出乎意料又情理之中的微创新，《Into the Breach》才能将每一关的通关时间限制在了10分钟左右。而其每一章也就5关左右，一共也就4个章节加两个额外关卡。掐指一算，完整一个周目的时间恐怕也就200分钟。这使得《Into the Breach》就完全进入了其Roguelite内核的游戏节奏之中了。

Parfois, tu lances un jeu, & plus tu avances, plus tu hallucines sur le souci du détail & la perfection du moindre élément de gameplay. C'est rare. Je crois que la dernière fois que j'avais éprouvé ce sentiment c'était sur Inside. 

Into the breach rentre clairement dans cette catégorie. Mélangeant des éléments de roguelike à un tactical tour par tour à la advance war, il offre une expérience unique, ou chaque tour de jeu est un casse tête savament dosé pour se sortir d'une situation qui parait mal engagée. La force du jeu réside dans la grande lisibilité de son interface & le choix des devs de laisser le joueur réagir aux attaques de l'adversaire. Tous les effets & dégats sont connus à l'avance, il n'y a aucun hasard dans la résolution d'un tour de jeu. On est toujours confronté à des choix complexes ; prendre de la "vie" pour pas crever enc cas de coup dur, ou de la "puissance" pour avoir de mal sur les prochaines map ; éliminer 3 des 4 monstres présents à l'écran, mais laisser le 4° taper un batiment, ou n'en tuer qu'un seul, protéger les civils, mais prendre le risque d'être débordé au tour suivant... 

Le jeu est rapide ; une bataille dure 5 tours, si vous réfléchissez plus vitre que moi ça peut être bouclé en 5 minutes. 

Là où FTL reposait sur beaucoup (trop) de hasard, Into the breach semble toujours vous laisser une issue & n'est jamais frustrant ou punitif. Les 3 niveaux de difficultés permettent à n'importe qui de s'y lancer, & je pense que c'est vraiment un jeu à faire, que ce soit votre style de jeu ou non (comme il faut jouer à Inside, même si vous n'aimez pas les plateformers). 

A la fin de votre première partie, vous vous direz "ho lalala mais c'est dingue toutes ces possibilités". Et vous n'aurez vu que 3 mecs sur les 27 que compte le jeu, tous avec des armes offrant un gameplay radicalement différent. 

La bande son de Ben Prunty est parfaite. Tout est parfait dans ce jeu. Foncez.

不愧是FTL制作组成员的新作品，一上手颇有停不下来的感觉。作为一个独立团队，又一次打磨出了新的精品。

游戏的背景是一队未来机甲战士传送到过去尚未被虫族占领的地球。作为指挥官的你将指挥机甲保护人民和电力设施[spoiler] 红色警戒/误[/spoiler]。最后逐渐提升机甲的性能并且毁灭虫子们的老巢。[spoiler] 当然，大部分时候是你断电了然后任务失败...[/spoiler]

如果FTL的难易度是8/10的话，这款游戏难易度我给6.5/10。这并不表示每关的难度会降低，仅仅是因为在将地图清理掉一半的时候就可以打boss了，不像FTL一局要打很长时间。作为一个xcom玩家来说，这个游戏风格很熟悉，因为都是要保护地球，[strike] 只可惜这个世界里的地球只剩下四个没被海水淹没的小岛了[/strike]。

This game is a 10/10 in my books, and after owning it for a day and sinking into it a solid 4-5 hours ish let me tell you why, by the end of this month I expect that to be closer to 50, if not 100 hours played. 

The story is simple, a group of time travelling pilots in mechs jump back in the timeline in an effort to save humanity from a bug menace emerging from underground (yay, squashing bugs, starship trooping done right). As long as you protect the power grid and fight your way through many varied bonus objectives with a nigh -on- endless amount of gear to find, pilots to save, styles to build, enemies to fight, and elements to weather you find yourself getting ever closer to saving humanity, at least in this timeline. 

Instantly the replayability is off the charts, comparable to slay the spire, or the binding of isaac, a game that once I start playing I don't want to put down. Run ended great? SWEET what new mech group can I unlock? or what new pilot did I save that run? Let's go test them out? Run ended bad? Man this play I made inadvertantly cost me my run, or this one thing I didn't realize was going to happen cost me because I was rushing, or I didn't use this piece of information correctly and it bit me in the behind. Let me dive right back in there and go again.

The game rewards and calls to the player that wants to try to improve themselves with each run, while at the same time discovering new techniques, units, and abilities that are an unlock addict's (such as myself) wet dream. It is the perfact marraige of solid gameplay, tactical soundness, having all the pieces laid out before you to puzzle out while at the same time doom is ticking above reminding you that this world needs you.

And the soundtrack. It feels so...nostalgic and fresh. I wish i could purchase it myself and put it on my phone, but alas I'm poor. There is this overwhelming comfort that hits me right in the chest while playing this game. The mixture of the beautifully tailored mechs, lush enemies, and perfectly performed music strikes a resonating chord with every part of me. At times it almost feels like I'm being pulled into something from my past but at the same time being thrown against something new and exciting. 

Should you get this game? Yes. 
There is little more I can say.

The best and worst part of this game is that it's extremely fair.

There's virtually no RNG that you cannot plan around. No 95% chance to hit that misses your enemy. You can see what your enemy's next turn is so there's no need to try to outguess the computer. You can come up with intricate, multi-stage plans and have them go off perfectly to decimate your enemies. I also suspect the AI behaves in a 'fair' manner (in particular if there are more than 3 enemies, it looks like only the first 3 enemies prioritize attacking buildings). Having played many tactics games, all of that feels great.

The only issue is that the game can feel somewhat bland, because once you understand the systems you generally don't run into any particular challenges due to it being so fair. It's fun, but the highs and lows are also muted. As much as I enjoy the game, I think that's probably what may cause this game to have somewhat lower replay value; as long as you, the player, don't screw up, you should be able to win pretty much every run.

40595499.review:
Для такой игры как Into The Breach 10 часов не показатель, но первыми впечатлениями поделиться хочется.

Все пока указывает на то, что игра - шедевр калибра Faster Than Light. То есть это довольно крупный калибр, миллиметров эдак 460, как главное орудие на линкоре "Мусаси". И эта пушка системы Subset Games оставит гигантскую пробоину в свободном времени любого человека, который сядет в нее поиграть. Одно прохождение может длиться всего час или два, и игра дает возможность как растянуть удовольствие, так и спасти мир в формате fast food, но, как и в FTL, соль тут не в каком-то одном прохождении. Into The Breach хватает за душу и держит крепко своим бесконечно вариативным игровым процессом.

Пройдя ее один раз на легком уровне сложности, игрок не испытывает обычного чувства законченного дела, эдакой "проставленной галочки", позволяющей забыть об игре и двигаться дальше. Вместо этого прохождение побуждает игрока пройти ее снова, но теперь уже не ради "просто победы", а ради достижений! А также ради новых пилотов! А также ради новых мехов! А также секретных мехов! И секретных пилотов! А также в качестве вызова самому себе. На Easy спасти мир каждый может, а ты Hard попробуй... Вообще достижения и способы открытие нового контента сделаны в Into the Breach прекрасно. Они вызывают у игрока интерес, азарт и кураж, но не фрустрацию и скуку. Общий подход перекочевал сюда из FTL, но по дороге набрал scrap-а и здорово прокачался. В Into The Breach открываемый контент не привязан к конкретным достижениям, что делает его приобретение максимально удобным. Он как бы покупается за энную сумму ваших успехов. Больше нет нужды мучить один и тот же космический корабль... ой, в смысле, отряд мехов, чтобы открыть следующий за ним. Разблокируй тот, что больше нравится - и в бой! Очень гуманно. 

Что лично меня особенно удивило здесь, так это то, что разработчикам удалось сделать сухой и "математичный" игровой процесс действительно увлекательным. Мне вот, например, никогда не нравились шахматы. Перебирать варианты ходов для ферзя или пешки, по-моему, ужасно скучно и утомительно. И уж конечно во мне никогда не возникало желания сесть и попробовать решить какой-нибудь шахматный этюд или задачу, опубликованную в газете или журнале. Однако, когда в ходе схватки с кайдзю после десяти минут тяжелых раздумий мне вдруг пришла в голову идея выстрелить по своему меху, складывая таким образом идеальную победную комбинацию, ко мне пришла еще одна догадка. Ба-а! Да это же просто бесконечный генератор шахматных задач, но только с сюжетом, гигантскими монстрами, реактивными кулаками и перемещениями во времени!

Представьте теперь, какой простор для развлечений и размышлений открывает для игрока этот "генератор задач", где игрок заранее из приличного запаса подбирает себе наборы местных "слонов" и "коней", которые можно модернизировать по ходу игры («рокировку» там усилить…), которые неповторимым образом сочетаются друг с другом... и которые, не смотря на пиксельную графику и абстрактные способности, по-прежнему воспринимаются как могучие боевые роботы, организующие восход солнца вручную. Чудесным образом игра всегда остается живой и настоящей, чему способствуют сотни мелких и милых деталей. Простой пример: вместе победных очков в Into The Breach подсчитываются спасенные жизни. И исполнив умопомрачительную комбинацию, счищающую толпу чудовищ вокруг здания с кричащими людьми ты чувствуешь себя не просто хорошим игроком, но величайшим пилотом, который даст прикурить любому герою из фильмов про больших роботов. [i]"Нет, вы видели, как этот придурок швырнул кайдзю в небоскреб?! Там же люди! Да кто тебя так воевать учил???"[/i]

Игра: [b]10 спасенных небоскребов из 10[/b]
Саундтрек: [b]10 Milky Way (Explore) из 10[/b]

How long do I take to unlock all squads?
- It took me around ~47h to unlock all achievements / squads (I still don't have all hidden pilots)

So, once I unlocked everything, is the motivation gone?
- You can randomly roll squads or create your own custom squad. Unlocking everything just means you're free to experiement more!

Does it get repetitive?
- It's fun for a very long time, but one can't deny that battles do become repetitive at some point as 8x8 grids offer only just so many possible combinations. Also the enemy variety is limited since a lot of them are just the same enemies with slightly stronger abilities.

Is it frustrating?

Conclusion:
Definetely worth it's money. It's a great and unique concept, even though it also has a lot of room for improvements.

40595118.review:
Other tactical games often feel like they have so much going on that it's mentally exhausting to remember everything - every unit's abilities, which get steadily more complex over time, ranges, where each enemy unit is and what they are capable of. Mistakes are usually caused by a simple lack of RAM in my brain, or forgetting something and making a mistake.

In Into the Breach, everything is always 100% clear. What your enemies will do, what they can do, where they will emerge next turn - what your abilities do. Thanks to hyper-polished UI and the stripping away of absolutely all and any fat from the system's bones, what's left is simply you and your brain to figure out the best solution with the tools that you have.

As a result, a single mission might take five minutes. An entire campaign could easily be finished in an hour. In XCOM, a single mission can take an hour, and leave you feeling bloated, like a heavy meal. In Into the Breach, missions feel like finger food - you have one, you have another, and you have another. They're delicious and you can stop at any time, feeling satisfied.

Did I mention the unlockables? Every unlockable squad completely changes your toolset. What's brilliant is how each different squad, and the achievements associated with it, teach you new tactics. I wouldn't have fully-upgraded my Swap Mech unless it had been tied to an achievement - but when I did, I realised just how ridiculously powerful it was. With the Iron Judoka, I was forced to rely on using enemy's attacks against each other. After using them, I spot all kinds of opportunities to have enemies efficiently kill each other.

The achievements themselves give you coins to unlock new mech squads. You can play with the preset squads, built around a certain tactic, or make a squad of custom or random mechs. You have so much control to customise how you play, giving endless opportunities for silly challenge runs, which become so much more appealing with how fast the game plays. You don't even have to play every map in a campaign - once you're halfway done, you can immediately go to the ending, or complete the rest of the maps. It feels like the developers just lifted the arbitrary restrictions and said "play how you want - it's your free time".

If you found FTL to be impossibly hard, or if you are often turned off by the complexity of normal tactical games - give this game a try. If you also love the heavier tactical games like XCOM but fancy something you can fit into a lunch break, this might also be up your alley. For me, Into the Breach is infinitely worth the price point - and I'd love to see even more content in the form of DLC or an expansion.

This has rapidly become one of my favourite strategy games. Not of the year, but overall. No worries about micromanagement or crit-chances, you get damn near complete knowledge of just what will happen and how. There's not an overwhelming amount of information, it's been pared down very finely. 

At the same time, there's a great deal more depth than is readily apparent. Initially limited choices like where to deploy actually have a bit of subtle strategy, weapons interact with different spaces in clever but logical ways (fire turns out to melt ice faster than normal, for instance), and the moderately limited variety of starting setups is enhanced by the ability to customize or randomize squads to create more interesting challenges for yourself.

It's not replayable in the same way that FTL is replayable, but I think that those who I've seen criticize it on that front are missing some of the point. It's easy to drop in and out of Into The Breach, and to have success easily. It'd be simple to play it with a friend. I believe I saw the designers compare it to a boardgame, and I think that comparison is very apt. Even when I'm not playing ITB, it'll be sitting in my list of favourites, and I have no doubt that every so often I'll come back to it when I want a game that's simple enough to not overwhelm but deep enough to actually be fun.

Not that I'm done playing it right now, or expect to be done any time soon. I might have all the achievements, but there are some really stupid squad decisions I want to see how much I regret making, and a couple of personal goals, to boot.

40589849.review:
The short version of this review is that I really like a lot of things about Into the Breach, and really WANTED to like all of Into the Breach, but laziness in the design process was what knocked it from a potential long-time classic down into something I really only replayed for the soundtrack and to get my money's worth.

So, first off, what's good about this game?

The soundtrack and art are absolutely ON POINT. Ben Prunty delivers a damn good soundtrack like always and the artists did cool mech designs, character art and monster art. It really draws you in on all the levels you could expect the presentation to. The game is also good at communciating mechanics, what your actions will do, etc. the UI is very well-designed in general. What it shows is what you get, and every option and piece of info is easily accessed.

The core gameplay is also a really solid thing, both conceptually and execution-wise. You drop in your three mechs, you have three to five turns to preserve as many civilian buildings you can, as well as accomplishing various bonus objectives(protect this building for a reward, kill this many bad dudes, wreck this thing, stand here, etc.). To do this you've got a bunch of weapons that can move enemies around, damage them, move you around, inflict status effects or sometimes a combination of all three.

And when it works, it REALLY works. It's going to feel sweet when you line up the alien invaders in a way where a single shot will bop three of them into the water and drown them, or when you untangle a particularly twisty tactical puzzle in a way that pulls off a perfect save.

The problem, though, is randomness. Not so much the roguelike randomness, though there's a bit of that, in that the amount of rewards you get, and which, are extremely random(on any given mission you might randomly get a "time pod," and a couple of those early on can put you INCREDIBLY far ahead of the curve, because some of the weapon upgrades are MASSIVE power boosts. The game has no sidegrades, only upgrades. So you want these upgrades fast.), and that some maps play extremely well to certain teams and terribly for others(for instance, if you have one of the teams that has low damage, but many options for moving enemies, a map full of chasms and ponds to kill enemies with is a wonder. A totally flat map on the other hand screws you massively).

No, the problem is in the randomness of the enemy AI. Playing on anything but Easy(and even then, some of the time), you're going to have more than three enemies present. If four enemies decide to all pour on the same objective(or even civilian buildings, lose too many of those and you lose the game), and not helpfully bunch up in a way that lets you take out multiple of them with one hit? Then you've basically lost that objective with no recourse. On the other hand, if they all pour on one guy who can just side-step out of the way? Then they've given you a free turn to beat them around with.

The reason this is a problem is that enemy behavior is 100% random. There are no enemies that prioritize objectives over you, or vice versa, there are no maps where the enemy shows any awareness of the objectives and pursues them actively, etc. so the only way to prevent "unwinnable" turns is to always whittle the enemy down to less than your number... which you don't always get the option to. Again, because of randomness in the maps, in enemy spawns(are they all brick shithouses or flimsy 1-HP enemies? Totally random!), in the drops that determine your combat ability, etc.

For this game to get an upvote from me, it would've needed either a longer, hand-crafted campaign(so every mission was a genuine puzzle, set up with certain solutions, options and balancing) or actual enemy AI that prevented their completely RNG AI from sometimes making missions impossible and gave you another thing to take advantage of(thereby offering more tactical depth).

Oh, and speaking of RNG. Almost everything in Into the Breach is deterministic. An action will ALWAYS have a given outcome, a given amount of damage done, distance moved, etc. there are no hit and miss chances. Except for ONE thing, which is that when the enemy attacks a civilian building, it has a random chance to fail. I'm not sure why they kept this in.

So, yeah, long story short. Contains bad randomness, stupid AI that's somehow more pointlessly challenging than intelligent AI because it coughs up unwinnable scenarios sometimes, and a severe case of winning-gives-you-more-winning(i.e. you get more rewards for doing well, so a flubbed early mission or two can prevent an unwinnable run with little chance to turn it around, while doing really well early on can give you an unlosable run where you hardly even have to pay attention).

Really wish I could recommend the game, because there's obviously a lot of love poured into the design. Just wish there was as much love and effort poured into the gameplay.

40584173.review:
Into the Breach is an excellent game that straddles a couple core genres - isometric tactics games and puzzle games - with a "Humongous Mecha VS Giant Alien Bugs" theme and a simple low-fi graphics with moody sci-fi music aesthetic. It borrows from the devs' prior game FTL in some meta structure elements, namely how things unlock and the rogue-like elements that generate each game from partly pre-determined and partly randomized sets. 

The real hook here is the dedication to minimalism. While it at first appears to be fully a tactics game like XCOM or Fire-Emblem or the like, just with shorter 4 turn scenarios, the systems are all reduced to be very simple and easy to understand and there aren't that many variables you need to keep track of on a per turn basis. The end result is that the simplified tactics gameplay of each turn comes to resemble something a lot closer to a puzzle game than a traditional tactics game. By which I mean, there always seems to be a way to "solve" each turn so that you protect all civilian buildings, all objectives points, and take no lethal damage. 

The brilliant thing about that, if you think about it, is that this is actually true of all games in this genre. Into the Breach just highlights this fact extremely well because it's stripped away most of the fat (there's enough stuff in the game to play around with however - new equipment and characters and such that helps to create more gameplay variance). 

The game's narrative is likewise minimal, but it works. It's both minimizes a sense of loss, and also minimizes a sense of accomplishment. You're playing as a (at first) lone time traveler trying to save a doomed world, and when you die you just shift to a different timeline to try again. But when you succeed you . . . also shift to a different timeline to save another doomed world. It's great for an endlessly replayable game, but therein lies the rub. 

Because one of the problems here is that ITB probably isn't endlessly replayable for most people. There's meat here, but you can strip most of it away pretty quickly, and there's nothing (so far) that encourages endless play. If you really dig the game the variables will add extra time to that clock, but it didn't take me long, once I got past the initial difficulty cureve, to realize that the variations on the core themes are only going to go so far here. 

But overall and for the time you'll play the game, you're very likely to enjoy the heck out of it. So long as you enjoy either puzzle games or tactics games and want something medium sized to play for an hour or two at a time rather than a super long campaign or a quick coffee break diversion, it's a strong recommendation. Less so if you're not into those things, but it might be worth a gander if you want a good and simple intro to these types of games.

[h1]Introduction:[/h1]

Do not be fooled by what you see, into the beach is not a grid based tactical game, nor is it a roguelight. It is first and formost a puzzle game. Made by the developers of FTL, Into the Breach ascribes to many of the same design principles. Play with small numbers, make the mechanics known to the player, make multiple systems that while simple, interact with each other to provide a more complex experience. 

You play as a small squad of timehoppers, piloting advanced mechs in order to defeat the bug-like vex menace. Each turn the aliens will move, and you will see their attack actions. On your turn it's your job to reposition them to save civilian populance, or kill them outright.  In adition to shooting them for damage, you can knock them into other enemies for damage, knock them into damage tiles, drown them, even reposition them so they'll murder each other. 

[h1]Gameplay; [/h1]

The gameplay basics, just like FTL, are very simple. Putting them into action is often much more difficult. I call it a puzzle game because there's often only one "right" move you can possible make in order to save the grid (your lifebar) In addition to the starting enemies, you'll see the burrowing locations of enemy reinforcements, and you can delay or stop them outright by blocking them with either your mechs or other enemies. Each mission also has bonus objectives, from killing X amount of enemies, to using a terraformer device to make desert. There's special tiles that have different effects, like forests that can be set on fire, or ice blocks that be destroyed into water. The game can also be severly punishing. You often won't see a wrong move until the next turn happens and you're overwhelmed by the enemies. Unlike FTL there's very little free cruising: you're either barely scraping by with most or all the objectives complete, or you're dead. Your first couple of hours with the game will be brutal and unforgiving. Still, there's a lot of triumph when you manage to change what looks to be an impossible situation to shifting the tide in your favor.

[h1]Graphics [/h1]

The pixel-art aesthetic from FTL hasn't changed drastically, and still looks good on ITB. The animations are simple, the enemies (mostly) visually distinct from each other, and the UI is functional and shows pertinent information easily.

[h1]Sound [/h1]

The soundtrack is good, fans of FTL's soundtrack will like this game's. I don't know what else do say about it, other than it's less synth with more guitar and more oppressive in terms of feeling compared to FTL.


[h1]Conclusion [/h1]

Honestly, this game is incredibly stressful for me, probably because it actually requires good critical thinking and effective resource management. Unlike FTL, where your biggest enemy is RNG, in ITB the biggest enemy is you, the player for making bad mistakes. There's still a bit of RNG involved, unfortunatally I feel like way too much of the mission is decided on the success of your first turn, and enemies that web units tend to really fuck you up.  I want to again emphasize that ITB is a puzzle game. Fans of advanced wars, fire emblem, and all those other SRPG games will probably not find it as enjoybable, or may be expecting something completely different. 

 [h1]8 / 10 [/h1]
+Fairly Unique Gameplay
+Good Aesthetic
+Replayability  (Plenty of different weapons and mechs. acheivements, custom squads)
+Unlike FTL there's no gatekeeper that will destroy your run if you haven't been successful enough (No flagship equivlant)


-Small maps tend to make enemy movement ranged irrelevant
-Too much is determined by the started round
-Some mission objectives are absolutely awful
-Deep down we wanted a ftl-ish mech tactics game

[h1] 先上总评	[/h1]
评分：9/10
　　用位移代替攻击，给了《突破》不同于其他策略游戏的玩法与策略深度。再加上随机生成的战场、酷炫的机甲、还有种类繁多的敌人，你很快就会情不自禁地陷入其中无法自拔。在SLG日薄西山的今天，我很高兴还能看到这样一款小而精悍的游戏，它堪称是近几个月我发现的最大惊喜。

+丰富、有创意的玩法
+有挑战性的策略深度
+烧脑、硬核的游戏体验
+总想再来一局的魔性
+令人印象深刻的画面与音乐风格

[h1] 其实这是环太平洋！	[/h1]
　　《Into the Breach》（中文暂译名是《突破》）是此前大受好评的独立游戏《超越光速（FTL）》的工作室时隔六年推出的新作，同样也是一款带有Roguelike元素的回合制策略游戏。不过它把舞台从宇宙飞船搬到了一个近未来的世界，那时候人类正遭受可怕的外星虫族的袭击，已经到了差不多玩儿完的地步。为了扭转颓势，人们便派时空穿梭者回到过去，用巨大的机甲机器人抵抗虫族的入侵，并寻找机会，一举消灭这些可憎的虫子，拯救人类于水火。

　　所以，别看这个游戏只是像素画风，如果你脑补能力出众的话，甚至有种在体验“环太平洋”的感觉——反正这对于玩《精灵宝可梦：红蓝宝石》能脑补出盖欧卡和固拉多毁天灭地场景的我，并不是什么难事（￣▽￣）

　　你能控制的机甲只有三个，一般而言分为近战攻击单位、远程攻击单位和辅助单位这几种。你可以直接选用系统预制的机甲编队，它们通常也都隶属于同一种风格，比如陆军风格、机器人风格、或者黑科技武器风格等等。当然，你也可以自由地组合搭配，比如你不喜欢辅助单位，那就上三个攻击性比较高的机甲；又或者你想用高难度挑战自己，那就多选几个没有伤害技能的单位。

　　游戏总共准备了9组编队，共27种机甲可供自由组合——其中甚至包括一组隐藏的虫族编队，需要你达成成就才能解锁。这些机甲外形不同、定位不同、血量和移动力不同、武器和攻击方式也不同，可以说玩法相当的多样——就看你的脑洞和操作的意识能不能跟上了。

　　机甲多，而作为敌人的虫族种类更多。有会飞的，有会跳的，有远程的，有会大范围AOE的，有本身没有攻击力只会投掷支援单位的，还有给队友上Buff给你上Debuff的，简直令人眼花缭乱，让你不禁感叹人类被它们追着打不是没有道理的。你经常能在某一关发现几个之前从未见过的敌人，那就要小心了，记得提前看一看它们的攻击方式，否则你可能就前功尽弃了。

　　是的，《突破》是一个非常硬核的游戏，一旦Game Over，你之前积累的经验，升级的装备，购买的武器，全部会清零（除了收集到的驾驶员，可以在下次开始的时候选择一个使用）。游戏会判断你穿越回去的这条时间线人类失败了，于是你必须找到另一条时间线，从头开始。

　　游戏判断时间线失败的条件和一般游戏不同，不是说你的机甲在某一关被敌人打爆了你就失败了，而是电力值降到0才会宣布Game Over。电力是驱动机甲的动力，而它们是由城市这样的建筑来提供的。虫子如果破坏了太多的城市，你的机甲就会因为没有动力而失去作用，这条时间线也就救不回来了。

　　相比之下，机甲的生命就没有电力值重要，因为报废的机甲会在下一场战斗之前满血复活。只是坐在里面的驾驶员就回不来了，就像《火焰纹章》里角色死了之后就不能再用的“经典模式”那样。

　　综上所述，很多时候你都需要做出这样一个取舍：保机甲还是保建筑？如果你的电力值够多，如果你觉得这个驾驶员的能力在之后的关卡还有作用，你就可以大胆地战略放弃一些城市——反正电力值还可以通过完成任务目标或者直接购买的方式再拿回来；但如果你想得到更高的分数、或者因为电力值本来就不足，那也完全可以让自己的机甲去送死，来掩护城市的生存——毕竟，机甲是可以复活的。

　　比如，我个人就非常喜欢一种看上去有些莽撞的自爆式玩法（艺术就是爆炸！）。我会让一个经验值不高、血量也不高，却经常冲锋在前的单位，装备上一个自毁按钮。当有必要的时候，我会让它Boom Shakalaka，直接杀死所有十字范围内的敌人（当然，自己人也能杀死……）——哪怕是BOSS级的虫子，也是一击必杀。这种技能搭配，可以完成很多特殊的战略目标，也能在危急时刻起到一锤定音的效果。但是，它也是把双刃剑，如果掌握不好自爆的时机，就会让剩下两个机甲陷入被动；而大部分你可能不会选择自爆的关卡，就相当于让这个单位少装备了一个技能。

[h1] 8X8的战场	[/h1]
　　游戏里的战场只有8X8个像素方格，但就是这样一个看似不大的地图，却能让玩法和体验千变万化。游戏中所有的关卡都是随机生成的，这也是体现它Roguelike元素的地方之一。根据大地图风格的不同，你会看到平原、沙漠、雪地、火山等等不同的战场，在这些地方战斗时需要考虑的问题，显然也不尽相同。

　　例如平原上的森林，一旦被火炮这样的武器攻击过，它就会燃烧起来。如果有单位（不分敌我）在回合结束的时候站在了那个方格上面，那它每回合都会因为燃烧而扣掉一格血，除非你花一个回合去修理自己的机甲，才能消除掉这个负面效果。

　　地图上还有可能会出现阻挡去路的山脉，承受两次攻击就会变成水面的冰面，还有地雷或者冰冻炸弹等等东西。再加上机甲要占的格子，敌人要占的格子，还有城市和建筑的格子，这么一看，8X8的地图好像会变得异常的拥挤。

　　但是，“拥挤”才是《突破》想要营造出来的环境，因为它最主要的策略深度，都是体现在“位移”这个玩法上的。

　　什么意思呢？就比如说某个虫族下一回合要攻击它面前的城市，那么这个时候你用机甲把它往右推一格（有些机甲一开始甚至都没有攻击技能，只能使用没有伤害的纯位移技能），城市的危险不就解除了吗？而如果你选择的位置比较好，推的方向也恰好准确，还有可能让这只虫子转而去攻击自己的同类，可谓一石二鸟。

　　除此以外，你还可以找机会把不会飞的虫子推进水里、岩浆里、酸液里、甚至是闪电风暴里。而地图上的障碍物，也会增加位移技能的伤害。比如把虫子推到山脉上，它就会多掉一格血；如果把它推到另一只虫子身上，那么两只虫子都会受到伤害。但是同理，如果你不小心推到了自家单位的身上，甚至是城市或者建筑物的上面，那就不是什么好消息了。

　　和其他以伤害为主的策略游戏不同，位移才是这个游戏的核心。你甚至可以不用一个攻击技能，只通过这样的拖拉推拽，就通关这个游戏。

　　事实上，游戏的某些机制也在鼓励这种玩法。例如，通过每一个关卡的条件并非是消灭地图上的所有敌人，而是坚守4回合。在这4回合里，你只需要尽可能地保住城市和建筑不受伤害即可，杀不杀这些虫子其实无所谓。4回合一到，只要你的电力值没有下降到0以下，剩下的虫子会自行撤退，这一关就算你通关。

　　所以说，《突破》是一个非常看重走位逻辑的策略游戏，因此它不会把战场设计得大而空旷，反倒是这8X8个方格，最适合它的发挥。再加上随机生成的地图，自由搭配的机甲与装备，这个游戏的玩法和策略简直有着无数种可能，每一个新关卡都像是吸引着你的财宝，让你不忍心停下来。

　　而且，8X8的战场也不像很多传统的策略游戏那样复杂，每开一局都不会给你造成太大的心理负担，这是一个可以随时拿起放下的游戏。这就是它比其他“再来一回合”的策略游戏还要更加魔性的地方。

　　在我看来，目前它唯一遗憾的也就是单周目流程太短这个问题了。我不是说这个游戏不耐玩，相反，它有着非常高的重复游玩价值，毕竟有那么多的机甲等着你去搭配，而且每一关的地图也都是不一样的；然而在同一个周目下，只有4张大地图和1个最终关卡等着你去挑战，打完一次所花费的时间其实没有想象中那么多（当然，高难度除外）。大多数玩家第一次通关之所以都在四五个小时以上，其实很大程度上是因为不熟悉玩法导致中途失败，而被迫从头开始了而已。

　　如果在未来，工作室能加入更多风格的地图和关卡的话，我对它的评价肯定会更高。不过这应该算不上什么奢求，毕竟8X8的地图尺寸还是给日后的更新提供了很多便利的，我对此十分期待。

[h1] 写在最后	[/h1]
          最后再提一句，这个游戏的难度可能会比一般游戏的难度高一点，就算是EASY模式下，如果不熟悉游戏“拖拉推拽”的逻辑的话，也很有可能会翻车。特别是到了后面的关卡，从一开始机甲的布局，到每一次移动、每一次攻击，都要三思而后行，否则真的有可能就一着不慎满盘皆输了。所以，可想而知Hard难度下它有多硬核。

           至于游戏的Roguelike元素，每一局的地图和敌人确实都是随机的，Time Pod的出现，以及能够买到的装备应该也是随机刷新的，不过我也不知道是算法比较好还是什么缘故，至少我没有发现过系统故意针对你的情况，比如压根打不过去的关卡，或者刷出来的装备都是Shit之类的。嗯，这也是我比较喜欢的那种Roguelike的调调，毕竟，它还是保障了相当的策略性和主观能动性的。

It goes for a retro style but still makes things presentable on a modern screen. It's not glitch free, but for me it's run perfectly with no faults which I can't even say of TETRIS of all things these days. It has a wonderful visual style and is an interesting twist on the Tactical RPG genre that plays heavily with positioning and using your terrain above leveling. Some of the characters actually stand out in terms of portrait or dialog, the first time I've been okay with playing Grizzled old men but I've also unlocked a girl who I enjoy. The controls are simple, the variations of units and pilots are complex. It can feel a little samey sometimes, but if you enjoy the gameplay then you won't be bothered by it. 

Some people's only experience with Tactical RPGs is Fire Emblem, or some other game, and they think that's the entire genre; that no other game is like that. If you're someone who likes Tactical RPGs then this is a very worthwhile addition to your library. It even has options that many Tactical RPGs are honestly missing like speeding up combat animations and the ability to LIGHT EVERYTHING ON FIRE. BURN. 

It's a very good game, even for someone who's not into rogue-like/rogue-lite games. If you play Fire Emblem, Super Robot Wars, FF Tactics, Disgaea, Front Mission, etc you'll probably enjoy it. If I had to compare it to anything though, I'd say Vanilla Fire Emblem Heroes where once everyone was the same level it was all about positioning. 

The biggest flaw imo is tha customization is a little weak and it could use deeper lore, but all in all it's a fun game. I haven't put consecutive hours into a game in a while.

[list]

[*]Plenty of content

40574644.review:
[h1]Into the breach is an outstanding game[/h1]
A turn-based strategy game with tiny maps, where every error counts and your strategy must be perfect.

It play very much like chess but you have robot and tanks punching giant insects. You know in advance where the enemies are going to attack, so in the battlefield the ITB almost becomes a puzzle game where a perfect solution means 0 casualties and a bad one means the loss of (almost!) every progress. You know, rogue-like.

The advancement in the game is composed by three main aspects:
[b]Pilots[/b]: every time you lose the game you can take with you a pilot, saving the one with the best abilites. You can also find special ones in time pods and they'll become available at the start of a new game.
[b]Islands[/b]:the islands are like levels in this game. Once you complete one, it'll become unlocked for the future games.
[b]Mech squads[/b]: which are unlocked with money. You get money by earning achievements. The squads are very different and based around different themes: change position of the enemies, blocking attacks, chain attacks, etc. Unfortunately non every squad is super balanced and some are less powerful than others (but still very usable).
You can also create your own squad by using mechs from purchased squads!

The only thing that I don't really like is the poor customization between the games. Yes you can choose the pilots and the mech, but that's really it. It would be cool to be able to choose also the weapons and other stuff. Also when a pilot levels-up he gets a random ability from a pool. These abilites are not balanced (aka +3 grid defense, the hate when I get that).

Anyway, Into the Breach is a great game. For 12€ on humble bundle (with FTL for free!) or 14€ on Steam, this game is a indie gem that you should buy NOW.

The maps are small, the units are small, the dmg you deal is small, your hp bar is small but not for long. If you're good. If not you're just gonna get to the game over screen faster than the Rift Walkers can find a new timeline to save.
Into the Breach is a hard as nails, turn-based tactical strategy game but it's essentially just one thing: a puzzle.

Lemme explain. In order to win a battle you just need to survive for a certain amount of turns. Like four or five. So yeah you don't even have to kill every unit aaaand you don't even have to take care of your pilots since it doesn't reeeeeeaaaaaally matter too much whether or not your mech's piloted by a real pilot or by some robot. The only bonus you get is by leveling up your pilots and that's only possible if they survive a battle. Once they're down they're dead. That's it.

You can choose your starting island once you've unlocked them and the enemies get tougher and harder from island to island. So you can technically plan which island you wanna nuke the Veks out of first but I'm not too sure if it makes that much of a difference.

So here's how the battle system works. You essentially push the enemies around while dealing damage to them at the same time. The pushing part is really important. See the enemies always act first. And you also see what they're targetting and so on. So if you play smart you can make sure that they kill each other.
Oh and btw there are also some RNG events like storms or cataclysms. The areas that are gonna get hit by those are marked yellow. Enemies targets are red.
You can sit there and think about the best possible solution for your current puzzle and that could take some time.
The beautiful thing about that part is and what makes it so fun for me is that you're trying to find the best solution with the least drawbacks.
Speaking about drawbacks ... The grid. Oh how I love and hate the grid. Your mechs are powered by it. What this means is that once the power reaches zero you're done. Better luck next time.
Here comes the stressful part. You have to make sure that the enemies don't destroy the grid by damaging the houses on the map.

You see there's a lot of stuff to plan out before you're making your move.
And even if you utterly fuck up ... You can reset one turn per battle. If you notice that you've done a grave mistake you can just reset your turn and try again.

During the course of your run you can also upgrade your mechs by spending reputation which you've aquired through objectives.

Aaaaaaand once you meet your death you're then able to choose one of your pilots to use him in a new run.

That's pretty much the whole game.

Quick facts:

Puzzle. Push and damage enemies. Defend the grid. Upgrade mechs. Die. New timeline. Don't compare it to FTL.

It's well worth it people and really, really fun.

Not to mention time flies when I'm playing it which is also quite nice.

This game is very different from FTL, but the charm of Subset Games' last creation still remains. At its core, Into the Breach is a grid and turn-based strategy game that will force you to use the environment to your advantage. There is a lot of pushing, pulling, blocking and using chain reactions in this game, which is a very welcome change from the usual clinical damage calculation of these titles.

You control three mechs and you need to defend your planets from the invaders, one zone at a time. Usually the objective is to protect your building from damage for a set number of turns with some bonus objectives sprinkled on top. There are a lot of unlockable mechs, which is the part of the game that's going to keep you playing beyond the first few hours. The squads are very different from each other and have interesting synergies that you can exploit. Furthermore, like FTL, you can assign power slots to your units and change their weapons and abilities before the battle depending on your needs.

Into the Breach does not have the longevity of a true roguelike, but it's a fun, strategic game that will challenge you to find the most creative solution to survive each turn.
The pixel art is nice to look at and will not distract you from the action; the soundtrack is a little repetivive but has that retro sci-fi vibe that fits very well with the theme.

The main shortcomings are the relatively low map count, low replayability if you don't care about unlocking other mechs and lackluster story. 

If you feel like the value for money is too low at 15 euros wait for a sale. If you're a fan of the genre, you won't be disappointed even at full price.
