Subset Games se ha sacado de la manga un juegazo. Reinventar un género como la estrategia táctica por turnos no es nada sencillo, y menos cuando la influencia más cercana que se siente de este Into the Breach proviene del exponente más clásico imaginable: el ajedrez. Y es que el núcleo del nuevo título de los creadores de FTL es una reinterpretación del género desde sus bases más primarias, y dándole la vuelta de tuerca justa para hacerlo sentir novedoso pero a la vez con una solidez innata, que no reduzca el resultado final a un experimento extraño. No titubeo al afirmar que es uno de los mejores títulos de estrategia que han salido recientemente, y más si nos centramos como digo, en su núcleo jugable, pero como diría Jack el Destripador: vamos por partes.

La humanidad está siendo amenazada por una invasión de Kaijus enormes denominados "Vek", y solo los escuadrones de Mechas que tendremos que dirigir parecen ser la solución a este problema, pero el camino para erradicarlos será complicado, y nuestra tarea no solo consistirá en matar a tantos como podamos, sino también defender las ciudades e instalaciones a nuestro paso para que las defensas globales no caigan a cero. Si se da ese caso, uno de nuestros pilotos abrirá una brecha temporal y volveremos a intentar una vez más la salvación de la humanidad. Esta es la premisa del escenario de Into the Breach, y no hay mucho más que nos deba importar en torno a un argumento que es de lo menos importante en este juego. 

Una de las cosas que sí debéis recordar en torno al anterior párrafo es este: habrá tanto que matar a los Vek como defender las ciudades, y es aquí donde radica uno de los mayores atractivos de Into the Breach. A diferencia de otros TBS, Into the Breach se centra más en la contención de amenazas por turnos, y para ello nos valdremos de nuestros mechas y la combinación de sus acciones, con el fin de aguantar un turno más sin daños. Por ello una de las mecánicas más importantes será la capacidad de desplazar a los Vek cuando atacamos o realizamos acciones. El desplazamiento y el movimiento en general es esencial para aprovechar todas las posibilidades que brinda un escenario, desde tirarlos al agua o al vacío, empujarlos contra otros Vek o montañas y herirlos en el proceso, situarlos en la casilla donde caerá un rayo, empujar una roca y cruzarla en el camino de un enemigo, desplazar un Vek a un bosque en llamas y calcinarlo... las posibilidades son enormes gracias al diseño de los escenarios y las mecánicas del juego.

Pero también será importante desplazarlos porque tendremos que evitar que sus ataques alcancen aliados o ciudades, y aquí entra en juego otra peculiaridad de Into the Breach: siempre sabremos qué movimiento van a realizar los Vek, y nuestra tarea será alterar esos ataques para evitar catástrofes o incluso hacer que estos jueguena  nuestro favor. Todo esto, junto a lo mencionado antes, abre un mundo de nuevas posibilidades, y es lo que hace de este juego algo tan especial. Cada nuevo turno es un nuevo problema a resolver, tendremos que gestionar nuestras limitadas unidades para intentar abarcar todas las posibles amenazas, o realizar jugadas conjuntas que demandan creatividad en nuestros movimientos, como de pequeños puzles se tratasen, obligándonos a aplicar un pensamiento más lateral que otros juegos del género, sin recurrir a aspectos de gestión de recursos y otros aspectos que el juego simplemente no necesita.

Hay muchos otros aspectos a comentar, desde una considerable cantidad de mechas, armas, personajes con habilidades, hasta una buena cantidad de misiones que nos otorgará bonificaciones si resolvemos con éxito, aunque su naturaleza "cíclica" puede hacer que al cabo de unas horas pueda ser un poco reiterativo en sus objetivos, está bien planteado y compensa con el buen diseño de escenarios, los efectos cambiantes de estos, y muchas otras sorpresas. Un run del tirón por todas las islas de Into the Breach puede llevar a unas 2-2.30h de duración, pero créeme que reintentarás varias veces hasta llegar hasta el final. Es bueno también que se sienta un poco más accesible que el anterior juego de estos chicos: FTL, y auqnue no tiene la imprevisibilidad de aquel, sí gana en un sentimiento de control constante, en el que los errores son errores nuestros, y no los azares del destino.

Así que ya sabéis. Amantes de la estrategia táctica, a por él pero ya!!!!

Pretty much a hybrid between a Roguelike, Chess, and Advance Wars.  Brilliant gameplay, but there are several design choices that are questionable.

There are a set of 4 islands that you have to rescue, as well as a boss island that must be completed to end the game.  However, you only need to complete 2 islands to get to the final boss, and the final boss scales based on how many islands you complete.  I don't like this design choice, as it is usually better to go to the final boss after 2 islands instead of 3 or 4.  It also makes the playthrough a lot shorter.

Secondly, there are hazards scattered across the map that have effects on allied and enemy units.  These include inflicting damage every turn or cancelling attacks.  Most units have abilities that can push other units to take advantage of these hazards.  However, water will simply outright kill a unit that falls into it.  In some instances, this can be the only effective way to kill durable attackers, which is rather 1-dimensional.  I would personally have liked to see methods of cascading damage implemented with more than 2 enemies colliding with each other after an attack.

I think the power grid is an underdeveloped concept.  Based on power, I think giving bonuses to your crew would be an interesting dynamic.  It also would incentivise keeping your hp high.  As it stands, there is no difference between 1 grid hp and max grid hp other than additional grid damage is lethal.

The last complaint is that the game is too easy, even on hard difficulty.  The game tree complexity is limited, and that limits the number of possible moves you can make. The primary reason for this is that you can only really see 1 move ahead that the AI is doing, and you are unable to see which AI units are spawning on the next turn.  This means that you can only account for immediate threats, and cannot predict for long-term defense.  Positioning units in the center of the map helps, but is not ideal.

The good news is that mods can likely address some or all of these problems, and give yoy the specific gameplay you are looking for.

Now, I've griped about all the problems this game has.  You should still buy it because it is an outstanding game.

40566715.review:
Okay, so... this game has 94% positive reviews BUT if you go look at those positive reviews, a large portion played for less than 20 hours, often less than 15. I got bored after 16. After enjoying FTL for 150+ hours, Into the Breach really is quite a letdown, even if you do enjoy the gameplay changes (more strategy and less rogue-lite). Here's why...

It feels unfinished. Over 50 possible coins from achievements, but everything you can currently unlock totals for less than 30 coins. There IS some variety but far less replay value than FTL. After 16 hours the game starts to feel like a phone app.

There are no quests, no shops, no random events with different possible outcomes depending on luck and your team / decisions. The maps are randomly generated but there aren't that many different objectives and everything starts to feel very samey after a while. What bothers me the most, though, is the scarcity of rewards and meaningful upgrades. I've finished the final battle with almost exactly the same weapons and setups I started with. FTL has sooo many different weapons and modules... there is very little of that here.

The mech squads play very differently but unlike the various unlockable ship types in FTL, some of the squads aren't fun to play and you won't know if you like them until you've already spent the coins to unlock them. This is a matter of taste and different gamers will prefer different setups, but I'd rather have all basic squads available from the beginning so I can try them out and unlock more advanced types of the same models. More unlockables overall. More weapons variety, more slots for passives, more... everything.

Also, I've no idea why the developer decided to let you advance to the final battle after 2 islands. Imagine if you could complete FTL after 2 maps, with the final battle scaled down in difficulty so you CAN win the game after 2 maps? Yeah.

I haven't given up on it yet, but the game needs a LOT of content upgrades before I'll even consider sinking 150 hours into it.

40566185.review:
Into the Breach is a simple and fun tactics game that combines Pacific Rim theming with gameplay reminiscent of Advance Wars.

The core gameplay loop for Into the Breach begins each time with your choice of 4 islands (when you begin the game you will have limited options and you will unlock the other islands as you go). It is your job as the player to defend these 4 islands from the Vek, an insectoid alien monster race, by completing a series of missions on that island that culminate in a final mission with a boss Vek.

To accomplish this task, you are placed in command of a 3 "mech" squad, with each mech having different abilities. The 'mechs' in Into the Breach vary somewhat from the typical definition, and include planes, tanks, artillery, drones, and the traditional humanoid mechs to name a few. 

As you complete missions and beat the campaign with various squads, you will unlock new 3 mech squads with different theming and abilities that help you take on challenges in new and interesting ways.

The beauty of Into the Breach is in its simplicity. Each mech unit and themed squad has very defined strengths and weaknesses. They each require a different set of tactics to lay effectively, but at their core they are all based around a central idea, whether that is pushing around enemies, dealing a ton of damage, chaining damage through multiple adjacent enemies, or something completely different. It makes playing through the campaign multiple times a more varied and interesting experience.

I would recommend this for anyone who wants to play a fun, casual tactics game that makes you think, but not too much.

Карты очень маленькие, буквально 10 на 10 клеток (не считал, лишь примерно), всего 3 юнита на вашу сторону (разнообразить их можно перед стартом игры, но менять уже в процессе- не выйдет, нет возможности). И тут... бац, конец миссии... Хотел бы раза в 3 дольше затянуть такие бои, но нет. Карты в большинстве случаев генерируются случайным образом (мне так показалось) и от этого... ну... как бы 4 разных острова, и почти мало отличаются друг от друга- защити то, защити это... Если думаете, что будет нечто похожее с вашей осадой на жуков, то нет... 5 ходов- от 0 до 10 трупов врагов= конец битвы, идем дальше.
Я бы хотел больше контента- в локациях, в уникальности пилотов (+1 к движению, хелсам, энергии- это основные), ибо " после выстрела мех может сделать дополнительные очки движения"- редкость (по уникальности). The maps are small and have a lot of special tiles and conditions you need to consider, so it's very focussed. Sounds easy, and it basically IS easy for a turn based tactics game veteran like me (on normal difficulty), but you have to think hard for the best possible outcome each turn and overwhelming numbers of enemies against your three dudes makes it challenging. 
Each mission you get 1-3 bonus objectives which give you upgrades, currency or power, which is basically your health.

About power: this meter rises when you get it by a mission and falls EVERY time the enemies destroy a city tile on a map, which takes only one attack. So if that happens often enough, that is when you lose your current playthrough, but there is carry-over of pilots you find.

Upgrading mechs between missions is a blast and you are highly flexible once you got some reactor power to spend. You can choose between moving more tiles, gaining more health, doing more damage or special abilities like charging towards an enemy for the melee based mech. That are just some poor examples, after freeing each island you get to spend your currency where you can buy new abilities and weapons, which allow you to freeze opponents or drop smoke on them so they lose their attack this turn. You  can detach reactor power and put it somewhere else if you want to shift your tactics.

So this game comes highly recommended from me. A worthy successor from FTL, and as with FTL, I expect additional content in one or two years time to come.

Just about what I expected from Subset Games. It's really cool.


Now I'm going to make a few comparisons between this, and their previous game FTL:

FTL seems to be a bit more based on luck. While in Into The Breach, no matter how bad the situation is, you can bust your head to minimize the potential damage as much as you possibly can. Ofcourse you can do that in FTL too, but you are way more limited to how accuracy and evasion plays out. And the random events that you get with RNG. There are no such random events in Into The Breach other than randomized optional quests in each area.

In conjunction with that, FTL feels way harder and stressful (kinda in a good way) than Into The Breach (or I dunno, maybe I got used to tactical games). Case in point, I've achieved victory just in 2nd run in Into The Breach, while I had like 5+ tries until I got it in FTL.

Risk versus reward management still feels the same in both games. 

I feel like it's way easier to unlock stuff in Into The Breach than in FTL. In FTL, you have to do specific challenges to unlock each ship type or gain a victory to unlock "the next type", in Into The Breach, you collect these "achievement coins" and spend them on any of the unlockables in any order you want.

With that being said, Into The Breach feels way more customizable as you can create your own custom squad out of pieces that you unlock. 

While in FTL if you are underprepared for the boss fight, you are dead meat. But that doesn't matter in Into The Breach, as final fight scales with your levels. 


These are all the comparisons that I can think of right now. But keep in mind that despite both being very tactical-heavy games, they can't substitute for each other. Their gameplay are still pretty different, one is about mechs versus aliens on a tactical grid combat, the other one is about 1v1 space combat and  resource management. I honestly like both, but since FTL was the game that first introduced me to roguelike genre, I hold it closer to my heart.

40553289.review:
TLDR; This is a good little game with a range of mech types and enemy types. It's more of a puzzle game than anything. Replay value is relatively low and you can see all the features within an hour, but there's certainly still some fun to be had by trying out mech combinations and looking to clear the various achievements. It's no FTL, but then what is?

In Depth Review

Is it worth the money?

First and most importantly. 
This game is smaller than I was hoping, there's only four islands and maybe...a dozen scenarios.  It could certainly be said to be an advantage that my biggest criticism is that there wasn't enough of it but I'm not sure if it warrants the pricetag. Then again, maybe Subset know this since for a first-time buyer you also get free FTL and so 15 dollars for FTL + ITB is actually pretty decent. 
Basically, each game takes maybe an hour at most and so if you have cash to burn ITB is a fine addition for a few hours of fun after work or school, so I'd give it a soft yes. 

Gameplay

It's a lot more like a tactics game than a Roguelike. 
It has a cool premise that fans of Pacific Rim or the Super Robot genre will instantly recognise as you take the place of a team of mech pilots fighting giant bug monsters. The game is divided up into four main islands and a boss fight island. Each island functions as a sort of mini-campaign map where you can choose between one or two missions. Once you've completed half a dozen or so missions you have a boss fight to defend the island HQ and then move on to the next island.
Each mission is pretty similar in that they all end after you have survived for about five turns and invovles you fighting a handful of these giant bug monsters (Vek).
Different enemy types have different special abilities; such as direct-fire ranged attacks, webbing your mechs to immobolise them, others will spawn smaller units, some function like artillery and can hit multiple targets. A lot of the tactical creativity comes from trying to pull or push these bugs monsters (Vek) into the path of each other's attacks. Most of the Vek will also die if submerged in water or lava, and so there's some cool moments of rocket punching giant spiders into the ocean for massive damage. There's also some limited environmental factors such as smoke or forests which can be lit on fire to damage Vek.
New Vek enter the map by burrowing onto the screen and so trying to block these tunnels before the Vek emerge adds another layer of tactics. 
Each mission will have a specific goal or two, achieving these goals grands you "corporate favour" which at the end of each island can be traded for power, more mech cores (to upgrade your mechs) or new weapons and accessories. There's regrettably not a lot of choice in scenarios. You usually need to protect a unique building or unit (trains are a very common one) or you might need to kill a certain super enemy. There are only a couple of more unique missions (smashing ice off cities, terraforming terrain).
Each city will also inevitably have cities which you need to protect to maintain power. Each time a city dies your power grid is reduced and only certain missions will allow you to replenish it. If your power reaches zero you lose the game. No exceptions. 
Basically, if you like the general shtick of this sort of tactical puzzle fighting (somewhat reminiscient of Fire Emblem/OB: Knight of Lodis/Advance Wars) then you'll probably enjoy this. If you haven't tried it, I'd recommend it. 

Customisation and Replayability
There's a roster of pilots you can choose from. They have some vey rudimentary personalities that will influence what they say at key moments and they each have a special ability. Some abilities cost additional power, which is often scarce but they might give a mech "flying" so it's not effected by terrain or give it armour to reduce damage. Others might increase movement range or exp gain. 
In additon to changing the pilot, there's a range of mechs you can choose from which come in pre-made teams but which can be mixed and matched as you gain more. You gain more mechs by unlocking achievements, which can be a little tedious for certain mech teams (looking at you Steel Judoka).
Each mech team has a theme and some are actually really fun -such as the fire-based mechs which are immune to fire and all have abilities that set things on fire or the Hazardous Mechs which all do good damage but damage themselveswith every attack and rely on killing enemies to regen their health.   
It's a good thing these mechs and pilots exist, or replayability would be almost completely absent. As it is, it's more of a delaying tactic than a cure. 
It's a bit like playing games like DoW or old school Command and Conquer where no matter the little changes in each map the premise does become pretty stale pretty quickly. 
I'm not sure if Subset plans to support this game after release, but I hope they do. I'd like to see a "mech building" DLC at the least. 
You also get badges for beating the game after two, three or four islands with each pre-made team. This doesn't really seem like an achievment to me since once you've beaten the game with a team it's pretty much enough (and the final battle scales with your level, so it isn't really that much harder).

Plot
Pretty much completely absent. The worldbuilding is a lot weaker than FTL, or most other tactics games actually, where you got the feeling you were were travelling across a galaxy. 

  
Inevitable FTL Comparisons. 
It's probably not fair to compare this game (or many others) to FTL. One is an entirely serviceable little game, the other is a fan-favourite that single handedly brought the Roguelike back into style. I've not played an indie game on FTL's level since and that includes this title. 
If you're looking for something to scratch the FTL itch, this is unfortunately not it. The game is shorter, more prone to RNG and less developed. FTL managed to compactly worldbuild whilst never getting boring and had a heap of depth and secrets. 
As far as you can compare them, FTL is still lightyears ahead. 

Other Stuff

I don't know. This game just...feels...a little incomplete to me. Like when I beat it I was like "that's it?" I expected there'd be more. 


In Closing

It's not a bad game, I recommend it. I'd recommend it even more if it's on sale. It's worth a play, but don't expect it to match up to FTL and you'll be reasonably well pleased. Know that it's short and doesn't have a lot of depth and you weren't be disappointed.

1、虫族具有非常多的种类，每种具有特定的攻击方式且攻击的方式固定，所以可通过位移攻击操作，使虫族互相攻击，挡住增援虫族的刷新点，死亡爆炸杀伤其他虫族等等。

战斗胜利可将敌人全灭，或者撑到倒计时回合结束均可。

40551781.review:
[h1]Giving a downvote because of the price.[/h1]

I feel like this game is about a 7/10, and would be good for $10 USD, not its current price of $15 USD. I played it for about 2 hours, finished it, and feel like I'm done with it.

If I decide to play it more and change my mind, I will revisit this review.

[h1]The Good[/h1]

The best part about this turn-based strategy game is the mechanic where you able to move enemies during your turn, making their attacks land on different locations than they intended. That's the gimmick of this game. There are also other things you can do, like launching artillery at an enemy on a sand tile to turn the sand into "smoke" which stops their attack. You can also get enemies to hit each other-- this wouldn't be possible to plan if the game did not have its Move Order menu where you can see the order in which enemies will attack. It doesn't tell you the order of anything else though, like movement or burrowing or environmental effects. You have to work that out as you play. 

In my time playing, I never saw a method to make enemies *rotate* their stance, which would have been really interesting. Only methods to translate (move) enemies one tile at a time. 

Enemies frequently burrow in (are introduced into the battle) turn after turn, and their movements were unpredictable to me. Because of this, I could only take moves one turn at a time. I never planned a single move ahead, apart from maybe 3 exceptions where I had a vague idea of where I wanted my unit to be next turn. In a way, I really enjoy this because I can take my time with each move, and not stress too much about what will happen next. That aspect of the game is very enjoyable. But I'm sure many will see this as a fault. After all, I did win on my first time playing (on Normal, not Easy) without ever planning ahead...

[h1]A few problems with the game:[/h1]

[list]

[*][b]Previous runs impact your future runs.[/b] First of all in the form of unlocks, which I feel are pointless gates that exist to stop the player doing well or experiencing variety until they've played long enough. The more annoying thing is that when you finish a run, you're allowed to take one of your pilots (playable characters; presumably fully leveled up from the completed run) to your next run. Uuhh... why are you allowed to give yourself a handicap on your next run if you did well on your previous one? It just makes you feel like you're at a disadvantage if you DON'T have a previous pilot to take with you. I do not understand why creators  of Rogue-like feel the urge to do this. The victory itself is the reward, not the ability to give yourself a handicap next run; that isn't satisfying at all!

[*][b]The game doesn't tell you the consequences of death.[/b] I deliberately killed a mech to gain extra experience right at the end of a battle (using self-destruct), because the tutorial told me that mechs would repair themselves after battle. But it neglected to mention that your human pilot inside will die and you will lose bonuses. Thanks, tutorial!

[*][b]Consequences for death are inconsistent.[/b]In the final battle, there is a second phase. Your mechs are restored to full health, except pilots are not resurrected if they died, and the mechs will be stripped of any additional weapons (and presumably powers) that they had. Once again, would have been great if the game told me there was a second phase, and that death had a large penalty. Then I could have planned accordingly. But nope no mention of that, just trial and error. Not to mention that this is inconsistent with how death normally operates, where the mechs keep their weapons/bonuses. So this is just unique to that battle I guess. Maybe it's a bug/oversight.

[*][b]There weren't enough "mech cores" to upgrade my units much[/b]. I equipped a second weapon on each of my mechs, and that was just about all I could afford. The game gives the appearance of there being more upgrades available, but I doubt if you could actually afford many of those. To be fair, I only completed the first 2 islands of 4. Perhaps the 3rd and 4th islands have significantly more mech cores to find; I don't know.

[*][b]Missions are generic permutations of the same ruleset.[/b] There are four kinds of objectives: (a) Take less than X damage (b) Kill X enemies (c) Protect this special building (d) Kill this particular enemy. The environmental hazards are a great breath of fresh air.
[/list]


[h1]Variety dried up[/h1]

Now that I've completed the game, (on my first run, and on Normal) I feel no desire to play again. I know the content; I will be repeating the same battles with the same objectives permuted around. Maybe I'll get a different weapon here or there. I can't choose different mechs because that's behind a pointless unlock wall. Like FTL, the unlock walls are completely arbitrary objectives which you must go out of your way to complete, sacrificing the actual mission. For example, one involves dunking 3 land enemies into water within one battle. I didn't do this because it was never strategically viable. If I want to unlock stuff, I have to waste time by making a game with no intention of winning, just completing the arbitrary objectives.

40551736.review:
For fans of turn-based-strategy games and rad as hell mechs.

It recreates those season finale episode moments of shows like Gundam, Evangelion or Starship Troopers (there is a show) where you arrive at the last possible second as the space bugs are arriving to attack one of the last surviving human settlements.
It is up to you to figure out the best way to keep casualties low and when to jump in front of a bullet.
You'll also be sweating bullets since it very often feels like you're outnumbered until you figure out the best way to position your mechs and the enemy.

This is very much like Chess if you could move your opponents pieces with your attacks.
If you are patient and read all the information the game gives to you (of which there is quite a bit) you are sure to find the best way forward.
Don't be afraid of trying it on Easy to unlock more mechs which might be better suited for you, since they play quite differently.

It is a game about managing loss and learning to accept failure.
Few victories (in Normal mode) are not snatched from the jaws of total defeat.

While it is indeed punishing it's not unfair. It has a high skill ceiling but presents all the information you need to get there at all times. It feels extremely rewarding as you start to internalize all of the rules and put them to use.

I look forward to finding videos online that show high skill play with team combinations I could not think of.

The reality that Subset Games has created for us to explore is bleak and original. All of the incidental dialogue is great and really sets the mood perfectly. As far as world-building goes this knocks it out of the park.
Hopefully you'll enjoy it as much as I have.

5/5


See you later Space Cowperson.

40549281.review:
Into the Breach - ☆☆☆

Le jeu en bref

Catapulté dans le passé, vous devez grâce à votre escouade de mechs allez sauvez la terre d'une invasion de Veks (des genres d'aliens). Beau petit rogue-like Tactique, si vous aimez les combats dans le style de XCOM vous allez probablement apprécier ce jeu. Il souffre quand même de bémols non négligeables nottament un manque de contenu brut et a un aspect trop générique à mon goût.

Les points forts

Les combats sont extrêment bien fignolés et représentent tout l'intérêt du jeu. Contrairement à plusieurs jeux similaires où le but de chaque missions/combats consiste à éliminer ses adversaires, ici on cherche à survivre pendant un nombre fixe de tour tout en défendant la population locale. On passe donc beaucoup moins de temps à tenter de réduire la barre de vie des bestioles mais surtout à les bouger afin qu'il n'endommagent pas les objectifs clés.  Le tout donne à chaque mission beaucoup plus le sentiment d'être un mini puzzle très gratifiant plûtot que d'être une sorte de lancé de dé avec une prière au bon dieu. Il y a quand même une part d'aléatoire et une fois de temps en temps il y aura des situations sans autres options que de laisser un bâtiment ce faire détruire ou de devoir abandonner un des objectifs secondaires.

Sans être nécessairement exceptionnelles, les graphismes, la bande sonores et les animations font du beau boulot et rendent le tout très agréable. Bref, pas grand chose à dire dessus.

Les point faibles

Le jeu est, pour un rogue-like, assez maigre en terme de contenu. J'ai, je crois, 16 heures au total présentement et j'ai vraiment le sentiment d'avoir fait le tour même s'il reste des achievements ici et là à faire. S'il y a une bonne diversité d'escouades de Mechs et d'armements pour ceux-ci, les niveaux et les aliens on en fait vite le tour. Il n'y a pas vraiment d'autre objectif que de finir la mission finale à part les achievements qui eux-même vont se faire plus souvent par hasard et moins par réelle volonté.

Le jeu est extrêmement transparent, tout les éléments du jeu ne sont que là pour valoriser ou justifier les combats. Ce  n'est pas mal en soi mais ça lui donne un aspect jeu flash un peu générique sans ambition. Surtout venant des créateurs de FTL, on aurait aimé un jeu ayant une pointe d'originalité en plus.

Bref il faut prend le jeu pour ce qu'il est, une excellente exécution d'un jeu tactique mais qui n'en fait pas plus. Je lui donne trois étoiles sur cinq.

I hear a lot of comparisons to FTL, which are probably inevitable, but ultimately pointless - they are very different games. The consensus seems to be that this is a lot more of a chess-like puzzle game with a light progression system. I do not agree with the 'rogue-lite' label, even though the game does carry with it a few randomised systems; the randomness does not appear to affect runs as drastically as something I would consider a rogue-lite, nor does there seem to be the staggering amount of randomised content that a typical rogue-lite would tout. If anything, it's a rogue-lite-lite.

It isn't perfect. I take issue with how lacklustre some of the weapon purchases can be (although some are fantastic); the poor incentive to play longer sessions; and the somewhat wasted opportunity to do something more interesting with the final level in relation to how many islands you've completed.

Nevertheless, I'm 30 hours into it because I personally enjoy tactics games, and this is a fantastic tactics game - one of the best you can get. The music is great, and is what I think invites the best comparison to FTL: they give off similar vibes, naturally, thanks to composer Ben Prunty. For USD $15, it's hard to argue against trying it out, especially if it goes on sale. I've paid more for board games that I've enjoyed less and played fewer times.

Is this game FTL? No. Is it shorter than FTL? Yes. Is it "easier" than FTL? Yes. With FTL I find my success rate is still about 1 in 3 games on "normal" whereas for Into the Breach I can usually successfull save the islands with the basic mechs. 

Where Into the Breach shines is its simple, elegant execution of its core idea and wonderful implementation of turn based strategy. The short length allows for experimentation and iteration. Easier unlocks elementates the grinding that was at times necessary in FTL. Clearly telegraphed moves by the Vek (the monsters in this game) make for a very thoughtful, tactical game. Especially once you realized you positioned your mecs wrong the previous turn and there's no way you can get them to where they need to be to complete the mission/prevent loss of grid power (your "life"). Keeping a time travelling pilot between playthroughs also gives a consistent narrative to the game. 

Is Into the Breach FTL? No. Into the Breach is very much its own game and a worthy successor to FTL. I suspect I'll be playing both for a long time to come.

40543965.review:
A wonderful game of placement and strategy.

My biggest complaint about normal Tactics-style games is that the numbers come first. You position yourself around an enemy and punch them with numbers, then grind to get better numbers. The movement and the positioning is important, but it comes second to the offensive intention.

Into the Peach switches that around. Position is vital because your HP is fragmented into various squares that need guarded above all else. Numbers are useful, but a victory can be had without any damage at all if that's the style of your team.

A lot of very clever decisions have helped reinforce the feeling that you are playing a defensive game, rather than an offensive one. And this is important in a Giant Mech game. Many others focus so heavily on killing the enemy that the surrounding environment can be completely destroyed all in the name of "protecting" it. Here, you truly protect the cities.

It's not without its faults. The ending comes too soon and too often. And after a few playthroughs you'll feel like you've seen most of what the game has to offer; there won't be many new surprises along the way, which is a shame. But it's well worth the money.

I'd recommend this game in general if you like tactics gaming to show you a new way of play. And I'd Double Recommend  it if you are the type of person who likes both video games AND board games, because this definitely has blood from both.

40541013.review:
Normalをクリアしたのでレビュー。
FTLを散々やり込んだ身としてはSubset Gamesの新作が遊べるというだけで僥倖というものだが、今作も果たしてその期待に十二分に応える快作であった。というかこんなレビュー書いてないで早くゲームに戻りたいみたいなところすらある。

いざプレイしてみると、もうあのドットで描かれた「LOADING…」の文字だけでテンションが上がる。1ステップずつ丁寧に解説してくれるチュートリアルのおかげで導入も全く問題なし。

様々なギミックが仕込まれたコンパクトなマップを舞台に、3機のみと割り切った自機達を駆り、Vekとの闘いに身を投じていく。オーソドックスなターン制バトルながら、ランダムな所とそうでない所の塩梅が絶妙で、コントロールできないのはVekの出現位置とターゲッティング、あとは自然現象くらいという、世界観的にも筋の通った構造になっている。逆にそれ以外の情報はすべて開示されているので、戦闘の行く末は全て自分の指揮にかかっている、という状況が見事にデザインされていると言える。これでクリティカルや回避があったらまったく別のゲームになっていただろう。

このストラテジー部分のデザイン的な美しさはすでに多くのレビューで語られているため、個人的には演出的な部分の秀逸さについて触れたい。とにもかくにも今作は随所で効果的なアニメーションとSEがふんだんに取り入れられ、非凡な手触りの良さを実現させている。ユニット説明のアニメーションは言わずもがな、なんなら配置の時点で気持ちいいし、放物線を描いて敵に激突する迫撃砲の爽快さや、押し出しのギミックを使ってVekをA.C.I.Dの沼に突き落とす快感は、もはや単体のアクションゲームのそれとなんら遜色ない。

前作FTLでも、Glaive BeamやVulcanといったハイコストながら浪漫のある兵装は、1とか2のダメージがほとんどの中で「4」ってめっちゃ強くね！？みたいなミニマルゆえの鮮やかなコントラストをデータ上で生み出していた。今作はそのステータスバランスはそのままに、コミカルで爽快なアニメーションが付加されたことで、より「触っているだけで楽しい」ゲーム体験を生み出すことに成功していると思う。

当然今作はただ楽しいだけではなく、ユニットの移動忘れで戦況が悲惨なことになったり、Environmentの見逃しでパイロットを失ったりという自己責任の「絶望」がそこかしこにある。この失敗から学んでいく過程や、何を取るべきか延々と煩悶するアップグレード、より個性がついたパイロットなど、FTLから受け継がれた「精神」が宿っているように感じられるのもファンとしてはとても嬉しい。

加えて、今回もBen Prunty氏による悲壮で美しいBGMはゲームプレイに華を添えるどころかフラワースタンドのようにそびえ立っており、本当に氏がSubset Gamesと仕事してくれて良かったなぁと思うことしきりである。

まだHardもプレイできていない序盤ではあるが、所感としては上記のような非の打ち所がない感じである。しいて言えばマップ数が多くない印象はあるが、Squadによってプレイ感はガラっと変わるし、将来的にAdvanced Editionとかで追加されるかも？みたいな期待もあるのでさしたる問題ではない。一点、タイトルについては”FTL”に比べるとやや略称としてのユニークさや語感が落ちたかな？と思うところはある。

以上、FTLファンなのでまったく一見さん向きのレビューではない自覚はあるが、FTLが好きならやって損はないと思うし、前作未経験でもストラテジーや将棋が好きな方には問題なくオススメできる品質だと言えるのではないだろうか。Subset Gamesの偉大な仕事にあらん限りのリスペクトと感謝をこめて、今後もプレイしていきたいと思う。

This game is good.... but not as good as I would hope for it to be...
Right now, I would 100% reccomend getting this game for the sole reason that you also get FTL with it for free.

Mechanics wise, this game is very fun. It is a simple turn based strategy game with a few basic rules, and to be sucessful you just use and exploit these rules to the fullest potential. The game is most rewarding to the patient player who takes their time to plan out many different possible moves during a turn before settling on one, and this is the main aspect of the game that I found very entertaining. Each level becomes a puzzle, and there is almost always a solution that can be found without that would give you the best possible outcome, unless you're playing on hard, where often times I had to settle for sub-optimal solutions due to the sheer number of enemies thrown at me.

While the core gameplay is fun for a while, the biggest issue I have with the game right now is its lack of deapth and replayability. There are 11 different mech squads for you to unlock (10 standard and 1 hidden and play as in the game, but for the most part I felt very little urge to play each squad more than once because repeated runs using the same squad always began to feel samey after one or two runs. Most of the gameplay and strategic variety came from which squad you started with, and not from the upgrades you choose or unlock during the game. Often times I found myself beating the end level with the same loadout I had started with in the beginning, and to me, that's a huge problem because subsequent runs become very boring. 

Comparing the progression of this game to FTL really highights this issue. Runs in FTL are almost ALWAYS unique and interesting, you almost never end with a ship that remotely resembles the ship that you had at the beginning, unlike in Into the Breach. Your path choices in FTL also feel like they had so much more of a risk/reward tradeoff than decisions in Into the Breach. In this respect FTL is a much better example of an in deapth rogue like game. Even at 50+ hours into FTL there are still many different things I have yet to discover and several ships I have yet to unlock, whereas in Into the Breach, I'd already unlocked and played all 10 base squads at only 15 hours, and at this point I really don't feel like this game has much more to offer in terms of entertaining gameplay.

Overall, I am happy with a game if I can get $1/hour of gameplay, and while this game 100% hits that mark, I still feel like something was missing. Much of that sense of dissatisfaction comes from the fact that I had expected so much more from Into The Breach since it was made by the same people who gave me the hours of entertainment from FTL. But I digress, buy this game, play it untill you unlock each squad, then go and play FTL for a million hours because its a freaking amazing game.

Vous gerez un squad de 3 unités avec des attaques ou des compétences différentes, et vous combattez des envahisseurs appellés "Vek".
De nouveaux squads sont débloqués grâce à des jetons remportés par les 55 succès possibles.

Flammes, glaces, fumées, boucliers, acides, armure, expérience des pilotes : il y a de nombreux mécanismes dignes d'un bon jeu de stratégie.

Mais Into The Breach est aussi un titre novateur. 
Le principal objectif du jeu est de défendre au mieux les bâtiments sur les cartes.
A chaque tour, vous voyez les attaques des Vek. Vos attaques font des dégats ET elles repoussent aussi leurs cibles.
Du coup, vous pouvez non seulement défendre vos unités et les structures, mais aussi retourner les attaques de vos ennemis contre eux! Ou bien les empêcher de surgir de terre, etc...
Les batailles se déroulent en 5 tours. Vous pouvez annuler les déplacements de vos unités mais pas leurs attaques. A moins... à moins d'utiliser le bouton de réinitialisation, mais cela n'est possible qu'une fois par bataille,.

Si la partie est perdue, vous n'avez pas tout perdu! Vous pouvez choisir de garder un pilote. Votre voyageur du temps!

Ami voyageur! Tentez l'expérience!

10 hours in and I think I've got enough of a handle on [i]Into The Breach[/i] to say some things.

I was initially rather undewhelmed, but time spent with the game has improved my opinion. I don't love it (yet?) and I've still got a nagging doubt haunting me, that this isn't as good as FTL...

However, it is good. It's very pure; the story and world building is sparse, just enough to colour the proceedings with some sci fi flavour. I feel the influence of movies like [i]Edge of Tomorrow[/i] and [i]Pacific Rim[/i] at work. I would have preferred a lot more in this direction; more story, more dialogue, more flavour, more to connect me to the world and characters and really make me care more about the lives at stake. Compared with FTL, there's very little text. On the other hand, the game is never bogged down with bloated writing, cutscenes, or other flim flam.

The game is quite chess like, in that you have a grid to play on, and you have pieces with limited and individual movesets. The board is more dynamic than chess, with every piece moving and attacking every turn, and each turn you have to survey the board to find threats, and use your limited forces to best defeat those threats. It's quite like a puzzle game.

ITB relies on throwing many simple moving parts together to arrive at a certain level of complexity. However, at some point you'll have seen every interesting and surprising combination of mech/enemies/weapon/pilots/powers.

There are four islands to fight over with unique terrain and features, and they are cool, but I feel like four is way too few. I feel like this aspect of the game is crying out for expansion. I'd like more variety here, and I'd also like the option of longer campaigns (the option to play very short campaigns is welcome). I'd also like there to be a bit more in terms of mech upgrades and pilot experience levels. Enemies get samey, as there's a very limited pool of different types. There's a fair few things that feel underdeveloped in ITB, and I hope Subset are planning some fairly major updates to the game, perhaps as a DLC on par with the one FTL got. 

In summary, it's good fun, I think it's worth the tenner, I'm sure I'm going to get a decent amount of play out of it, but I'm pretty sure that this is in no way a work of genius in the same league as FTL.There just isn't the same level of depth and expansiveness, there's not enough dramatic surprises, not enough excitment. I can't see myself playing hundreds and hundreds of hours of this...

Oh, and if anyone reads this and has never played FTL, hit me up to get my spare copy.

40535440.review:
[b][h1]It's no FTL[/h1][/b]

Ah, the difficult 'second album'. I loved FTL - and I really wanted to like this - but it's disappointing. FTL was unique and compelling on many levels; best defined as a rogue-like, but really, it was its own entity. Into the Breach is really just a turn-based board game, dressed up as a video game. You could play your own version with a4 paper and tiddlywinks - seriously. 

FTL had a feel-good factor; an easily understandable (if well tried) scenario, bright, clean graphics and colours, all primaries, secondaries, blacks and whites. All this, accompanied by a perfectly complimentary, catchy, and non-annoying soundtrack. The whole thing had a lightness of touch, and felt good to play. 

Into the Breach, by contrast, is a wholly more acquired taste. The time travel theme of the story seems to have been contrived to fit the gameplay (predicting the enemy's moves), and the mechs and kaijus thing is all a bit more niche than FTL's familiar Star Trekking, or Blake's 7ing. The colour scheme is completely tertiary - everything is a shade of green, brown, or grey, and all the action seems to take place in a surreal twilight. Ben Prunty's soundtrack is noteworthy - dark and brooding - but contributes, along with everything else, to make Into the Breach more cognitively and sensorily dissonant than FTL. 

FTL's success, I'm convinced, was as much to do with its clean audio and visual aesthetic as it was to do with the brilliant gameplay. If FTL flerted with pixel art, ITB declares its undying adoration for the look and feel of late 80s/early 90s video games, and throws itself prostrate and earnest at their feet. It just isn't cool. 

In fairness, it's polished, and the mechanisms in the game have had a lot of thought. For some reason I can't explain, I just don't want to play it longer than the few hours I already have. I think it might be boring, but I can't be bothered playing it for longer to find out - it just doesn't grab me like FTL did. 

Unfair comparison? No - not when the promo images have 'From the makers of FTL' splashed all over them.

　この様にプレイヤー側は怪獣側の出方を見てから行動して、一方的に攻撃出来ます。しかし、怪獣はロボだけを狙ってくる訳では無く、民間人の住むビルも壊そうとするし、ロボは3体なのに怪獣は4～5体だったりします。
　ただ攻撃するだけでは無く、時にはロボがビルの盾となったり、崖から突き落としたり怪獣の相打ちなども利用しなくてはいけません。
　これら上手く捌き、決められたターン数凌げばプレイヤー側の勝利となります。


[h1] 絶妙なランダム要素と難易度設定から繰り出される高いリプレイ性 [/h1]

　怪獣の出現テーブル、地形、マップ効果はランダムに決定され公開されます。
　出撃先を選択肢し、戦闘が始まると、出現テーブルからランダムな位置に怪獣が投入され、ランダムな位置にマップ効果が予告される。
　回避、クリティカルなどの乱数が一切無く運ゲーでストレスを感じることはありません。
　戦闘中、タイムポッドが漂着することがあります。傷つけずに回収できればボーナスが貰えます。

　公開された情報から慎重に出撃地域を選択しましょう。駒の状況や環境をよく観察し、時には何かを犠牲にしてでも最適解を選択しましょう。慣れてくるとパズルがさくさく解けるような気持ちよさがあります。

　難易度はすこし高めですが、前作のようにEasy(Hard)みたいな事は無く、表記通りの難易度といった印象でした。
　クリアまでの時間は1～3時間くらい。
　Hardmodeもシステムに慣れた頃にしっかりと時間をかけて考えれば運に左右されずクリアできます。
　スクワッド、怪獣、地形、ミッションこれらが組み合わさり何周もしたくなるリプレイ性、中毒性あり。


　日本語未対応ですが、長文は出てきませんしテキスト量もかなり少ないので、読める英単語だけ拾っていけば十分遊べます。
　FTLという偉大な前作のハードルを楽々飛び越した文句なしの[b] 神ゲー [/b]です。

40532701.review:
Let me start by saying that Into the Breach is by no means a bad game - in fact I'd even say it's actually a pretty good game. To put it bluntly, the game is incredibly short and easy. I put 200 hours into FTL and I could go back for another run even now. But after one sitting of Into The Breach, I had already seen the majority of the content. There's 4 small islands with a few missions each, then a surprisingly easy boss fight with very little replay value. Outside of unlocking all the mechs and trying some combinations of mechs, there isn't much to do. 

[b]Lack of Replayability[/b]
The first few hours of this game were a blast. It was fun to figure things out, and it was very rewarding to win fights in clever ways. However in less than 8 hours you will have virtually seen every aspect of this game. You'll have seen nearly every gameplay mechanic, seen most of the weapons and enemies, and unlocked most of mechs and pilots. Beyond that is just grinding for achievements and the remaining unlockables, which would be fine except that ITB has almost no replay value. There are only a few different types of missions, nearly all of which you will encounter in a couple playthroughs. 

The final fight is not only incredibly stale (there's not even a unique enemy type or boss there), it's incredibly easy as well. It's also scaled so that if you do it early, it'll be significantly simpler, so you're not required to complete all 4 islands before going there. Even if you're not great at these kinds of tactics games, you could easily "beat the game" in under an hour on your first play-through by going to the final fight after completing 2 of the 4 islands.

[b]Lack of Customization Depth[/b]
You begin the game with a squad of 3 mechs, they come in themed groups of 3 but you can mix-and-match and make a custom squad as you unlock more to choose from. Each mech can be equipped with a second weapon, and that's basically it. As you play you'll find reactors to upgrade your mechs HP and Movement (once each), and maybe a couple of weapon upgrades too (like +1 damage or +1 range). By the time you're ready for the final fight you won't feel like you had much a choice in upgrading your mech other than the order in which you did it.

You start with 1 unique pilot that has a signature ability like "Can move through other units" or "Has Armor", and 2 generic pilots with no ability. As you level the each pilot up, they will get 2 randomized skills (out of a pool of 4 possible skills) and cannot be customized at all. Just pray to god your pilot doesn't get "+3 Grid Defense" as one of his skills instead of something that's actually useful. You can find more unique pilots as you play, replacing the generic ones. If you lose the game, you can keep 1 pilot for your next play through, and he keeps his skills.

Overall the game severely lacks variety and depth, that's really all there is to it. I can see myself coming back to this game if they ever add an expansion or big content patch to the game, or perhaps if the modding community really takes off, but I was definitely disappointed with how short the game was. Perhaps my expectations of Subset Games were simply too high?

40531073.review:
When I saw the announcement for this game, I was hoping for another Invisible Inc. It looked like this game would offer a procedurally generated series of tightly-focused, small-scale puzzles that I would then have to solve using a modestly varied set of tools with a pre-determined, RNGless set of capabilities. Once the pieces were in place, I hoped, I could then plan how a turn would play out to the last exact detail.

Turns out? That's EXACTLY what I got, and I highly recommend this game IF that sounds appealing to you. On the other hand, DO NOT buy this game if you want another FTL. If you want that, play the Captain's Edition mod for FTL instead, if you haven't already (if you have, try A Strange New Galaxy or Stations Job, which offer unique appeals of their own even though they're not as polished or feature-complete as CE).

As far as roguelites go, Into the Breach is fairly light on equipment and enemy variety (variance in general really) and on fleshing out the setting, but is VERY similar to Invisible Inc. in that respect. The two games are almost part-and-parcel in that they are both immensely satisfying little brain teasers where the fun and challenge of the game is in racking your brain for the optimal solution to the situation each turn presents, then feeling so very accomplished indeed when you discover and execute a series of moves that leaves the enemy floundering helplessly, doing no damage to either you or your buildings (or in Invisible Inc.'s case, the guards running around like headless chickens with no idea where your agents are).

Beyond that, Into the Breach has a simple but stylish aesthetic, simple but stylish music courtesy of FTL's composer Ben Prunty, and is generally simple and stylish all the way around. It's a very clean, almost clinical sort of game, but that is, I feel, as it should be for a game of its type, another quality it shares with Invisible Inc. It shows you exactly what you need to know to plan your next move and nothing more, leaving your thinking space free of distractions.

Again, the satisfaction of this game is the intellectual satisfaction of a well-executed plan. If you're looking for the visceral satisfaction of giant robots punching giant bugs, you won't really find that here as the combat animations and sound effects are fairly minimalist (though pushing the monsters into water or chasms never stops being funny). If, on the other hand, you're down for a well-realized puzzle game with a fascinating rule set and a helping of giant robotics on the side, you'd be mad not to check out Into the Breach.

Then check out Invisible Inc. once you're done. Not the Contingency Plan DLC, though. It sucks ballz.

40531057.review:
前作FTLがどのようなゲームかは説明不要だと思うが、
本作はそのランダム要素とアクション性を削り、
プレイヤーの思考のみフル回転させることで、
「超頭脳派ローグライク」ともいえる作品に仕上がっている。

敵の次ターンの行動はすべて把握でき、
それにどのように対応するかが基本システムとなっている。
主なランダム要素といえば手に入れるアイテムや
敵が攻撃対象を定める時ぐらいで、
ターン制ゆえに手の器用さは何の役にも立たない。
常に己の頭脳とAIとの対決になる。

ローグライクの醍醐味といえばランダム要素だろう。
この攻撃を外せばゲームオーバーというところで外し、
余裕だったのに気づけば無数の強敵に囲まれている。
ローグライクのランダム性は毎回のプレイを刺激あるものにし、
リプレイアビリティを大きく高めてくれる。
現実では嫌な「不運」がゲームでは何故か楽しくなるものだ。

本作にはそのような「不運」、ひいてはその刺激があまりない。
攻撃は必ず当たるし、与えるダメージも決まっている。
敵の増援マスを押さえればダメージと引き換えに妨害することもできる。
本作の大きなポイントである地形マスの変化も必ず何かしらの通知がある。

運要素があまり絡まないため、結果はほぼ全てプレイヤーに起因することになる。
攻撃がキャラクターを1マス押すことを忘れて大惨事になったり、
移動アップグレードをしなかったために攻撃が届かない、
前ターンで倒し損ねた1体の敵が災いとなり詰むなど、
どれもこれも「正しい手を打てなかった自分のミス」で片付いてしまうのだ。
運のせいにはできない残酷さ、そして常に最適解を求めるストイックさが、
今作の大きな魅力になっている。
あの時ああしていれば、と悔やむことが多々あるだろうし、
逆に思い通りのターン進行ができればアドレナリンが止まらないだろう。
自分の一挙手一投足に必ず結果がついてくる。

付随するもう1つの魅力が、場面場面での取捨選択である。
ローグライクらしく、少なからず運が場面を左右することもある。
狙われたくないキャラクターに何故か攻撃が集中したり、
最後の1ライフを建造物のダメージ回避確率に賭けるなどはよくある話。
そうしたギリギリの場面になると、何かを天秤にかける必要が出てくる。
敵の直線攻撃に自機が間に入ってダメージを負うべきか、
2周目覚悟でゲームオーバーになりパイロットを救うか、
一つの犠牲が僥倖になり得るかもしれないし、破滅になるかもしれない。
少しの積み重ねが未来を大きく変えるのはローグライクそのものである。

ただ、根本的な面白さは、やはり極限まで最適解を目指す頭脳戦にある。
ちょっとでも思考の甘さを見せれば一気に自分に返ってくる。
その分、完璧なプレイングを引き出せば次の展開が必ず楽になる。

ゲームの概念の話ばかりになって恐縮だが、
実際のプレイ感覚も「シンプルながら奥が深い」を地で行くものになっている。
ターン制のため操作量がものを言うこともなく、
扱えるユニットも基本3体なので毎ターンしんどさを感じることもない。
敵は直接殴る以外にも水に落としたり同士討ちさせることも可能。
プレイヤーの取れる選択肢を多すぎず少なすぎないよう設計してあり、
この洗練ぶりには舌を巻くほかない。

前作FTLはその完成度からインスパイアされたゲームがいくつか出ているようだが、
このInto the Breachもゲームとして新たな指標になる、そんな気がする。

Into the Breach jest grą strategiczną, nie ma tu ani jednego elementu zręcznościowego, mamy tyle czasu ile tylko potrzeba na zaplanowanie i wykonanie swoich ruchów. Gra polega na przeprowadzaniu turowych walk z wrogimi owadami - Vekami, w próbie uratowania ludzkości przed inwazją tychże niemilców.
Do dyspozycji mamy chyba 9 zespołów, każdy wyróżniający się w jakimś stopniu. Są to mechy, pilotowane przez pilotów. I jedne i drugie można rozwijać. Pilotów poprzez zdobywanie doświadczenia, a mechy przez instalowanie nowych broni i technologii. Dzięki temu wszystkiemu możemy próbować przejść grę na wiele sposobów z wykorzystaniem wielu taktyk.  Zupełnie jak w FTL, nieprawdaż?

[b]Jeszcze tylko jedna tura...[/b]
Tak tak, tu też gra została przeklęta czy też zauroczona. Jak się już zacznie grać, to ciężko się oderwać. Misje są krótkie i szybko się je przechodzi. Są one podzielone na 5 członowe cykle odbywające się w ramach wyspy. A na koniec wyspy jest możliwość zakupu i rozwoju mechów. A co to było w 30 minut przejść wyspę i zrobić zakupy? 
Albo przejść jeszcze jedną misję, może w niej będzie kapsuła czasu z darmowymi fantami? 
A może tylko zacznę, bo ostatni run mi się nie udał?
Wymówek, by zagrać jeszcze chwilę nie brakuje, gra wciąga i cały czas daje satysfakcję. Misje są zróżnicowane, możemy atakować, możemy bronić. Możemy wykonywać specjalne zadania. I mamy wybór (nie osteteczny, ale jakaś elastyczność istnieje).

[b]Przebieg misji[/b]
Sama walka na gridowej mapie też nie jest starym odgrzewanym kotletem, bo Subset Games i na tym polu dało powiew świeżości. Otóż gra wygląda tak. Najpierw desantujemy swoje trzy mechy potwierdzamy i gra rusza. W tym momencie to wrogowie wykonują swój ruch. A raczej go... planują. Czyli ich jednostki się przesuwają i pokazują się różne strzałki i kratki  pokazujące co się STANIE, gdy im na to pozwolimy. Teraz jest nasza kolej by wroga powstrzymać poprzez przesunięcie jego jednostek albo ich zabicie.
Możliwości nie brakuje, możemy wroga uderzyć, przepychając go, tak by wpadł na drugiego i obaj odnieśli obrażenia. Można go zamrozić, albo na przykład przerzucić w inne miejsce tak, by jego atak trafił w jego towarzysza. Jest tutaj sporo do kombinowania i ten aspekt daje naprawdę dużo frajdy. 
A pamiętajcie, że zespołów jest kilka, więc i taktyk sięznajdzie nie mało.

[b]Trochę lekkich rogalików[/b]
Gra jest przedstawicielem rogue-lite. Czyli jak przegramy to gramy od nowa, ale coś tam jednak zostaje i nie jest to start od zera. Odblokowane zespoły oraz odkryci piloci zostają na zawsze i możemy sobie wybierać do woli. 
Ale jest coś jeszcze. Fabuła gry polega na ciągłym powtarzaniu  próby uratowania ludzkośći. A gdy nam się nie uda mamy szansę wysłać jednego pilota, wraz z doświadczeniem jakie zdobył z powrotem w czasie. Wtedy nowa rozgrywka jest prowadzona właśnie z nim. Ciekawe, bardzo fajnie uzasadnione fabularnie no i przydatny mechanizm.

[b]Czy gra się nie znudzi[/b]
Ciężko powiedzieć, póki co przeszedłem ją tylko raz (zajęło mi to około 90 minut), było to dokoanne przy pomocy pierwszego składu. Do dyspozycji został mi więc wszystkie pozostałe. Poza tym są jeszcze osiągnięcia. Myślę, że czeka mnie jeszcze wiele godzin zabawy. Sama formuła gry pozawala na nawet 5-10 minut grania. Albo kilka godzin. Bardzo mi to pasuje.


[b]Plusy[/b]
- grafika - poza faktem, że jest to pixel art, to wszystko jest takie przejrzyste klarowne.
- muzyka - nadal ten sam kompozytor Ben Prunty, osobiście nie jest aż tak dobra jak w FTL, ale daje radę
- gameplay - gra się miodnie, satysfakcja aż się wylewa z ekranu
- małe wymagania sprzętowe, a gra zajmuje raptem 177 MB.
- do 6 marca zakup gry oznacza dodatkową kopię FTL.
- niedrogi zakup - 54 zł.

[b]Minusy[/b]
- ludzie zgłaszają od momentu premiery sporo problemów technicznych (nawet uniemożliwiające grania)
- gra zawiera trochę bugów,
- i jest ciut niezbalansowana jak donoszą gracze,
- ale nad obydwoma powyższymi pracują devovie, zresztą ciągle się udzielają.


Podsumowując, zachęcam fanów FTL. 
I każdego miłośnika strategii turowych, bo jest to fajna gra, z ciekawą formułą rozgrywki i dość dużym potencjałem do powracania do niej.

40527346.review:
あの名作FTLのスタッフの待望の新作。
人類は地底からやって来た巨大生物Vekに敗北し、滅亡……したかに見えた。だがまだ希望は残されている。
貴方は僅かに生き残ったタイムトラベラーとなり時間を遡ってMechを駆り滅亡の未来を書き換えるのだ！
ってのが大まかなストーリー。

昔ながらのターン制シミュレーションゲーム。8×8の小ぶりなマップで戦闘が行われる。
人々の居る建物を毎ターン押し寄せるVekから守るため一定ターンやり過ごすのが基本的な流れ。
建物が攻撃されると画面上部のゲージが減る。これが無くなるとゲームオーバー。
ステージが終わっても状態は引き継がれゲージ回復手段も多くない。
なので建物、もとい人々はとても大事。俺たちが守護らねばならぬ。

ゲームは毎ターン敵の移動＋攻撃範囲決定→プレイヤー側の移動＋攻撃→敵の攻撃＋移動＋攻撃範囲決定……と流れる。
それを利用してプレイヤーの攻撃で敵を押したり引いたり攻撃を止めさせたり、
時には敵同士ぶつけてダメージを与えたり地形効果も利用したりして建物を守るのだ。ついでに敵もぶっころがせ。
敵は攻撃範囲決定後は必ずその範囲に攻撃を仕掛ける。上手く動かして同士討ちも積極的に狙おう。
ものすごくシンプルなゲーム。だがそれがどうしてこんなに奥深いのか。
色んな知恵を総動員して敵を壊滅状態に持って行けた時は脳汁が出る。
逆に敵を動かしたことで建物や味方が攻撃に晒される事もあり、そんなときはやっちまった……ともなるのだ。
ともあれ毎ターン最良の結果を導くために画面の前でうんうんと唸ること間違いなし。おススメできる良作。
自分は英語苦手だけど問題なくプレイできた。更に有志の人たちの手で日本語化も進んでるんだぜ。ありがてぇ。

40527021.review:
1000% worth its price.
From the creators of FTL (Faster Than Light), Into the Breach brings a simple, yet genious turn based strategy rougelike game. Different from FTL, this is Its a turn based game, like Final Fantasy Tactics or Advance Wars.

The game:
The game is pretty simple. You select a squad of 3 mechs and try to save the earth. Each squad of mechs has its own unique theme and you have to adapt your playstyle in order to make it work. For example there is a squad that focuses on burning enemies and the terrain while your mechs are inmune to fire damage, or there is the Judoka squad that focuses on re-positioning your enemies with pushing/tossing moves in order to make them attack themselves.
In order to beat the game you have to fight in 4 different islands with different kind of terrains and enviromental hassards, and once completing them you can go to the "last stand" fight and try to beat the game. The game allows you to fight the last stand with only 2/4 islands complete if you are up for the challenge.


Unlocking squads:
Every time you complete the game with a squad you earn coins that are used to unlock new squads (any of them). Completing challenges also grant coins for new squads. Different from FTL, there is no locked path to unlock stuff. In FTL you needed to do challenges with ship A to unlock ship B, and after that you do challenges with ship B to unlock ship C and so on. In Into The Break you can unlock whatever squad you want as long as you have coins.
You can also play with your own custom squad! Make your dream team squad with the mechs you have unlocked and try new strategies. There is also the option to play with a random generated squad. Both options have their own challenges as well to earn some extra coins.

Pilots:
When you start a game you can choose a Pilot for one of your squad mechs. Pilots have skills that can alter A LOT how you play a mech. There a pilots that make your mechs tougher, others allow extra movement options (like flying) and many other great passive skills.

Conclusion:
The game is great, but its full of bugs (pun intended). If you want to play a great tactical game, you cant be wrong with this one. The amount of replayability is insane and you can easly tell that the game was made with a lot of passion. Great price, great devs and a great game.

PS; you get a free copy of Faster Than Light (FTL) with the purchase of this game!!!! If you already got that game you get an extra copy for you to gift it to your friends. Honestly you get a lot of value by buying this game.

40526413.review:
My initial impression of this game was that it was a charming little thing worth a few evenings of play. That was on normal difficulty with the starting mech squad. Then I changed the difficulty to hard, unlocked a couple more squads, and suddenly the game completely changed. Now it's easily one of my favorite indie games on Steam.

This is because the starting squad is a bit plain and predictable - aim the artillery, line up the cannons, and march your heavy in for a solid hit. It's a good way to become familiar with the game mechanics. But the game opens up once you leave that squad behind. The other squads all have entirely different play styles that require you to completely rethink your strategy and how you approach the game. What worked for one squad won't even get you past the first stage with another. There are squads with self-destructive attacks you have to arrange carefully, squads that light the field on fire and require you to manipulate enemies into gradual damage, squads that have a single heavy hitting mech and two others that exist solely to move enemies into position for devastating chain hits. I spent hours learning the quirks and strategies of one squad to finally beat the game on hard, then I switched to the new one I unlocked and got my ass handed to me anew. Each squad feels like a different take on the game, and the replay value resulting from that is fantastic.

I enjoy difficult games that make you work for victories, and on normal difficulty it took a couple tries before it seemed a bit too easy. But on hard the difficulty ramps up to perfection - extremely challenging moments have you staring at the screen for ten minutes plotting your next move and running thorugh every scenario in your head. It's been very common for me to be faced with a setting that seems like there's simply no way to come out alive, then suddenly a eureka moment where I see a long chain of events that could potentially lead to a narrow victory. These kinds of moments remove the frustration from the game and make you think that if you feel stuck, you aren't - you just haven't seen the solution yet. The music has a great feel of determination to it that perfectly suits those moments when suddenly you realize you may have found your way out.

There is a huge amount of strategy packed into the tiny maps in this game, and a considerable amount of content that far exceeds it's extremely reasonable price tag. If you've ever enjoyed games like XCOM, Final Fantasy Tactics, or even just chess, you'll be thrilled you picked this one up. And do work towards playing it on hard - that's when the multi-tiered strategy of the various squads comes into its own.

40526289.review:
[h1]Хуже FTL, но лучше большинства.[/h1]

Сложно было выбрать что ставить этой игре. Палец вверх или вниз. В тоге решил все же, что нужно ставить палец вверх. Но только потому что таких игр вообще мало. А не потому что она хороша - особенно на фоне FTL.

Начнем с минусов.

1. [b]Реиграбельность.[/b] Я прекрасно отдаю себе отчет в том что FTL была прежде всего рогаликом, а эта игра по факту оказалась гексагональной пошаговой головоломкой с ограниченной генерацией уровней.... И все же. Что вы ожидаете от игры на которой жирно написано "От создателей FTL"? Правильно - реиграбельности. Так вот ее сюда завезли в куда меньшей степени чем в FTL. В FTL были рандомные события с разными вариантами прохождения этих событий. Со всякими скрытыми и явными проверками на то есть ли у тебя тот или иной модуль на корабле или член экипажа или еще что.... Тут этого нет.

2. [b]Музыка.[/b] Она никакая. Она как творожок от Данон или песни кастрата о любви. Плоская, безвкусная, незапоминающаяся. Какого хрена, разрабы? У вас же был норм композитор, который для FTL написал бодрое электро, где местами встречались даже нотки джаза и электро-амбиента... А тут что? Полторы музыкальных темы на всю игру и все нечеткие и бессвязные? Вбейте на ютубе "FTL - The Last Stand". Даже не играв до этого в FTL вы услышите в ней все - и пустоту за бортом корабля и нарастающее напряжение за счет ударных, и вступление, и оснеовную часть и кульминацию, и части трека которые как бы говорят "подумай, рассчитай ход, может удастся схитрить" и части, которые как бы говорят "ну все пиздец! Все орудия к бою, у нас нет кислорода и мостик горит, но мы не сдаемся!" А что тут? Какая-то каша вместо треков.

Старая музыка словно писалась под кокаином. Новая музыка максимум писалась под водочкой с абсентом. 

3. [b]Графический дизайн.[/b] Это пиздец. В FTL была бедная 2d-графика, такая же она и в этой игре. НО! В FTL были объекты за которые мог зацепиться глаз и на которые могла в последствии опереться память - космические корабли. Корабли разных рас были выдержаны плюс-минус в одном стиле, в близкой цветовой гамме и т.д. В них был свой стиль, своя идея, своя харизма. Что мы видим тут в дизайне мехов и врагов? Вторичность и блеклость. Мало того что на экране они выглядят как нанописюны из Сколково так они еще и не оригинальны ни разу. Мех с кулаком, мех со щитом, летающий мех, мех-арта, мех с лазером... Серьезно?

4. [b]Проработанность лора игры.[/b] Смешно про это говорить в отношении быстрых игр, где каждая партия это максимум час, но все же. В FTL существовало 8 рас. Каждая со своими склонностями к тем или иным технологиям, каждая со своими характеристиками непосредственно у самих человечков-членов экипажа, каждая со своим взглядом на мир... Что видим тут. Есть вы, условные люди, есть враги, условные насекомые-зерги, есть 4 острова на которых сидят примерно одинаковые корпорации. Плюс минус, у одной там много старой техники, у второй всякие особенности на поле боя типа обваливание земли, молнии, терраформинг, у третьей значица заморозка и роботы, у четвертой кислота и эскалаторы, которые передвигают твоих мехов в начале хода (лол?). Как бы все. Разнообразия нет.

5. [b]Улучшения.[/b] Ну они реально не чувствуются. То есть в FTL была тактика и стратегия. Тактика это в процессе боя как бы победить врага быстро и с наименьшими потерями. Стратегия - как проложить маршрут, выполнять квесты или нет, как побольше ресурсов надыбать... Тут маршрут пролагается вообще изи, квестов считай нет (ачивки это не квесты) и как-то нет особой мотивации подбирать какое-то крутое оружие или как-то прокачивать их до предела. Почему? Потому что в новой игре очень сильно решает тактика. Можно пройти игру за бомже-сквад за счет выверенных ходов и можно слить супер прокачанных мехов буквально за 2 неверных хода. Стратегическая часть провисла, уступив место тактике. В FTL ты хотел поднять уворот через движок, нарастить щиты, закупить оружие по мощнее.... Тут ты сидишь и понимаешь, что решает не прокачка мехов, а твои ходы и их выверенность. И немного плюешь на прокачку.

6. [b]Общий геймплей и мотивация.[/b] Как оно было в FTL - летишь слева направо, рассчитываешь прыжки, сражаешься, закупаешься, приобретаешь членов экипажа, новые модули, выполняешь квесты, решаешь помочь или нет случайным встречным и в конце в рамках классической трехчастной композиции убиваешь босса. Что тут? Есть три меха, четыре острова и последняя локация вулкан. Все как бы - держи вилку и чисть. Что? Почему? Зачем? Это все человечество теперь живет на 4 островах? Почему именно острова? Откуда вообще взялся этот архипелаг (кроме как не от того что людям надо было как-то графически изобразить несколько отдельных друг от друга групп локаций и ничего умнее чем острова они не придумали)? 40525367.review:
[h1]Pros:[/h1]
+ An overall quality product from FTL developers
+ Great soundtrack
+ Fantastic visuals
+ Awesome setting
+ Achievement hunting made fun

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
- Maps
- Mission types

[h1]In-depth:[/h1]
So, first of all, this game has practically nothing to do with FTL. Yes, it's made by the same devs. Yes, it's visually somewhat similar (especially the UI). And yes, it also is a quality product. But the gameplay is completely different. Which is a great thing. We already have FTL which is a masterpiece, so why repeat it when you can make something new?

This game is challenging, but never once have I felt that it was unfair. Their can be tiny bit of luck involved in your initial unit placement and enemy spawns, but other than that I don't think that I've blamed the game much (if at all) for my losses. I always felt responsible for the moves I've been making, and it's great. That is exactly what a strategy should feel like.

I absolutely love the setting of this game. "Edge of Tomorrow", "Pacific Rim" and a bit of "Gundam" mixed together. Which gives us a variety of nicely designed weaponry to play with.

Music is limited, but however little there is - it's very pleasant. Feels like a bit of a mash-up of "Borderlands" and "Gravity Falls" soundtracks to me.

This is the first game in a long time where I felt like achievements weren't a chore, but instead a nice little extra challenge. Some of them are tied to your squads and help you learn its mechanics in a fun way. And then for doing it you unlock other squads.

If there is one issue I have with this game - it's its replayability.
So, you have your achievements, you have new unlockable squads and you can create your own made of the units you've unlocked. You have different pilots with different passive abilities as well. All of this is cool. However, the map and mission variety is extremely limited. You'll start noticing the same maps no further than your second run. And mission types - even sooner. It didn't stop me from enjoying the game so far, but I can see how it can be detrimental for long-term enjoyment.

That said, this game is still an easy recomendation for anyone who loves themselves a bit of tactics or is interested in the setting. Especially considering it's low price.

40525239.review:
Into the Breach is a puzzle rougelike that requires thought and planning for each consecutive turn. You are given a squad of three mechs and face off against waves of enemies. You can kill the enemies by attacking them, pushing them off cliffs or into liquids, or by having them attack eachother. Rounds end after a set number of turns, so routing the enemies isn't required. Enemy attacks are shown at the start of your turn so you can anticipate and turn them against eachother.

It's a fun formula, and it's made difficult through cities that you must defend, each hit to city takes away from your global health and if it reaches 0 it's game over. There are a couple of ways to restore that health, some missions offer it as a reward, and at the end of an island you have the option of spending earned renown on more health.

The game is divided between different islands that are similar to the sectors in FTL, there are 4 in all and once they have all been unlocked they can be tackled in any order. After completing 2 islands you can choose to do the final mission rather than do the remaining islands. 

Each island has its own theme and mission types that appear. The desert island tends to have missions that involve killing a set number of enemies compared to an ice island where you have to protect/destroy robots that act on their own. The variety between the islands is nice, but 4 islands feels like far too few, after a couple of playthroughs the missions start to get a little repetitive. 

Since Into the Breach suffers from a lack of content in regards to scenarios, the replay value comes from trying out different squads. Unfortunately, playing the game a second time with the same squad isn't as appealing as trying again with the same ship in FTL, as the mech's starting kit is generally worth using for the duration of the game.

So in its current state, I do recommend Into the Breach at its modest price of $15, I think it could easily provide 10-20 hours of entertainment and if additional islands are added even more. It also comes with FTL for free, which is an excellent game worth giving a try.

The time travel system, through which you're able to bring back your favorite pilot on your next  run to try again (whether it was a success or failure) it an amazing way to soften the blow of defeat and encourage you to push for another try.

It's an excellent gaming experience, and I look forward to many more runs to come.

You can kill a monster by using abilities that hurt it, or you can knock it into the water, or you can knock it into the zone another monster is attacking. There are so many different combinations of moves you can make, and it always feels like there's one perfect move each turn that prevents any building from getting hit. It's okay. It's no FTL (by which I mean FTL is a more entertaining game.)

This is, at the end of the day, a puzzle game. It is all about shifting units on various tiles in order to either cause them to damage their own allies, move your units/buildings/items out of the way to safety, or avoid insta-death from natural or manmade one-hit kills. 

There's unlockables, there's customization, there's a lot of good stuff. And don't get me wrong, it is fun, though there are frustrations where you simply don't have any chance of doing everything you need, not because of a bad choice or planning on your part, but simply due to lack of numbers or the random nature of where units spawned, moved to, etc. Sometimes you'll simply have to accept a loss that is out of your control and start over. At least starting over is neat, as you get to choose one pilot to carry over (not their upgraded mech, just the pilot), and that is a great boon, as they can have some great skills unique to themselves, like being able to move through enemies or start with a shield.

It's not *amazing*, but here's nothing wrong with that. It's a solid get, and will entertain you on and off for bits of time over the next few years.

40520302.review:
Simple yet genius. Into the Breach proves that you don't need fancy graphics or an immersive storyline to create an addicting, satisfying piece of art. Breach is a turn based gem, free of unfair RNG, where your moves have to be carefully planned  in order to be executed just right and secure the win. 

   The plot is very straight-forward. You're 3 mech-armed defenders, protecting the earth from alien threat known as Vek. You have to save as many civilian lives as possible. If You fail, You travel back in time in order to try again from scratch. That's the jist of it.

   Now the gameplay is where the meat of the game is. It's soo fun and rewarding. Every battle is very tactical, taking place on randomly generated maps with many different objectives. The game world is divided into 5 islands, each with it's unqiue special mobs and environmental mechanics like being able to freeze an object or set an enemy on fire. You also obtain numerous items and ennhancements for your mechs, changing their move set or stats. In all of the fights you are outnumbered with your 3 mechs. Utilizing their strengths and being aware of their weaknesses is key to success. Every mech has a very unqiue kit, allowing them to turn the odds in their favor. There are various 3-man mech teams known as squads, which you can unlock with coins acquired by completing challenges and various achievements.  During the turn-based mayhem you are able to use the environment itself as a tool of destruction, slamming enemies into walls, pushing them into the water and drowning them, etc.

   Regarding audio, the sound effects are great. You can really feel the abilities connect and the damage being done. As far as the soundtrack goes, it's pretty climatic. Has that tactical-ish sort of mood to it. It's not particularly memorable but while playing, it feels right at home with the games atmosphere.

Overall Into the Breach is a very satisfying and rewarding game, beautiful in it's simplicity yet amazing in execution. This is what video games should strive for! Great game!
