40518438.review:
Into the Breach is, in short, a well designed concept executed with a very strong soundtrack, solid visuals (notably the interface), and gameplay that rewards both reactionary and preemptive strategy.

For this game's audio and music, I don't feel the need to elaborate much further than to state the fact that Ben Prunty, the artist responsible for FTL's fantastic soundtrack, also created the soundtrack for Into the Breach. This is another way of saying that it's absolutely fantastic, and fits the game's genre just as well.

From a purely visual standpoint, the animations are more on the simplistic side, and the design of everything is fairly simple. I'm sure this game could have had a higher level of attention put towards the graphics, not explicity the style or design itself, but they are still solid and very servicable for a turn based strategy game of this scale. On another design note, the interface itself is very, very clean and easy to read, and mousing over units highlights their actions and their consequences enough that it is impossible to make a mistake due to misinterpreting them.

Speaking of mistakes, this game has extremely little RNG factored into the core gameplay, which for me is a welcome departure from the experience FTL delivers. Enemies move, before your turn even begins, and then telegraph their attack before you are able to move your own units. This creates gameplay where you use the many different weapons each mecha has to both kill, disable, and manipulate the positioning of enemies to mitigate damage to friendly units and structures. Manipulation of positioning allows one to drown an enemy to end them instantly, force them to block another emerging unit, or even cause friendly fire, the latter having an entire mech squad dedicated to such a gameplay strategy.

The core gameplay loop of this roguelike, similar to many others, is not very long. Resetting takes almost no time at all, and only leaves you with the experience on one pilot to give you a slight edge, so subsequent runs depend more on personal performance than outside progression. Every mech squadron has a unique gimmick that forces you to approach threats differently, and they all can be used to beat the game. The overworld is seperated into 'Islands', which have one approach a set of missions in a mostly non-fixed order until there are 3 left incomplete, where they do a final mission with a boss-type enemy, and after which they are able recieve and spend their reward for clearing. After new islands are introduced, they can be played in any order, and the game itself can be shorter or longer if one desieres, as the final island is open after one clears 2 islands, which is technically only half of the overworld.

As far as difficulty is concerned, 'Normal' is easier than the 'Normal' that FTL offered, though it will still prove to be a notable challenge, there is also no visible penalty for playing on an easier difficulty other than a reduction in score. Changing difficulty also only really changes the number of enemies one encounters, so if one is frustrated I would support playing on a lower one to gain a better understanding of this game.

The biggest miss of Into the Breach, however, is that the game conveys very little story within itself. This is mostly due to the very low amount of dialogue outside of combat, and while there is surely an interesting story within, there is little done to elaborate upon it. The map size also feels a bit limiting, though I suppose with only 3 playable units by default anything larger would become too daunting.

Overall, however, I would strongly support purchasing Into the Breach, as it has more than enough replayability to merit the price tag of $15 USD. If I was forced at gunpoint to give a nondecimal numerical rating for this game, out of 10, it would most likely recieve an 8. Though if they add any content at all, such as was done with FTL, said nummerical rating will spike to a 9 immediately.

(I'm also morbidly curious how this game would play on mobile but please port it to android too)

40518428.review:
Did you love FTL? Do you think it's a masterly combination of exploration, combat, and hard decisions; both prioritization throughout your journey and in every choice you make? A true example that sometimes less is more?

Do you remember that one run where you got the perfect gear that catapulted you to the final boss, or do you reminisce about that one run where everything went wrong, but you still prevailed again and again before finally grasping triumph with the shredded remnants of a crewed ship on the verge of defeat?

Into the Breach is none of that.
None at all.

Now don't get me wrong, I enjoyed the game. Got myself a good pilot, trained him to max level, and started a run with a randomized set of mechs that turned out to be excellent. Went from one island beat to complete 4 island run in a single game. And it was great.

But that was it. 

There was no exploration element. Sure, there are four islands, but because you're supposed to be able to play them in any order they feel generic and bland, even when they're anything but.

Combat is fun, unique, challenging. And repetitive. Found a strategy that works with your current setup? Good. Now use it for the next 10 missions almost exactly the same way. Found an upgrade? New weapon? Good for you. It's rarely going to replace the standard weapons of your mechs, it's just a new backup option in case the primary weapon isn't ideal. Which is good, don't get me wrong, but it doesn't have the gratification of finding that one piece of gear that you just KNOW is going to change the fate of your run.

And decisions? Well to be fair, there's plenty of priority decisions to be made. Do you sacrifice a pilot, or do you run the risk and sacrifice a building? Or the bonus objective? Hard choice. Unless you're having a good run, in which case you can buff up your grid to the point where it hardly even matters if buildings get hit anymore.

If you ask me what really could have made a difference, I would have gotten rid of the optional island sequence, made the game longer (though I really like the option to attack the boss early, if you dare), and let the player start with a single mech and having more join the squad through the game. Too much is decided already with you deciding your entire loadout from the start.


I'm done. I tried going back, tried wanting more. But I'm done.
It doesn't feel like there's anymore to come back for.
This game isn't FTL. Do not buy this game if you loved FTL and want more.
Because there is no FTL to be had here. And more than anything, that is the nail in the coffin.
Because it's a good game. It's just not a good FTL.

An Elegant Game... From a More... Civilized Time...

         OR..... 
"Five Minutes Ago... From A Galaxy... Actually... pretty similar to the last one.... and.... the one before that.... and...."

    Five hours in, this game is already very different from their last offering.

   This is a good thing! Faster Than Light was brutally difficult even on easy. And for the casual gamer, or the worker looking to relax, a ten hour easy campaign to get randomly annihilated by a mother ship was... frustrating.

   Behold! The easy mode is actually easy. And, thankfully, the difficulty curves exponentially, so the challenge is worthy of Subset Games vision of what a game should be. Perhaps Matt Davis and Justin Ma are rolling their eyes at that, but whatever. We cant all play a game just to lose.

    The aesthetics of this game are very tight-  high contrast, post 8 bit format, lends to a unique, cartoonishly  hyper-realistic visual experience. It is ultimately appealing as the aesthetic is consistently reflected. I am never broken from the battle narrative by, "Oh. That enemy looks stupid." or "that attack doesnt feel... MEATY." The audio lends strongly to the battle experience, with a tight, edgy soundtrack by Ben Prunty.

    The battles are strategically fun, with an interesting enemy forecasting mechanic that makes the game more chess like and much less random than Faster Than Light. That being said there is still a certain degree of randomness that is teeth clenchingly frustrating. You cannot save every building sometimes. Sometimes enemies will spawn and mass attack one important mission objective. But the various unique abilities of your mecha creat interesting oppertunites; the potential for clever tricks that leave you feeling like a cunning mecha general is pretty deep.

   So far the only downside is how short it is! But this is a nice change from the grueling lenght of FTL. Since my free time dried up returning to community college for Computer Engineering, I suddenly find my self appreciating games with a 1.5 hour run time. I think the aesthetic of beggining in the hanger bay, and watching your mecha drop to the surface is a great metaphore for this game. Drop in. Blow some bugs up. Change timelines. Drop out. Repeat.

   It is a throwback to the classic arcade style game where the emphasis was on learing the program, mastering the tricks and strategies, then endlessly replaying for that high score. And do it again, because along the infinite, glittering curve of space time....

                                                                                                   Theres always another damn bug.

   I give this game 4/5 golden Shoggoths, a Golden Nightgaunt for sound track and audio, and a Silver Nightgaunt for battle mechancis and a bit of story. (But shout out to Chris Avalon, Black Isle whut, whut!) 15$ you cant go wrong!

40516145.review:
I'm a big fan of turn-based strategy games. From Final Fantasy Tactics to Hoplite, nothing engages more than having thousands of lines of play, all of which could end your run outright, or give you a perfect turn that annihilates your enemies and gives you hope that you can win this game, and everything in-between.

Into The Breach accomplishes this flawlessly and I don't use the word flawless lightly here. Every map in the game is tailor-made rather than procedurally-generated, and it really shows. The tight designs of these maps really make the experience feel extremely difficult, but very rarely unfair.

Every map is an 8x8 grid. You control 3 Mechs from the future. AI-controlled bug creatures are trying to exterminate the human race. Into The Breach flips the normal "Mechs vs Aliens" dynamic. Its the buildings filled with people that are important to protect, not necessarily your mechs. This adds so much depth and flavor to the game, as every single building is precious. When you lose too many, you lose the game. The crystal-clear UI for the game makes for a silky-smooth play experience, as you can easily absorb all the important information quickly to start formulating your lines of play for that turn.

To add to an already great strategy experience, you can unlock different sets of Mechs with completely different abilities. You can play these mechs as a set, or custom-make your own squad of mechs from the ones you've unlocked. Or, you can even roll a random squad of Mechs to send into the breach for a real challenge. You can also customize your mechs during your playthroughs for a different experience. I don't really see an end to the replayability of this game.

Into The Breach might just be a Best-in-Genre turn-based strategy game.

Okay, so after a few hours of playing this game I have to say that I'm falling in love with it. The soundtrack is eerily similar to FTL, which is a good thing. The premise is good, and being a roguelite with a reason (using Rogue Legacy as an example, each time you die your heir takes your place), is a good thing. It makes every loss and playthrough feel like it is just a continuation.

The game seems simple. The tutorial is pretty quick and you learn the fundamentals through it. The fundamentals stack like bricks allowing for more strategic decision-making in game. This is where the game becomes wonderful. With each SHORT mission (you can finish any mission in about 5 minutes),  you are presented with multiple tasks and scenarios. You have multiple things you need to accomplish and while the game might seem easy at first, most of the time you are not given the means to accomplish each of these things.

When you fail to accomplish a small task, they build up. They wreck you. Do you want to save a pod for a future enhancement to aid in future missions? Well, it will cost you the pilot in your artillery mech... or a critical resource. It's a consistent series of critical thinking and decision making.

Well I initially was on watch with this game when I found out who was developing it; the team who made FTL - in my opinion, one of the best Spaceship crew managment sims out there, one that blends RPG and RNG with a clear understanding of how "Tactical battles" should actually be tactical. 

And in Inot the Breach - they once again have shown themselves capable of delivering on that. Into the Breach plays out like a randomized persistent game of mini Chess problems that you solve with three Mechs - each Mech, like a Chess piece has it's own unique moveset and, Mechs come in 3s from different "squads." Each squad has it's own gimick - for example, the starting three Mechs you're given heavily rely on pushback as a mechanic - using your bruiser Mech and pushback effects to keep the enemy away from your objectives - and your Mechs themselves, who're quite fragile if you let them take hits.

There are several different squads and each come with three unique mechs, and their own well thought out strategy - but where the game really gets interesting, is that you don't have to employ these pre-set squads and their pre-formulated startegies - you can mix and match. You can take the units from the Push and Pull squad and mix them with say the Smoke screen squad - any combination you can come up with. 

To me that's the biggest plus of the game is that level of real strategy present in Chess has been successfuly translated into a Rogue-lite RPG. 

The theme of the game as well as the artwork is also a major draw; think Live, Die Repeat meets Starship Troopers meets Pacific Rim. 

Overally I'd rate this game 8/10 and I'll list my very few qualms with this game below.

Cons: 
-Pricepoint of 17$ might be a little bit much, but I still highly recommend you support this studio
-Could use a bit more content
-This feels like a mobile game - and I want it to be one.

Great game though, from a very talented team - I look forward to seeing more from them in the future. And hopefully they port this title to Android because that's where it'll truly shine, on your daily commute.

I have played the game for ~5 hours, and reached the end a few times on normal. I wanted to love it, but I just don't. Apparently a lot of people do, but I wanted to give my opinions of the game, as it clearly wasn't a game for me.

Pros:
-Great core gameplay
-Solid challenge, that is hard, but fair

Cons:
-Minimal improvement over the course of the run. In FTL (and roguelikes in general) you get substantially stronger during the run. In into the breach I felt like I could have almost as easily beaten the final level with base stats as with what  I have had in the actual runs.
-Upgrades are uninteresting, and the currency mechanic as well. Not once have I felt like "Oh yeah, this I want to buy" at the end of an island.
-The unlock system is tedious. It takes so long for me to unlock new squads I just don't want to do it.
-Replay value is pretty low. This is related to the minimal improvements that happen during the run: all of the runs with the same squad just feel identical, and there is not much variety in how I played a certain squad. 
-No story or anything else to keep you involved.
-The choice of how many islands you want to complete makes very little sense. There is no reward to be had by doing extra islands, and the final level scales, so it feels completely pointless. Coupled with the low scaling during a run, there is no feel of "Oh yteah I want to pwn enemies with this build a bit more".

Overall the game is just a thinly packaged random puzzle generator. As such it can be great for some people, but I do not think I will continue playing the game myself.

40508467.review:
TL:DR 9/10. A must for casuals, turn-based or indie game lovers. Highly replayable and worth your money. Full review below.
___

[i]Hence the saying: If you know the enemy and you know yourself, your victory will not stand in doubt; if you know Heaven and you know Earth, you may make your victory complete - Sun Tzu[/i]

If I were to describe this game in one sentence, it's like having a game of chess but you have to plan every possible options for the best outcome when everything is against you or it's game over. Into The Breach is a chess kind of turn-based PvE where it takes place in timelines of a planet facing the threat of an alien species known as Vek. You are the commander of a squad of three so-called "Mechs" each with a pilot that have skills when levelled up and your job is to protect the cities from the invasion of Vek. Sounds simple right?

Easier said than done. By miles.

During each battles you have to protect cities or facilities that both contain a bar of your power grid. The power grid is your 'health bar' in this game and if it reaches zero, game over. You don't get to recover much power and the grids' defense are as low as 15% to resist an attack so protect your cities/facilities at all cost. However, your Mechs also have HP as well. If they reach zero, your pilots will die like permadeath and your mech can't move until the battle is over. You also have the fact that your enemies, the Vek, all come in different abilities and pattern so they are unpredictable as ever. They even have reinforcements in every turn unless you stand on their spawing spot for a cost of 1 HP of your mech. How on earth are you gonna win then?

With a plan. No, the greatest plan with perfect execution for the sweetest smile on your face.

Every move and action in this game is crucial. Like chess, you must not only know your units capabilities but your enemy and your positions. Knowing your mechs abilities and stats will allow you to determine who to face and not face as well as avoiding unneccesary consequences on the next turn. Position is even more crucial as it determines a lot of factors such as movement, risks, enviromental hazards, blocking and knockback. Every battle/map may have enviromental hazards of different kinds and they INSTANT KILL everything, even bosses. Oh did I mention knockback in this game is a double-edge sword? IMO mostly good if executed well in your favour. and it feels so good. Plan your positions and/or actions every turn in the right order for the right execution and you'll have the greatest triumphant feeling at every turn when you get many ways to save your grids from Vek in such variety of ways. That's how everyone feels when a plan goes well.

ITB also has some roguelike elements that FTL had where you can get equipments, exp and cores to upgrade or give your mechs new abilities that can either change your playstyle or give you certain buffs/advantages. Pilots that are promoted will have new skills that could benefit you in battles so pay attention to what they can do. You are given bonus objectives which I highly recommend fulfilling if you wish to gain either more corporate points (money to buy equipments/upgrades/power at the end of a boss fight), mech equipments/upgrades and grid power that if full, will add extra grid power or defense if you have full power. Time pods also fall on the map and have super valuable equipments so grab them ASAP or defend them. While mech equipments can be equipped and unequipped, reactor cores are permanent so choose wisely. There is a lot to choose from so I do recommend trying them all...if it works for your squad's strategy.

If you either get a game over or win the game (with one pilot alive for both), that selected pilot will be the 'time traveller' and can be brought in into a new game for you to start over. A nice little advantage if you think the last game either went well and you wanted to try something harder or new or you wanted to have vengeance on those Vek.

Achievements in this game btw rewards you with a coin that allows you to buy new sets of mechs with unique abilities. They come in form of mechas, tanks, artillery/ranged and so on. The greatest thing about this is that you can customize your own squad and have at least one 'mech' into your squad of 3. This is why the game is super replayable because every squad has a different playstyle and strategy and you have to plan how to synergize the squad. Some can pull, some have knockback, some are tanky, etc. Every mechs can have a variety of roles in your game which what makes the game so amazing. You make the team, you command them according to plan and watch Vek fall right below you.

The game also allows you to do unlimited redos but only for movements. If you attack/fire/use an ability you can never undo them. You could reset the entire turn yes but it is only used once per battle. Use it wisely and plan carefully because you only have 1 to 2 shots. What's even more intense is that some choices are inevitable and such sacrfices like a damage or a grid power loss is necessary for the best result. It's a bittersweet feeling but this gives a rollercoaster of emotions on your decisions. War is not won without sacrifices after all so pick the best strategy for the long run.

Overall, I love this game  so much for actually rewarding you on planning and understanding the art of war. The only RNG elements you get are either the grid defense which barely helps much or enviromental hazards and those are just 10% of the game. The rest are all about outsmarting your enemy. They may make the first move but you have to make the best counterattack for the best result. You may be outnumbered, you may be weak, you may be cornered but the greatest plan and judgement at the end of the day will make you win the war. Into The Breach is a super fun, replayable and intense turn-based game that encourages smart play against the enemy and it feels real.

This game gets a 9/10. I would love this game to have some kind of online PvP or mods or even more content and I would have given this game a 10/10. Get the game. Highly recommended if you love turn-based games like Xcom/Fire Emblem/Advanced Wars and if you're a casual, do try it out! It's a must.

Now excuse me as I need to get myself to review this game in another timeline. Have fun reader.

If you like pixel art, rogue-lites and mechs, this is an immediate buy for 15 bucks if you ask me.
I've already spent over 5 hours with it and just scratched the surface...on easy. And there's 2 more difficulties. Easy feels mostly fair though. Not sure what the higher difficulties change. Probably more enemies, maybe smarter, maybe more HP or special abilities, maybe less resources for you.

In any case, Into the Breach is a rogue-lite mechs-vs-monsters game. It is your goal to defend humanity vs. a monster invasion. To do so you have 3 mechs at your disposal, each differing from another not only visually but also in gameplay. You have to utilize your 3 mechs together to achieve victory. Some mechs shoot, some hit, some ram and take damage, others push or pull, some have long range, some special effects, area effects, etc. There's an almost endless mix of possibilities here. In order to win you have to save 2 to 4 islands. The choice is up to you. The more islands you successfully defend, the more resources you get to upgrade your mechs or your defenses, but the final battle will get harder as well, since you got stronger. Modular difficulty so to speak. This enables you to have quick 30 minute runs or drag the game out to over an hour, but the outcome is the same.

By completing the game and earning achievements you earn coins to unlock other squads. There are 8 in total. You only start with the basic one. Some are cheaper, some are more expensive, but each squad has 3 unique achievements you can complete. Together with the generic world achievements you will eventually get and some other hardcore achievements you shouldn't have too much trouble unlocking all squads. I'm currently missing 2 or 3 I think and I'm just playing with the 2nd squad now. And if that is not enough you can also create a custom squad with all unlocked mechs or let the AI cobble together a random one for you.

After each defended island you will get the chance to spend your resources and upgrade your mechs if you want to. What you can get is mostly random, but upgrading your reactor core power will always enable you to plan at least somewhat ahead. More HP? More movement? More damage? Easy.

Combat is turn based. The enemy always starts first, then it's your turn, etc. Enemies will attack your mechs and the buildings you need to protect. Losing a building means losing power. When all power is gone, your run is over. You can also get more power through missions or purchases and there is a certain chance that buildings will resist damage. Should one of your mechs fall in combat, however, it's gone for the remainder of the battle and its pilot usually dies, leaving you with a weaker mech, unless you have a spare pilot that has also earned XP in your run. Very precarious when you have mechs in your squad that deal damage by taking damage...

All in all it's a highly interesting game and the 2 hours to test it out should be enough to finish your first run and refund it if you hate it.

I've just spent 30 minutes staring at the screen, stuck in a dilemma. There are 3 positive outcomes possible: I save 2 cities under attack, I destroy the remaining mountains with the acid thrower, and I can save one of my mechs. The problem is that  I can only acheive any 2 of those outcomes:

I can save the city, and destroy the mountains, but the mech pilot will be killed, which is probably the correct approach, as mech pilots are supposed to be expendable. However, the mech pilot is fully levelled, and this the last island, so I can't replace them, which will make the finale harder.

I can save the cities and the mech, but then the objective of destroying the mountain is impossible. While I am not losing the perfection bonus, having already failed previous objectives, I need any help I can get for the finale, and that extra reputation could be the difference between life and death.

I can save the mech and destroy the mountains, but leave the cities to die. Obviously losing 2 grid power is bad, but despite this, I am tempted by the 18% resist chance that I only lose one grid power, and the 3% chance I could take no damage any way. This option has the tiniest chance of getting all three outcomes, but if it fails, it is clearly not the heroic option.

I took the risk after 30 minutes of deliberations.

This is the part where I would like to tell you that 3 in a 100 chance came through and everything was great, but both buildings fell, killing 100s, and I ended up spending that reputation on getting back a power grid unit.

This is the story of the hardest decision I've ever taken in a video game, and the reason that Into the Breach might just be one of favourite games.

The game is not expensive for the quality of the final product so go ahead !

40505246.review:
This game is fucking amazing. It's very intuitive and tells you 90% of the information that will happenn. Imagine playing a turn-based war-game with tanks and mechs against giant insects--except the computer tells you EVERYTHING the computer is going to do that turn. It's up to you to reverse the effects. The game reminds you which tile is under threat and from which direction, so you can't scream you didn't know which direction the attack was coming from.

Besides directly damaging opponents, you can also utilize various effects, such as pushing them into hazards (your units are amphibious even if not all of them can still fire however most land-based Vek are not; likewise a giant pit is fatal to anything that can't fly), or canceling their attacks straight off through a smoke-screen or something.

As a Rogue-lite, it also has some legacy effecst. If you fail completely, you are allowed to send one of your pilots back in time. This allows you to restart the beginning of the game except you have a decent pilot. You may not have an awesome vehicle that's been pimped out anymore but at least the pilot retains his/her/its skill. 

If you get tired of playing the same pilots and squads over and over, you can unlock new pre-set squads and even random squads, similar to FTL's ships or Convoy's different starting options. 

This game has the same level of polish that FTL does and has a lot less RNG involved. Sometimes you get a bad deal with the map spawning tilesets in a way you feel like you can't escape unscathed, but such is the case with any procedurally-generated game. The game permits you to completely reset a turn once a battle, as well as undo any action you've made provided it wasn't an attack or a special ability.

I could gush and gush like a money-shot here but seriously this game is a must-have for ANY strategy enthusiast.

22 hours in. I have nearly every mech team unlocked. Multiple victories. And currently achievement hunting. There are some things I've noticed about Into the Breach both good and bad. Of course being spoiler-free as best I can.

Lets start off with the bad. Ultimatly, it doesn't seem to matter who you have on your team or what equipment you use. I can only count one time so far that the enemy was doing something I could literally not stop. Every other time it was purely bad positioning on my part, or not fully understanidng what tools I had access to. Every turn is a puzzle game version of chess. To achieve this, Into the Breach has AI that takes into account what you can actually do and tailors the enemy to allow you to beat them. For example, one of the mechs can upgrade to drop fire behind them when they shoot their main gun. Before getting this upgrade I never saw a time to use it at all. In fact, I only picked it up originally because I was going for an achievement. However the very next game after I upgraded it I had TWO moments where that ability was super important to my actions. Now I prioritize upgrading my base stats like movement, damage, and health instead of new abilities or equipment. The only new perks I get are those that would outright prevent damage to structures or things that prevent issues I've had. The more options I have the more complicated each puzzle becomes since there are more ways the situation can play out. This has caused it to feel like none of my choices going into a game matter. It's all about what flavor of defeating the enemies I go with.

What also adds to that feeling is the somewhat small equipment pool available to you. There is just enough for each mech team to have almost entirely unique gear, and that is it. I have one more mech team to unlock, and I suspect that the equipment I've seen in shops that I've yet to be able to start with all belong to them. The best you have to really tailor your team is the time travelling pilot you pick. There are a sizable amount of them to unlock and each one has a "perk" that can actually alter how that mech plays significantly. One give you a shield, one let you hover, one gives you one more "retry" per game, etc etc. When you beat the game or lose entirely you can pick one of your pilots to start with again. Keeping their perks and experience for the next game. However once you are getting through games all the way to the end and not really losing any pilots you are actually incentivised not to ever change them. I've had one pilot for 5 victories now. Because if I change him, I lose the bonus experience perks they have now. Whoever else I pick, the AI will account for and I will not have really gained much. Just changed the flavor of the game slightly and then lost the bonus perks. Into the Breach needs a bit of an expansion to the equipment pool and to have earned experience not matter for the special pilots. I want to have unique, cool items I can only find in shops. Original Review:

So... I beat it.  Cleared all four islands and completed the final objective on the volcano island on my third playthrough.  It took me a little over 3 hours of playtime to do so.  Obviously I'm not done, I still have a bunch of factions and acheivements to unlock, but I feel like I have seen enough to render a review.
I bought this game strictly on three grounds: I love FTL, and I love SRPGs, and I love roguelikes/roguelites.  So, let me address the three in order.

1. FTL
You can tell that this was the same development team as FTL straight from the menus.  The loading icon is even the same.  Is this game like FTL? ...no.  Other than visuals, ergonomics, and progression system, the games are very different. FTL is realtime with pause.  This is turn based.  In FTL the scope is narrower but deeper.  You have one ship at a time, but there was so much you could do with it, and there were so many playstyles.  You had a bunch of different weapons with different effects that you could synergize together.  You could play without weapons and only use drones.  You could use mind control.  You could board ships.  You could disable life support systems.  The list goes on. 
In this game you play as three mechs, and all you essentially do is attack or push enemies around the playfield.
Is this game as good as FTL?  No.  FTL is a masterpiece, an essential piece of gaming history.  This game I would not classifiy as a masterpiece.

2.  SRPG
Strategy Role Playing Games (aka Tactical Role Playing Games) are top down tactics games where you manipulate your characters in a grid, typically from an isometric perspective, moving them around and attacking one turn at a time. What makes it an RPG is that the units gain experience from combat and level up, and carry equipment.  Some examples of SRPGs are Tactics Ogre, Final Fantasy Tactics, Front Mission, Fire Emblem, Advance Wars, and Disgaea.  Is this game like those games?  Not really.  The game it most resembles is Advance Wars, but you generally only command three units at a time in Into the Breach, there is no base capturing, there is no unit generation, and there are no in battle resources to spend, there is no fog of war, the maps are all the same (square) shape, the maps are much smaller, there are far less types of units, there are no ally units, or commanders.  Honestly this game feels much more like a puzzle game than an SRPG.  You have to survive 5 rounds of enemies spawning in.  Your "life" is tied to the buildings in the game.  Everytime a building is destroyed, one unit of power is removed from the powergrid shown at the top of the screen.  Run out of power and you lose.  How you stop the enemies from destroying your buildings is by pushing them around the field or destroying them, or interupting their attack by freezing them or putting them in dust clouds.  That is esentially it.
Is this game as good as those SRPGs I listed?  No, those are seminal entries in the genre.

3.  Roguelike/Roguelite
ADOM, Caves of Qud, TOME, Nethack, Brogue, Pixel Dungeon, these are roguelikes.  Into the Breach is not a traditional roguelike.  Would I categorize it in the more nebulous genre of roguelite?  ...no.  Your toolset and the interactions are far more limited, and the action is turnbased while games in the roguelite genre are typically realtime, like Binding of Issac, Spelunky, FTL, Nuclear Throne, etc.  I'd say this game would more accuratly be categorized under the puzzle roguelike subgenre, like Desktop Dungeons, Hoplite, Road Not Taken, and perhaps UnExplored.  Is this a good puzzle roguelike?  Well, I am not a fan of puzzle roguelikes, so I can't say authoratively, but I will say that the "puzzles" are very carefully balanced, and I never encountered a moment where I would have to take power grid damage or fail an objective without making a tactical error.  In fact I feel that it is too balanced, but that is likely just my preference for the other genres listed.  In SRPGs, by carefully leveling up and equiping your characters, you can overpower your enemies, although they typically outnumber your units.  Or you may encounter overwhelmingly powerful boss units, and have to lure them into traps to beat them.  The variety in challenge makes it exciting.  In roguelites, the rendomness and interactions can make for exciting chaotic events, like in Spelunky, when you grab an idol and it crashes into an offscreen shop, which pisses off the shopkeeper, who then hops around the map, killing everything in sight before impaling himself on spikes.  Similar situations also occur in traditional roguelikes.

So, ultimately do I like this game?  Yes.  Is it a good game?  Yes.  Is it a great game?  No.  What would make it a better game?  I would prefer if there was more depth overall.  I feel that it needs more map shapes, bigger play fields, more units to command, and more variety in playstyles.  I hate how every enounter is 5 turns.  I also don't like that every encounter is against waves of unknown enemies spawning from randomized locations, limiting your ability to prepare for battle.  I also hate how every encounter is so carefully balanced and that there is a right and wrong way to deal with every encounter.  If you play correctly, you will never take grid damage or lose an objective.  If you make a tactical error at a critical moment (after using up your 1 retry turn ability) it may cost you the game.  The game feels like the skeleton of a better game.  I wish that the mechs had the depth of play that FTL has.  Hopefully the developers continue to add more meat to that skeleton and flesh out the gameplay.

TLDR
As of right now I'll give it 7.5-8/10.  An 8x8 grid is too small.  3 units are too few.  5 rounds every battle is too limiting.  Constant, random waves of enemies every match is tiresome.  The game is still fun and addicting, it just feels very limited, and at times, frustrating.

Into the Breach is a strategy game for strategy game fans. It intentionally avoids all the regular flashiness and long animations in favor of stark presentation and snappy gameplay that gives you the important information with minimal waiting, a sin many other strategy games are incredibly guilty of.

In Into the Breach, you have a persistent resource across all battles called the Power Grid, which goes down if you let damage come to a civilian building. This puts careful positioning at the forefront of every decision. Before every turn, you're shown exactly what attack every enemy is about to perform, and your goal is to use your tools to shift enemies in a way that works to your advantage, whether that's keeping a civilian building out of harm's way or even turning enemy units against one another.

It's extremely good, and like the very best strategy games, it imparts the feeling that every single victory or loss is entirely up to your skill. The game has almost no RNG, except for a potential saving throw on civilian buildings.

None of this is to say that the game is inaccessible - if anything, Into the Breach is probably an amazing starting point for anyone looking to get into the genre due to its clear presentation and helpful tutorial system.

（1）难度的浮动性太大：游戏内通过你岛屿的解放数量影响高强度Alpha型敌人的出现量来控制难度的递增，但如果在前期岛屿的必经之路上出现同时“摧毁两座山”“击杀七个敌人”，对前期没有成型的小队来说有非常有难度的，就基本告别这个岛屿的完美奖励了。反面的例子是，后期遇到有绿洲毁灭者的关卡，或者酸液实验室的关卡，等于本方多了一个强力范围输出，难度直线下降。
（2）算半个缺点：建筑物的免伤概率，经过我两天的思考后确定，是一个败笔。在一个相对硬核的战术游戏加入了一个随机看脸的因素，会影响战局中行动的利弊计算，干扰指挥者的决断。这一点是我的主观认知，对于喜欢随机因子的人来说也许是另一种乐趣。

说完缺点说优点，人尽皆知的战棋游戏的优点就不讲了，讲讲我个人心中的三大亮点：
（1）八个小队，二十四台战车（战机），各有特色，每个小队有三个特色成就，非常贴合小队特色，用新的小队开新的一个时间线是一个非常有乐趣的挑战，让人乐此不疲。
（2）十三个机师，初始技能迥异，有些技能几乎是为了某个小队的主力战车定制的，比如烟雾和网免疫，配合第二小队……相比较下，升级技能倒没什么亮点，基本上离不开“反应堆+1”“机体HP+2”“网格防御+3%”这几个。
（3）也许有一百万个人已经说过了：这个游戏最大的亮点就是本身的战术体系，位移，射击和抛射，敌方全程先动的模式前无古人，甚至让我看到了战棋游戏对战新模式的突破口，有种五子棋先动方追求活四活三的感觉，让对战双方真正从战术层面上对决，用各自有限的行动来取舍，而不是攻防，移动力和视野的比较。

总体来说，这个游戏的思路已经领先当前的所有战棋游戏一大截了。
评分修正为—— 9/10。

40500021.review:
[i]2 Minute video review coming soon![/i]

[h1]Overview[/h1]

Into the Breach is a roguelike strategy game that looks quite similar to [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QKRpm-M2Qgs] Advanced Wars[/url] . The game however does not play almost anything like Advanced Wars but instead much more like a puzzle game. The game is very cut and dry. Given thought it's almost certain you'll win every time. It holds very few elements that are both random and something that you can't deal with. This steps away from the formula of FTL but that's not to say that the love there doesn't carry over. Let's dive into what makes this game what it is and see if it's worth your time.

[h1]The Good[/h1]

[b]Visuals[/b]:
The game is immediately quite pretty. I don't think I have to tell you this but I should mention it in this review to give the designers credit where it's due. The pixel graphics are well shaded and set up the foundation for a satisfying game. Following this is the animation quality which is equally good if not better. This is clearly seen when you [url=https://youtu.be/5XHEyH6diV8?t=35s]click on a map[/url] to start the battle. The moving and fighting animations themselves are simple but fit the game well.

[u]The game is pretty and offered solid animations to boot.[/u]


[b]Gameplay[/b]:
Moving to the gameplay itself the game holds up remarkably well. At its core the game is a struggle for survival in both the lore and each individual match. This is something that is not immediately obvious until you start seeing the game. Each and every single mission has the same goal. [i]Survive 5 turns[/i]. Immediately this appeared to be something that would quickly become stale but instead it acts as the perfect goal for the formula. On top of this moving units is a large theme and is quite powerful. Not always is it necessary to kill any of the bugs. Simply displacing them might be enough as enemies don't change what they are about to do regardless of what happens to them.

Before I continue it's important to note that enemies broadcast everything they do loud and clear to the player. On top of this if an enemy plans on attacking the space in front of it then it won't change it's behavior. So if you were to drag a bug in front of another bug then it would attack and potentially kill it's friend. So let me recap. The game gives you all the information on what is about to happen in the following turn, it sets up movement and attack based puzzles and makes succeeding at them efficient and satisfying.

[u]To put it more simply the gameplay is a unique masterpiece that was done with love.[/u]


[b]Variety[/b]:
The variety that the game poses is perfect. There are enough enemies that you'll see a different puzzle all the time, enough maps, map tiles and map modifiers, mechs, items, pilots that you'll be sated for quite some time on variety. Also unlike many games the different items and variety can really change how you look at a battle and how you play. The different puzzle pieces mix alarmingly well and present an entire new dimension once any of them encounter a new one. In some rogue likes the variety sort of melts into the bigger picture and the joy of seeing new stuff is lost after some time. After 8 hours of play I still am seeing the joy in the combinations that can be seen.

[u]The game offers a huge amount of variety that mixes really well with other bits of variety to stay fresh.[/u]


[b]Unlocks and Achievements[/b]:
Something else to mention is the unlock system which is a gigantic step up from FTL's system while changing very little. The game has several sets of mechs. Each set has 3 mechs that function quite differently but hold some kind of theme such as smoke clouds, dealing damage, linking enemies in connected lines. Each set of mechs also has 3 achievements for you to attempt to get. There are also general achievements that apply to any gameplay run that you do. Each achievement you complete gets you a coin and you can spend these to get a new set of mechs. This means however that you don't have to play and hope for random events to get the new mechs that you want. This differs from FTL as you had to do things in the run that were likely random and wouldn't guarantee you the ship you wanted.

[u]The unlock system has you earn coins for achievements that you can buy new squads with.[/u]

[h1]The Bad[/h1]

[b]Gameplay[/b]:
[i]If you don't want a game that has you thinking long and hard about moves to make like you're peering at a chessboard then immediately I would advise you to avoid this game or at the very least read this sentence again[/i]. It really is closer than anything to a puzzle or a very deep abstract strategy game and this won’t appeal to everyone. There is very little luck that will suddenly let you win or randomly wipe you completely.

[u]The puzzle like gameplay certainly isn't for everyone.[/u]


[b]Story and Theme[/b]:
Furthermore the story and theme is quite thin. The theme of the game is the idea of jumping from timeline to timeline in attempts to stop gigantic bugs from destroying the town is quite thin. All that being said this doesn’t particularly bother myself. However much like a good porn I’m not here for the story.

[u]Story and theme are quite thin.[/u]


[b]Game Length and Pacing[/b]:
On top of this the game isn't terribly hard to finish in about 2h or less. My first run on the game was a success and I beat the boss all the way. That's not to say there isn't difficulty. The game has achievements that mean something, hard mode, different mech combos that are much harder or easier to use and challenge runs but it doesn’t take long enough to become invested and it’s not nearly short enough per mission to be snappy and short like a floor from binding of isaac

[u]Game length is awkward and is too long per mission and too short in the full playthrough.[/u]


[b]Progression[/b]:
The choices on upgrades is something you don’t get a whole bunch. For many this might be a deal killer. Every 5 or 6 missions or so you get to spend your points on upgrades to get for your mechs. This would be fine but missions usually take a lot of thought and by proxy a lot of time. This can lead to breaks between progression feeling larger than almost any other rogue like/lite game out there. There is still xp that you get and your pilots will gain new skills but you don’t get to buy for about 30 minutes sections.

[u]Progression is minimal and fits in with the poor pacing the game sometimes provides.[/u]


[h1]Verdict[/h1]

For 15$ I think this game is an easy buy. It’s not only satisfying and pretty but holds a good variety to keep you coming back time after time. The game’s faults are really minor and haven’t bothered me a whole lot. The story and theme aren’t amazing but fit well for the game and act better as an excuse for some clever game mechanics to fit in. If you are someone who enjoys a good puzzle or the satisfaction of figuring out the right move in a strategy game or can revel in the moment you realize you screwed up then this game might as well have been made for you.

先抽一根烟（吹爆蓄力），好好回忆回忆那段被SRPG统治整个市场的黑暗时期。



不知道从什么时候开始，SLG消失于市场，SRPG大量出现。对于大部分不想动脑的玩家来说，SRPG的养成给他们带来很多的乐趣，也同时大大降低了游戏的难度。当然其中不乏一些佳作，我本人喜欢的也不少。

但对于一个真正的战棋爱好者来说，他再也无法找到那种绞尽脑汁后从无数选择之中洞察正确的那条道路所带来的“险、诡、惊、奇”的感觉。
[quote]自古弈者为棋谱、残局而疯狂，此心此行未有稍易。[/quote]
当这片阵地最后的留守者《火焰之纹章》也向大众市场选择了妥协的时候，对于硬核战棋玩家来说，无异于灭顶之灾。



但就在这个时候，就在这短短几年中，有三个游戏相继问世，如拂晓晨光，撕裂黑暗。

这就是[b]XCOM系列、隐形公司和Into the Breach[/b]。

接下来，我想聊的是这三个游戏各自给我们带来了什么不同的体验……



这三个游戏各自围绕自己的主题，进行了对应的玩法设计：
[list]
[*]消灭入侵的外星人（XCOM）、率领反抗军推翻外星人的控制（XCOM2）
[*]潜入、HACK、撤退
[*]驾驶机甲与巨大的异星怪兽战斗，保卫城市
[/list]
不同的背景造成了玩法的不同：

如在XCOM中，你需要收集完整的外星人尸体用于研究。

而在XCOM2中，因为外星人已经统治了地球，所以你的行踪可能被路人、探测器等发现，而需要小心的潜入，不要暴露你的行踪，选择合适的时机开始攻击。

外在的经济系统也由原来的世界各国发射卫星共同抵御，变成了驾驶复仇者号联络各地反抗军这样的形式。

在隐形公司中，因为主题是潜入（不是那种潜入，你懂的，就是那种“看见我的都死了就等于没有人看见我”的潜入）。隐形公司里的对手是各大公司的安保人员，在载入界面的TIPS里就写着：“不要和安保人员正面战斗，你完全没有胜算。”

事实也是如此，当你被安保人员瞄准的时候，再动一下，就是死，哪怕只是说一句遗言。

特工们常用的手段是电击枪，将安保人员击晕后，利用这段时间做你想做的事。在这个游戏里，充满着各种诱敌、伏击的技巧，当然，也少不了HACK。杀伤性武器也是有的，但每一个安保人员的心脏内都安装有探测器，一旦你杀死了安保人员，不但结算时需要付出找人善后的费用，在当时还会增加警戒系数。而在这个游戏里，警戒系数就意味着危险程度。

在极端的情况下，你甚至会与一群保安共处一室，或者利用地形、或者利用对他们行为的预测、或者利用一些引人注意的道具（甚至包括将一个击晕的安保人员放在一个合适的位置故意让他们发现来争取时间），总之你需要从他们的眼皮底下逃出生天。如果特工被击倒了，而你将他留下没有救醒或扛到撤离电梯，那么你就会永远失去他。

隐藏自己、快速侦察、完成目标、避开对手、闪电撤离，这是三个游戏中最不像战棋的战棋游戏。



而ITB是什么？

我对ITB的评价，介于上面所说的两个游戏之间，XCOM系列之下，隐形公司之上。当然，这只是主观上对设计水平或者说设计量的一个评价，不代表个人喜好和游戏的好玩程度。这三个游戏我都十分喜欢，也都非常好玩，这个角度上是不分上下的，各有特色。

如果说XCOM是现代（未来）武器打外星人的科幻片，隐形公司是赛博朋克背景下的特工片，那么ITB就是像环太平洋、奥特曼、哥斯拉一样的特摄片。

所以它的玩法设计也是围绕着这个主题来的。

当怪兽还有五分钟（下个回合）就要接近并攻击城市的时候，你作为对怪兽作战的指挥官，你有哪些选择呢？
[list]
[*]直接消灭怪兽，这毫无疑问是可以的，但消灭不了呢？
[*]从侧面撞击怪兽，使其偏离攻击位置甚至攻击了另一只怪兽，这是个不错的选择。
[*]制造一片烟雾，使怪兽分不清方向而暂时无法攻击，这也是个不错的选择。
[*]暂时冻结怪兽，这也很好。
[*]给城市加一层防护罩，使怪兽的攻击无效，这也不错。
[*]这只怪兽不会飞，而我的机甲力大无穷，我直接抓住怪兽，一个过肩摔将它扔下了悬崖/大海！
[/list]
在熟悉这个游戏的过程中，我想到的是去年看过的一部日本电影《新哥斯拉》（Shin.Gojira.2016）：电影展现了呈梯次，不同目的的行动，只为阻止哥斯拉攻击城市。



从小，我就在电视上看着克赛号、奥特曼，但我从没想过有一天，我会指挥一支穿越时空的地球防卫队，来和这些巨型怪兽作战，并从它们的手下拯救城市。



[h1]谢谢FTL的制作组，你们用了五年时间，满足了一个我未曾想过的梦！[/h1]

Превосходная компактная тактическая игра.

Если одна партия в XCOM может отнять десятки часов, то в Into the Breach легко управиться за полтора часа. Правила элементарные, но менее интересно и менее просто от этого не становится. Into the Breach напоминает шахматы: рандома в базовой механике практически нет, ты всегда знаешь, сколько урона нанесёшь противнику. Поэтому бои в Into the Breach — тактика чистой воды и вызов твоему умишку без лишних примесей.

Для большей увлекательности бои завёрнуты в два слоя дополнительного геймплея. В первом, локальном, ты прокачиваешь свои махины, извиваешься ужом между несколькими важными показателями и устанавливаешь апгрейды, пытаясь подгадать оптимальный комплект для каждой миссии. Во втором, глобальном, открываются новые типы юнитов и новые пилоты, а также сохраняются уже закалённые в боях воины — их можно перетаскивать из партии в партию. Слои связаны друг с другом: достижения, которые вы зарабатываете в локальном слое, влияют на анлоки в глобальном. Выходит отличный игровой круговорот: в Into the Breach можно возвращаться снова и снова, каждый раз получая новые впечатления.

При этом обставлена игра с нужным градусом пафоса, словно попадаешь в «Тихоокеанский рубеж» и возглавляешь свою команду «Егерей». Огромные махины валятся с неба и лупасят исполинских жуков, туши отлетают в горы и крушат их до основания, а беззащитные люди в домишках вокруг радуются твоему прибытию. Несмотря на скромный внешний вид, фантазия дорисовывает недостающие детали и ощущение эпичности всё равно не покидает.

В общем, Into the Breach — маленькое откровение, которое наверняка войдёт в зал славы тактических стратегий. Я бы даже сказал, что она вышла ещё лучше, чем FTL.

FTL is one of my favourite games of all time, so, to say that I had high hopes for Into the Breach is a bit of an understatement. After having played a good 20-something hours I'm  happy to report that Subset Games hasnot let me down and has met my expectations for their new game, even though it is nothing like FTL.

Don't die, protect stuff, kill enemies. So far, so good. Not too spectacular a formular for a turn-based tactics game. Except that Into the Breach plays extremely fast, every match just takes five turns on a tiny 8x8 grid. That is it. The next mission awaits. The base-mechanics are clean-cut and easy to learn, the difficulty, however, can be brutal - especially on hard and with one of th weaker, more puzzle-ish squads like the Steel Judokas. This minimalist approach to map size and gameplay is met with several options to customize your squadt. The ten base squads (which you can unlock) all play differently and require fairly different approaches to problem-solving. And last but not least, the game has this "just one more game" quality to it. 

Into the Breach is not as innovative as FTL was, but it took the best parts from a genre I liked anyways, stripped them down to the core and mixed in a big bag of customization options. If you like turn-based tactics, this is a must buy. Think XCOM mixed with the Neuroshima Hex! App distilled into a faster but still equally complex challenge.

Into the Breach, obviously, is worth its full price!

[h1]Miniature Time Travelling Chess[/h1]

It's your team of three class specific Mechs against an alien insect species collectively called the Zek. 

[b]Subset Games[/b] creates yet another [u]masterpiece[/u]. You don't need the latest game engine, or a $60 price tag plus a long line of DLC to create an engaging, thought provoking, brain stimulating, addictive experience.

No, no you don't. No. No, no, no no no, [i]no[/i].

What you need is the creative masterminds who run Subset Games and a maximum of $15 in your pocket. 



[b]Into the Breach[/b] is a game that is less about overpowering the opposing forces and, instead, is more focused on maintaining position control and sacrificing units to gain a larger advantage. I am pretty positive this is where the [i]Chess[/i] feeling stems from. There's also this deep fear of losing your main pilot, which could closely resemble losing your Queen in Chess. 

[i]Fear[/i]. Let's talk about fear. Into the Breach is not a game about dominating the battle field. Oh, no, no, no. You will be barely scraping by. Just like in [b]FTL: Faster Than Light[/b], you will feel powerful [i]and[/i] powerless at the same time. It's not about "[i]How much[/i] can I keep safe from the Zek this round?", it's "[i]What[/i] do I keep safe from the Zek this round?". And THAT is where the addiction lies. 

Into the Breach is [b]not[/b] FTL: Faster than Light. However, you can totally tell Subset Games made it. The UI reminds me a lof of FTL. Being able to name each of your Characters and Mechs is just like naming your Ship and Crew Members in FTL. The graphic style is reminiscent of FTL. The love, consideration and top shelf tactics are all present.  Plus, the music. Oh. LAWD. The music is top notch. 

Where FTL was breaking the mold with new game mechanics and putting a different spin on the old Turn Based Strategy genre, Into the Breach has went back in time ([i]you see what I did there[/i]) and [b]masterfully[/b] created a turn based game with ALL the familiar mechanics, yet it [i]feels[/i] fresh and very [b]very[/b] well done.

40494645.review:
[h1][i](TL;DR at the base of this review)[/i][/h1]

[b]PLEASE NOTE:[/b] This is a tactical strategy rogue-lite, in which failure resets your progress to the beginning, but thankfully, Into the Breach allows you to choose your best pilot from a failed mission to rise again to the next challenge. You will also keep new continent access once you have unlocked them. This review is based on the "Normal Mode" level of difficulty.

*********************************************************************

[h1]How the game is played:[/h1]

You will deploy a Combat Mech (powerful punch attack), Cannon Mech (ranged attack that cannot initially fire through obstacles), and Artillery Mech (ranged attack that can fire over obstacles) with complimentary abilities to protect civilians housed in buildings and the additional objective specific to each map. Hazards abound, and you will quickly find yourself scrambling to position your mechs in the best possible way to take out the enemy while mitigating damage and trying to keep new bugs from surfacing from cracks in tiles. 

Thinking ahead is the name of the game, as you will often find yourself short on actions, with only the three mechs limited to moving and attacking (or repairing), and pray none of them get webbed in place. Be wary of your actions, however, as they often will have consequences. You can damage assets and your other mechs if they are parked next to an enemy you fired on, or if you knock a bug preparing to fire into their line of attack on the map's grid. Directionality is an important consideration when attacking, as you will frequently knock targets away onto another tile. This can be very advantageous for knocking them into water, into mountains for additional damage, into the line of fire of another enemy or physically into another enemy, damaging both targets. 

Pilots level up after achieving enough XP to do so, unlocking new abilities to help you power through. Upon defeat, you will be allowed to keep one pilot out of a maximum of three to begin your next attempt.

Win conditions typically take on the form of repelling and/or mitigating enemy attacks for a certain number of rounds depending on the map (such as protecting a train until it has escaped the map or keeping civilian/corporate buildings and power generators intact for X number of turns). You will also be given bonus objectives on each map, such as protecting friendly tanks or destroying a dam to flood a section of the map. Bonus objectives reward you with quality of life upgrades to aide you in your progression. You will also earn reputation as a currency, which can be spent on weapon upgrades or supplies. You can sell unused weapons and pilots in exchange for additional reputation.

"Game Over" if you lose all of your mechs before exhausting the turns required to win, if your power grid meter becomes empty, or if your primary objective has failed.  

[h1]What I liked:[/h1]
+ Unique and exciting strategy gameplay. Nice to see new and innovative tactics.
+ The pixel art is absolutely top notch. Just beautiful.
+ Fantastic user interface. Very clean.
+ Music is soft, mysterious, and pleasing...this is especially important with the high replayability. You will be hearing it a lot.
+ Sound effects are appropriate and satisfying. 
+ You are allowed one turn reset per map.
+ Option for Easy, Normal, and Hard modes.
+ I loved that Into the Breach had me obsessing about tactics while I was away from my PC.


[h1]Room for improvements:[/h1]
- Sometimes, the randomness just royally screws you at the worst times, like at the end of a hot streak when you are doing particularly well and nearing the completion of a continent. You won't always be equipped to deflect every building attack while trying to block surfacing bugs, while webbed, with the current bugs spread out across the map and hazards in between. It's going to happen.

[h1]TL;DR:[/h1]
A thoughtful, well-designed and deeply challenging tactical strategy rogue-lite game that isn't afraid to bring fun, fresh ideas to the table. This has been a very enjoyable experience.

[h1]メックに乗って地底生物Vekと戦い人類を救え！[/h1]

Steam屈指の名作FTLの開発チームによる期待の新作。スケール的にもゲーム的にもFTLより大分コンパクトにまとまっているが深みがすごい。見た目は2018年とは思えないようなありふれたターン制ウォーシミュレーション(フロントミッションみたい)だけど、押し出しと衝突ダメージを前面にフィーチャーした戦闘はありそうでなかった感じで斬新。敵の移動と攻撃予告→自分の移動と攻撃→敵の攻撃実行→最初に戻るというターンシステムが独特で、これによって例えば敵の予告射線上に別の敵を動かして同士討ちを誘ったりできる。

また、バランス調整が相変わらず絶妙で、毎ターンうんうん考えさせられる。一つの戦闘は5ターン凌げば終わりだけど、建物に被害を受けるとPOWER GRIDというリソースが減り、ゼロになるとゲームオーバー。POWER GRIDはミッションを跨いでも引き継がれ、回復できる機会は多くないので、じっくり考えてプレイしないとすぐゲームオーバーになってしまう。また、POWER GRIDが満タンの時にさらにパワーリソースを獲得すると、建物がVekの攻撃を受けた時に抵抗する(ダメージを受けずにすむ)確率が恒常的に上昇するので、POWER GRIDはできるだけ満タンを維持していたい。

どうしてもダメージを避けられない時はどこにその被害を引き受けさせるか…？そもそも本当にこのダメージを避ける方法はないのか？絶望的に見える状況をひっくり返す打開策をひらめいた時の脳汁がヤバイ。みんな言ってるけど「詰将棋」という例えがとてもしっくり来る印象。FTLのようなリアルタイム操作は要求されないし、回数制限はあるものの「待った」もできる。

有志による日本語化プロジェクトも進行中。ゲームは深いがとっかかりはシンプルかつ、武装の機能がアニメーションで説明されるなどインターフェースも親切なので、英語のままでもプレイには支障なし。フィールドは8x8の64マスとコンパクトで、ワンステージが短く中断セーブもいつでも可能なので隙間時間でも遊べるところはスマートフォン・タブレットと親和性が高そう。ぜひiOS版も出してほしいと思う。

お得意のランダム生成ローグライト要素がタイムトラベラーと複数の世界線設定によって理由付けされているところが芸が細かい。実績がゲーム内実績と同期していて出撃チームのアンロックにも使うので無駄なく実績取りのモチベーションにも繋がるところが地味にお気に入り。出撃チームごとの個性が強く、チームが変わると戦略もガラリと変わって面白い。

アクション性はゼロですが、ウォーシム好き・パズル好き・ローグライク好き・パーマデス好き・ムズゲー好きなら「買い」です。

あと、これ好きな人、[url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/243970/Invisible_Inc/]Invisible Inc.[/url] もきっとハマると思うので未プレイなら是非そちらもオススメです。

Into the Breach is a game from the creators of FTL and could be described as a mix of XCOM (turn based, aliens, mechs) and chess (board with grid, tactical gameplay, no RNG, emphasis on your skill over dice rolls). Your main objective is defending earth defense systems against aliens (called Vek in this game) taking control over a squad of 3 mechs

Pros:
- great tactical gameplay with marginal amount of RNG
- clear pixel art graphics
- a lot of stuff to unlock / strategies to employ
- good soundtrack

Cons:
- lack of sense of scale. Have you ever seen Pacific Rim movie? You really felt the size of the gigantic mechs. In ITB these giant robots feel like puny toys created from LEGO by 3 years old toddler. Sound effects are also underwhelming. It just feels like you're fighting a bunch of ants instead of giant aliens. In other words - it's hard to connect emotionally to what you're doing.

Do I recommend Into the Breach then? Absolutely :) It's a great indie turn based strategy game that has the potential to suck you in for hundreds of hours

8/10

遊戲很好玩，難度也相當高。你的每個動作都必須思考，不只是戰役中，也包括如何強化機體。敵人的強度上升的非常快，如果資源亂花，很容易一下就打不動對手，最後崩盤。玩家必須仔細思考到最後一關的最後一回合，才能順利全破。很久沒有玩到難度設計這麼精巧的遊戲，讓人十分滿足。

不過這個高難度同時也是敗筆。

遊戲的問題大概在第一輪遊戲結束後出現。一輪遊戲大約四個小時。基本上就是過關拿資源強化過關。隨著遊戲進行，機體和怪物的強化幅度都非常大，讓人有挑戰性的同時，也有建立自己隊伍的滿足感。

一名滿級的駕駛員是什麼樣的概念呢，大概是一輪裡面前二分之一，你就可以把三名駕駛員都升到滿級的概念。也就是說跟沒有繼承差不多。新的一輪開始了，你花了整整四個小時辛苦建立起的隊伍被打回原形，沒有任何其他的報酬。

喔不，因為破了一輪所以可以買新機體了，你可以用新機體破關啊。然而那些機體並沒有比較強。如果舊機體用習慣了，反而還會覺得比較弱。

也就是說，我全破得到的報酬是我可以用更跛腳的機體再破一輪。再重複一次從零開始幾乎一次失誤都難以容忍的遊戲過程，你是要滿足玩家還是要玩家自虐？

打個比方就像下象棋，你贏了，好棒喔，那你現在可以讓一隻馬再來一局，讓一隻不夠那你有讓兩隻嗎？
更大的問題是這遊戲一輪要跑四小時，四小時這個不上不下的長度代表你不能快速刷好幾輪打發時間，你也不能把自己的隊伍培養到令人徹底滿足的強度。你心裡還在期待更多報酬，遊戲就叫你重來。
講白了就是我明明還沒將軍啊，你怎麼就說我贏了要重新擺盤呢？而且你還想要叫我再讓一隻車。

這樣的體驗讓人一點都提不起幹勁繼續跑下去，在第二輪不到四分之一的地方我就放棄了，而且這輩子大概不會再碰第二次。

Ich habe das Spiel jetzt ein paar Stunden gespielt und finde es bisher sehr gut.

Obwohl man jeweils mit nur 3 Einheiten auf einem von der Größe her relativ überschaubaren Terrain spielt, hat man jede Menge taktische Möglichkeiten und wird immer wieder neu gefordert. Zum einen haben die 3 Einheiten unterschiedliche Fähigkeiten, zum anderen gibt es auf jedem Einsatzgebiet immer wieder Besonderheiten oder spezielle Ziele die man zusätzlich zur Feindabwehr erfüllen muss/kann. Manchmal muss man z.B. als Zusatzziel einen Damm zerstören. Tut man dies wird aber ein Teil der Karte mit Wasser überflutet. Manchmal gibt es vulkanische Aktivitäten oder Unwetter auf einigen Feldern, was zu Schäden an den gerade dort stehenden Einheiten führt oder man muss nebenher Terraforming betreiben, was ebenfalls Einfluss auf den Ablauf des Kampfes hat.

Das macht jede Runde wieder von neuem spannend und lässt zumindest bisher keine Langeweile aufkommen. Daneben steigen mit der Zeit auch die Fähigkeiten der Piloten und man kann zu bestimmten Zeitpunkten die 3 Kampf-Mechs aufrüsten, was ebenfalls zu neuen Kampfoptionen führt.

Die Kämpfe sind zumindest im Schwierigkeitsgrad „normal“ hervorragend ausbalanciert und immer wieder fordernd.

Was ich auch gut finde, die einzelnen Runden dauern nicht allzu lange. Man kann also auch mal ein oder zwei Runden zwischendurch spielen ohne gleich ein paar Stunden Zeit einplanen zu müssen. Der Spielstand wird nach jeder Runde gespeichert, so dass man später bequem weitermachen kann. Gespeichert wird allerdings immer nur der aktuelle Fortschritt, mehrere Speicherstände sind NICHT möglich. Das finde ich aber gut, so muss man sich immer gut überlegen was man als Nächstes tut. Das macht es für mich sehr viel spannender und interessanter, als wenn man ständig neu laden und einen einzelnen Einsatz immer wieder neu durchspielen kann. Wenn Alles schief läuft, fängt man wieder fast ganz von vorne an die Welt zu retten. Nur einen Piloten mit seinen gesammelten Erfahrungen kann man mit ins neue Spiel nehmen. 

Aber auch wenn ich gerade zu Beginn mehrfach komplett neu anfangen musste, hatte das (wegen der schon genannten wechselnden Rahmenbedingungen und Zusatzziele je Runde) bisher keinen Einfluss auf den Spielspaß.

Die etwas einfache gehaltene Grafik ist stimmig und passt gut zum Spiel.

Alles in allem ein super Spiel und sein Geld in jedem Fall wert.

Das Einzige was ich nicht nachvollziehen kann, ist der teilweise Hype um den Soundtrack. Der Sound im Spiel ist völlig normal und auch passend, aber in keiner Weise herausragend oder besonders. Ein zusätzlicher Kauf des Soundtracks lohnt also nicht.

(3월 1일 기준 쉬움 난이도로 1회차 클리어 후 작성한 평가입니다)

FTL의 성공요인을 발전적으로 계승한 후속작입니다

1) 파일럿과 기체, 그리고 각종 자원 관리를 통한 전략

FTL에서 등장했던 자원 관리 매커니즘이 ITB(Into the breach)에서도 동일하게 적용되어 있습니다. 다만 획득하는 과정에서 더 많은 선택을 요구하는데요. FTL이 전투 전에 발생하는 이벤트의 분기 선택이나 임무(전투) 완수를 통해 무작위로 자원을 획득하는 형태라면, ITB는 전투 자체가 곧 어떤 자원을 획득할 것인지의 기로가 됩니다. 이를테면 전장에는 무수한 민간 건물과 발전소가 존재하는데, 적이 그것을 파괴하게 냅두면 자원을 잃게 되고 적을 처치하여 저지하면 얻게 됩니다. 어떻게든 승리하기만 하면 되었던
 FTL과 달리 ITB는 어떻게 승리하느냐가 관건이 되는 것입니다.

2) 장기를 닮은 전투

ITB의 전투를 XCOM에 빗대는 분들이 계신데요, 엄밀하게 말하자면 아군/적군 번갈아 움직이는 턴제 전투라는 점을 제외하고는 많이 다릅니다. 일단 ITB는 명중률, 회피 개념이 없습니다. 공격을 하면 무조건 타격을 하고요, 마찬가지로 적이 아군을 때리면 반드시 피격 당합니다. 적의 다음 행동을 미리 확인할 수 있다는 것도 차이점입니다. 장기처럼 적이 들어올 길이 미리 '예측'할 수 있다는 게 아니라 아예 '예정'되어 있습니다. 

ITB가 다른 턴제 게임과 다른 재미는 바로 이렇게 예정된 행동을 하나하나 막아내거나 조작하는 것에 있습니다. 자, 적은 다음 턴에 민간 발전소를 공격할 예정입니다. 그럼 어떻게 해야할까요? 물론 가장 기본적인 해결책은 때려서 죽이는 것일텐데요, ITB는 그 적을 당기거나 밀어서 바로 옆에 있는 물 타일에 빠뜨릴 수도 있고, 심지어는 다른 적을 때리게 만들 수도 있습니다! 누군가가 '묘수풀이'라고 표현하던데 그게 딱 맞는 것 같네요.

3) 리플레이 

ITB는 로그라이크 게임답게(?) 컨텐츠 볼륨 자체는 되게 짧은 편입니다. 스크린샷 보시면 아시겠지만 비슷한 턴제 전투 게임 대비
 전장 규모가 작은 편이고요, 4,5개의 전투로 구성된 스테이지도 고작 5개 밖에 없습니다. 로크라이크 장르에 생소하거나 볼륨을 중요하게 여기시는 분, 1회차 클리어하면 그 뒤로는 흥미를 잃는 분들은 일찌감치 다른 게임으로 눈을 돌리시는 게 좋습니다. ITB는 적은 컨텐츠 대신에 여러가지 해금요소를 배치하여 리플레이 요소를 강조하고 있습니다. 게임 내에서 조작할 수 있는 전투 유닛은 3개로 구성된 1개 스쿼드인데요, 게임을 거듭 클리어할수록 선택할 수 있는 스쿼드가 늘어납니다. 유닛 안에 탑승하는 파일럿도 마찬가지고요. 

출시하기 전부터 해외 게임매거진을 통해 소식 접하면서 기대했던 게임인데 플레이해보니 정말 만족스럽습니다. 개인적으로는 FTL보다 재밌어요. 특히 매순간 어떤 신에게 기도를 올릴 필요 없이(운에 맡길 필요 없이) 두뇌에 맡기기만 하면 되는 턴제 전투 게임이라는 점에서 꽤 마음에 드네요. 그렇다고 운빨 턴제 게임이 매력없다는 건 아니고요. ITB가 또 다른 매력을 가졌다는 의미입니다. 어찌됐든 관심 가시면 한번 플레이해보세요.

I am really enjoying this so far.

It plays somewhere between a roguelike and a puzzle game, with a lot of focus (at least, the way I play - I assume this isn't universal) on finding a workable 'solution' each turn.

Each playthrough is relatively short, and I didn't have a huge amount of trouble getting my first win on 'normal' difficulty, but wins with different squads aren't coming quite as quickly. It isn't punitively difficult, at least in part because there is no RNG - you have perfect information, and just need to make the right decisions, unless you let the enemy get out of control.

I have two criticisms, but neither are gamebreaking.

First, the amount of content seems a bit light. There aren't a massive number of mechs to use, customization options, etc - technically there is huge variety, but you will see an extremely small subset in each playthrough, and the repetition on items seems very high - the 'item pool' does not feel very deep, and there is a fairly limited set of enemies and environments. Hopefully, this will be added to post-release by developers or modders, but this might impact the replay value over the not-too-long term.

Second, the balance between squads seems very poor. This could be because some are simply intended as more challenging, which is reasonable, but a few of the squads I have unlocked have almost no damage output, leaving them with an extremely 'niche' early game which makes the unable to consistently complete some objectives, and heavily reliant on lucking in to a decent 'drop' or shop item. Other squads seem very well balanced from the start, and need little other than the 'skill point' analog to really come together. This could be a design decision rather than a mistake, but i feel like it is a questionable one.

All in all, I see myself getting quite a solid amount of play out of this. Turn-based iterative roguelikes I can play in a window while watching things are always nice, and this one is well presented and engaging. I hope there is some additional content, but even without it, I will get more than my money worth.

Wer kein 10/10 erwartet, wird ein 10/10 bekommen.

Der Titel, zugegebenermaßen, mag etwas übertrieben klingen – ich halten ihn aber aufgrund der aktuellen Reviewlage für dennoch angemessen. 

Das Spiel ist aktuell nur in Englisch verfügbar und das wird wohl auch so bleiben, allerdings reichen geringe Sprachkenntnise aus, um Into the Breach spielen zu können.

[h1] Allgemeines: [/h1] 
Fraglich ist, ob sich in Into the Breach wirklich ein solches Meisterwerk befindet wie das aktuelle Medienecho vermuten lässt, immerhin blickt der Spieler eigentlich nur aus der isometrischen Perspektive auf eine in Quadrate eingeteilte Karte, bestehend aus drei eigenen Einheiten, diversen verschiedenen Feinden, sowie Häuser, besonderen Infrastrukturgebäuden, Wasser, Wald, Sand und einige Charakteristika wie Vulkane oder Dämme. Hier steuern wir Runde für Runde die verschiedenen Einheitentypen und lassen dabei den Feind verbrennen, zerquetschen oder ertrinken. Dabei ist Strategie gefragt, da der Feind in der Regel quantitative und gelegentlich auch qualitative Überlegenheit besitzt. Außerdem ist er nicht so angreifbar wie wir – wir die nebenbei auch noch die letzten verbliebenen Strukturen der Menschheit beschützen müssen.

 [h1] Gameplay: [/h1]
[b] Gutes: [/b]
[list]
[*]Spielmechaniken sind einfach zu erlernen und schwer(er) zu meistern. Es ist möglich den Feind direkt anzugreifen, ihn zu entzünden, ihn ins Wasser oder gegen die Wand zustoßen oder auf die nächste Kachel zu schupsen. Alles ist in jeder Situation mal sinnvoller, mal weniger sinnvoll. Die Kombination macht es aus und so liegt die Entscheidung über Erfolg oder Fehlschlag in der Hand des Spielers.
[*]In der Regel treten kaum unfaire Situationen auf. Scheitert man, so ist meist eine Fehlentscheidung des Spielers ausschlaggebend. Unterstützend kann der Spieler einmalig pro Kampf die Runde neu beginnen und so eine schwere Fehlentscheidung revidieren – manchmal kann aber selbst das nicht mehr helfen.
[*]Viele Einheitentypen erfordern verschiedene Strategien.
[*]Großartiges Gefühl, wenn man selbst bemerkt, dass der eben ausgeführte Zug die eigentlich ausweglose Lage meistern konnte.
[*]Taktische Tiefe durch viele Items und eigenschaftentragene Piloten.
[*]Verschiedene Kartenziele, teilweise müssen wir einen Damm sprengen, einen Zug begleiten oder einfach nur überleben.
[*] Hoher Widerspielwert. Durch Errungenschaften schalten wir (wie etwa in FTL^^) neue Einheiten mit neuen System frei.
[/list]
 [b] Schlechtes: [/b]
 [list]
[*]Insbesondere die ersten 5 Minuten jedes Durchgangs gleichen sich oft deutlich!
[*]Alle Karten sind wild zusammengewürfelte Gebäudeanordnungen, die jegliche Systematik der Architektur vermissen lassen.

40483943.review:
No TLDR included, reading helps to sharpen your mind for this game. You'll need it. :p

Into the Breach truly lives up and rises above my high expectations that were set by the quality standard of FTL (one of my favourite 3 indie titles on Steam).

[u]Gameplay[/u]
The game is mainly a kaiju chess game with the only difference that the enemy AI telegraphs its following moves.
Your arsenal to counter the alien invaders not only consists of your squad of three mechs (that can be chosen from unlockable squad presets before you start the run) manned by pilots (who are to be levelled up to unlock additional perks), but the enemy itself that can be tricked into destroying each other or themselves and also the 8x8 grid of terrain which can be manipulated and used against them as well.
The different units and enemy types create a lot of gameplay variation and every move has to be planned accordingly, because one mistake can end the run quickly and also permanently.
The goal is basically to reconquer islands that the aliens invaded. In doing so, you are free to work on additional objectives. If you fail to protect the population and energy sources, you fail the run. If you lose a mech, your pilot dies and is replaced by a (still controllable) robot AI that cannot level up or provide perks anymore. After having freed an island, you can invest your earnings into improving your gear/crew.

[u]Visuals and UI[/u]
The aesthetics of the game are - like in FTL - pretty minimalistic, but very appropriate and add a nice "Battle Isle"-ish retro feel to the game. Additionally, the player is able to distinguish between the different units easily and isn't distracted by an overload of special effects. The overall design of the grids and the UI offer the exact amount of features that you need, no more or less, and offer the tools for more detailed preplanning of the battle phases and macromanagement as well. This is done way better than in other titles like XCom that unfortunately come with such a high amount of features, that the player is totally on overload sometimes. Minimalism sometimes beats complexity, this is the perfect example of how it's done!

[u]Bottom line[/u]
I'm pretty sure the game can fill the big footsteps its predecessor carved into stone before. This game was a no-brainer for me and one of the few release day purchases that do not disappoint.
I will keep this review updated to include new findings/experiences, but so far I am sure that I will be willing to put a lot of hours in. It's definitely one of these "Just one more round!"-titles that get you hooked, so beware! ;)

当然，在其他人眼里这也许并不是缺点。我真的很喜欢这个游戏，希望出点DLC，加入更多关卡和机甲类型。关于所谓队伍养成，自然是不太可能的了，毕竟游戏已经被设计成短流程多周目的偏向挑战类型的游戏了，这是后话。作为一个最纯粹策略游戏，已经是很不错的了。

但这种像素风且结构简单的游戏展示了如此实力，如果有手游学习一下这种策略战斗的设计思路我觉得可行，一定是个大作。

40480194.review:
TL;DR-Looking for a fairly balanced fight? Into the Breach may be right for you.

[h1]Predictable Chess Games[/h1]

Into the Breach is not like chess. In chess, the first moves are not predictable. Your opponent can choose any of the eight pawns to move. After that one move, it gets more and more impossible to predict which moves your opponent can make and it ends up being "protect the king at all costs."

In ItB, it's nothing like that, at first.
Your main objective is to protect the buildings. At all costs. Failure to do so multiple times on different maps results in a game over. Thing is, you will know which move the computer controlled Vex will do. Maybe they'll target a building. Maybe they'll target you and your allies. You can stop that by pushing/killing with the mechs at your disposal. You can also move yourself out of the way, take damage to protect a building, or protect your mechs and buildings altogether. Like FTL, there are many, many ways of tackling the situation, except this time you make decisions and very hard ones at worst. 

The RNG of ItB is not the main enemy this time around. You are always able to tip the scales in your favor, through movement of your mechs and the correct place to shoot. Everything can be controlled to benefit your game, even when things seem at their most dire. That doesn't mean all games can be easily flipped. Maybe you will get a round that, no matter what you do, a building will fall. That doesn't mean you can't stop the others from the same faith. It is all about the future, for the greater good, that will linger in your mind. In ItB, you have to think about what you have done and what that means next turn.

Whatever you do will be your fault when you play this game. That's just the beauty of the game: the RNG makes it so you can't easily blame the system if you fail. It's all about the actions you take, and that really makes you feel like a commander. If you want that feeling, I highly recommend this game.
