40478250.review:
Yet another fantastic game that came as a surprise to me.  Though I gave this developer's previous game, FTL, a positive review, I ended up not liking it much.  RNG-overload, you see.  So many elements of that game have little to do with strategy, and everything to do with rolling the dice.  As a huge fan of roguelikes, I"m used to RNG, but... that game didnt do it very well, at least in my view.  It just wasnt for me, I guess.


This one, however, went in the complete opposite direction.  Into the Breach is a combination of turn-based strategy and roguelike (yes, I"m going to call it that.  RogueLIKE.  Deal with it.).  This is a combination that, theoretically, has alot of randomness to it.  And indeed, the roguelike-style randomness of each run's "structure" and events is certainly there (so is the permadeath).  But it's the combat that makes  this what it is, as the combat will never use RNG against you.  Aim at an enemy with an attack that does 2 damage?  You *will* hit that enemy for 2 damage.  There are some exceptions to this (such as buildings having a certain chance to not take damage), but for the most part, once you're in a battle, RNG is *not* going to be what kills you (unlike a game such as XCOM, or FTL itself).  Your own mistakes and bad planning is what will do that.

And the game gives you plenty of opportunity to plan and strategize.  One of the defining features is how the game handles enemy attacks.  Enemies always attack first, and THEN move.  On your turn, you will see exactly what type of attack or ability each enemy is going to use when their turn starts, and exactly what effects it'll have, where it'll hit, and how much damage it will do.  All of this will be brightly marked so you cant miss it.  The game gives you all the info you could conceivably need in order to puzzle out a solution to deal with each situation that it'll create.

And "puzzle" is the key word here.  Individual battles are short, but every single turn will have you faced with some sort of daunting situation, and your job will be to take the various screwy abilities your squad of 3 mechs has, and come up with a way to use and combine them to put a stop to the enemy's plans.  It's not as simple as just protecting yourself though.  Your real goal is to protect all the innocent citizens that live in the many, many buildings on each map.  If a building goes down, your power-grid meter drops.  If that runs out, it's game over for you, and that meter is persistent throughout the entire run.  Wheras your HP refills completely after every battle.  Since every mission lasts a specific number of turns (usually 4 or 5, and battles dont end until the turn count expires, with more monsters spawning every turn), your actual goal isnt "kill everything".  Instead, it is simply to thwart the enemy in any way.  Many of those methods wont even involve doing damage.

And this is part of the brilliance of the game.  Your mechs have all sorts of abilities that they can use (and you'll be able to pick up more over the course of each run).  They can dish out damage, sure, but what's more important is all the OTHER things they can do.  An artillery unit, for instance, can fire an arcing mortar shot.  When this impacts, the tile it's on takes 1 damage, which isnt much, but the true strength of this move comes from the fact that any movable object on adjacent tiles will be forcibly shoved away.  Is a powerful enemy about to blow the funky crap out of a line of buildings?  Instead of slightly annoying it with a direct mortar shot, land it next to the monster, and simply shove it out of position, so that when it attacks, it whiffs, hitting empty tiles instead.  Most attacks that you can use have something they do beyond JUST damage.  A punch attack for instance might do damage, but then shove your target forward one tile.  Every single mech you have, whatever weaponry they're using, they're going to have some real versatility in terms of how you use their skills to deal with the enemy.

Those mechs also have alot of variety to them.  Firstly, you have a bunch of different mech squads you can unlock, each working very differently from the last. On your first run, you'll be using a fairly basic team, good at easy to understand traditional sorts of attacks (but with lots of added versatility).  You'll be doing things like punching stuff, using the artillery shot, and fairly basic things like that, to damage/shove/whatever the enemy.  But other squads will be very different.  In my second run, I went with the Zenith squad, which plays nothing like the default guys.  I've got one mech that's a very heavy hitter... but is also a master of collateral damage, which can be a very bad thing here.  The second can use a dashing attack to deal a good solid hit (and this also shoves the target), but it damages itself every time it moves, which makes it hard to use as it only has 3 HP to start with.  And then the third one has trouble doing any damage at all.  It has a bizarre ranged bolt that does no damage, but simply pulls a target one tile towards it, and this powerful but limited shielding move.  It's possible to do damage with this guy by pulling on an enemy that's standing right next to it (it causes the two to collide, dealing 1 damage to both) but that's terribly risky and hard to make use of.   So this squad is just way more screwy than the one I had started with.  Yet despite this, they are every bit as capable, and just as satisfying to use.

On top of that, you're going to be able to upgrade these guys over the course of any run.  You can improve equipment, level-up your pilots, and buy all sorts of modules and such at the between-island shops.  Any weapon you have equipped can be replaced by a different module, so you can drastically change things up if you see a good reason to.  Any module can go onto any mech, but some will require additional power as a penalty if they're not on the correct "class" of mech.  Overall, I think the upgrade and customization mechanics are fantastic here, adding even more depth to an already deep game, and making it so that each run's progression feels satisfying and rewarding.

And there's so much more to it than just that.  All sorts of unique enemy designs, special units that may appear in certain missions, different side-goals that give you bonuses if you complete them, and all sorts of other features.

It's important to note though that like FTL (and most games that are at all procedural) this WILL be repetitive in alot of ways.  There's no avoiding that.  Of course, if you play alot of roguelikes or other sorts of procedural games, you probably arent going to be bothered by this.  And in my opinion, the game is fantastic at changing things up.  I had heard of players that were in testing for this one, and were getting a couple hundred hours out of it, and I can totally see that.  If this game suits you, you will probably find yourself coming back to it over and over.

Note also though that the difficulty is VERY subjective.  Some players have been getting wrecked... others cleared a run on their very first try.  Of course, a game like this isnt just about clearing ONE run, but if you're the sort that tends to lose interest after your first win, this may not be for you.  The game does have a scoring system, so trying to win WELL is a major goal here too.

There's so much more I could ramble about, but I've made my point.  I play ALOT of games with a high emphasis on strategy and tactics.  But I have a very hard time thinking of any that I like more than this one.  Absolutely recommended.

And I see Steam is being an embarrassment again.  I wish they'd fix this review-posting bug.  But then, they dont like fixing stuff much, do they?  Sigh...  That's a whole other rant though.  Just go play the game.

40476662.review:
Let me say up front that Into the Breach is a very well realized turn-based strategy roguelike. It's got an appealing art style, an interesting concept, replabaility, a good unlock system (hey look, unlocks that aren't tied to loot boxes work, and I still have plenty of sense of accomplishment EA!), and it's ultimately a good game.

However.

People who were coming to this game off of FTL hoping for a game as deep, replayable, and addictive as FTL are going to be disappointed. Into the Breach is a decent game, but it's a far worse game than FTL.

ITB's main and greatest strength is that strategy layer. While FTL had a great deal of RNG that you had to dodge around, most of that from ITB is just enemy spawns and behavior (as well as the chance for buildings to resist damage). Every battle is very much like a puzzle. You'll find yourself baffled at a particular scenario, thinking the game has screwed you, and a few minutes later you'll be patting yourself on the back for finding a creative solution for minimizing damage. That's fun and a solid core that the game is built around, and my hat's off to the developer for making such a balanced and rather excellent combat system. There are even a fair variety of mission types (though to be fair most of them devolve into some variation of "kill a thing," "defend a thing," or "survive.").

Unfortunately, everything else around it is just okay. The story is set up really well, but doesn't really go anywhere from there. The game, while very mentally engaging, isn't nearly as difficult as FTL, which is actually something of a problem for a Roguelike, where part of the addictive quality is supposed to come from ramming your head against the brick wall until you break through. In FTL, is was probably more than ten hours before I secured my first win after over a dozen failures and experiments with different ships, parts, upgrades, and crews. In ITB I beat my very first run on Normal difficulty using the base gear, the default team, and few additional weapons. It wasn't a blowout victory; I won with only a hit point or two left, but that's not the point. I should be hitting the "scraping by via the skin of your teeth" stage somewhere around hour 12, not hour 2.

Unlocks in ITB are tied to your achievements. Each one grants you a coin, and those coins are used to buy new mech teams. Those teams also each come with a color pallet that can be applied to mechs from any other team, and you can create a custom team using mechs from any unlocked team. While this is fine, I much preferred the story-based unlocks in FTL. Stumbling across a quest that unlocked a new ship was exhilerating, and that just isn't here. FTL had some progression based on achievements, but not all of it, and I think that balance was important (though to be fair it does seem like Pilots need to be unlocked some other way, but I'm not sure exactly how to do that without FTL's narrative layer).

Speaking of the narrative layer, that's almost completely stripped out in ITB. Running across interesting scenarios like pirates attacking a commerce ship, a station infected by a virus, or similar scenarios was what really tied FTL together. The fact that you could use that layer to take risks and find new scrap, weapons, or crew was what really made the game as juicy and addicting as it was. Not only is that not here, but there also seems to be something of a variety problem. In FTL, there were tons of different system arranged in new and interesting ways each time you play. This time, there are four islands arranged in the same order (Read: Whatever order you want) and with the same layout every time you go to that island. There's also a fifth island, but that one's just a final boss scenario (which, by the way, isn't nearly as intereting as FTL's final boss of the Rebel Flagship. Here it's just two normal back-to-back missions, the final of which has a normal boss in it).

You have the option to complete anywhere from 2 to 4 islands before approaching the final boss. You'd assume that going the distance is a risk vs. reward scenario where you need to press your luck in later islands to get the better gear you need to tackle the final mission. Or that you're taking a huge risk by attacking the final mission early without weakening the forces on the other islands. However, that just isn't the case. The game flat-out tells you that the final mission will scale to your strength. Which begs the question of what even is the point is to letting players choose how many islands they want to fight? The only real decision you're making at that point is how "long" you want your game to be, but that hardly matters when you can just save and quit whenever you want.

I'll also mention that progression in this game (within an individual game) isn't nearly as fun as in FTL. In FTL, finding scrap is always fun and will have you constantly on the lookout for shops to spend it at, if you're not already dumping it into ship upgrades. There are tons of different ships with tons of different ways to upgrade them, lots of crew to man them, and lots of different ways to fight with your ship. While that exists with the mechs and you'd assume the lack of complexity with each mech is made up for by the fact that there are three mechs instead of one ship... it really isn't. Upgrading your mech seldom feels as good as upgrading your ship, and frequently you'll find yourself passing up entire stores worth of weapons because at the end of the day, most aren't worth it. You'll need a ton of Cores to make them work, and frequently just upgrading your primary tools are going to be far more effective anyways.

Really, at the end of the day, Into the Breach just makes me want to play more FTL. By no means does this mean I think that Into the Breach is bad, but it does mean that it looks best without comparing it to FTL. You'll have fun diving Into the Breach, but you'll find yourself coming up for air a lot sooner than you'd think.

I give Into the Breach a 3 out of 5.

So far, so good.

Only a couple of hours played, but I can already tell that I am going to end up racking up a lot of hours on this turn-based strategy roguelite. FTL is one of my favourite games of the last 10 years, and so I was always going to buy this game on release. The music is again by Ben Prunty, which can only ever be a plus point for a game.

If you've played FTL, then you probably have a fair idea of what to expect already. This follows on in the same vein, where you're battling enemies as well as RNG; and while losing is inevitable and can be frustrating, every death gives you an insight into what you did wrong and what you can do better next time.

Despite many similarities to FTL, Into the Breach is still definitely its own game. There is far less in the way of procedural storytelling than FTL - this game is far more rooted on the strategic combat side of things.

Using a small squad of mechs, each with their own weapons and abilities, you are tasked with deploying them to a small map and defending the buildings in that region until the turn counter runs out, at which point the enemy retreats. At the beginning of each turn, all the enemy units' attacks are telegraphed, so you know what is going to happen as soon as you hit the "end turn" button. You can inspect enemies to find out how each of their attacks works.

And therein lies the main strategic element of the game. While it is usually beneficial to kill as many of the enemies as possible (as is the case in most turn-based strategy games like Final Fantasy Tactics or XCOM), sometimes it is preferable to use your attacks to knock the enemies around the map, forcing them to miss their attacks, or even hit their own units. You can push enemies into the water or off the map, killing them instantly, knock them into mountains or each other, or simply move them away from what they were trying to attack.

As the campaign goes on, you are introduced to many other features that will affect the way you play each map. Sometimes, an earthquake or tidal wave causes the edge of the map to disappear each turn, instantly killing any unit that ends the turn in that area (unless the enemy can fly, of course). Sometimes, random areas of the map are bombarded by air strikes each turn. Like FTL, there are several different systems in place within the game, all of which interact with each other to create a feeling of emergent, varied gameplay.

Each map has its own objectives (e.g. protect a certain building, or kill a certain number of enemy units, or take less than a certain amount of damage). Maps are small enough that each battle plays out in around 8-10 minutes, but a campaign can go for an hour or longer if you continue to be successful. As you progress, units can be leveled up and equipped with new weapons to give them greater tactical use. There is a real feeling of progression as you complete maps and improve your mechs.

The game's interface manages to communicate a lot of information very effectively (as was the case with FTL), and complement the mechanics of the game very well. There is definitely a feeling of satisfaction when completing a map without taking damage.

Overall, I would definitely recommend this game to anybody who enjoyed FTL, or anyone who enjoys turn-based strategy games.

Not only does this make starting over again less painful (you still have a trusty pilot at your side), it also allows you to try different things!

The replay value of this game is amazing, especially for this price. I highly recommend this game!

Absolutely amazing game and a fresh take on the turn based genre. It's different than say X-Com or Atlas Reactor. In X-Com you move and attack, they move and attack with chance to hit being % based. In Atlas Reactor is synchronous turn based where each side selects their moves based on what they see and then everything plays out at once. 

In this you start off by seeing where the enemy units are and then place your units where you want, but it is limited to a starting zone. Then the enemy will move their units and decide where to attack, once this is completed the enemies attack will always happen in this direction. Say a melee unit moves to your tank and attacks to the left (to hit the tank) or a range unit is aiming north. These attacks will happen at the end of your turn in a predetermined order that you will see ahead of time. In this aspect it is closer to a puzzle more than a typical turn based game, but does a great job of mixing them together with a lot of RPG elements / char building as well.

Back to the enemy attacks... You use your attacks / CC to destroy the enemy. Often you will need to use strategic movement of the enemy units and most of your attacks will move them in certain directions. You need to think ahead and move the enemy about to hit your tank into the same row as another enemy who attacks after the first one so it will kill the other enemy unit. It's very fun and so far feels fairly challenging. Definitel worth checking out.

When I heard the guys behind FTL were making a new game, I was all ears. Betas and whatnot combined, I have put several hundred hours into FTL, and would easily rank it as one of my all time favourite games. With that in mind, Into the Breach is not FTL. Although similar philosophies are present and it's clear that the same guys made both games, Into the Breach is very much its own game, and an amazing one at that.

Whereas FTL was a roguelite/role playing game/space trip, Into the Breach is a deterministic turn based strategy game, which is played on 8x8 grids. A squad of three time-traveling mechs takes on invading giant bugs in an effort to save humanity from the disaster which wiped them out in the mechs' original timeline. I like many things about Into the Breach, from its slight roguelite twists -- you unlock new pilots, new mechs and new abilities from run to run, and all the missions are slightly randomized -- to the little touches, like people shouting encouragement at your mechs from the buildings you're trying to save.

But what really elevates Into the Breach is the deterministic nature. The word might sound strange, but what it means is there's practically no RNG in the game. On your turns you can see what the enemies will do when they get their chance, and that is 100% what they will do. Attacks won't miss, armour won't save anyone, and the percentages are never against you, or for you. They don't exist. Instead, every turn presents itself as a small puzzle where the player tries to chain together their mechs' different attacks to manipulate and maneuver the bugs around. Let's have a small example.

On your turn it looks like one bug is about to unleash a massive flame attack which will burn everything in its path. The attack is originally aimed at one of your mechs, and several buildings behind it. If these buildings get destroyed, your power meter runs out and you lose the game. Not to worry! One robot goes around the bug and punches it, shoving it one square to the right. Now the attack is going to miss its original targets and instead splash some mountains. But why stop there? With your other two mechs you can damage some of the other bugs around, and to add insult to injury, push them into the flame attack's path. End the turn, and sure enough: two bugs are now burnt to a crisp and one is looking awfully embarrassed.

Into the Breach might sound like a very simple game, and in a way it is. The mechanics are immediately obvious, the game does a wonderful job of presenting the player with all the information they could need -- in as big or small doses as they desire -- and the game never feels unfair. Despite this, Into the Breach is extremely hard. The objectives in each mission mean you're rarely just getting away with killing as many bugs as you can, but instead have to constantly rethink your strategies depending on what you're asked to do. The enemies are ruthless and will exploit any mistakes you make. The margins are thin and one badly executed turn can send you into a spiral which will inevitably end in a loss. You will try, fail and try again.

If you're like me, as you try and try again, you're having a blast. Into the Breach is an amazingly fun and well playing game with a gorgeous low res look, a great soundtrack by Ben Prunty and all the attention to detail you'd expect from the guys who made FTL. Add in hefty amounts of replay value and a very customer friendly price point, and you've got one hell of a game. 

Buy it!

40471152.review:
Into the Breach is a hard and addicting strategy game by the devs that brought us FTL.

[h1] Video Review [/h1]
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yU02D3zC21k

[h1] Written Review [/h1]
You play as a squad of time-travelers tasked with the mission to stop humanity's demise. Earth is being attacked by giant alien bug creatures, and you pilot mechs to combat them.

The main gameplay objective is to maintain your "Power Grid" health. Bugs will constantly target buildings. Each successful hit will drain your Power Grid by one bar. Once it gets to zero, it's game over, and you will get very few chances to regenerate those bars throughout your playthrough, so it's very important to protect your buildings.

This forces you to play in very clever ways, sometimes even placing your mechs in front of projectiles to protect buildings from getting hit, since they will heal after every battle anyway.

The gameplay is turn-based. For every round, bugs will set up their attacks. Then it's your turn. All enemy attacks are telegraphed, and the game will show you exactly where all projectiles and such will land, allowing you to properly plan. You have infinite time to make your decision, which is good because you'll really need it.

A mechanic I find very interesting is that a lot of your attacks do not simply damage enemies, but also push them. This way, if a bug is about to attack a building, you can simply get a good angle and push them out of the way of the building. They will follow through with their previously planned attack, however it will be wherever you pushed them to, instead.

This allows you to sometimes get enemies to attack each other.

The game does a good job at keeping the game fresh, as well as multiple playthroughs. This is because the levels are randomly generated, and the enemies are varied. 

Each level will have optional missions that you definitely want to try accomplish, because you will need them to help your playthrough last. You'll be able to heal your power grid, or purchase upgrades for your mech depending on the optional mission.

Enemies also have unique skills, and behave differently with the environment, which keeps you on your toes.

There are a lot of small details that allow you to really plan your moves nicely. Such as special tiles like a forest, which if attacked will cause it to ignite. If any one steps on it will then catch fire. Your attacks can also throw enemies onto their friends, causing them to both be damaged.

If you fail your playthrough, the planet will be overrun by bugs and you are given the choice to choose one of your mech pilots to save. This will transport them back to the future, and then back again to the past on your next playthrough. This allows you to really make them powerful over playthroughs, however it's also more horrible if you get them killed.

Overall, although I've explained the basics, there are so many fun aspects to this game that can't properly be explained through text, so if you're interested I'd invite you to watch my video review at the top. 

It's a great game, that really captures that simple-to-learn-but-hard-to-master fun that FTL had. The music is also done by the same artist behind the FTL soundtrack, so it's still great. I highly recommend the game!

I read somewhere someone said this game looks like a flash game and at first I didn't agree. The problem I see is that there are very few animations. I would even go so far as to say that the enemy and mech animations are too sparse. I think the best thing to compare this to is like final fantasy tactics how when your guy swings, you see him reel back and then lean forward and swing but the weapon he's holding is a sprite that can be changed.

I think what I'm getting at is that I think the animations are lazy. I think this is done to let you identify enemies easy (I guess?) but there's no point since your guys are very, VERY obvious and there are so few so if you lose them on the battlefield then that's your bad. I feel like this game would have benefitted from at least different directions for enemies. Was the budget really so thin for art or was this a design choice? Should have spent less on oldy mc old bitches face and more on animations.

The meat of the game itself is outstanding in terms of raw gameplay. The music is largely forgetable. Sorry but this music is not FTL tier music. It fits, but it's pretty mediocre. I think that's a pretty good theme for most of the game aesthetics. It's all meh. I mean don't get me wrong, I fucking love mechs and I think that's cool, but it's all very...low effort.

Story for this game is ok. I find the ending to be very disappointing, but the presentation for it is done well. Instead of hitting you with a text wall you learn little bits here and there through dialogue. Usually I abhor games that use time travel as a plot device (WoW and FFXIV are good examples), but when it's the main theme of the game I like it (Ghost trick, The sexy brutale). Like maybe one that pushes an enemy back into the ground but 1 time use would be good.

Variety is the spice of life and this game fails to have enough variety and content. Four islands with a final area just isn't enough, but I'm still going to recommend this game because of how unique it is and because of it's core gameplay being as enjoyable as it is. The devs are known for being good about updates so who knows, maybe more content is on the way, but I don't give points for liking the game devs either sorry. If the game gets more content I'll make the review better.

40466877.review:
A worthy follow up to FTL.

This game might be easier than FTL but its tactical depth allows for a level of replayability that will ensure entertainment for many dozens of hours. If I had to make an analogy I would say FTL is like WarCraft 3 while ITB is like HearthStone. 

FTL had more emphasis on a strategic plan; such as taking steps to acquire and manage resources, crew, rooms, equipment and planning an optimal path. ITB focuses instead on a deeper tactical game. The tools and mechs you start with is often sufficient for victory - there's not as much critical decision making involved when playing ITB at a strategic level. 

ITB focuses instead on a series of tense levels where you'll try to meet tactical goals by rearranging and removing pieces from the board. Since enemes telegraph their actions on your turn you will immediately know how your decisions pan out. 

There is no XCOM style RNG to mitigate - in fact, the only RNG elements are benificial ones, first there is a percentage chance of your buildings shrugging off a hit and second are your rewards from time pods and the shop. This ingenious design takes away the frustrating and sometimes unfair element from other turn-based tactical games but the result is that this becomes an easier (but more fair) game. 

If something goes wrong, it's because of your choices and not RNGesus.

This game has the charm, fun and replayability of FTL but with a different focus. It has strong mechanics and innovative design all at a very affordable price. Get this game, you won't regret it!

FTL is one of my favorite games, so I couldn't help but buy Into the Breach on release. I had high expectations of it, which were blown away.

Into the Breach is a tactical turn-based game that's all about positioning. That's why you have mechanics that are all about movement, pushing/pulling enemies, AoE etc. It all flows nicely and it creates an interesting puzzle at every turn. It's satisfying to stare at a difficult situation for several minutes, followed by figuring out a flawless sequence of moves. The game pulls that off constantly, which is insane considering its levels are procedurally generated! To complement all of that, the game has really clean and clear UI (keyboard shortcuts included), a variety of mechs with accompanying toolkit and a solid soundtrack.

Before release I've read that Into the Breach wasn't going to be as difficult as FTL. I was skeptical at first, but that was dispelled after playing. Think where the replay value comes from FTL: from the fact that it's difficult to beat (as a new player), or from the fact that you can now beat it with another ship you've unlocked, get more achievements, unlock more stuff and so on. Into the Breach embraces the latter, even allowing completely custom squads. It just works so well.

I have to commend the devs for making something on par with their previous monster success of a release, if not better. Into the Breach has that same amount of depth and love put into it as FTL did.

40463445.review:
Subset innovated the Simulation/Strategy genre once with the release of Faster Than Light. With the bar set so high, one would think that conceiving a better game would prove impossible. Yet, Into the Breach accomplishes this incredible feat with ease. Where FTL's flaws lay within its brutally difficult RNG system, Into the Breach successfully corrects this by implementing a system that strongly encourages creative problem solving.

This was the first release on Steam that a eagerly awaited, and Subset failed to disappoint my anticipation. The game proves tough, but fair. If you lose a pilot, let a city fall, fail an objective, or lose the game, all the blame lies on you. Just as FTL did, this game preys on our inherent ambition, pushing us to better ourselves every run.

The aesthetics of the game greatly add to one's experience, with a soundtrack that transports the player to an apocalyptic wasteland. The minimalist artstyle proves incredibly effective with this genre, allowing the player to focus on gameplay rather than graphics.

Subset crafted the combat system incredibly methodically, allowing the player to have myriad ways to overcome a threat. One can beat the game purely off of direct attacks, or you may choose a more manipulative strategy, forcing enemies into pits or directing their attacks at each other. It is for this reason that the game is enjoyable, as it gives the player choice.

On a final note, a flaw that draws away from the game's successes. The coin system proves awkward and slow. Whereas in FTL the player unlocked new ships through accomplishments and milestones, Into the Breach forces the player to complete achievements to earn coins, which can later be spent on unlocking new mech squads. This system feels less integrated into the game than FTL's unlocking system did. However, the system for unlocking new pilots remains locked away within gameplay.


Lastly, a few things NOT to expect:

FTL 2.0 - the only similarities here are art style and the roguelike nature of both games.

An Advance Wars clone - stylistically, the games are similar, but whereas advance Wars was all about direct combat, Into the Breach promotes creativity.

Overall, I highly recommend this game for anyone who enjoys strategic gameplay and creative thinking.

然而同时让本作超出3a前辈的 是游戏能在满足上述的同时 同时使要素有简化的空间 不知道大家感觉如何 在游玩这款游戏的过程中 我想到了《史蒂芬的香肠卷》中进退两难的局面 想到了《hitman go》中排除法最终化繁为简 根据敌人攻击目标的重要程度 玩家可以选择必须优先解决的从而简化自己的思考 通过直接排除不可能选项 最终实现看似不可解的局 在我心目中这让本游戏成功的让回合策略真正的策略化了
锦上添花的 本游戏提供了多种的初始兵种选择 笔者选择解锁了第8种部队 可以说是完全不同的体验 因为这一系列的部队每次攻击都会伤害自己(那可真蠢)
也就是说:在回合策略这一方向上 本游戏简直可谓前无古人后无来者 
然而 本作也存在较大的缺陷 在笔者看来就是剧情 不知所云的轮回剧情 恐怕比火纹系列(233)的剧情还让人失望 任何游戏不搭载哪怕一点点有想法的剧情 都终究是没有感情的架空世界
另外游戏还有几个令我遗憾的点:
怪物种类太少 且雷同
高难度不够难
没有令人印象深刻的点
下面是简单的一点建议以及攻略:
1.核心少的时候优先移动力 其次激活副武器
2.局面难以解决时尝试让对方自相残杀
3.最终boss战分二阶段 
4.如果大陆做过的任务目标全部满足 会有额外的完美奖励
另外我还有一点想说的 就是评分媒体最近对独立游戏太宽容了 一年之前别人说媒体宽容 我不相信 可是最近数款高分独立游戏的出现说实话让我不是很开心 游戏的质量确实不错 但是要各种mc评分过90 我觉得过分了

Das Spiel wird dem Hype den die Spielepresse darum macht nicht gerecht und profitiert da im großen maße vom FTL Bonus.

ゲーム性が一番近いのはInvisible, Inc.
というか、Invisible, Inc.で微妙だったところを潰したような感じかな。（もしそちらをやってなくてこのゲームが好きならそっちもやればいいと思う）
ゲームのルール部分としてはランダム生成の１画面マップで濃密に遊ばせてくれる。それでいて成長要素もある。ローグライクと戦略シミュレーション（FE的なやつね）のいいとこどりだ。
ランダム生成と言っても、内部的にシナリオがあって接待はしないけど理不尽もしない。そういうとこがInvisible, Inc.と同じ。

敵を全部倒すんじゃなくて、街を守ることが目的だからプレイヤーのキャラには痛みを伴う形で守っていく必要もあったりする。ユニークな地形変化やルールがあるステージも多い。

たったこれだけのマップにそれだけでとんでもない奥行きを出している。

40460316.review:
If you have ever been pushed around in a game or by stupid bullies at school, this is basically how this game plays out.

In "Into the Breach", you control a squad of mechs in turn-based combat against robotic and organic (bugs, mostly) enemies (about 85% of gameplay). The battles are fought on 8x8 tile maps. In battles, your goal is to protect buildings spread across the map being destroyed by your enemies. The key to succeeding in that task is careful planning of your units' movements and actions by responding to and altering the turn execution plan of your opponents' next turn. During your turn, you can, with 100% transparency, see what your enemies intend to do next turn, e.g. attack a building or attack one of your units for X damage. You can throw wrenches into the enemy units' plans by pushing them around. Almost all of your units (as well as your enemies') attacks move whatever they hit a set amount of tiles back or sidewards. You can use this to crush enemy units into mountains or push them to attack other enemy units. You lose the game when the enemy units succeed in destroying too many buildings on the maps you deploy your units on.

The remainder of gamplay (approx. 15% of your time playing), you manage the strategic layer of the game, purchasing squad unit upgrades like increased damage, new weapons, or new (usually highly movement-related) abilties for your mechs. You can unlock different mech squads through gameplay, which greatly enhances replayability (and achievement hunting) for this product.

On the presentation layer, you get an awesome Ben Prunty soundtrack, an informative and functional UI presented in pixel graphics with strong FTL vibes.

Highly recommended, as it feels very very very satisfying to figure out your "best play" for any given turn.

I'm going to leave this as a positive review, however I do have some reservations about the game.

Up front, its very fun, semi-challenging on normal with the default squad (probably the most balanced one). There are 10 different squads you can 'unlock' (achievments and progress earn coins, use them to buy more squads which have more coins you can earn) and about 20 different 'unique' pilots and unkown number of random non-special skill ones.

You get 1 'rewind' per map, aka start turn over from fresh.  Other than that you can undo any number of moves as long as you don't perform an action.

All enemy turns are telegraphed and you have unlimited time to decide how to best proceed with your counter attack.   

There is a LARGE diversity of mechs

7 Prime
6 Brute (tank)
6 Ranged (artillery)
5 Science (weird)

Each has a 'primary' type weapon, however you can mix and match any weapon to any mech by paying +1 power cost.
You can equip two weapons/passives (total) per mech as well as a few minor upgrades outside of pilot bonus's

Unique pilots have a 'special' skill and all pilots gain levelups which grant randomized bonus's

It is also not prone to RNG failure.

My reservations: SPOILERS Ahead!!!!
The game feels short per playthrough, that being said there is HUNDREDS of hours of playtime here to try/unlock everything

Each Continent is 4 missions +boss HQ mission.  2-4 islands per playthrough(your choice) + final 'island' (2missions)

This is a maximum of 22 missions per 'map' of 5 turns average. 110 turns of 3 mechs+auxilary units.

This is a great, fun and deep game that will have you thinking of solutions; and if you try to win with every squad you will have a TON of playtime.  I just can't help but feel the game would be better with 7-8 islands and 6-10 turns per map.  More pilot levelups would be cool too.

This game can only improve! Its fun and great; just doesn't feel as 'epic' (per playthrough time) as ftl did.

1) it focuses on the important things, like gameplay, replay value, easy access (i.e. without need to read manuals or long tutorials)
2) the gameplay is in small chunks of 5-15 minutes, depending on your speed solving the "puzzle". 
3) Immense replay value due to lots of different units with different abilities, weapons and pilots
4) difficulty: on normal the game is challenging enough that typical gamers may need several attempts, before they make it to the final battle> Easy and hard difficulty allow to make adjustments, if normal is to easy/hard...
5) graphics and sound: i love the pixel art, it is beautiful and also doesn't distract from the important things happening on the map. Music is great as well, really fits the game. And it is running smoothly on my surface tablet computer... 

I played quite a bit of Slay The Spire and I appreciate that Into the Breach has like the former an indication of the enemy 's upcoming action that requires "counterplay". This makes the game a bit of a puzzle, requiring your units to work together to meet objectives. E.g. getting a supply pod with equipment is really valuable, but is it worth taking damage on your mechs or the power grid for it. Many decisions require careful planning and thinking ahead. Into the Breach is a bit like chess (not just because of the 8x8 board). It requires resource management and a good understanding when you have to make a "pawn sacrifice". It is a great game for the price asked by Subset games and is surely a game of the year contender.

I highly recommend this game, if you enjoy turn based games!

40459275.review:
Did you ever feel while playing games like Super Robot Wars or Advance Wars, etc, that you were tackling an optimization puzzle, especially when going for optional objective or just trying to shave down your turn count in general?

I think this game makes me feel like that, only more concentrated. Size and scale of individual engagements have been reduced here if comprared to most tactical turn-based games on a grid I've seen before, but there is enough things going on that the action becomes 'compressed'. There are effectively no 'empty' turns or even individual actions that are just busywork to continue doing what you decided several turns ago. But the engagements are small enough that it doesn't get tiring. This careful balance of meaningful density even manages to offset the lack of elevation differences on the playing field - something I am usually against in this kind of game - because the game manages to make the stage layout, unit movement range and modes matter regardless.

Special mention needs to go to the UI. It is simple, clear, concise, but very informative. Detailed preview of the results of an attack action helps visualise the results very handily before you commit to it.

If you are familar with FTL, a few things could be directly compared and contrasted with it:

- Shop location is much more easily predictable now, even if you still don't know the wares beforehand.
- The finale of a run can be attempted before all 'sector' equivalents are finished, if you feel you are ready / not sure you will get more than you'll lose. The engagements scale to your progress to allow earlier challenge / compensate for late arrival.
- 'Ship' specific achievements still exist, but you are no longer required to get 2 out of the set of 3 to unlock another starter options. Every achievement rewards a Kestrel coin instead which you use to unlock what you want inbetween runs.
- Overhealing of the 'hull' gauge gives benefits now.
- Losing 'crew' replaces them with perk-less mooks that can gain no exp in the next engagement until you manage to get a replacement pilot. But there are potential benefits to having expendable team members, including equipment options encouraging suicidal tactics.
- It is possible to carry over a single surviving pilot at the end of a run, win or lose, into the next one. Exp caps appear to be fairly low so far, but level up benefits can improve mech perfomance quite notably.

I have enjoyed my time with this game so far and am looking forward to following developments, in case any expansions will happen in the future.

~ Avant Propos ~

Je suis pas un gros fan hardcore de FTL. J'aime bien le jeu, mais j'en suis pas dingue. Donc je juge ce titre pour ce qu'il est, pas en comparaison/admiration pour le précédent titre du studio.

~ Avis ~

Into the Breach...

Je n'avais pas regarder / lu de test ou vidéo avant de me lancer dans le jeu. Etant fan de stratégie tour par tour, j'avais juste vu le pitch et le résumé du gameplay, j'étais curieux. 

Et après quelques minutes de jeu, je suis soufflé. La profondeur stratégique, les possibilités de chaque escouades,.. Sans non plus raconter le jeu voici quelques points qui font (pour moi) de ce jeu, un petit bijou de Game Design :

 * Aléatoire minimisé : seul les récompenses et les missions sont aléatoires. Les dégâts, les actions, la réussite sont fixés à vos seuls compétences de stratège. Pour un jeu qui se rapproche énormément d'un Rogue Like, c'est plaisant d'avoir le temps et de savoir que le résultat 

 * Punitif mais pas que : Vous avez valider votre tour et vous n'aviez pas vu ce petit monstre qui va vous conduire au game over directement ? Tant pis pour vous, le jeu ne vous fera pas de cadeau... ou presque. La possibilité dans la défaite de conserver un pilote avec toute son expérience vous permettra de recommencer avec un petit avantage lors de la prochaine partie.

* Jouer en réaction : "Bon du coup, si je fais ça, peut-être que si, ou peut être que ça" NON ! Ici, Vous savez exactement ce que va faire votre adversaire. Je vous vois les joueurs de Fire Emblem sur Emulateur qui utilisent des Save States au début du tour pour revenir en arrière car l'IA vous a fais le pire coup. Into the Breach vous offre l'oppportunité de savoir exactement les intentions et l'ordre d'action de vos adversaires. Il faudra utiliser ces informations pour contrôler, déplacer ou tuer les éléments adversaire avec vos capacités. Il est ainsi possible pour les adversaires de s'entre tuer !

Et j'en passe sur les détails, entre les événements de cartes (Tsunami, Bombardement, Gel...), les quelques 30 mecha à dispositions, une farandole de succès/challenges... vous avez là de quoi jouer des dizaines d'heures pour un prix dérisoire.

Ah oui, j'allais oublier. J'adore l'ambiance graphique. "Ouais lol, c'est un jeu GameBoy Color"... Jean-Kevin, va jouer à Call Of et m'ennuie pas. L'ambiance est cohérente entre elle, c'est fluide, et puis au moins je peux y jouer même sur un petit pc portable au cas où. Les informations sont claires et compréhensive. L'interface propre... Bref les graphismes sont adaptés au gameplay, pas besoin de plus.

40457925.review:
https://youtu.be/jlL58dDYERo

Si des développeurs ont su imposer leur marque sur leur jeu vidéo de manière durable, ce sont les développeurs de FTL, un jeu indé de référence, sorti au début du "rush indé" qui a vu une accélération sans précédant des sorties indés et qui a complètement revigoré le marché PC que la plupart des analystes voyaient mourir au profit des consoles au sommet de leur force.

Est sorti FTL, un jeu fantastique, tactique, d'une clarté artistique, d'une grande profondeur de gameplay avec de nombreuses options et variations, accompagné d'une bande son que j'écoute encore aujourd'hui de manière régulière.

Ce jeu fait partie des jeux les plus palpitant auquel j'ai joué malgré son côté statique et sa simplicité graphque. On aurait pu craindre que ce fut un One-shot, une oeuvre artistique unique que les développeurs ne parviendrait pas à égaler; au fond de moi, j'en étais convaincu.

Il a fallu attendre le 27 février 2018 pour pouvoir éssayer ce nouveau titre et cela confirme une chose: l'équipe de Subset Games est talentieuse.
Un nouveau style de jeu (de la stratégie au tour par tour) qui vous met aux commandes d'une escouade de 3 ROBOTS GEANTS face à une menace insectoide inaretable. Vous avez une escouade de base d'autres sont déblocables en ...réussissant des succès steam, je trouve ça plutot sympa, ça donne envie de s'investir dedans, après je vois deja des gens raler et qu'il aurait mieux valu tout avoir d'un coup mais passons.

Les robots sont sur une petites cartes qui contient des batiments qu'il faut protéger à tout prix, à chaque fois qu'un bâtiment est détruit, on perd de l'énergie, si la barre d'énérgie tombe à 0, vous mourrez et vous recommencer en choisissant un de vos pilote précédant, offrant ainsi une petite continuité d'une partie à l'autre.

Le jeu est quasiment un puzzle game ou chaque carte (qui dure 5 minutes) est un ensemble de problèmes à résourdre pour avoir le résultat le moins dégeulasse possible: vais-je sauver ce batiment au prix de mon méca? Dois-je abandonner l'objectif secondaire car trop risqué alors qu'il m'offrait un bonus?  Il faut faire des choix, souvent compliqués, il faut anticiper ces mouvements et l'utilisation des compétences. Une erreur et le plan que l'on a mis en place s’effondre, d'autant que le jeu est extremement brutal et sans concessions.

Simple en apparence, le jeu faait s'imbriquer une multitude de systèmes : la direction des attaques des ennemis etant connue à l'avance, on peut s'arrager avec les compétences des mecs pour le pousser à attaquer un autre ennemis, le faire tomber dans un trou, le pousser sur une mine, ou le pousser sur une montagne qui fait un point de dégaat en plus,... je pourrai vous parler des combinaisons possibles pendant 30 paragraphes mais je vais rester concis.

Si des objectifs secondaires sont réussis, ils octroient des étoiles, qui à la fin d'une zone (il y en a 4), offrent l'opportunité d'acheter du matos pour avoir de nouvelles compétences, qui doivent être alimentées en énergies et les générateurs sont rares et précieux, impossible de pouvoir améliorer tous ces mechs, il faut faire des choix constamment. 

Votre barre de vie peut également revenir en protégeant les centrales de la carte tactique. Je vais pas continuer plus longtemps, j'ai fais un tour grossier de ce que le jeu propose.
Le jeu a un aspect graphique simple mais très clair au niveau des icones, et de ce qui va se passer au tour suivant, comme dans FTL, la clarté des informations visuelles permet de comprendre instantanément ce qui va se passer et permet de prendre les meilleurs décisions possibles. Après, on est pas à l'abri d'un oubli d'une conséquence de nos décisions: "zut, j'ai poussé l'insecte loin de mon robot mais maintenant, il va peter le batiment, quel con", voilà ce que je me dis souvent en jouant à ce jeu.

L'ambiance musicale est totalement recommandable, très bonnes musiques, bons bruitages. 
Une simplicité tactique qui cache une grosse profondeur de jeu. Un jeu qui confirme le talent de l'équipe de Subset Games.

A tous les amateurs de jeux tactiques exigeants, achetez ce jeu!!!

Thus far I have to say that Into The Breach is absolute gold.
The games turn based strategy has been boiled down to just the essentials. Units have few stats, and in general, limited upgrade options. Which in a traditional turn based setting like Disgaea or Fire Emblem would be problematic, but in this "micro strategy" setting works just right, with the end result feeling more like FTL and Chess had a baby.
The removal of traditional RPG elements lends itself better towards making the game about positioning and strategy. Finding additional weapons greatly change the way a unit can be played and open up a whole new range of tactical options.

The design philosophies of simplicity and "no one winning team comp" are quite clear in the end result. Each squad plays quite differently and have their own unique strengths and weaknesses, and inevitably will appeal to different players.

While the games are so different its maybe not a fair comparison, but many of the most frustrating elements of FTL have been removed. While still difficult, the game is significantly more forgiving than its space faring counterpart. For example the ability to completely redo a turn once per battle will be a huge boon to new and old players alike.

Its to early to say if Into The Breach will have the same staying power in our hearts and minds as minds as FTL did, but its clear that Subset Games 2nd work is filled with just as much love as the first.

The enemies telegraph their attacks as they plan them, meaning that you the player know exactly what the AI has planned and can then start throwing spanners into the works. And by that I mean shuffle the board. In Into The Breach you'll find that your weapons are only effective against basic enemies, and if you really on their raw damage output, you're screwed.

Instead you may choose to instead of punching the enemy from this tile you decide to punch them from this one instead, and all off a sudden they've been knocked into the sea. Rather than use a killing shot on an enemy, you hit them with an attack that causes smoke, preventing them from attacking, saving that killing shot for a bigger threat. These tactics are also reinforced by the fact that you're not there to dominate, you are there, like the rest of humanity, to survive. Whether or not you kill all the Vek is irrelevant, they'll pack up and go home once the the map times out. It's your job instead to protect the civillians and their homes.

In terms of how can I brace against RNG, you can do a bit. The grid defense % is essentially the evasion meter of FTL. Word of advice, do NOT depend on it to save you from screw ups. The higest it can go probably 49%. Realistically, 30-35% is what you'll see on a [i]really[/i] good run. If you have one of your mechs die so that the run doesn't end, it's rebuilt so you aren't left a [strike]man[/strike] mech down. Resetting the turn so that you can try and find a better solution is also an option too.

Oh and the final multi-stage boss fight is primed to crush you like the bugs you crush yourself... so ITB definately inherits that trait of FTL.

40449644.review:
This is the first game that made me wish Steam had a "meh" score for reviews.

tl;dr: Excellent game mechanics and polish are wasted on a game that's FAR too easy. The climax is tremendously unsatisfying.

I got nearly a perfect score on my very first runthrough of the game, and I'm not exactly a tactical genius. The basic tools you're given are incredibly powerful ('push' mechanics are insanely valuable) and the game is so forgiving of mistakes that I didn't feel genuinely challenged the entire time. Coming from the FTL pedigree, I expected a game that would require mastery in order to succeed, but what I got was a game that can be bumbled through to completion on your first attempt.

Don't get me wrong - the game is extremely polished and FUN, but when I finished the final mission all I could say was "....that's it?" Where's the big, challenging final boss? Where's the climax? All you do at the end of the game is defend a bomb until it blows up (from basically the same set of enemies you've encountered all game,) and then when it explodes, your mechs just... disappear to go help "other timelines." The story has no resolution, you don't actually feel like you've made any kind of real difference.

Instant kills are too easy to achieve - pushing any non-flying enemy into water deletes them instantly, and multiple missions give you control of extremely overpowered superweapons that just obliterate large sections of the map for free, every turn. The enemy reinforcement mechanic is problematic, too - it's easy to block enemies from spawning, so if you can get an advantage in numbers in the first few turns you can basically auto-win the subsequent turns, leisurely picking off single enemies as they spawn. I finished multiple missions with zero enemies alive going into the final turn, and I'd just pass without even moving a mech.

Look, I'm not asking for FTL here. That game was rightly criticized for being heavy-handed with RNG and having a final boss that blatantly cheats. But Into the Breach swings the pendulum WAY too far in the other direction for my tastes.

Other steam reviews have called this "easy to learn, hard to master". Maybe that's true, but since the game never actually demands mastery from the player and provides no suitable avenue to challenge a 'master,' I wonder why anybody would even bother. Just pay a little bit of attention and you'll win with ease, which I find extremely damaging to my long-term enjoyment of a game.

UPDATE: Just completed hard mode with a set of unlocked mechs. I can now confidently say that this game does not offer the kind of difficulty or longevity I was hoping for. I'll probably play more of it - it's a very fun casual strategy game, so if that's what you're looking for, by all means pick this up. If you're looking for an experience like FTL with tons of content that will eat dozens of hours of your time while you slowly master the game, this isn't it.

40449314.review:
ITB is a grid-based, turn-based strategy game that is also a rogue-like. Much like advance wars your strategies will be heavily based on units areas of attack.  However instead of being able to rely purely on damage and value plays, you must also weave in skills that move the enemy and/or damage them as well.  Each map has several buildings that you must protect, the buildings serve as your HP or Life Points, and you will have to sacrifice damage and make clever use of mechanics to protect them while you also aim to destroy the enemy.  

Enemy attacks are broadcasted 1 turn in advance, allowing you to accomplish a great deal despite only controlling 3 units at a time.  For example, say you have two enemies attacking a building from a different angle.  You could simply kill both enemies, but your units will not always be in the right position or have the required damage to kill them.  Letting both of your buildings take damage would be a very punishing turn, and would have dire consequences for the rest of your current campaign.  The optimal move to make would be to push one enemy unit into the enemies line of fire, causing the pushed unit to miss its target, simultaneously blocking the other units attack (and damaging the pushed unit via friendly fire).  

FTL fans will have a new game mode/style to learn, but many similar rogue-like elements from FTL have found new life in ITB.  Highly recommended to any fans of FTL/Advance Wars or other grid-based strategy games akin to Final Fantasy Tactics or Fire Emblem.

고로 구성된 메카의 패시브 , 장비에 따라 적절한 전술을 구사하는 것이 제일 중요한 부분. 

개인적으로는 연막류 장비가 효율이 상당히 좋다고 생각되기에 다른 장비를 쓸 염두가 잘 안난다. 장비 이름은 까먹었는데 연막 + 밀치는 속성을 가진 미사일이 대부분의 상황을 커버 가능할 정도로 유용함.

2. 파일럿 

FTL과 마찬가지로 회차를 반복하면 타임포드등으로 여러 파일럿들이 로스터에 추가되는데 , 기본 능력으로  턴 리셋 1회 추가 , 시작 단계에서의 자유 배치가 가능해지는등 , 여러 다양한 플레이를 가능하게 해주는 요소.


3. 환경 요소

바다 , 용암 , 화학물질 , 지뢰 , 테라포밍기계 ,얼음 , 댐같이 여러 환경 요소또한 게임의 흐름에 큰 영향을 준다.  기본적으로 날아다니는 적이 아닌 이상 밀치기 등으로 쉬운 정리가 가능하기에 애용하게 되는 요소.
또한 특정 지역 인카운터로는 해일 , 공중지원 , 눈보라등 잘 사용하면 유용하지만 그렇지 못할 경우 난감한 요소도 있다. 




Pros

++ 상당히 잘 만들어진 다양한 전략 / 전술 시스템

++ FTL과 마찬가지로 회차 플레이는 상당한 가치가 있음.

+ 깔끔한 비쥬얼과 UI , 그리고 OST.

++ FTL과 마찬가지로 잘 구성된 학습곡선.


Cons

- 약간은 아쉬운 장비 밸런스. 상술한 연막류 장비가 기본적으로 효율이 좋은 편.

-- 장르적 변화로 인해 FTL에 비하면 '기본적인' 컨텐츠 볼륨은 많다고 하기 어렵다.

-  익숙해지면  FTL과 달리 랜덤 요소가 적다보니 중~후반에 갈수록 강해지는 플레이어에 비해 '보스'나 '난관'이 그리 어렵지는 않다. 



참고로 FTL과 비교해서 장르적 변화로 크리스 아발론이 참여한 작품 치고는 스토리 요소가 생각보다는 아쉬운 편.

首先不能免俗的先提該團隊Subset的前作
FTL_Faster_Than_Light

簡單講就是扮演一台太空船逃離叛軍努力在太空船決鬥中存資源升級船，最後反殺對方旗
艦的遊戲

有玩過FTL的一定對那個隨機性恨得牙癢癢的，不管怎麼算都會被平衡性害死被RNG踢回起
點

那麼試試這款把隨機要素弄得更加的策略性的新作吧

單看畫面可能還不太明白這遊戲到底是怎麼回事

首先 遊戲的主線規劃成時間線(timeline)
玩家要回到過去保護人類擊退侵犯的vek

一開始就能看到有五座島嶼(相當於前作的星系地圖)

每個島嶼又細分成數個小關卡並提供不一樣的次要目標去達成以獲得獎勵

戰鬥準備則是選擇三名駕駛員，與三台功能不同的機甲(自訂部分還不清楚)

如果失敗了還能選一名駕駛員繼承下去

戰鬥是回合制輪流行動，但講起來比較像是下棋

一開場先投放三隻機甲的位置，接著每回合vek會先移動到要攻擊的位置後蓄力

就輪到我方反擊了 我方三隻機甲初期有

近距離 人形 高血量 中移動力 射程1格 2傷
中距離 坦克 中血量 低移動力 射程直線 1傷
遠距離 高射炮 低血量 高移動力 射程一格外直線 1傷 範圍擊退

都必須先移動後才能攻擊 可以取消移動指令，但攻擊後就不能再反悔移動跟取消攻擊了
且a移動後如果b攻擊了 ab同時都無法繼續移動(但a可以攻擊)

遊戲的精華在於這8x8的攻防戰上
只要上方的hp跟機甲沒有癱瘓撐到最後一次vek攻擊後 敵方就會撤退

上方的hp為城市的護盾狀態(grid)
每一次被vek直接擊中城市都會扣一格電(1滴血)
初期都是1跟2格電 後期四格電左右被高傷一敲下去可能就輸了......要靠額外的方式補
護盾本身有一定的機率豁免傷害 但是機率跟船閃飛彈一樣不可思議

機甲部分也相同 不過也可以消耗一次攻擊修復部分hp

特別要注意的是 如果機甲血噴乾癱瘓了
機甲能回收 但是
戰鬥結束後駕駛員會殉職 但如果有準備一個能夠補血的裝備.... 理論上就不會死了

戰鬥中傷害數值很硬，機甲吃三發左右傷害就掛了 駕駛員還會給你說機甲快掛了 救人喔

至於遊戲最好玩的就是介紹中有提到的push要素

幾乎所有機甲攻擊都會把敵人擊退 高射炮的又額外可以往四個方向推擠
因此人形揍vek撞vek一發賺四傷是基本功
而地形也會有各種優惠 比方說地面單位是不會游泳的 所以一腳踢下去的蟲子都會淹死

不過缺點就是連我方機甲都會撞壞，所以要貼心點

既然把敵人排在一起撞很有趣 那哪裡難？

遊戲一開始讓你丟三隻機甲下去的原因就是
基本上vek有先移動權 接著mech才能行動
所以經常有被vek一開場就被四五隻圍毆城市一回合遊戲就輸了喔喔喔喔的局面

然後算好時間差讓他們自己揍死自己人再自己跳下水檯面清得乾乾淨淨的 超舒壓

最後是依循rogue like的慣例 遊戲這次分數比較紮實的就是救多少人 就多少分

FTL的船艦配置方式也拿來套用在mech上
加裝反應爐，插上第二武器 升滿武器特性 讓駕駛員活到滿等 都是很有成就感的

也同樣的有各種配置方式的(開場選擇的機甲)次要挑戰目標
像是基本套裝的機甲有dash攻擊，次要目標就是要你一口氣衝超過五格後幹掉vek

目前沒特價 但是才268的
而且是很新鮮roguelike系
是很有意思的遊戲

不過如果輸了也不要氣餒
要記得
lost is fun!

40446365.review:
Amazingly fun. 

You play as a squad of time-travelling mecha pilot in a combination of very tight turn-based-strategy game with a "puzzle" bent. 

The summary is: it's very "distilled". There's no big map and meandering around to search or move toward enemies, and no RNG to determine whether anyone hit anything. There are no turn where you don't do anything, because most missions end in less than 4 turns anyway.

Each mission  you're deployed in a small map, and try to think how you can survive, complete the objectives, and try to limit civilian casualties. The "Puzzle" part works because of the small map and the tight strategic gameplay, because there's a small area of fighting, you'll try to think what's the most efficient way to do every turn, rather than moving around meanderingly like in usual turn based strategy, especially since most of your mech can push the enemies around and you can also use the environment for your advantage.

And as expected, if you lose because there's too much civilian casualty, you go back in time to try to save earth in another timeline, complete with a farewell message from that doomed timeline.

As with FTL, each campaign isn't long, but this is a game meant to be played over and over while you try different combinations of squads.

40445687.review:
刚刚把游戏打通了，马上来写个评测
  游戏大体剧情就是人类被毁灭了，你作为时空旅行者回到过去的时间线拯救世界。游戏共有4个岛，在前两个岛收集物资打怪升级强化自己，之后可以选择进行最终任务（或者在第三个岛和第四个岛之后再进行，不过貌似最终任务难度会提升）
  游戏本质上是个回合制游戏，每个小关的主要目标是保卫建筑物不被攻击，并坚持一定回合。如果建筑物被攻击就会损失能量。能量降低到0则游戏结束。敌人在他们的回合会进行移动或者使用干扰的技能，不过敌人的攻击会在你的回合结束之后才进行，而你可以看到敌人攻击的提示。在自己的回合你可以通过击杀敌人，推走敌人等方式来阻止敌人攻击建筑物，甚至可以让敌人相互攻击 把敌人推到特殊地形秒杀。
  你的机甲可以通过更换装备和提升能量来强化，装备和能量点的获得方法是有三种一个是每小关次要目标奖励，一个是收集关卡中随机出现的时间胶囊，或者利用完成次要目标的奖励在每个岛结束后购买。装备种类目测很多，比如上局游戏中我就见到可以冰冻自己和周围单位的装备，还有更加干脆的自爆装备......
  与ftl类似本作也有一定的rl要素。如果你的单位被毁，那么驾驶员就会死亡（万幸的是机体还在）。如果能量耗尽，那么游戏失败。你也没有读档的机会只能重新开始。不过相对的你可以让一个驾驶员继承到你的下一局游戏中（别高兴得太早，驾驶员满级就3级......）其他的驾驶员需要通过在游戏中获得来解锁。而其他的机甲组合则需要通过每场游戏结束后换算的代币解锁。
  游戏中经常会遇到一个回合需要进行大量思考的情况，最后通过你巧妙的策略化解危机（或者翻车），这也是这部游戏最主要的乐趣所在。
  最后，通关后感觉游戏的流程对比ftl略短，毕竟只有4个岛，各种解锁要素也还没开始尝试，希望接下来的游戏可以给我带来更多的惊喜吧。
  总得来说本作是一个需要花大量精力来思考的游戏，如果想要更轻松的游戏体验，请慎重购买。虽然还没更加深入的玩不过相信可以带给我不亚于ftl的游戏体验吧。

Очередная оверхайпнутая игра от создателей ДляКогоТоШедевра.  В целом неплохая, но ИМХО гораздо слабее FTL.
- Вся игра – просто набор арен для битв, кроме них по сути ничего и нет. Ну, предположим, сюжета и раньше не было, но где замена ивентам с выбором, квестам, случайные торговцам, наступающему на пятки флоту? 
- Стиль… изменился. Несомненно, это дело вкуса, но ИМХО стиль стал хуже. В FTL были красивые корабли и фоны, и стильный минималистичный интерьер, здесь же всё просто плохо.
- Малое количество боевых механик.  Большое количество рандома в поведении соперников. Скучно не будет, но на глубокую стратегию не тянет.
- “Минималистичная” ролёвка. Прокачка экипажа есть, но она куда слабее влияет чем в FTL, да и рас нет.
- На смену качественным улучшениям пришли количественные. Вместо принципиально новых отсеков тут за местную энергию можно получить + к ХП, + урону, + к движению и т.д.

+ Множество разнообразных пресетов, открытие которых потребует не один десяток часов. Действительно разные пушки у юнитов.
Итог: Представьте себе FTL из которой выкинули всё кроме боёв, а всю кастомизацию свели к выбору орудий. Представили? Добро пожаловаться в Into the Breach. На пару вечеров хватит и этого, но чтоб занять меня на 50 с лишним часов текущего контента недостаточно.

40443951.review:
[b][h1]Into The Breach (ITB) is to chess as what FTL was to Space Invaders.[/h1][/b]
[b]FTL takes intership combat from simple interactions and remade it in vivid detail.[/b]  ITB takes chess's simple rules with its vanilla layout and near infinite potential plays and crushes and twists all of those elements to evolve chess into something more.

[h1]My pros:[/h1]

[b]~ Simple mechanics[/b] at the start, progressing to more mechs and more skills after a little play time.
[b]~ Cool graphics, cool setting.[/b]  Basically a modern SNES game (AKA the best game system ever).

[h1]My cons:[/h1]

[b]~ Feels a bit too easy.[/b]  It's like biting into a delicious looking apple but inside it's mushy.  This isn't a fatal flaw but getting your first victory doesn't bring a huge amount of satisfaction.
[b]~ The music is thematically off.[/b]  It's too poetic for a setting where giant machines are smashing up huge bugs.  It's good music!  I can see why they're charging $6 for the soundtrack!  But it feels more like a deal they made with Mr. Prunty where they get cheap, high fidelity music and he gets his work featured for sale alongside a Subset Games title.  I'd say the soundtrack is just an OK match with the game, not amazing.

[h1]The Review[/h1]

[b]Consider:[/b] each stage is played in an 8x8 tile arena (like chess) with specific pieces with their own quirks and skills (also like chess).  But where in chess your pieces are already determined, ITB lets you choose sets of 3 pieces - or mechs - to be deployed as you see fit.  Knowing the enemy set and terrain of an island beforehand, you are challenged to use those 3 mechs as a team to beat an enemy.  An enemy that is slightly/much stronger than you, but with the crucial advantage that you can see what they will do before they do it.

[b]This is much like[/b] trying the different layouts of ships in FTL.  Different ship, different upgrade paths, and different starting crew.

[b]- The biomes and terrains[/b] and objectives are randomized.  But there's a clear pattern to how the maps are put together.  You'll often see water on the map edge for example, or rows of cities together with a power plant next to them.

[b]- I certainly can feel[/b] that each map I am outnumbered and therefore need to treat it like a puzzle.  A puzzle that reveals itself turn by turn, forcing me to adapt.

[b]- As of the first island[/b] (think Super Mario game worlds) I can feel a lot of variety in the enemy skills, and in terrain variances and considerations.  My mek's skills are relatively boring but I haven't acquired any mek upgrades yet so I am anticipating the strategic possibilities - possibilities that I am uncertain of the existence of.

[b]Also, the art style[/b] is completely [b]SNES/Sega Genesis[/b] - that's a [i][b]!GOOD THING![/b][/i] btw.

[b]- I recommend it.[/b]  It doesn't feel totally THE SAME as FTL, but the approach to development feels the same and I feel confident that I'll have the same amount of interest in this as I have in FTL (ie. 70+ hours).  If you liked FTL, I'd say there's a good 70% chance that you'll enjoy this as much.  However there are many mechanical differences; almost 0 RNG for instance (not zero though, more like 10%).

[h1]Responses to criticisms:[/h1]

First impressions: playing [i]Into the Breach[/i] is like meeting up with an old friend you haven't seen in years. Some things are the same, some have changed, and others seem unrecognizable--until you look a little closer.

40442403.review:
[h1]Update - I've fallen in love, and you should too. Into the Breach is even better than FTL[/h1]

FTL was Subset games surprise hit, out of nowhere was this finely balanced, brilliant game that could run on anything and was both accessible to just about anyone with a vague understanding of "Man go here" and "Zappy lasers make boom" but allowed for the kind of finesse and theorycraft that a hardcore strategy game would actually lift an eyebrow at. Not -both- eyebrows mind, but one for certain.

It was such a success the poor developers had to duck into hiding for a while as the sheer awesomeness of the game (which, by the way, if you don't own it yet, FOR THE LOVE OF DOG FIX THAT) literally blew them away, this was also backed by a seminal soundtrack by Ben Prunty which has probably seen him become the hottest thing since sliced bread as far as game soundtracks go (if not, again, that's a crime against humanity). He's back, much like Subset games, the three man band once more, making a new, and completely different game, rather than play it safe with "FTL the second" (HELLO AMPLITUDE, NO HIDING AT THE BACK, WE ALL KNOW WHAT YOU DID WITH ENDLESS SPACE 2 AND IT WASN'T FUNNY), they've been bold.

[i]Very bold.[/i] And dear lord has it paid off, welcome to the end of the world, the planet is overrun by giant godzilla size nasty things that come out of the earth like an episode of Earth Defence Force and you're pretty much the last one standing, so the only fix? Go back in time and try to find a timeline where you don't suck. This may take a few goes. You get to select a mech team of three, all with clearly defined roles, and a named pilot (the other two spots go to Redshirts, competent redshirts mind, but definitely redshirts).

This is "hard" strategy in the sense that your enemy sets up their moves first, your job is then to mess up their plans as much as possible during your turn before they execute theirs. It's a blindingly simple formula that works effortlessly, you have perfect information on what your enemy is *going* to do at the start of your turn, you have limited resources (each unit has one move action, and one use action) and you must maximise their efficiency to protect the board resources against an ever growing threat.

TLDR? They move > You move and act > They act - That's what a turn looks like, by inserting you right in the middle of their turn cycle you get to *react* to their plans and by knowing exactly what's coming, there's no unfairness or BS from the AI. All the information including damage (there's no chance to miss, there is a slim chance for a building to -resist- but if you count on that you're a braver Tiger than I), and zones under threat is served up cleanly and easy to parse. Think invisible Inc but in a much tighter space.

Nothing is kept away from the player, there are no AI fudges, no hidden bonuses or maluses, you know where units will spawn on the next turn (and can even use that information to your advantage), you can manipulate opposing units through push and pull actions depending on what you have equipped (and through use of this you can slam enemies into the terrain and each other), as well as debuff them in a variety of ways, and of course, you can kill 'em.

[H1]Mind. Blown.[/H1]

Much like FTL you're given a [i]massive[/i] number of unlockables to unearth, in this case coming both in the flavour of pilots with portraits and skillsets, and mech companies who bring their own unique weapons mix to the table (the first company is, much like FTL's baseline ship, actually pretty competent all round, and as you unlock the more esoteric options, you'll come up with increasingly clever strategies to bug hunt). There's even the option to configure your own custom mech loadout (though the requirements to earn medals from that setup are steep, demanding you show some real mastery of the game at that point).

The opening mech team is effective, if a little weak on damage, and will find themselves in need of serious upgrades if they are to remain capable beyond island two, however, once you unlock Blitzkrieg or the Rusting Hulks, the game opens up dramatically, electric smoke and weapons that can chain through half the map really give you ways to clean up large chunks of the map in a hurry, though with the additional power comes the need to manage positions and be a lot more careful in the use of such things (big weapons mean big messes if you're not careful).

This is a game where every decision really does matter, and every turn is laden with cost/benefit choices, do you protect a city block or put your mech in harms way in order to buy your ailing power grid a little more time, do you make a high risk blitz move to kill some bugs knowing your mech is going to be on nearly no health the next round, who do you prioritise, can you find a way to shove that high health bug into the water, instantly killing it, the game is full of micro-decisions that keep the game tilting between victory and defeat and it never feels like you're effortlessly coasting nor being utterly overwhelmed (except the times you screw up, and then you *know* things are going to hit the fan).

[H1]They've done it again damnit. They've done it again![/H1]

Graphics and sound are very much stamped with that FTL signature, retro graphics but once again to a superb standard, with the kind of soundtrack that's going to have people reaching for the "Buy soundtrack" button again. FTL had one of the best soundtracks for it's time and Into the Breach isn't that far behind it.

It took a long time for the makers of FTL to come up with something and you know what?

If they serve up dishes this good, I'm happy to wait.

Verdict : [b]Buy the everliving hell out of this. They've done it again, those magificent bstrds[/b]

40441001.review: Subset Games doesn't disappoint, and just like FTL, what seems to be a simplistic game is pretty intuitive and requires a good bit of planning and strategy. You play as a mech pilot/time traveler sent to stop alien bugs from destroying the world, and every chance you get is a chance you can use to improve your odds next time, even if you fail the timeline you're in. If you enjoyed FTL, you'll definitely enjoy this, but it is a different game in severel respects, so don't just expect a re-tread. They definitely made this game its own. If I had to pick out one major flaw, it's that it ends too early. I do like a game that makes me want to come back for more, instead of one that lasts too long and is begging to be put out of its misery. Also, I think the game fits at a 10 dollar price tag, although 15 wasn't unreasonable. Here's hoping we get an Advanced edition like FTL to flesh the game out.
