40440498.review:
[h1]TL;DR: Into The Breach features a short core game that shines nonetheless because of addictive gameplay and fun, achievement-based incentives to keep coming back again and again. Buy with confidence! [/h1]

I'll expand this with updates (see below) once I spend more time with it, but for now I want to help anyone trying to decide if this is a day one purchase versus waiting for a sale. All you need to know is this: if you like turn-based strategy in the theme of Advanced Wars (or even X-Com minus the RNG), Pacific Rim-esque mech vs. monster battles, or light RPG progression systems you'll really enjoy this.

If you're like me and you are sort of obsessed with all three of those things, you'll freaking love it. The combination of those elements works so well together, and the result is a little slice of nerd heaven. Buy it now-- you won't regret it.

Initial impressions are 100% positive-- it's fun, yet challenging. The graphics are great as long as you enjoy this brand of retro-style visuals (I do). Same with the story/lore: it does the job well enough, but the gameplay is the main event here.

The tutorial was succinct and didn't hold my hand too much. I have played the first few missions on "normal," and I found myself winning but rushing/playing a little sloppy and realizing I had to slow down and approach it with an almost chess-like mentality. Some might call this a "hard" game, but I would say it's simply a game you can't rush through-- which is exactly what I hope for when strategy is involved. It will be worth your money for that reason alone.

In other words, you have to think like this: "If I make this move now, how will this affect my future turns? How will it affect the enemy's turn?" That's standard with turn-based games, of course, but the "pieces" in this game have pretty rigid rules and the maps are pretty small, so it amplifies that chess-like intensity in each turn.

Here's a quick example: maybe I decide to get in the path of an enemy attack and take damage this turn to protect a building, but then I might need to heal my mech on my next turn and that will remove my ability to attack with that mech (since I can only attack or heal, not both). With that in mind, I might choose to have a particular mech (you have three at your disposal in the matches I have played) take damage so I can utilize the unique attack type of one of the others-- perhaps to do something specific like punch an enemy into the water for an instant kill.

That's just one simplified scenario, but you get the picture. I'm sure that aspect will be fleshed out even more as I continue to play and unlock content, thus getting exposed to new elements.

Well, that's all for now-- back to playing for me. I have Vek to kill and buildings full of innocent people to [strike]save[/strike] accidentally destroy by punching a Vek into them.

[h1]Update #1:[/h1] After a few rougher matches that I barely survived and a little internal debate, I actually ended up starting a new game on easy just to get a feel for some of the more in-depth strategy before diving back into normal. I highly recommend this approach. It's not that the game is too hard on normal, it's just nice to be able to focus on soaking up knowledge on an easy playthrough before eventually ramping it back up. I just finished my second island, and I'm really having a blast now that I'm unlocking some more upgrades that make the strategy even deeper. Your mileage may vary, but I like the thought of getting the fundamentals down before I shift back to the more challenging enemies.

[h1]Update #2:[/h1] Well, after just under 3 hours I have "beat" the game. I'd estimate about an hour of that was my first "normal" playthrough before I started the "easy" campaign that I beat pretty... well... easily. I wouldn't worry about the game being short though, because if it weren't for life obligations tonight I'd be starting up my next timeline (think of it like a New Game+) and continuing on to the higher difficulty. The gameplay is going to keep you coming back for sure. I don't see myself getting tired of it for a long, long time.

I will admit it slightly complicates the discussion of value though, because some might prefer a longer campaign of original content versus starting over with new randomly generated missions that will look and feel pretty similar to your previous runs. But here's the thing: I can tell there's still a ton of content I haven't seen/used/unlocked yet-- based on the long list of Steam Achievements alone I've only scratched the surface.

I'm particularly excited to keep trying out different Mechs since that will change the gameplay dramatically. I'll do another update once I get a few more runs under my belt. That should give me a much better idea of long term replayability.

It's still a [i]very strong[/i] recommendation from me thus far!

[h1]Update #3:[/h1] I've completed 3 or 4 runs now, and I'll just say that the fun from trying out new mechs and their abilities gives the game some major replayability for sure. Also, the desire to complete achievements and beat old scores adds even more on top of that. Definitely worth the money if you are motivated by those types of incentives-- but be forewarned that there is essentially no additional story, character development, etc. after your first run. I for one don't care because it's not that kind of game and the gameplay itself is so addictive, but others might be bothered so it's worth mentioning.

[h1]Update #4:[/h1] Well, this is probably my last update. I'm about 50% done with the Achievements. Now I'm no Acheievement hunter usually, but with this game I'd argue that Achievement completion is a good gauge for replayability and the overall life of the game in terms of fresh content. Why? Because the Steam Achievements line up with the usage of new mechs and experimentation via additional playthroughs. In other words, if you're doing multiple playthroughs and focusing on experiencing new content each time you'll continuously be getting the Achievements along the way.

So, my point is that if I continue at this pace I'm guessing I'd be able to really "finish" the game (AKA get most of the Achievements) in about 30+ hours. Now that being said, some Achievements are much, much more difficult than others. As such, you can probably add a healthy chunk to that total.

The reason I'm going down this path of thought is to dispell any concerns about value. I'll admit my only pain point with this game was seeing the credits roll for the first time only a few hours into playing. I loved the gameplay, but I worried if I'd get $15 of value out of it.

I can definitively say that you'll get a heck of a lot more than $15 of value out of this game now that I've experienced roughly half of the squads. And even after you achieve everything, I can see it being a game I'd come back to from time to time just to try and beat my old scores and experience the gameplay again. Very happy with the game and I'd give it a final score of 9.5/10. If there are free updates, or even paid DLC, to add even more original content (new enemies, new squads, new islands) in the future, it's a 10/10 game without a doubt.

40439953.review:
You will constantly see this game compared to chess, and the comparison is apt. Into the Breach is essentially a constant chain of chess-like puzzles where you use your units to disrupt, distract, and destroy the enemy. Finding those clever moves which annihilate the enemy is an incredibly satisfying experience. The lack of RNG elements in the games means that there are no frustrating "95% misses" like you'd see in similar tactics games, meaning your success (or failure) is all up to you.

Unlike FTL, the game has a much more approachable difficulty curve. Easy can be tackled by almost anyone, Normal is a good step up, and Hard will provide a satisfying challenge.

If you like thought-provoking puzzles and challenging tactics games, Into the Breach is the game for you.

40439670.review:
FTL was so amazing that initially, I was disappointed that this game was nothing like it. That mild resentment quickly went away after I actually spent some time playing.

This game falls somewhere between chess and Advance Wars. You have complete knowledge of enemy movements and capabilities, and your job is to counter it before it happens. Unlike FTL, very little is left up to pure chance.

The game is incredibly well thought-out. Lots of nuance to the art and sound cues. The music is also very atmospheric and fitting.  The achievements are fun and reasonable, and there's lots to unlock and discover.  The game continually forces you to make interesting choices and tradeoffs. And it has all the love put into it that FTL had.

I can't recommend this game enough.
